[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Scarapelli for putting this on the agenda and for your kind words.

[Justin Tseng]: I went to school at Duncan and

[Justin Tseng]: It's tough to say anything because I think it hits particularly hard when it's a family of someone you know.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, um, because, um, uh, and, and, and is aware that we have a limit on, um,

[Justin Tseng]: public participation speaking time, we've coordinated so I can give you a fuller update about what's happening on Quincy Street.

[Justin Tseng]: And then I can give an update about what I've learned so far, and then Anne can give an update about how things are going from her end.

[Justin Tseng]: So essentially, Anne reached out to me, letting me know that on Quincy Street, there are a few problems that in summary, you've read out, Mr. President.

[Justin Tseng]: The first big one is a very big rat infestation, one that is at least a city hired inspector from Yankee Pest in the fall let us know, let residents know, was of a very, very big size.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the numbers disputed, but it's what we had heard, what residents had heard in the fall was possibly 1,000 to 3,000 rats.

[Justin Tseng]: um in three kind of large nests identified um one um is on a property that's currently on sale um there are two off north street behind um

[Justin Tseng]: Clever Green Cleaners and Stevenson's Construction.

[Justin Tseng]: And there are incidents of rats jumping out of closed trash cans, running through yards, being run over on the street.

[Justin Tseng]: And the neighborhood has been quite proactive in preventing rats.

[Justin Tseng]: Neighbors have been making sure that no pets are being fed outside, that pets are being cleaned up after, that there aren't any birdhouses in use, that the burrows are being stuffed with steel wool, vinegar, and ammonia, and that all shrubbery on the private property is trimmed.

[Justin Tseng]: But with the note that there is some overgrowth behind the cleaners that might need addressing.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, that's the rat issue.

[Justin Tseng]: And from what I understand and can give us an update as well, I understand that a few weeks ago, there were some inspectors from Yankee Pest who went, who gave a different number, a different estimate of the number of rats who were there, but did say that there are rat problems.

[Justin Tseng]: Director O'Connor let me know that,

[Justin Tseng]: that there are some residents who were contacted about boroughs being observed who didn't call the city back for follow-up treatment or inspection, and that

[Justin Tseng]: The inspector from Yankee Pests, who did recently visit the neighborhood, met with the owners of Stevenson's Construction and Clever Green Cleaners.

[Justin Tseng]: They both gave them permission to inspect the property and that both properties are free from rats at this time.

[Justin Tseng]: But from the rear of Clever Green Cleaners, the inspector could see rat burrows in two abundant residential properties.

[Justin Tseng]: The inspector did take note of evidence of rats in residential properties, including rat burrows, rat damaged lattice under porches, damaged trash cans, and rat droppings.

[Justin Tseng]: But in the inspector's professional opinion, they don't have thousands of rats there.

[Justin Tseng]: They did observe that the residents have been doing well as far as they can in terms of

[Justin Tseng]: um, putting out rat bait, acting responsibly, doing their own rat control, um, but that, um, there might be some, um, some things that we can do as a city moving forward.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, the inspector also noted that some of the rat burrows that he observed were from the rear of the dry cleaners under the wood, uh, pallets in the residential backyard and that, um,

[Justin Tseng]: We can't, as a city, we can't service these areas with carbon monoxide or carbon dioxide unless the residents move some of their stored items.

[Justin Tseng]: And so their recommendations is that we work either as a city council, the board of health, or as a city to reach out to everyone in the neighborhood and coordinate rat inspections and services from Yankee Pest.

[Justin Tseng]: And that they would keep knocking on doors while they're there to see if they can do any inspections while they're in the neighborhood.

[Justin Tseng]: And they would help us put together a list of what might need to be done to control the rats.

[Justin Tseng]: but essentially think that if we can do a neighborhood meeting, maybe work with the board of health to do that, that would be helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's the rat issue.

[Justin Tseng]: On the next two issues, I don't have as many updates, but I will say the commissioner, DPW commissioner did get back to me and say that he's putting these on the repair lists for the summer.

[Justin Tseng]: So the first problem is that the street has from Quincy Street from where Osgoode meets Quincy to the end of the Somerville line has been patched, but the patching is coming up.

[Justin Tseng]: And a lot of the patches are tossing tar onto the streets and sidewalks as well.

[Justin Tseng]: One of the patches is seven feet by five feet, and there are nine of them in a 12-house radius.

[Justin Tseng]: And so the street needs a more thorough repaving, and the DPW commissioner is aware.

[Justin Tseng]: There are a lot of streets in Medford at this time that need similar work, but he's told me that he's put this on the list.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and the last concern that Mr. school brought up to me, um, was that there is a dangerous intersection with the need for two more stop signs at the junction of Quincy and Osgood.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, as a lot of folks who are accessing Boston Ave and Mystic Valley Parkway speed down the street.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and there have been incidents where, um,

[Justin Tseng]: moms who are putting their kids in car seats and people who are being picked up and dropped off after school on that corner have almost been hit.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I think councillors are at present very well, so I don't want to be too repetitive.

[Justin Tseng]: unsettles things because we've all seen the evidence online that they're not always just going after who they have a warrant for.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of the times there is profiling.

[Justin Tseng]: They're trying to stop anyone and trick them into opening their car doors or opening their house home doors.

[Justin Tseng]: And so it's important for us to know what kinds of things are happening in the city so we know how to best respond and best protect our residents' rights.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, so I'm, you know, grateful for Councilors are for for sponsoring this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: I would even be open to an even more frequent report from the police department.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that, you know, a lot, even after we pass this resolution, a lot of work has to be done.

[Justin Tseng]: And if there isn't enough compliance will

[Justin Tseng]: I would be open to revisiting parts of the welcoming city ordinance to strengthen what's there and to explore paths there.

[Justin Tseng]: a public building or even a non-public building, like, for example, a library or a food bank.

[Justin Tseng]: If agents come in without a warrant and are trying to look for someone, what can we do to protect our residents there?

[Justin Tseng]: And there's just not a lot of clarity at the moment.

[Justin Tseng]: on those issues, on those scenarios.

[Justin Tseng]: There's not a lot of clarity on what the police department's policy is when it comes to peaceful protests and what gets interpreted as a threat to justice or obstruction of justice.

[Justin Tseng]: How do we as a city create the policies to define what falls under that bucket and what falls under another bucket?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to, you know, add to the conversation in case it addresses some of the worries.

[Justin Tseng]: was what they would consider not wise.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I appreciate and agree with everything that my fellow councilors have said about this issue.

[Justin Tseng]: The freedom to protest, freedom of speech is a sacred right, in my opinion, of humankind, but it lies at the very core of our country's history and our identity.

[Justin Tseng]: as a nation.

[Justin Tseng]: When the revolution started here in the Boston area, all those years ago, I think that those protesters would be deeply disappointed and deeply, deeply troubled about where our country is headed right now with our treatment of protesters.

[Justin Tseng]: And the deployment of Marines and of

[Justin Tseng]: You know, this number of National Guards into the, you know, the protest area in LA is substantial and it's not something that we should look lightly over.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we need to really understand that a lot of these protests, you know, there are

[Justin Tseng]: pictures of certain scenes, but I know many of these friends who are participating in these protests in LA.

[Justin Tseng]: And you can look from their live streams, their posts, everything, their reports, their articles that they're writing about it, that the vast majority of these protests are peaceful protests.

[Justin Tseng]: the federal government is trying to provoke a reaction to manufacture the conditions for which they can suspend liberties, create conditions where they can march in and just tell people to bow down.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's certainly not going to happen, certainly not something that we're going to stand for in Medford, certainly not something that us as your elected officials will stand for.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think

[Justin Tseng]: It's really, really, really scary looking at how this moment compares to other moments in history.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, I genuinely don't know.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I studied a lot of history in college, and a big focus of that history was, you know, the world leading to World War II and coming out of World War II.

[Justin Tseng]: this moment genuinely reeks of fascism.

[Justin Tseng]: And it reeks of the lead up, the build up, the manufactured incidents and attacks that led to the suspension of democracy in Germany in 1933.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think we need to be very careful to make sure that that doesn't happen here in this country.

[Justin Tseng]: And it takes every single one of us to do that.

[Justin Tseng]: I think in addition to that, I think this issue highlights that, again, that these issues can be municipal issues too, they can be local issues because these protests were, you know, were protests at the city level, you know, at the Los Angeles level.

[Justin Tseng]: They were protesting a national issue, but that's a right, right?

[Justin Tseng]: LAPD has done some questionable actions, but they've also made the point that they ask the feds not to come in.

[Justin Tseng]: They ask the feds not to risk provoking the situation.

[Justin Tseng]: And I don't want to see the day where in Medford, the feds think that they can come in against anyone's requests here in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'll leave it at that.

[Justin Tseng]: And I thank Vice President Collins for sponsoring this motion.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: This is a resolution to discuss an issue that residents have been raising up, particularly in South Medford and Hillside.

[Justin Tseng]: But I know it's an issue in different parts of the city, especially in East Medford as well, that these large trucks are going down neighborhood streets that they're too big for.

[Justin Tseng]: And not only are they causing traffic, oftentimes they're getting stuck.

[Justin Tseng]: making turns in the streets as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's, you know, that creates even more knock on effects.

[Justin Tseng]: So from violin one,

[Justin Tseng]: And in our high school string orchestra, we have Lincoln Bell, Justin Cho, Maggie Fowler, Samuel Keith, Mary Schmidt.

[Justin Tseng]: In violin two, we have Nikki Chow, Safran Jacobs, Eliana Lam, Kyle Tam, Vasiramirez Alvarez, Jayden Ville.

[Justin Tseng]: In violin, or viola, we have Mai Hughes, Leanne Lam, William Malone,

[Justin Tseng]: in Kiana Tran.

[Justin Tseng]: And in cello, we have the Maya Aman, Owen Barzak-Kroll, Kira Huynh, Wesley Kwong, Karina Lewis, Caleb Strauss, Christina Joselagi, Jaden Wu.

[Justin Tseng]: And in double bass, we have Kelvin Lee and August Velasco.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you all for your beautiful playing.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you all for your hard work for our city, for making us so proud of you.

[Justin Tseng]: And congratulations on this huge award.

[Justin Tseng]: Please come up and receive your awards and we'll get a picture of everyone together too.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, feel free to fill in the middle space.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to thank Councilor Leming for putting this on the agenda and to thank him for his really meaningful words yesterday.

[Justin Tseng]: It's important that our residents see ourselves reflected in the things that we celebrate as a city and the things that we recognize as a city.

[Justin Tseng]: So many Medford residents have given their lives and, you know, even put their lives on the line for our country, for the ideals that we hold together, for freedom, for justice for all.

[Justin Tseng]: for life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness, and these really, I think, unifying values that, as a country, I think we need to take a deep look at and embrace.

[Justin Tseng]: And as our veteran service director said yesterday in her wonderful remarks at the ceremony too,

[Justin Tseng]: it's time to remember those who gave their life for their conscience, for serving a country with those ideals.

[Justin Tseng]: And I found that very meaningful.

[Justin Tseng]: Great, thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Madam Mayor for coming and presenting this budget and being so thorough in your comments.

[Justin Tseng]: I appreciate that crafting a budget is always

[Justin Tseng]: tough.

[Justin Tseng]: It requires making tough choices and saying yes and no to certain projects.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm grateful, especially to the voters, but I'm grateful in general that this year we're in a better position than the previous years, certainly much smoother this year in my memory compared to previous years.

[Justin Tseng]: And

[Justin Tseng]: You know, I appreciate that we're truly making some historical, historic progress, especially in the schools, but, but, including investments in DPW and recovering what we've lost over, you know, decades of austerity.

[Justin Tseng]: and making progress on that.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, there's still a long way to go, and I think residents recognize that as well.

[Justin Tseng]: We, as a city council, through the Resident Services and Public Engagement Committee, put out a public feedback form with regards to what people were looking for from this budget.

[Justin Tseng]: And through just the whole budget crafting process, we've received a lot of feedback.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of it is about infrastructure.

[Justin Tseng]: and about improving roads, improving road safety for cyclists and pedestrians as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's why in our city council budget recommendations, we included funding or requests for funding for an additional traffic engineer, for staff positions, for restriping, adjusting signal timing, patching potholes,

[Justin Tseng]: and shrinking the repair backlog and also just more money to install and maintain road safety markings, signage and bike related equipment.

[Justin Tseng]: I was wondering what progress we can expect to make this year with regards to those like infrastructure and traffic safety improvements, what we might not be able to get this year and how we can plan the budget for that going forward.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Obviously I think infrastructure is always an ongoing conversation so anything that you know what what goes through my mind is how can we plan long term to get those positions that we need and.

[Justin Tseng]: Commissioner McIvern was here earlier today talking about how there's still positions in DPW, we need to fill.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think a priority for this council now and going forward, especially, is about how can we make, how can we fill those positions, because it's so important to get the, you know, people in the office.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't want to steal the thunder from Councilor Callaghan.

[Justin Tseng]: I know she's been working on a volunteer tree planting program as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I was wondering what capacity we might have in this budget to get that off the ground.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, we also talked at our first committee the whole meeting about updating our financial software because we don't necessarily, the system that Medford uses is really archaic and it's, it's hard for people coming, you know, coming to Medford to work to use the system.

[Justin Tseng]: It's also slowing down, you know, payments to workers and especially when we do

[Justin Tseng]: retro, and that, you know, affects morale as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I was wondering what we might be able to see in the upcoming year about getting us to a place where we maybe look at new options for software.

[Justin Tseng]: I know Director Dickinson's kind of looked at options, it's a little pricey, but what can we expect in terms of long-term planning for something like that?

[Justin Tseng]: Got it.

[Justin Tseng]: That's a helpful answer.

[Justin Tseng]: I think residents have also been asking about,

[Justin Tseng]: protections for immigrants, especially at this time.

[Justin Tseng]: And we have our non cooperation policy.

[Justin Tseng]: But in we you know, I know, members of city staff are making various efforts to protect residents and inform you know, residents of what they're able to do.

[Justin Tseng]: I was wondering what you could speak to in this budget about about protecting our immigrant neighbors?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: And my last question, I promise.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: So we met on three items.

[Justin Tseng]: One will appear later on tonight's agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: 24069, I believe, is the updated HRC ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: We voted out a final draft for this meeting for first reading.

[Justin Tseng]: 24354, I believe, is sending out the most recent monthly newsletter.

[Justin Tseng]: and 25041 I believe is on the public engagement strategy for the budget process.

[Justin Tseng]: We sent out a Google survey for residents to be able to give their input to us about what they'd like to see in the city, this budget season, what they want to see long-term and how we can best engage them as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I encourage all residents at home to

[Justin Tseng]: to fill out that form, and you can contact us if you have any trouble accessing it.

[Justin Tseng]: We discussed preliminarily the results that we found.

[Justin Tseng]: At the time of the meeting, we had about 92 results.

[Justin Tseng]: We've since gotten 10 to 15 more, and we will continue outreach.

[Justin Tseng]: At a moment where I think a lot of residents are scared, concerned, afraid about their human rights, civil rights of their own and their neighbors, I think it becomes incumbent upon us as elected officials to do the most that we can to safeguard those rights here in our community.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the city council has repeatedly shown over the last, especially over the last few months, but in the last few years too,

[Justin Tseng]: that we stand on the side of human rights.

[Justin Tseng]: And we stand on the side of our city being more proactive in reaching out to residents to let them know about their rights, proactive about solving inequalities and disparities in our community, and to do better in general.

[Justin Tseng]: This effort, this particular effort, came about over a year ago, if not two years ago, with members, former members of the Human Rights Commission who, you know, reached out to me and let me know how the existing ordinance, the one that we have right now, is quite outdated.

[Justin Tseng]: and has led to a lot of problems where the HRC can't do what HRCs normally do in surrounding communities as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And a lot of these are basic functions that we really think that we would conceive of a human rights commission doing, like hosting events and letting residents know about their rights, stuff like that.

[Justin Tseng]: And as well as creating recommendations and studying data that we collect in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: In this day and age, I think it becomes important for us to act on that and fix those problems that we've seen in that old ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm so grateful to the hard work of a lot of our residents, a few of whom are here in the audience tonight, but I know a lot of folks at home are also watching this meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: who, and, you know, this group of residents came together and we all worked together on a draft ordinance to update the HRC to make it fit for modern times.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm, you know, so thankful and grateful for their hard work because I know it was the labor of love.

[Justin Tseng]: We've been spending a lot of time on this over the last few months, reaching out to our DEI director, to the mayoral administration, to different stakeholders, making sure that we have something that

[Justin Tseng]: is ambitious and actionable.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's what I want to say about this.

[Justin Tseng]: In essence, this ordinance update reestablishes the Human Rights Commission and re-empowers it to do even more and to be even more proactive in serving our city.

[Justin Tseng]: I know a lot of people who are even currently on the HRC have been pushing for this because the HRC is

[Justin Tseng]: currently pretty defunct.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I'm excited for the city council to finally be voting on this tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: There are some small technical amendments for the most part that I would make a motion to adopt.

[Justin Tseng]: And Mr. Clerk, I'll send these to you via email as well.

[Justin Tseng]: But in section 50-62, because we changed the committee composition for the kind of the staggered terms at the very start, we just need to fix the language there.

[Justin Tseng]: So instead of a third of members shall serve for one year term, a third, a third,

[Justin Tseng]: I would amend that to read two members shall serve for one year term.

[Justin Tseng]: Three members shall serve for two year term and three members shall serve for three year term.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's the first amendment.

[Justin Tseng]: The second amendment would be to strike the words administration in the public school system after the word city in section 50-66 in subsection B.

[Justin Tseng]: And that would be in section 55-66.

[Justin Tseng]: And then the third edit would be also in section 50-66 to strike subsection D2 and to renumber the subsections.

[Justin Tseng]: That last edit is a little bit more substantive

[Justin Tseng]: it's still mostly technical, that was upon request of the school committee who said that the DESE reporting isn't necessarily a complete picture of what we have at the schools.

[Justin Tseng]: And so we shouldn't put it in the ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: So D2?

[Justin Tseng]: D2, yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, in B1, just to strike the words administration and public school system, just to leave that.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: I think my math is off.

[Justin Tseng]: Sorry.

[Justin Tseng]: I meant to say 344.

[Justin Tseng]: All right.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm glad that I can always count on Councilor Bears to check my math one more time.

[Justin Tseng]: We had quite a lot, few, we had five at least, five meetings on this, five or six.

[Justin Tseng]: Thanks.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Great.

[Justin Tseng]: I recognize Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: I appreciate the compliment.

[Justin Tseng]: Through the Chair, I think that's an excellent question.

[Justin Tseng]: So essentially the data that is listed out here are things that we know slash historically know the City has collected.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of the data is honestly one of the problems with

[Justin Tseng]: these types of issues in municipal governance is that we don't have a lot of the data we really should be having, which is why there's a whole section on requesting that the city council and the city administration collect data.

[Justin Tseng]: Of course, I think it's just we could create a whole list.

[Justin Tseng]: And we just wanted something from

[Justin Tseng]: different, you know, we wanted examples of data points that each department could collect or relevant departments could collect.

[Justin Tseng]: Police stops is the main thing that we know at least, we know that the MPD does collect and that we have used in the past to analyze disparities.

[Justin Tseng]: I do hear your point, which is why in front of every list, we've made sure to add

[Justin Tseng]: that these data points are minimum requirements, or at minimum, the HRC can request x, y, z. Or at minimum, departments should collect x, y, z and report x, y, z.

[Justin Tseng]: So all that's to say that the lists that we're referring to right now, they're not exhaustive.

[Justin Tseng]: They're just a starting point for the HRC to be able to work on in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: I think there is also a lot of worry.

[Justin Tseng]: There would be a lot of worry from the administration, at least from an executive viewpoint, of an ordinance asking them to collect data that

[Justin Tseng]: isn't currently being collected.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that would create some consternation in the corner office, which is why part of the negotiating process was to have data that or to have these categories that we thought were implementable.

[Justin Tseng]: I also know that a lot of this comes from the basis of this version of the HRC ordinance is kind of like a collection of different HRC ordinances from different municipalities as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So a lot of this is based on what other municipalities HRCs are collecting and reporting on.

[Justin Tseng]: That was the long answer.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the short answer, the short answer is this isn't an exhaustive list.

[Justin Tseng]: The HRC can request that.

[Justin Tseng]: That's more data from the police department.

[Justin Tseng]: That's within their powers here.

[Justin Tseng]: And we just kind of put into the ordinance data that we know the city is slash has historically collected.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, there there's a lot so I'll take it one by one on the, the, the data from police department see authorities.

[Justin Tseng]: I would support inserting a sentence in there to request timely information.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the reason why we didn't is because there's not a neat place to put it, where some of the data that's under requests is more about requests rather than it is more about data that we might not currently have

[Justin Tseng]: mixed in with data that we know we have.

[Justin Tseng]: So it'd be good as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think that's a good catch.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I will say that I'll have to, you know, the mayor's office will also have to sign off on this ordinance as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So I would suggest reaching out to her office because her office is the one that will execute this ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: On the second resident's concerns about the city staff person slash liaison situation, this is something we talked about in committee as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So essentially in committee, we discussed how currently there is no assigned city staff person to the HRC.

[Justin Tseng]: Historically, it's been the DAI director, but the DAI director has said that she won't.

[Justin Tseng]: be the liaison to the HRC.

[Justin Tseng]: And so then it becomes, you know, it falls upon the mayor to decide who else will do it.

[Justin Tseng]: That's something I'm working with the mayor on currently.

[Justin Tseng]: And with the kind of people that we the city staff that we have traditionally kind of thought of to be well suited for this role.

[Justin Tseng]: No one has, you know, no one has offered.

[Justin Tseng]: And no one has said yes to it, which is why I'm part of.

[Justin Tseng]: through conversations with the mayor's office and with the DEI office, we put in the words or city council liaison were relevant to give us the most flexibility to make sure that we can at the very least get this off the ground.

[Justin Tseng]: And maybe once it's off the ground and up and running, we can get a city staff person to do that.

[Justin Tseng]: I suspect this is also something that the Resident Services and Public Engagement Committee is gonna keep working on in the future as well, to make sure that we do have an assigned city staff person.

[Justin Tseng]: But I would say that we shouldn't strike the words that were suggested, that was suggested to be struck, just in order to make sure that we give ourselves the most flexibility going forward with getting this new HRC up and off the ground.

[Justin Tseng]: With regards to the Section 50-62B, I believe that most of us can agree that the role of a Human Rights Commission necessitates diversity on that commission, or that we have that flexibility to make sure that we have

[Justin Tseng]: you know, the best qualified residents joining, but in this case, qualification includes life experience and diversity as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we've seen in the past, especially with HRCs, but board and commissions in general, they don't always reflect the makeup of the city.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this ensures the best outcome that we can get.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, with regards to the policy advocacy work, the research and reporting that the HRC does, I believe that inherently human rights includes questions of morality, and that's something for a representative body of our city to get together and discuss.

[Justin Tseng]: something that we did actually make sure that was in this ordinance was that the HRC statements will be in the name of the HRC.

[Justin Tseng]: But you know, this is also a public forum for just like City Council is, although I'm sure with different rules, is a public forum for residents to talk about what

[Justin Tseng]: what we see as human rights.

[Justin Tseng]: But the fact is that so many of the human rights and civil rights that are under attack in our country right now are things that I would believe that at least 90% of the city believes in.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I don't see that language affecting that work.

[Justin Tseng]: I can read it out.

[Justin Tseng]: Sure.

[Justin Tseng]: So at the end of the blurb in 66D, I would insert the words, the following list shall not be exhaustive and all requested information from the city shall be provided in a timely manner.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, no, I, that would not be correct.

[Justin Tseng]: Because, um, it's this is the kind of similar language as in other commission ordinances where, um, you know, she's asked, like,

[Justin Tseng]: With the current HRC, for example, it's the same language.

[Justin Tseng]: She's asked the DI director.

[Justin Tseng]: They would not be obligated.

[Justin Tseng]: And I suspect this is something that the city council could also vote on, although that's not a must.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes, yes, exactly, exactly.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, and that was a suggested language from the mayor's office.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing none... There is one technical edit that I forgot to mention when I was reading out the amendments.

[Justin Tseng]: It was just cut off.

[Justin Tseng]: I would add our standard severability language at the end of this ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: the standard language our city uses is the provisions in this ordinance are severable if any part or provision of this ordinance or the application of this ordinance to any person or circumstance is held invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this ordinance shall not be affected by such holding and shall continue to have full force in effect.

[Justin Tseng]: That was in an earlier draft and I just forgot to copy and paste it into this one.

[Justin Tseng]: That would just be its own section then.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I know you all have been working really, really hard on this.

[Justin Tseng]: there's just this enthusiasm.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I want to remind everyone, I mentioned this a few meetings ago, but the first time it was knocking on doors, Medford Square came up alive.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think at the time people asked us, or asked me at least, when are we going to stop planning and when are we going to start doing?

[Justin Tseng]: And I think this is us doing, and I'm really, really excited about that.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think a key point is,

[Justin Tseng]: I think with any big redevelopment project like this, you're never going to get 100% of what everyone envisions Medford Square to be, because we all have different visions and different needs and priorities too.

[Justin Tseng]: But I actually think that the transit proposal reaches really high marks on what people who have very different lived experiences are asking of Medford Square.

[Justin Tseng]: we're getting that parking lot and that it's not just gonna be any parking lot, that it'll be a parking lot that the city has some say over, that they'll be public art integrated to.

[Justin Tseng]: Vic Schrader joked to me, because there are residents who are concerned about increasing parking too.

[Justin Tseng]: And if the renderings are anything to go by, I think we're definitely heading in that direction.

[Justin Tseng]: So I am grateful for that.

[Justin Tseng]: very funny comment from him.

[Justin Tseng]: With the riverside, I think that's the riverfront opening up that capacity.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's something I hear just as much, to be honest.

[Justin Tseng]: I know it's really important to let folks at home know that, you know, the City of Medford is not in itself a private property developer, so we can't

[Justin Tseng]: build the buildings the way that we want to see it, but we can work with developers and work with property owners to nudge them in the direction that we want to see, to work with them to make sure that, you know, their vision is aligning with what our vision is.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm grateful that you guys are doing so much of that hard work reaching out to, I guess, to that point.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it was really important for residents to hear tonight that we are working really hard to try to reorient the square towards our natural features, towards our strengths.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's also important to hear the timelines and the permitting processes that go behind a lot of these.

[Justin Tseng]: It sounds like most of these permitting steps are state law requirements.

[Justin Tseng]: Is there anything besides what's in the current zoning update on our front that is adding to that timeline delay?

[Justin Tseng]: I'm glad to hear that I think it's really important that folks at home know that, at least on our side, we are really coordinating all our efforts, the zoning effort.

[Justin Tseng]: the Medford square projects to make sure that things can happen as quickly as possible on our side, and you know the state permits that's that's a whole other world chapter 91 that's a whole other world.

[Justin Tseng]: I think you've also addressed.

[Justin Tseng]: I've also been hearing quite a lot about banks and, you know, businesses that, at least in our last report were like labeled as, you know, we have a lot of these, we don't need that many more, you know.

[Justin Tseng]: I think a question that residents have brought up.

[Justin Tseng]: is that instead of why why why not instead of banning it outright because we know we still want these businesses here.

[Justin Tseng]: Why shouldn't be in zoning put something like a special special permit process for businesses that we see a lot of and.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, again, if there's anything that we can help with, you know, this, for at least the City Council, I know the City Council is very supportive and, you know, we'll have questions.

[Justin Tseng]: Look, I mean, I think any time that we can get together and talk about these issues, I know residents really do appreciate it.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, even if we're asking questions that are just clarifying points that we know a little bit about, I think it becomes a great moment for our city to get that information.

[Justin Tseng]: Awesome.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: My fellow councillors stole all my questions about the BWCs.

[Justin Tseng]: Can I,

[Justin Tseng]: ask while we have you guys here, I know residents have been reaching out to us about the police department's policy with Immigration Customs Enforcement vis-a-vis the non-cooperation policy that we have in place.

[Justin Tseng]: I was wondering if you could speak to reports of the FBI trucks that were in the police department's parking lot, as well as FBI agents walking through the offices and public spaces of the police building itself.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I understand it's like a it's a tight, tough tightrope to walk with regards to, you know, deep deep between different levels.

[Justin Tseng]: I think what the Council was what you know the Council was reminded of and what we've, we want to emphasize to is that in the welcoming city ordinance, there is language in there about not

[Justin Tseng]: using, not giving police spaces over, public space, or city spaces over to, for use in, you know, operations like that.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think just, just that was flagged to us, for us to flag as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And yeah, I mean, I think the question is, why were agents, why did it seem like agents were in the buildings, especially in private parts of the buildings that needed to, they needed to be scanned in?

[Justin Tseng]: I think that was a

[Justin Tseng]: I was there.

[Justin Tseng]: So I saw an agent walk through the first floor, including through the kind of doors that you have to tap.

[Justin Tseng]: You have to have a badge to slip into.

[Justin Tseng]: When was this?

[Justin Tseng]: This was, I went early yesterday, 10-ish.

[Justin Tseng]: It was in the morning yesterday.

[Justin Tseng]: It was someone in that FBI year, so it wasn't someone in ICE gear.

[Justin Tseng]: And I didn't know if those two things were completely linked with each other, so I flagged it to Councilor Bears, who flagged it to you and the Mayor.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the other kind of question that Councilors had at the time was if we have a kind of system built into place where at least we might know about these things happening when you

[Justin Tseng]: As the police department find them out as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I was wondering if it would be possible for you to notify the mayor's office city councilors department heads when you know you get a notification that they might be in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I think sending out know your rights information I think would be helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I think, yeah, I mean, this is the conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: This is why we're asking the question.

[Justin Tseng]: So we can have this conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: So members of the public can know what's going through all of our heads.

[Justin Tseng]: Yep.

[Justin Tseng]: And I do want to clarify that the non-cooperation policy law ordinance is just for

[Justin Tseng]: civil cases and not criminal as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's for the public to know that.

[Justin Tseng]: And I don't think that's what the ordinance would say, but yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, these are very tough questions.

[Justin Tseng]: We get tough questions ourselves.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think in these situations,

[Justin Tseng]: best for us to get a bit of transparency, just for us to know where you guys are coming from.

[Justin Tseng]: For us to flag things that residents are using as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I believe so.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I believe, at least the people, I mean, I think everyone was either in MPD year, and I think the MPD folks were just doing their regular jobs.

[Justin Tseng]: I didn't see them, you know, interact with or talk to the FBI agents.

[Justin Tseng]: And then I saw a bunch of FBI agents in the lot, because we were trying to park there to get the, I was there to get a police report.

[Justin Tseng]: And then while I was in the hall in the lobby, getting the police report, I saw someone walk through.

[Justin Tseng]: and exit from the front, but they looked like they were walking from the back.

[Justin Tseng]: And I just don't know the layout of the first floor well enough, but it seemed like they were walking through a place I hadn't been to before.

[Justin Tseng]: Of course, and that's why, you know, just wanted to flag this and say, I, the reason why I didn't make a big fuss about this was because I didn't know if this was like,

[Justin Tseng]: you know, another routine kind of cooperation.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to flag.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, sorry.

[Justin Tseng]: The mic is not powered on.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, so, um,

[Justin Tseng]: The HRC update ordinance, just to reorient everyone, this is meant to expand and empower the Human Rights Commission in Medford to do more work as an advisory body in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we see the need for it so much with what's going on in the world around us.

[Justin Tseng]: and especially in the pressure that municipal and state governments are facing to disinvest from diversity, from equity and inclusive initiatives.

[Justin Tseng]: And so, you know, having a resident-led body like this, I think, is something that is paramount.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, what I've done over the last month is I've talked with

[Justin Tseng]: the mayor about some recommendations or feedback that she had for this ordinance draft.

[Justin Tseng]: And then I also liaised with community members who have been former HRC members and community leaders who have been working on this draft with me together.

[Justin Tseng]: So in an email, I had a

[Justin Tseng]: clerk heard a piece forward earlier today.

[Justin Tseng]: I attached the document which has the mayor's feedback.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think what my goal would be for this meeting is to walk through the feedback.

[Justin Tseng]: Point by point, I highlighted everything that would be a change.

[Justin Tseng]: And then I think we should just talk about it as a committee and then either vote to accept or not make a change.

[Justin Tseng]: So,

[Justin Tseng]: pulling up that document, the first question that came up was the size of the Human Rights Commission, the proposed size.

[Justin Tseng]: So the original draft of the ordinance said a minimum of nine and up to 15.

[Justin Tseng]: And the mayor's kind of feedback here was that she thought that it would be hard to keep track of variable numbers.

[Justin Tseng]: And so she would want us to adopt a solid, a clear number here.

[Justin Tseng]: And her recommendation was nine.

[Justin Tseng]: She felt that nine was plenty and a lot of, would be a lot of people.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of the community members I've been talking to are a little concerned that nine is a lower number.

[Justin Tseng]: then, you know, especially when the HRC has so many different topics and realms to cover.

[Justin Tseng]: And so they would prefer to see a larger number in terms of just to get more life experience.

[Justin Tseng]: And so

[Justin Tseng]: The question is what number do we go with?

[Justin Tseng]: There's one path that is keeping the kind of multiples of three because we have mayor, council and HRC appointments.

[Justin Tseng]: Right now it's like spread a third, a third, a third.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think we should discuss if we think nine is appropriate number, 12, 15.

[Justin Tseng]: The drawback behind 12 is that it's an even number, but I think some community members have also said that in that case, if it's a 6-6 vote, then naturally the resolution shouldn't pass and that such votes would be pretty rare.

[Justin Tseng]: The kind of drawback with 15 is that I think there is more consensus that it feels like a very large number.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's kind of the back and forth with it.

[Justin Tseng]: There's been some kind of suggestions, maybe we don't split appointments a third, a third, a third, maybe do three from the council, three from the mayor, and then four from the HRC's kind of like appointment list.

[Justin Tseng]: So appointing from other city commissions and like nonprofit groups.

[Justin Tseng]: But I wanted to open the floor to councillors to see what people thought.

[Justin Tseng]: I think there's a diversity of views, to be honest about this.

[Justin Tseng]: I've heard community members say that

[Justin Tseng]: Some members think that we really could fill 15.

[Justin Tseng]: Some are a little bit more skeptical.

[Justin Tseng]: The administration's kind of views that 15 would be hard to fill, but nine wouldn't.

[Justin Tseng]: They think that we could get to nine, maybe 12, but they're a little hesitant to say that we would be able to fill 15.

[Justin Tseng]: And yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: I think my personal reaction to that would be that I think there might be some pushback from community members that we would give kind of the appointment list, like a smaller slot because like there's so much to possibly a point from, for example, like the Medford Housing Authority and the why and

[Justin Tseng]: just like the different commissions that we have, like Council on Aging, Disabilities and stuff like that.

[Justin Tseng]: I think there's such a list out there of potential voices to be included.

[Justin Tseng]: 335 then maybe?

[Justin Tseng]: Honestly, I'm open to possibilities and we should hear from the public if there are members who have thoughts about it too.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, Cambridge is 11, by the way.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I think I'd be open to opting for 335.

[Justin Tseng]: I think my only concern about it is the idea that an ultimately unlocked body is doing a lot of the appointments.

[Justin Tseng]: It's still not over half.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that could be a question with the mayor's office.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I would be open to it.

[Justin Tseng]: But I do think it's a logical solution.

[Justin Tseng]: Like I think if we actually think about it from a policy standpoint, it makes a lot of sense.

[Justin Tseng]: I think 444 also makes a lot of sense.

[Justin Tseng]: And if we're very worried about a tie break, we can ask the, we can make it so that the ex-officio member, like the staff liaison or the community city council liaison has a vote to break ties.

[Justin Tseng]: But it's not necessarily my preferred outcome.

[Justin Tseng]: I think 12 would be fine.

[Justin Tseng]: But, um, yeah, I don't know what you think trail living or, I guess.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, so essentially the the groups that

[Justin Tseng]: essentially reading through the point A under membership.

[Justin Tseng]: The second half of that is basically saying that the MHRC will appoint a resident from the Medford Housing Authority, and then it should appoint the rest of the members.

[Justin Tseng]: from or from, from like city commissions, community based organizations, or upon recommendations of those organizations.

[Justin Tseng]: So essentially, it's, you know, a broad definition, it's meant to capture, for example, when the city council maybe creates another ordinance, like establishing like a gender equity commission, or youth commission or something like that.

[Justin Tseng]: Allowing flexibility there.

[Justin Tseng]: Well, okay, okay.

[Justin Tseng]: But it's not a list.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not it's not a list of

[Justin Tseng]: these are the organizations that the MHRC has to appoint from.

[Justin Tseng]: it's saying that these are the types of organizations that they have to like appoint from.

[Justin Tseng]: Sure.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng I think, um I think Councilors have articulated maybe wanting to defer to, um, former members that they trust you.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think 335 is something that we should I would move to adopt.

[Justin Tseng]: Um I would motion to adopt language to create, um,

[Justin Tseng]: through 335 model where three members are appointed by the mayor, three are appointed by the city council, and then five are appointed by the city members of the HRC.

[Justin Tseng]: And then if it becomes an issue with the mayor's administration, we can revisit it in a regular meeting or something.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm going to recognize Councilor Tseng, um, before I quickly move on to the next point of feedback.

[Justin Tseng]: I something I had talked with community members about we settled on where we are now, but

[Justin Tseng]: we do create a different standard for the Medford Housing Authority by saying the HRC will appoint a member of the Medford Housing Authority.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to see if councillors were comfortable with that or if we should just make it a recommended body.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay, great.

[Justin Tseng]: Moving on to the next kind of sticking point.

[Justin Tseng]: This is maybe the biggest sticking point with the mayor's office.

[Justin Tseng]: The mayor has urged us to not give members of the HRC stipends.

[Justin Tseng]: The reasoning seems complex.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't completely understand why to be frank with everyone.

[Justin Tseng]: I think part of it, at least

[Justin Tseng]: way back when, when I was talking to Francis, is that people kind of want to wait until the classification compensation study comes out and to kind of find a fairer amount for all boards and commissions, because some are paid, some are not paid.

[Justin Tseng]: There's a kind of, I think there's a slight worry about that difference there, but the city council's policy, at least up until now, has been to

[Justin Tseng]: put in stipends as we revise ordinances and to find a fair level given the work that they're doing and what paid commissions are currently paying.

[Justin Tseng]: And what I find here that this seems, this is reasonable to me.

[Justin Tseng]: I think there's a secondary concern as well that the mayor did actually raise that about budgeting and about

[Justin Tseng]: worries that this would create a kind of big budget impact, but I kind of think those worries are a little unfounded, given the size of this commission and how, you know, how much the commission would be budgeted, at least in the first kind of first bit of time.

[Justin Tseng]: In talking to community members, I've kind of, I think everyone is

[Justin Tseng]: I think people are pretty unanimously supporting the idea of putting stipends in.

[Justin Tseng]: I think there's a question of, do we not specify how much and then create like an empty budget line item for the mayor to fill in later?

[Justin Tseng]: Do we lower this amount to maybe $1,000 instead of

[Justin Tseng]: 1,250, or do we just keep it the same?

[Justin Tseng]: I think I personally would rather us just keep it the same.

[Justin Tseng]: I think lowering it to 1,000 maybe could be an option.

[Justin Tseng]: I think creating the kind of empty budget item thing is a little bit too unstable.

[Justin Tseng]: But I wanted to hear from Councilors.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Callahan.

[Justin Tseng]: So currently the way that the budget for the commission works is it goes through the DEI office.

[Justin Tseng]: So Francis's salary is essentially, and Francis's office costs is essentially their budget.

[Justin Tseng]: And this was a little bit of a kind of a sticking point as well, at least when the HRC was trying to do events and had to get approval from the DEI office for every single event.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think a very concrete example of that was the Royal House invited the HRC to co-sponsor an event, and they were told no.

[Justin Tseng]: They were rejected, and the DEI office did not give them funds to help co-sponsor the event, which was an event that I believe they had co-sponsored the year previous to that.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think that's why

[Justin Tseng]: there's a big push behind creating a budget item and at least stipends for HRC members.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm happy to move on to the next point.

[Justin Tseng]: So the mayor also requested the ability to remove her own appointees.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I drafted some language allowing for that.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think if we choose to do that, it would only make sense for city council to be able to remove their own too.

[Justin Tseng]: This has kind of become a very big point of discussion.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the argument for adopting the mayor's amendment is, at least from her side, she just wants to be able to hold her own appointees accountable if they say something wildly off.

[Justin Tseng]: off-color or do something that is wildly off-base.

[Justin Tseng]: And she would want the ability to remove her own appointments and essentially use that in the backup in case the rest of HRC is unwilling to vote that person off.

[Justin Tseng]: The kind of pushback against that is that I worry that this would

[Justin Tseng]: endanger the political independence of the HRC, because then the question is, what does forecast mean?

[Justin Tseng]: So how high of a bar is forecast for removal?

[Justin Tseng]: So if the kind of, if her appointee to the HRC says something about a human rights crisis that is very different from what the mayor's views are,

[Justin Tseng]: is that then a problem, right?

[Justin Tseng]: And I think my understanding of for-cause, I think it would depend on the degree of what that statement would be.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think for the most part, it would be protected, but I can see the worry.

[Justin Tseng]: The clerk might be able to help me refresh my memory on this.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the mayor usually has power to remove her appointees.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I don't think it would be that different from for cause make a difference.

[Justin Tseng]: I think your assessment of the situation is how I kind of remember it as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Like usually, interestingly enough, huge constitutional question that like, what is very relevant?

[Justin Tseng]: Um, because it's, you know, or what is cause, but also like, what is removal?

[Justin Tseng]: Like what is appointment and removal?

[Justin Tseng]: Cause like, does the power to appoint also include the power to remove?

[Justin Tseng]: huge constitutional question.

[Justin Tseng]: Lawyers have been going at it for 150 years.

[Justin Tseng]: The answer seems to be yes.

[Justin Tseng]: So, yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: I can also quickly look at the case law right now.

[Justin Tseng]: We can move on to the next point and then come back.

[Justin Tseng]: The other ones are smaller.

[Justin Tseng]: So, for example, the next one, the next changes in officers in point a just clarifying like.

[Justin Tseng]: when the elections of officers happen, so annually at the start of a new term.

[Justin Tseng]: I would be open to that.

[Justin Tseng]: I did actually think about that before this meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: I think an alternative path is to say that policy differences or disagreements do not constitute good cause.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I think that would be awesome.

[Justin Tseng]: It's difficult.

[Justin Tseng]: I did actually look at the case law.

[Justin Tseng]: The case law is that a good cause is broad.

[Justin Tseng]: It's anything that's not arbitrary and capricious and an abuse of the person's duties or discretion.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, but it also depends on the context of the, um, the context of the, the thing itself.

[Justin Tseng]: So, um, like it would in this context depend on like hinge on the fact that this is an HRC ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: So if, if the kind of argument is, I think the argument is that, you know, like supporting Palestine is supporting human rights, then there's a case there to be had.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I,

[Justin Tseng]: to be quite honest, I think no matter what we do, it will always be gray.

[Justin Tseng]: I think even if we don't have something like that, I think then the gray area kind of shifts to whether the mayor has the power to remove in the first place.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's safer not to make the amendment.

[Justin Tseng]: Is that a motion?

[Justin Tseng]: Okay, so, um, I went through the clerk more clerical thing and a under officers and see under officers, basically just wherever it says assigned to the staff person that Mary suggested adding City Council liaison because right now, she can't find a city staff person to liaise with HRC, the director does not wish to continue the job so this is just to give us more flexibility in case.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, we do need someone to do it.

[Justin Tseng]: Maybe one of us from the city council does it in the meantime.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay, the next thing is under independence resources and council.

[Justin Tseng]: This is on the third page.

[Justin Tseng]: And then the blue is new edits.

[Justin Tseng]: So essentially last time we talked about access to council, the mayor was okay with letting them have some independence with regards to accessing council, but as long as it's done through the liaison.

[Justin Tseng]: So letting the liaison kind of make that final call.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think she's okay with that.

[Justin Tseng]: The next substantive change is in D of that section, basically saying that, so instead of the HRC itself submitting the proposed budget to the mayor, having the liaison do it, just to kind of make it the same as other commissions and other departments, it's more of a procedural thing, and it would still be upon the recommendation of HRC.

[Justin Tseng]: And then the last, okay, there are two more kind of sticking points.

[Justin Tseng]: The kind of the second to last one is the mayor feels that the HRC should not be able to speak on behalf of the city when it comes to state or federal legislation or state or federal international matters.

[Justin Tseng]: she's okay if she thinks it's okay if the HRC sends a resolution for us to pass or for her office to sign.

[Justin Tseng]: And so she's very happy to do it that way.

[Justin Tseng]: But she's afraid that an unelected body would be making a policy statement on behalf of the city then that then the mayor and the city council would have to kind of

[Justin Tseng]: kind of simmer down, she's kind of worried that that would impact relationships on Beacon Hill too.

[Justin Tseng]: And then the last kind of sticking point, oh, and obviously the kind of pushback against that is whether that kind of limits the powers of the HRC from something, especially from something that they currently have, the power that they have.

[Justin Tseng]: And the last kind of feedback point is just,

[Justin Tseng]: The original last sentence read that the HRC would evaluate allegations of discrimination and then refer them to NCAT and the AG's office or other appropriate bodies.

[Justin Tseng]: think the mayor's fear is that that reads a little too legal, like giving them a role in the legal process of like adjudicating disputes and determining which disputes are valid or not.

[Justin Tseng]: She's not necessarily against them having a certain power like that, but she just doesn't want to create a very explicitly legal role for them.

[Justin Tseng]: And so she would prefer the broader language that I have put in that document saying that the HRC can review as discretion discrimination allegations brought to its attention and consult with council to review.

[Justin Tseng]: Great.

[Justin Tseng]: Well, right now it's a question mark, because technically the HRC, I think it really depends on how you read the HRC ordinance right now.

[Justin Tseng]: If you read it super strictly, they don't have any, they wouldn't have any of these powers, period.

[Justin Tseng]: If you read it broader,

[Justin Tseng]: then they do have quite flexible powers with regards to this.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, to basically pass a resolution saying if the state house is debating a housing stability law and saying the HRC maybe would want to pass a resolution saying we support this bill.

[Justin Tseng]: she's worried that they would pass a statement saying the city of Medford supports it.

[Justin Tseng]: That's not what it says here.

[Justin Tseng]: So what the mayor's draft says is that they can't say anything with regards to state or federal bills or things that are happening on those levels, but they can send us a resolution for us to pass.

[Justin Tseng]: I would agree.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think the best solution is maybe just

[Justin Tseng]: I honestly this this the idea of submitting resolutions I think is a good idea.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it should be additive in in addition to what was there before of saying like that broader power.

[Justin Tseng]: And then the broader power, we can just say that we can create like a stipulation that they speak on behalf of the Medford Human Rights Commission, and not like the city of Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: But that's Yeah, that's my view on it.

[Justin Tseng]: Council is our

[Justin Tseng]: I think then in that case with this section, my

[Justin Tseng]: strike the words after improve social equity and then maybe insert the words on behalf of the MHRC or in the name of the MHRC.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and yeah, okay.

[Justin Tseng]: The, I did forget one edit.

[Justin Tseng]: It's like also a kind of, uh, clerical edit, um, under roles, powers, duties under B and then three at the end of B3 about like employment diversity.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, the mayor just wants us to put in the words based on data that's collected, like data collected just to clarify.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll be briefer about this because I did share the results of the survey with everyone on this committee through the clerk.

[Justin Tseng]: We got 92 responses, which is a good number.

[Justin Tseng]: It predictably skews a little bit above the median age of the city, a little bit higher income, but neighborhood-wise, it's pretty balanced.

[Justin Tseng]: And it does skew

[Justin Tseng]: towards those without children at home, compared to the census data, if I remember correctly.

[Justin Tseng]: But with those factors in mind, we do hear quite a lot about a lot of core issues.

[Justin Tseng]: education and streets being schools and streets being the top two issues that we see kind of throughout the whole the survey, but there is quite a lot of helpful information here, a lot of new ideas about how to leverage state laws, a few kind of worries about

[Justin Tseng]: shortfalls from federal funding, ideas about climate resilience, about safer streets after school, which is I know an issue we all hear quite a lot about.

[Justin Tseng]: kind of social programs, family supports, green spaces.

[Justin Tseng]: So I encourage Councilors to just read through this on their own time as well.

[Justin Tseng]: With regards to longer term needs, there's a lot of talk about longer term plans for infrastructure, roads, and also a new high school.

[Justin Tseng]: kind of focus on, there's this focus on how like investing in health and human kind of impact things, climate change, accessibility issues, like especially with regards to language services, immigrant services, stuff like that.

[Justin Tseng]: And of course, afterschool care, again,

[Justin Tseng]: In the kind of like first page, which is the meat of the results, I think those are the results that are most helpful for Councilors to kind of just digest individually as well, instead of me giving a summary, because I don't want to treat this like a poll.

[Justin Tseng]: We did hear that residents are there, there are a good number of residents who are reading the city's newsletter, obviously,

[Justin Tseng]: those who got this survey are definitely going to be very skewed in favor of that.

[Justin Tseng]: But to see that over 50 people are reading the newsletter is very helpful to know.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think all in all, when it comes to participation and updates, like ways to give, to kind of do participation, there's, besides social media and the newsletter, there's kind of an even spread.

[Justin Tseng]: There's a

[Justin Tseng]: less preference for attending listening sessions or getting robocalls about the budget.

[Justin Tseng]: But when it comes to

[Justin Tseng]: like a town hall with the budget, people are interested in doing a specific town hall with regards to the budget.

[Justin Tseng]: So I guess, in general, when it comes to general updates, people, the listening sessions, robo-call thing doesn't work as much, or at least with the people that did respond.

[Justin Tseng]: But with regards to getting people to engage in the process and give feedback, they would like those options open to showing up.

[Justin Tseng]: There's, there's a lot of great questions that people have in the kind of in that very last section there 28 responses for it.

[Justin Tseng]: I think some folks have suggested an increase-decrease metric.

[Justin Tseng]: There's some just general feedback with regards to when in the process we do this survey and how people get information.

[Justin Tseng]: So we did put a deadline on the survey or a soft deadline on the survey of this meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: saying that we were going to be reviewing responses at this meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: I think my hope is that we continue to keep this forum open and share this link with councillors to so people can see new responses that come in.

[Justin Tseng]: We all have the kind of spreadsheet here.

[Justin Tseng]: I would want this just to protect the privacy of those who did answer would want this to be relatively, you know, under control.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think if we can do more work to engage folks that aren't very much represented or heard in this survey, that'd be good.

[Justin Tseng]: So I know Councilor Callaghan has helped blast this across tons of different channels.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we saw better results with that as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think more outreach when it comes to like

[Justin Tseng]: renters when it comes to lower income folks, people of color, organizations of color, maybe doing more kind of like bringing printed copies to community centers and libraries, too, would be helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't know if there are any initial reactions from Councilors reading through the reading through this, the results, but Council Lazzaro.

[Justin Tseng]: No, I don't think so.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the survey is really just an open feedback form.

[Justin Tseng]: So I don't think it defeats the purpose at all.

[Justin Tseng]: And yeah, I guess I might add, I might suggest we add to the motion that

[Justin Tseng]: I share access with everyone on the council, because right now I have it with members of this committee, but I know the budget discussions are committed to the whole.

[Justin Tseng]: So just to get other councillors to have access to this data as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And then in the meantime, maybe I could try to put together a summary of what we see here in some kind of like representative responses.

[Justin Tseng]: No, so this was not, well actually I don't, I know I posted to my personal Facebook, but I don't know if it was shared across Facebook groups.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I think this is kind of difficult to just like sit down here and say, you know what people responded.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it makes sense for people to percolate on it.

[Justin Tseng]: And I guess we could give myself the option of preparing a summary for councillors.

[Justin Tseng]: For people who missed my comment, I said I do like to eat chicken.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, so we got 110 responses which is decent.

[Justin Tseng]: And these responses, I wanted to start with the demographic data just to frame like our sense of what kinds of people are engaging with it.

[Justin Tseng]: Of course, we always see that with anything with city government, anything with political participation really, it most reflects the people who are best able to engage with city, you know, with politics.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think it's important to look at the demographic data first.

[Justin Tseng]: So this survey, it's Hughes female.

[Justin Tseng]: We did get a decent representation from across the city, maybe a little bit less from East Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: But compared to my last version of the survey, this is a bigger, more diverse spread in terms of neighborhood representation in responding to the survey.

[Justin Tseng]: We also see that the survey is disproportionately high income.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's something to keep in mind when we review the results of this survey as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And it very much heavily skews towards homeowners.

[Justin Tseng]: According to the census estimates, the current spread of homeowner versus renter in the city is 53% homeowner, 47% renter.

[Justin Tseng]: So this is a very, very big skew.

[Justin Tseng]: And the median age in the city, I believe, is around 35 years old.

[Justin Tseng]: So this very much skews older as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's another thing to keep in mind.

[Justin Tseng]: And I couldn't find any clear numbers of parents, like percentages of parents in the city, according to the census.

[Justin Tseng]: This is just for our, for us to know.

[Justin Tseng]: So it ended up being around 54% saying that they didn't have kids under the age of 18, 42% saying that they did.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, very expectedly, excuse white as well, although we did do better with getting Asian American responses than the last time.

[Justin Tseng]: And I actually will say, compared to my last survey, there are more people in their 20s answering as well, but it's still, you know, a lot less than the actual proportion in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's very English speaking.

[Justin Tseng]: That's the other thing.

[Justin Tseng]: I forget what the census estimates are, but it very much skews towards English speakers.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and yeah, the DPW question really depends on how you cut it.

[Justin Tseng]: So, um, I should I actually I should update this, um, this should read, this should read 46.

[Justin Tseng]: And these were the two that really dominated the short term needs section.

[Justin Tseng]: When it came to schools.

[Justin Tseng]: The focus was on Medford public schools and just getting adequate staffing adequate funding for the schools, but there were a number of residents who brought up after school care as well.

[Justin Tseng]: When it came to streets and sidewalks think the heavy emphasis was on improving

[Justin Tseng]: road conditions, you know, cracked streets and sidewalks, potholes, stuff like that.

[Justin Tseng]: But there was actually a lot of talk, you know, comments about crosswalk safety, safer pedestrian infrastructure, cycling infrastructure as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And then there are five responses.

[Justin Tseng]: That's why I changed it from 41 to 46.

[Justin Tseng]: There are five responses that talked about DPW funding more generally.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's fair to infer that it's about streets and sidewalks, but they talked about just getting more funding for staffing in the office and better responsiveness there.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, we saw we had 25 responses mentioned, um, non street infrastructure projects that these are projects that are kind of like public buildings, the high school city hall.

[Justin Tseng]: We got 21 responses talking about affordable housing and development, particularly asking for more help for renters and kind of more just spending more money on housing as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And then this is a very new jump is there 16 responses that explicitly mentioned more support for vulnerable low income immigrant residents, particularly putting it in the frame of what the federal government is doing.

[Justin Tseng]: When I did the survey, two years ago, that was only mentioned by three or four people with a bigger, bigger sample size.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this is a really, really big change from two years ago.

[Justin Tseng]: And then some other frequently mentioned priorities, transit, transportation, 14 responses.

[Justin Tseng]: That was kind of more focused on public transit.

[Justin Tseng]: So safer cycling routes, better bus service, better MBTA access.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I think speaks to why the overrides were at least seen by a majority of residents in the city is really important.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think if I can add my own commentary to this, in reading through the responses, I got a sense that a lot of residents saw the override as just

[Justin Tseng]: like one step in the solution rather than the complete answer to the solution.

[Justin Tseng]: I didn't really get the impression that people thought that the overrides would solve everything about school funding or street repair funding, rather that they kind of just saw it as like, okay, this is what we need right now before we kind of either develop a more long-term plan or come back to the voters in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: And there are a lot of like,

[Justin Tseng]: This came up especially with the schools.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that was kind of, that was a decent like chunk of responses focusing on that.

[Justin Tseng]: I, this isn't completely unsurprising but young like younger respondents, particularly in the, in their 30s were more likely to highlight housing library, public safety issues, middle aged, like 4040 to 59 year olds were kind of more.

[Justin Tseng]: more emphasizing roads and sidewalks and big capital projects like buildings.

[Justin Tseng]: seem to be a little bit more correlated with youth.

[Justin Tseng]: And then another kind of important thing to titrate with is income, because we know that this survey is huge towards much, much, towards much, much higher incomes than, you know, our median here in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: So higher income respondents were more likely to emphasize non-street infrastructure and library services.

[Justin Tseng]: And then mid to lower income respondents were much more likely to bring up affordable housing and support for vulnerable communities as the short-term priority in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: there were kind of a few different ways of going about it, but I think residents were really focused on business development, supporting small businesses, supporting kind of the aesthetics of the or improving the aesthetics of the square or of Medford Square and our like smaller squares as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I think people see these as long-term priorities.

[Justin Tseng]: make City Hall more efficient.

[Justin Tseng]: And then when it came to the open-ended question about questions and comments about the budget process, I kind of looked at them and then broadly categorized them, although I think it's worth just going through it on our own and reading through what people responded because there aren't that many responses.

[Justin Tseng]: I think there are probably around 30 responses to that question, 30 to 50, somewhere there, maybe 30, 40.

[Justin Tseng]: But broadly, I think there's six buckets.

[Justin Tseng]: People want to know how the budget process is structured and decided.

[Justin Tseng]: They want to know where the money is going and how we track it and how we explain that.

[Justin Tseng]: They want to know how they can, residents want to know how they can participate meaningfully.

[Justin Tseng]: They want to know who is being included in the process and who is being left out.

[Justin Tseng]: They wanna know why aren't, why does it feel like poor services aren't more functional than they are?

[Justin Tseng]: And I think a lot of this is actually perception.

[Justin Tseng]: That's something we can talk about after too.

[Justin Tseng]: And then people wanna know if we are addressing urgent and long-term needs and how we keep track of stuff like that.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is the last page, the last part of it.

[Justin Tseng]: I think these questions go to talking about

[Justin Tseng]: like communicating better about things that we already are doing as a city, and especially as a city council.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of what residents raised are covered in the zoning reform, the zoning reform process.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of it is in the Medford square revitalization plan of the RFP that that is being proposed.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think more work has to be done to let residents know about that a lot of their ideas are in there.

[Justin Tseng]: I think

[Justin Tseng]: I think a good kind of encapsulation of that point I just made are the comments about permitting and about City Hall being slow.

[Justin Tseng]: I think a perception is there, but as we heard in our budget meetings, as I'm sure a lot of you guys have talked to our business and planning staff about this,

[Justin Tseng]: and building department staff about this, on the city council side actually, or on the Medford side, the city of Medford side, a lot of that actually happens very quickly.

[Justin Tseng]: We can get permitting done within a day or two, but a lot of it is at the state level as well.

[Justin Tseng]: The state has its whole litany of regulations and permitting processes as well, and that oftentimes can take up to two years.

[Justin Tseng]: And so there's a, you know, I think we might need to educate the public more about what is city controlled and what is state controlled, but also do more advocacy on behalf of the city to get the permitting done quicker on the state level.

[Justin Tseng]: So there's my summary.
