[Justin Tseng]: Dickinson for joining us.

[Justin Tseng]: I know oftentimes when we're here together, we talk about the need, how old our city's financial software is, and especially became an issue when you pointed it out when you came in, that the systems that we were using were not the systems that are commonplace throughout the state or are up to date.

[Justin Tseng]: And that kind of slows down the workflow, makes things more difficult as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I guess my worry about the issue is more that I think we talk about the issue and then we kind of kick the can down the road about when exactly we might see that transition to a better financial system or a new financial system like a software.

[Justin Tseng]: And it has these knock-on effects of

[Justin Tseng]: affecting timeliness of financial reporting, it can affect calculation of retro pay, different payroll and finance updates as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I guess, is there any money in here, at least any seed money in here, to develop that timeline, that plan for updating our city's financial software?

[Justin Tseng]: I appreciate that answer.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that helps explain a lot of it, but I think from this Councilor, what I would like to see going forward is us really think about what that transition looks like, even if it's spread over a period of time, because it would have, I think, long-term positive impacts for our city.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think it would go nowhere if we don't at least start to formulate what that plan may look like.

[Justin Tseng]: That's me speaking for myself.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I might not be able to speak as a parent, but I can speak as someone who was a kid.

[Justin Tseng]: And to speak to really, I think the wide range of programming that Medford Family Network has given Medford families throughout the years that so many people like me benefited from.

[Justin Tseng]: And more than just programming, really building a community of Medford kids and Medford parents.

[Justin Tseng]: who, you know, can get together help each other, build a build a community here in Medford and I'm so so grateful for that work.

[Justin Tseng]: Director Cassidy is like a Medford celebrity, I feel like, with all of the you know the dozens of years that she's given to this job.

[Justin Tseng]: has gotten to know so many of our residents so intimately, really knowing the happy things about Medford and the not so happy things and helping make sure that, you know, with the work, especially that you did during COVID, that we were able to help out the families that really needed help.

[Justin Tseng]: And she's just a, you know, a bridge builder, a connector in that way.

[Justin Tseng]: And we'll really miss having Dr. Cassidy do that service for our city.

[Justin Tseng]: I will always really, I will always remember.

[Justin Tseng]: the energy that she brings to all the events, seeing her at teddy bear picnics and fundraisers and just the regular MFN events, seeing her dressed up and the energy that she brings really brings the life to the party.

[Justin Tseng]: So I want to thank Director Cassidy for all her work.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm so grateful and congratulations on your retirement.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I also wanted to thank Laurel, thank everyone who's worked on this, and all the projects that we're funding for submitting their proposals.

[Justin Tseng]: These, you know, for a lot of Medford residents, these projects are part of their everyday lives, part of the ways that they get to their grocery stores,

[Justin Tseng]: the way that they put food on their dinner plate at night.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think it's really important that we fund this, that we pass this.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that something new in what we're seeing tonight is the vacant storefront initiatives, as well as generally the business development initiatives as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So money to

[Justin Tseng]: continue the vacant storefront district program to also create the second round of the project pop-up and computer program.

[Justin Tseng]: I was just curious, Laurel, if, I usually ask this question for the projects.

[Justin Tseng]: I was wondering if you could speak to how we're measuring that success, like the effectivity of those programs.

[Justin Tseng]: Is the, can I just ask a follow up, is the goal to help the micro enterprises move into storefronts of their own going forward?

[Justin Tseng]: Is there, I know this, this is a great program in itself.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm just thinking about, have we thought about bridging that gap between when, you know, their time at the incubator ends and kind of their next step?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll be brief because I think President Bears and Councilor Lazzaro have covered what I think.

[Justin Tseng]: Something that comes up again and again here on the City Council is the unresponsiveness of the State Department, KEOLAS, the MBTA when it comes to a lot of our requests.

[Justin Tseng]: That's not to say they're never responsive, but there certainly is a gap there.

[Justin Tseng]: And even though I think there's a lot of work for us to do communicating with them, I think there's a lot of work on their end as well to communicate with us about projects.

[Justin Tseng]: kerfuffle could have been mitigated.

[Justin Tseng]: It seems like an easy step for the state to have taken on that they chose not to take.

[Justin Tseng]: And so we're stuck in this situation.

[Justin Tseng]: I think when we do see that responsiveness from the state, it's when we speak together as the City Council.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I am very grateful for this resolution tonight, because I think if we are going to get anywhere, this has to be a part of it.

[Justin Tseng]: I really appreciate you coming here, and coming here is an act of bravery, particularly when you're being targeted by the federal administration.

[Justin Tseng]: I've spoken to this before, so I'll be a little brief, but I feel fearful, too, because of who I am and the work that I'm doing and my parents, their status in this country, a country that they've called home for 30 years, over 30 years.

[Justin Tseng]: a country in which they've lived more of their life than anywhere else.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm fearful because of what I do that it's gonna impact them as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why I think this council has been really on the forefront of thinking about productive and innovative ways that we can defend our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think Zach spoke to basically all of the, almost all of the things that we've passed, but you know,

[Justin Tseng]: That non cooperation cooperation deal with ice, you know, we can't completely stop certain groups from operating in the city, but we can do what we can to protect our residents and that is.

[Justin Tseng]: you know, that's a huge safeguard for our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: Because I hate to, I would hate to imagine what would happen if we didn't have that enshrined in our city policy, in our laws, if we didn't have that non-cooperation policy in the first place and what it means for our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the only thing that was left off was we also passed a resolution calling on the mayor to launch a Know Your Rights campaign in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and, you know, we suggested we were proactive and suggesting how that could go out to our residents where we could leave.

[Justin Tseng]: the messages, the cards.

[Justin Tseng]: So I would really encourage residents who feel strongly about this to reach out to the mayor to let them

[Justin Tseng]: to keep up the pressure, really, to let the mayor know that, you know, it's not, that some things are greater than a political kind of play, right?

[Justin Tseng]: Like, I understand that the mayor's thinking about it in a very certain way.

[Justin Tseng]: I think her values are in the right place.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think the approach is where we differ.

[Justin Tseng]: I think

[Justin Tseng]: there's value in reaching out to the mayor and saying that, you know, a lot of this funding is going to go away anyways.

[Justin Tseng]: That even communities that haven't passed these laws are being targeted.

[Justin Tseng]: Communities that haven't done these things are being targeted as well.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not just Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: And

[Justin Tseng]: It does make a difference when we do those things, when we codify those laws, when we do your Know Your Rights campaign.

[Justin Tseng]: And really, the gain is much more than the risk.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think there are ways to do these campaigns, too, without putting people at risk.

[Justin Tseng]: But it requires those who can step up to step up.

[Justin Tseng]: And a lot of the people who have been traditionally at the forefront of these fights are the ones being targeted.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think it becomes incumbent upon the rest of the city, particularly from the city government perspective to step up.

[Justin Tseng]: So that was that was a lot.

[Justin Tseng]: Uh huh.

[Justin Tseng]: I know the councilors want to say more and don't want to take up too much time.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm gonna go Councilor Leming.

[Justin Tseng]: Hi, I'm Justin Tseng, and I'm proud to serve as your city councilor in the city I've always called home.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm the son of immigrants who came to Medford chasing the American dream.

[Justin Tseng]: My parents stretched every dollar and raised me paycheck to paycheck, but it was our public schools, our neighbors, and this community that gave us everything.

[Justin Tseng]: For the past four years, I've worked to give back and to pay it forward.

[Justin Tseng]: Now as national politicians gamble with our economy and threaten our neighbors,

[Justin Tseng]: Medford needs steady hands and bold leadership.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll always stand up for you because Medford stood up for me.

[Justin Tseng]: And over the past four years, we haven't just made progress, we've made history.

[Justin Tseng]: While some leaders are busy banning books and turning neighbors against each other, we're building a city that welcomes everyone and works for all of us.

[Justin Tseng]: We've made record investments in our schools and passed laws to protect our neighbors and our freedoms.

[Justin Tseng]: While politicians in Washington and on Beacon Hill continue to cater to big money interests and leave us priced out and left behind, we're passing once-in-a-lifetime reforms to make housing more affordable, spur local business growth, and lead the fight against climate change right here at home.

[Justin Tseng]: Life is rocky enough.

[Justin Tseng]: Our job is to smooth the path.

[Justin Tseng]: We're fixing roads and sidewalks that haven't been touched in decades.

[Justin Tseng]: We brought back bus routes that families rely on because getting to work, school, or the doctor shouldn't depend on owning a car.

[Justin Tseng]: And we're making City Hall more transparent and accessible so residents have a seat at the table.

[Justin Tseng]: Because when national leaders fail us, Medford steps up.

[Justin Tseng]: We prove that by leading with heart, with vision, and with the courage to do what's right, we can achieve results for all of us.

[Justin Tseng]: But the job's not done yet.

[Justin Tseng]: More than ever, we need leaders who know this community, and who show up and listen day in and day out.

[Justin Tseng]: That's why I'm running for re-election.

[Justin Tseng]: Let's keep building a Medford that works for you, me, and our neighbors down the street.

[Justin Tseng]: Let's keep moving Medford forward together.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I, I think I have comments that kind of break break into two general categories.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, sorry, sorry, sorry.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Going back to what I was saying, again, I want to kind of split my comments into process and substance, because I think I can speak to both.

[Justin Tseng]: When it comes to process, President Bears and I have been really working closely with the mayor's office for a very, very long time to get this on our agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: for a very long time.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know, you know, I've heard residents ask, you know, why is this all happening so last minute?

[Justin Tseng]: Why do things feel quick at the end?

[Justin Tseng]: Why are we having so many substantive conversations towards the end?

[Justin Tseng]: And I really do think a lot of this could have been mitigated had we had the mayor's office helped us, gave us the green light to move on this forward earlier.

[Justin Tseng]: If you go to our governing agenda, you'll find that us as the city council we place this pretty early on to address in the governance can be early last year, like, March, April, and February.

[Justin Tseng]: That was the goal, the goal was to start conversation so we wouldn't have to end up in the place where we might have disagreements last minute, where we, you know, didn't have to, you know, have these conversations about balance of power last minute, where we weren't dealing with last minute, small edits that you know actually make a big difference from the mayor's office that get placed on our agenda, where, you know, Councilors feel very pressured to approve something even though we haven't, there were substantive edits that we had didn't have time to scrutinize.

[Justin Tseng]: I want to also note that, you know, even besides the governing agenda I wrote the mayor on August 8, and I CC president bears I wrote the mayor and the chief of staff, reaching out as the chair of the governance committee set to set up those meetings early on so that we could jump right into things in September.

[Justin Tseng]: And the mayor asked us to go offline to do a phone call, we called, and, you know, in that phone call she asked us to delay those meetings.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, we talked through it about why we thought we might need more time.

[Justin Tseng]: We ultimately decided to respect the mayor.

[Justin Tseng]: and the Charter Review Committee's decision to send us the product later in the calendar.

[Justin Tseng]: So we did that.

[Justin Tseng]: We scheduled a meeting then.

[Justin Tseng]: And at that meeting, we were then asked again to delay by a month or any substantive conversation that we might have because the Charter Review Committee hadn't yet delivered their products to the mayor's office.

[Justin Tseng]: We respected that.

[Justin Tseng]: And then once, but at that meeting, you know, we talked about some substantive edits that are substantive proposals from the Charter Review Committee.

[Justin Tseng]: during their times meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know, you know, members of the committee have asked, you know, our meetings were public.

[Justin Tseng]: Why, you know, why didn't you, why, why didn't you just follow then?

[Justin Tseng]: And we did follow.

[Justin Tseng]: And I compiled, at the time I compiled a list of the motions the committee had made to give us a sense of what this draft charter would look like.

[Justin Tseng]: But then, you know, I was asked to not send that list of motions out because, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: because apparently the motions would make more sense in context of the whole charter, and that it would make sense for us to look at things piece by piece, which is still eventually what we did.

[Justin Tseng]: But I respected that as the chair of the Governance Committee, respecting the wish of the Charter Review Committee as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And all of that is to say our timeline got pushed to be crammed towards the very end,

[Justin Tseng]: And then we were notified late last year that we were expected to push out a product by mid-April.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why we find ourselves timeline-wise where we are today.

[Justin Tseng]: And I also want to note that we made sure to get

[Justin Tseng]: the draft charter committee out of the governance committee as soon as possible we scheduled a committee of the whole as soon as possible.

[Justin Tseng]: So we sent this, you know, we got this out of the city council as soon as possible to get to the mayor's office while still trying to do our due diligence.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, we gave the mayor time to and

[Justin Tseng]: We could have gotten the product back enough back early enough for us to scrutinize the small edits that had been made since the council gave the mayor our version.

[Justin Tseng]: But then we were given just a little bit less than a week to review that.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we were, you know, through press releases, pressured to, you know, rubber stamp what had been sent to us.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, that's my perspective of what's happened from, you know, as the chair of the governance committee.

[Justin Tseng]: Of course,

[Justin Tseng]: I can see you know where folks might disagree but those are just based on the emails, based on what's been published, based on the phone calls that have been made, that's the timeline.

[Justin Tseng]: So the City Council has been trying really hard to make sure that we aren't in a position where we're kind of rushing against the deadline.

[Justin Tseng]: And I want to note that at that last meeting we could have

[Justin Tseng]: chosen not to hold special city council meeting today as well, which would have gotten us past the April 15th deadline.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's why I disagree with councillors Lazzaro and Scarpelli on their kind of characterization of the timeline.

[Justin Tseng]: I also believe very strongly that it is our job to scrutinize, to do our due diligence, and that can lead us different places.

[Justin Tseng]: And

[Justin Tseng]: You know, I'll put my hands up I did my due diligence I ended up in a different place than what the draft we have in front of us today.

[Justin Tseng]: And then I compromised and I gave up on big things that I supported.

[Justin Tseng]: And even honestly even a lot of this in the first place is me deciding not to bring up things that I had concerns with, because I thought they were good enough.

[Justin Tseng]: I, you know, I think this is all a complicated conversation, which is fair, because the Charter is a foundational document.

[Justin Tseng]: It's the Constitution for a city, and so going through small edits, going through the details actually does mean a lot.

[Justin Tseng]: I find it not helpful when

[Justin Tseng]: when a councillor might suggest that parts of this charter are to take power away from certain groups in the city or to reverse the decision of the electorate at the last two or three elections to get new people onto the council or to get different people onto different bodies.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think that's what any of this should be about.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's wrong to bring that into this conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we should just

[Justin Tseng]: look at the policies as is.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, we shouldn't suggest that any of these proposals are here to undermine anyone in this room or any voter and their preference in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's what it means to support a charter that represents all 60,000 people of our city.

[Justin Tseng]: Moving on to the substance of it, I think, and in particular, Councilor Lazzaro's

[Justin Tseng]: I think the mayor on and off the school committee is a really tough decision.

[Justin Tseng]: It's one that I've been grappling with a lot.

[Justin Tseng]: The reason why I voted yes to send it here tonight was because I had gotten a lot of feedback from residents, especially towards the end of our consideration period, that they didn't think that the balance of power shift was enough.

[Justin Tseng]: And that if we are going to take this,

[Justin Tseng]: you know, majoritarian stance when it comes to looking at the survey results, we should be consistent in that approach and consistent in, you know, recognizing that most people, or at least the plurality of people, voted to take the mayor off the school committee.

[Justin Tseng]: I have to be honest, I can see the argument in both ways.

[Justin Tseng]: I think there's a decent argument that

[Justin Tseng]: The mayor as the CEO of our city should be obliged to attend all the school committee meetings and have a deeper understanding of what that school committee process is like and what challenges the schools face.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the mayor has made to me a compelling point that certain really important reforms that we've had as a city like

[Justin Tseng]: The override vote wouldn't have happened if she weren't on on the school committee and gotten that perspective and that budget seasons might look really different.

[Justin Tseng]: And that the schools might have been fighting for even more money.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think that's compelling.

[Justin Tseng]: I think some other parts that I don't find as compelling, and what the mayor has kind of indicated through press releases and to us is, you know, the idea that the mayor plays a really important role in negotiating.

[Justin Tseng]: As we know, our mayor has to step away from a lot of our negotiating, the school committee's negotiating because of conflict of interest.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's actually a decent argument for taking the mayor off of school committee, because there are so many conflicts of interest.

[Justin Tseng]: I've been talking, I've been reaching out to members of the school committee and people who have, you know, recently served in the school committee to get their perspective on the issue because I think it's worth having a deeper conversation about this policy wise.

[Justin Tseng]: I think member Reinfeld said

[Justin Tseng]: I, she made an interesting point to me which I, which I want to read out because she said I could read out her message.

[Justin Tseng]: And she said, I was a firm maybe in my interview and also one of the 15.3 not sure respondents in the survey, because I saw both pros and cons.

[Justin Tseng]: After 15 months in the role I still see arguments on both sides but lean no, no being mayor off of school committee, mostly because of the budget process.

[Justin Tseng]: I also think it is challenging to have a city executive in a legislative role.

[Justin Tseng]: The arguments in favor for me are mostly about the two-way flow of information rather than the practice of running slash governing a school district.

[Justin Tseng]: Ultimately, while I appreciate the perspective that a mayor can bring to the table, I think it makes sense that anyone serving on the school committee be elected for the primary purpose of serving on the school committee.

[Justin Tseng]: And then she said,

[Justin Tseng]: I think the mayor's chair is challenging because it takes on a new meeting and takes on a weird power dynamic.

[Justin Tseng]: Non-chair is also weird because of subcommittees, because that's also extra time commitments, and chosen based on particular school-related expertise, which is not the basis of the mayor's election to office.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's a fair substantive argument against.

[Justin Tseng]: I think you know what I what I wanted to say right now is that I can see strong arguments for and against.

[Justin Tseng]: I haven't settled completely on where I fall in that debate.

[Justin Tseng]: And I wanna hear a lively discussion and I wanna hear viewpoints and make a decision off of that.

[Justin Tseng]: But I ultimately do wanna see this charter succeed, but also to make sure that we're making or passing a charter that truly does work for all of our residents in the city and to really take on the responsibility of what that means.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's preferable that this makes the fall ballot

[Justin Tseng]: I think we should also acknowledge that even if this goes on the ballot next year, it would still go into effect at the exact same time.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think I'll close with the debate that I was having at the last meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's important not to let perfect bait be the enemy of good.

[Justin Tseng]: But I also worry about creating a situation where it's so hard to say yes to better.

[Justin Tseng]: So essentially a situation where things feel good enough, but they're not actually working optimally.

[Justin Tseng]: And that there's that kind of like inertia to get to that optimal place.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I worry also about deferring better for the future.

[Justin Tseng]: And someone made the point to me in the two emails that I got supporting the mayor on school committee, someone made the point that, you know, we could just,

[Justin Tseng]: revisit this next time.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think 10 years sometimes doesn't feel like a long time.

[Justin Tseng]: But doing the math, if this charter were to go into effect in 2027, 10 years after that would be 2037.

[Justin Tseng]: And the next time a new charter would take effect would be 2039.

[Justin Tseng]: And by that time, I plan to have kids in the school system.

[Justin Tseng]: I hope to own a home here in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: That's a wildly different time than now.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's also weighing on my mind.

[Justin Tseng]: But I just wanted to be transparent with the public about where my mind is at right now.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Lemme.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I just want the public to note that they're kind of their two narratives out there.

[Justin Tseng]: One is, I think one is more.

[Justin Tseng]: realistic that everyone wants to do good, we disagree about the details, and that we're having a real deep conversation about how these policies would change our city and how they would apply, right?

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's the camp I fall in.

[Justin Tseng]: I just want people to know that

[Justin Tseng]: There's that more sinister narrative out there about ulterior motives, about political considerations.

[Justin Tseng]: I just think it's worth noting who's pushing what.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's worth noting that that's exactly the type of rhetoric at the national scale that's gotten us to political violence, to the governor of Pennsylvania's house being burnt down, to January 6th.

[Justin Tseng]: to things like that, right?

[Justin Tseng]: And I just want us to calm everything a little bit.

[Justin Tseng]: Just let's be able to acknowledge that we can disagree agreeably.

[Justin Tseng]: And you know, I hear like gasps from the audience and stuff like that, but it's not crazy.

[Justin Tseng]: We've had, I know one member of this council has had multiple death threats in the last few months.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that, and from a member of the Charter Study Committee too,

[Justin Tseng]: And another member of the Charter Study Committee was posting misinformation about what our governance committees were doing, was doing, and the things that we talked about, the procedural things, me supposedly not inviting members of the committee to meetings, which I did, which I have email proof for.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think it's really important for us to recognize

[Justin Tseng]: that we shouldn't fall into the trap that we're seeing all around the country and that we dislike.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we can all agree, every single one of us in this room, that those things are bad.

[Justin Tseng]: And we shouldn't encourage that.

[Justin Tseng]: We shouldn't feed that.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we should all work to lower the tenor a little bit.

[Justin Tseng]: But I do think we need to call it out when it happens.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think for far too long on the city council, over the last two years, we haven't been doing that.

[Justin Tseng]: I respectfully disagree that the mayor and school committee or off the school committee is not a small question.

[Justin Tseng]: I do think it's quite literally the biggest question you could ask for one of our three branches of government here in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: Which is why it merits an actual conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: I know all of us approached it from different degrees from different angles.

[Justin Tseng]: I, you know, the one of the reasons why I didn't push for this earlier on was because number one I was chairing those meetings I couldn't make motions.

[Justin Tseng]: At those motions, I tried to present different viewpoints on different issues, make sure that all of that was articulated.

[Justin Tseng]: And we had comments from the school committee members that did that.

[Justin Tseng]: But I also didn't bring it up because I thought that we could get a better faith negotiation with the position that the city council took earlier on.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think maybe I was a little silly to assume that.

[Justin Tseng]: Maybe it was a little silly to assume that people would be listening, that the people I'd be negotiating with would listen to policy concerns I had about different things, about a whole litany of things.

[Justin Tseng]: And I didn't completely feel listened to about that.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think with that being said, I'm still not completely decided on this vote yet either.

[Justin Tseng]: I recognize the reality on the ground.

[Justin Tseng]: I recognize the policy principles that cut in both directions.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the mayor is misunderstanding the points that members of the public, that school committee members, that I brought up with regards to conflict of interest.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not necessarily purely financial, but I actually think in the mayor's remarks, she brought up the very conflict of interest that is at the core of the mayor being on school committee, which is that

[Justin Tseng]: the mayor, you know, their job is to make sure that the running of the city, you know, like cities running in a certain way.

[Justin Tseng]: And the job of the school committee is to advocate for the schools to the best extent that they can.

[Justin Tseng]: And those two jobs, those two things often do clash.

[Justin Tseng]: And so asking the school committee to hold back on important recommendations that would help our teachers, that would help our students,

[Justin Tseng]: that is inherently a conflict of interest, and that goes against what the school committee is for.

[Justin Tseng]: But, you know, I mean, I'll leave that there.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that, I still think that there are policy arguments that are caught in favor of having the mayor on the school committee, but I think I wanted to explain that point in more depth.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, to the point of the representativeness of the Charter Study Committee, I think there are a million ways to go about it, but I don't even think the average conservative in our city would

[Justin Tseng]: send death threats to members of this body.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think the average conservative in this city would be posting targeted misinformation on social media about things that we've been doing.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I can respect the push for political representativeness.

[Justin Tseng]: But if that's the metric, we're still failing.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's really important.

[Justin Tseng]: to note that there's been a real lack of BIPOC representation on the Charter Study Committee as well.

[Justin Tseng]: The Asian community is the biggest minority community in our city, and there weren't any Asian people on the committee.

[Justin Tseng]: A historically Black community wasn't represented on the committee.

[Justin Tseng]: And you know what?

[Justin Tseng]: I think that it's really important for us going forward to make sure that that representation is there.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's a major qualm I have about the process.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't know if it's enough to have me

[Justin Tseng]: you know, vote to kill any effort.

[Justin Tseng]: That's certainly not my intention.

[Justin Tseng]: And I actually, that's another thing I want to clear up, is I actually do think, I haven't like asked, but I do actually think, judging from our comments on the floor, every single one of us wants to vote on something tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: And we all want to vote out a version of the charter tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: Whether we all vote yes or no is another question, because we might disagree on what's best in that charter, and what the

[Justin Tseng]: the balance of considerations looks like, but I do think that we all are approaching this with good intent, that we're all trying to create a product that would work for our city.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll just end with being grateful to Councilor Scarpelli for introducing the five-year review or asking for that amendment.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that would make a lot of sense here.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it would alleviate a lot of my worries.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Lazzaro for putting this together.

[Justin Tseng]: I think all in all, this looks good.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't know if it really is representative of our discussions completely as a council.

[Justin Tseng]: So maybe at the end of the

[Justin Tseng]: Mr. President.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm not saying that we, you know, say as a council that we like disagreed with different things about the thing.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we just say like, I think we can just say like,

[Justin Tseng]: a number of city councilors shared opinions about something.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we still wanna emphasize that if this passes, that it is the product of compromise.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I think that sounds perfect.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: I do want this to be a strong statement.

[Justin Tseng]: I also think it should reflect the conversations that we actually had.

[Justin Tseng]: I think reading it, the text should still stay in, but we can clarify it.

[Justin Tseng]: That's my reading of it.

[Justin Tseng]: We can also just cover our bases by passing a motion that we support that reading of it.

[Justin Tseng]: OK.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think the historic nature of this vote should be lost upon anyone.

[Justin Tseng]: We just, you know, talked a lot about history.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think

[Justin Tseng]: in the grand scheme of things, this inches us towards the right place for Medford to be.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that in scrutinizing anything,

[Justin Tseng]: this was the outcome I wanted.

[Justin Tseng]: Even if the vote is the vote, the product is the product.

[Justin Tseng]: It's a privilege to be a city councillor.

[Justin Tseng]: It's even more a privilege to be a city councillor during such a big change for a city.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, I hope, I know that, you know, most people have something they're not happy about in this charter, but that is part of compromise.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, I think that

[Justin Tseng]: I have a qualm with completely accepting that this is, by definition, a compromise.

[Justin Tseng]: I think there are worlds in which we could have reached better deals, but I think this is one that, as the gentleman in the audience said, we can make work.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the nature of the rich, deep conversations that we've had about

[Justin Tseng]: the policies about academic studies, about feedback from community members, from elected officials in other cities, looking at how the system works in practice.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it speaks to the fact that we have been listening.

[Justin Tseng]: The fact that we disagreed on key votes.

[Justin Tseng]: repeatedly throughout the process, I think also underscores the fact that we've been listening, we've been differing, and we've been coming back together.

[Justin Tseng]: I do want to thank the Charter Study Committee for their work.

[Justin Tseng]: I want them to know that my criticism of the process is more about the, is about the process writ large.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that folks really did dedicate a lot of time to put

[Justin Tseng]: to put together a product for us to consider.

[Justin Tseng]: And I believe strongly that the city council has a role to play, not just ethically, but also statutorily.

[Justin Tseng]: So when it comes to the law, we have a legal part of this.

[Justin Tseng]: We are a legal part of this process.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's where all that scrutiny comes in.

[Justin Tseng]: That's us doing our job.

[Justin Tseng]: It's us doing the job that we were paid to do.

[Justin Tseng]: It's us not just rubber stamping anything, but really considering every single piece of the charter, which we did line by line, section by section.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's important to note that the bulk of this charter was agreed on by all parties at play, agreed on by the Charter Study Committee, by the mayor and the city council.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's noteworthy.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I'll just finish my thoughts with a note for the future.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm hopeful for a future in which we feel less boxed in to options when we revisit this charter.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm hopeful for a future where the state house gives us more ability for us to respond to our residents, to hear their innovative ideas about how government can work in Medford to tailor

[Justin Tseng]: the design of our political process to what Medford actually needs and wants.

[Justin Tseng]: And I hope that that desire doesn't stop with our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: I hope that this version of the charter isn't the endpoint of political reform in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: I hope that we keep pushing all of our electeds at every single level to do better when it comes to when it comes to things like

[Justin Tseng]: autonomy when it comes to things like empowering cities to do what's right for their residents, for empowering cities to actually respond to resident feedback, to consider the more innovative things that cities should be able to do that in other states cities do all the time.

[Justin Tseng]: I think a lot of what I wanted to be considered in this process maybe could have come about with a home rule process.

[Justin Tseng]: what it could have come about with an elected charter commission.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think we are at the point where that's beyond the scope of our conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: I hope my Councilors will join me in pushing for those reforms in the future and pushing for more flexibility for Medford to do what's right by a residence.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, okay.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm happy to take that out of order but I do know a lot of people here for 25-053 the gender affirming care reproductive health care ordinance 25-055 the resolution to support the release of remains.

[Justin Tseng]: And 25-057, the resolution to create and distribute Know Your Rights information.

[Justin Tseng]: As those items came first in the agenda and are shorter, what I presume are shorter items to discuss, would you entertain taking those first before the City Charter conversation?

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Scarpello.

[Justin Tseng]: I think you can make the same arguments the other way, given that this ordinance has also been- So don't vote for it.

[Justin Tseng]: I would motion to take 25-053, 25-055, 25-057, and then 24-468.

[Justin Tseng]: On the motion of Councilor Tseng to take papers 25053, 25055, 25057, and 24468.

[Justin Tseng]: Is there a second?

[Justin Tseng]: On the second by Vice President Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes, I'm the affirmative, negative, the motion passes, Councilor say, Thank you, Mr. President, um, as we, as, as we know from watching the news and from paying attention to, you know, our neighbors concerns over the last few years.

[Justin Tseng]: The access to gender affirming care and reproductive health care has become an incredibly contentious issue in our country, despite these being basic forms of medical care and basic rights that individuals have, or should have in this country, and has have historically had in this country until recently.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of our residents are fairly asking us how we can best protect our own neighbors best protect our own residents and provide the security that they need and need for.

[Justin Tseng]: for enjoying their lives here in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: This ordinance would protect medical providers and people who seek that care from out-of-state arrest warrants and prosecutions, from out-of-state attempts to apply laws that aren't Massachusetts laws, laws that aren't Massachusetts values to Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: We've heard early on in the process years ago that if we didn't pass something like this, it was very likely, if not mandatory, that we would have to carry out those warrants.

[Justin Tseng]: Now the situation at the state level has changed, but it is important for us to reaffirm this and to acknowledge that just because state law says something doesn't mean that we can't back that up as well, and that we need that additional layer of protection for our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: During the process, Councilor Lazzaro and I worked hard to invite stakeholders, including medical providers in the community, including residents with experience, including city staff across the health police departments and the administration to work on this.

[Justin Tseng]: We know that Medford faces limited resources.

[Justin Tseng]: We've talked about that over and over again.

[Justin Tseng]: We want to make sure that those resources aren't expended to the end of denying any individual's right to their bodily autonomy or to criminalize any person's effort to live as their full and authentic self.

[Justin Tseng]: This ordinance, if you walk through it, essentially protects the information, the health information of people who come to Medford to use our care.

[Justin Tseng]: It protects health information from medical providers as well.

[Justin Tseng]: It affirms our city's policy and enshrines into law that we won't treat any individual differently based on their gender identity or gender expression.

[Justin Tseng]: It follows state laws language with regards to definitions with regards to how we're going to do what I just described.

[Justin Tseng]: It also empowers our city to to provide fair access to reproductive health and gender affirming healthcare information.

[Justin Tseng]: Because we know that there are predatory sources out there that are putting limited or fake information out into the community.

[Justin Tseng]: This empowers our administration to post proper guidelines, to post

[Justin Tseng]: a full comprehensive picture as to that information on the website.

[Justin Tseng]: I know there are residents who want to speak.

[Justin Tseng]: I know there are councilors who've worked hard on this.

[Justin Tseng]: I do also want to thank councilors Collins, Bears, and former councilor Morell for introducing parts of this ordinance as well, or a resolution language to support this ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Leming.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll be brief because I think councilors have been very thorough with their comments.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Bears and Councilor Lazzaro for introducing this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: I know a lot of residents have been clamoring for us to say something about it.

[Justin Tseng]: and the timing of the regular meetings didn't allow us to make a statement earlier, but this is, it's helpful that we're doing it at the earliest possible opportunity for us.

[Justin Tseng]: All I'll say is that this is a fearful time, and the freedom that we have to free speech and to our due process rights, which means not being deprived of our life, liberty, or property without a due process.

[Justin Tseng]: These rights are sacred to who we are as Americans.

[Justin Tseng]: They're sacred to democracy, and they form the bedrock of a strong society.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think this really exemplifies what I've been saying for a very long time, which is that oftentimes the national can be local.

[Justin Tseng]: And as the federal government seeks to interfere in people's everyday lives, seeks to interfere and retaliate against individuals for publishing their thoughts in an op-ed, be it something you agree with or disagree with,

[Justin Tseng]: As the federal government tries to commandeer state and local governments into following its policies when federalism exists, and when we have powers delegated to us, to the voters, to hold local and state officials accountable for, this all matters to the rule of law.

[Justin Tseng]: It all matters to who we are as Americans and our identity as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I think passing a resolution like this tonight, you know, I wish we could do more, but this solidifies our intent as a city council to stand by our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Sagan.

[Justin Tseng]: I'd be happy to add that amendment.

[Justin Tseng]: Should we do it as a B paper since the main paper is about Ramesa?

[Justin Tseng]: Is there a preference on this council?

[Justin Tseng]: Do you have a preference, Councilor Lazzaro?

[Justin Tseng]: And I also want to, to that point, draw attention to the work that we're doing in our resident services, resident services committee on a human rights commission ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: So essentially we are reforming that ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: So the HRC has a lot more power to advise city governments about

[Justin Tseng]: how to protect our residents, how to inform residents of their rights on DEI measures as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So defending diversity, equity, and inclusion, and having more voices there.

[Justin Tseng]: And I hope that residents will support that measure as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's always good for a government to inform their residents of their rights.

[Justin Tseng]: We have these rights for a reason.

[Justin Tseng]: We have these rights to protect our freedoms and to protect our way of life.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, I've heard a lot recently, I acknowledged this earlier, but I've heard a lot recently from residents about what we can do as politicians, as elected officials to protect our residents, to help our residents,

[Justin Tseng]: And we talked about how some measures might be symbolic.

[Justin Tseng]: It's important to do those, because if you can't do the symbolic, you can't do the substantive.

[Justin Tseng]: But likewise, we have to be creative, and we have to be smart in trying to figure out the little ways that we can help affect this issue.

[Justin Tseng]: Because sometimes, even the little ways can have great effects.

[Justin Tseng]: And for our residents to know their rights is one of those really great effects.

[Justin Tseng]: This is, you know, I spoke about how this is a fearful moment earlier as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, I want to underscore that from my perspective.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm the son of immigrants, my parents are green card holders, and even my presence on this council today makes me fearful for their own safety.

[Justin Tseng]: you know, not to say anything about the cases of U.S.

[Justin Tseng]: citizens that have been, you know, put at danger because of this administration's actions, but, you know, the lived reality of being afraid going out, being afraid for my parents, you know, to see their, to go travel abroad to see their family, their really old family, you know, for them to,

[Justin Tseng]: For people like my parents and so many residents in Medford to be afraid to go out to the grocery store, to go out to run their errands, for so many Medford students to be afraid to go to school, I think it's a real problem that we face in the city that we have to learn how to address, be it through the government doing something or be it through mutual aid.

[Justin Tseng]: I think knowing your rights is the first basic and maybe one of the most important steps you can know.

[Justin Tseng]: I feel privileged in that I've studied this stuff.

[Justin Tseng]: I've gotten this knowledge before, but I also know that when I was walking through these rights with my parents, even just last week or two weeks ago, I guess, they didn't know half of this stuff.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's really important for us to get this information out there ASAP, for us to translate this information into other languages as well, and for us to be creative in how we get this message across.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I've honestly had a difficult time thinking about how to vote tonight what to do tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: Because, at the end of the day I think it's, it is important for our city to get a new charter.

[Justin Tseng]: Also, at the end of the day, I think that this charter presents something that is better than the status quo.

[Justin Tseng]: And I've been reminded by residents over the last few weeks to not let perfect be the enemy of good.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think the added difficulty to this part is that I also do worry about this precluding something better.

[Justin Tseng]: in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: I think oftentimes we see good enough as just being good and we reject better.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think, you know, that weighs on my head.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think, you know, what my mind has gone to more in the last week has been

[Justin Tseng]: edits that the mayor's made that didn't make it to the press release that very much don't count as a compromise.

[Justin Tseng]: And that, you know, against the platform I was elected on and against the feed, a lot of feedback from the community shift power to the mayor's office and away from the city council, even compared to the status quo.

[Justin Tseng]: And that would go against

[Justin Tseng]: that would go against the platform I ran on.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm grateful that Councilor Lazzaro has introduced her amendments and communicated with the mayor about that and gotten to a point of understanding.

[Justin Tseng]: And I would support those motions, and which is why I also seconded her motion too.

[Justin Tseng]: In particular, I think it's important

[Justin Tseng]: to restore the words by ordinance 23-3A, because not having the section would remove the power of the council to have appointments to committees by ordinance, which is a power that we currently have.

[Justin Tseng]: We see it, I believe, on the Water and Sewer Commission.

[Justin Tseng]: The Human Rights Commission ordinance that we were talking about includes that as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't see that as a huge, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: I don't see that as a major problem for the mayor to accept.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's something that if we don't make that amendment, it would shift power away from, it would concentrate power in the office of the executive.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Councilor Collins has called a motion to amend the Charter, the Article 9-4B to have the Charter Review Commission be composed of three appointees of the Mayor, the City Council, the School Committee is just an inherently fair

[Justin Tseng]: amendments so it support that.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that really, really underscores that the way that this process was done this time inherently creates adversarial relationships between people who just want the best for their city and might not see the same.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, in my opinion, the City Council, we fought for what we thought was the best policy for our city.

[Justin Tseng]: I really appreciate a lot of the, you know, a lot of the support I've gotten over the last few weeks for speaking out, even from residents who don't necessarily agree with me.

[Justin Tseng]: And you know what, I accept the 8-3 plan.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think it's perfect.

[Justin Tseng]: But I accept it because I see that that is the way to move this forward.

[Justin Tseng]: But at the same time, what I think Councilor Collins's, Vice President Collins's amendment does help us with is making sure that next time that process is more collaborative, that people feel like they're on an even footing, that we get a lot of this rich conversation that we've had over the last few months in the next Charter Review Committee's iteration.

[Justin Tseng]: I also think that process-wise, this has been slightly frustrating just from a procedural standpoint, not because of things that members of the committee have done, but from a procedural standpoint, just because I've been, quote, asked, I've been asked to, quote, rubber stamp the thing, to rush it through committee.

[Justin Tseng]: I've been asked to not have counsel scrutinize it, but that legally is our job.

[Justin Tseng]: As enforcers of the charter in the future, we need to have a say in that perspective as well, even if we don't win out.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that goes to the inherent nature of the process.

[Justin Tseng]: I think another frustration I've had is that over the last week, I floated many different compromise models to the mayor.

[Justin Tseng]: Compromises that include not going to 4-5.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think compromises that gave up a lot of what I was arguing for.

[Justin Tseng]: And a lot of these compromises were very basic, doing things in a more democratic way, even just commissioning a poll.

[Justin Tseng]: All of that was rejected.

[Justin Tseng]: And there was a fear of how things would go down that way.

[Justin Tseng]: With regards to the motion to take the mayor off of the school committee, I'm still making my mind up on it.

[Justin Tseng]: I am compelled by the point that if we're doing things because are the people who answered the survey expressed their intentions one way, we should be consistent in how we apply that principle.

[Justin Tseng]: Frankly, I've also just gotten a lot of emails, a lot of messages from people in the last few days, asking us to revisit that.

[Justin Tseng]: And I do think it speaks to the Mayor's, or to the initial point that we were making, or the Councilors were making, that ultimately, while representation is important, that representation is

[Justin Tseng]: practically useless when the balance of power is not right.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think there's a real conversation to be had there.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I still feel of, I can see the merits of both arguments, to be quite honest with you all.

[Justin Tseng]: And I also hear the argument that urgency is important.

[Justin Tseng]: And I have to weigh that debate as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So urgency of getting this through versus making sure that even if the product that we get out of this council is something that I wouldn't have written myself, that it's sound enough to function.

[Justin Tseng]: And just to make sure that we have all the parts in place for this to work well.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's, yeah, I just want to be transparent about how I'm thinking.

[Justin Tseng]: It is my intention.

[Justin Tseng]: in my you know, my my intention to do in my powers what we can do to move this charter along but I also want to make sure that because this charter forms the foundation of our city's laws and we'll do so for at least 10 years that we do it right as well and even if you know, the bigger ambitious ideas that I had don't make it in.

[Justin Tseng]: I want to make sure that the

[Justin Tseng]: To that point, I would want, there are two smaller technical amendments that I think are important to make.

[Justin Tseng]: The first one being in article 8-2 to revert from city clerk back to the board of election commissioners because the city clerk's office doesn't have access to the voter rolls to certify the petitions.

[Justin Tseng]: So if we say city clerk, it just won't.

[Justin Tseng]: the article won't work.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's just a technical thing that we did switch back.

[Justin Tseng]: The other idea I'd want to float with the council is in part E, to revert back to a standard of 12%, not revert back, to revert to a standard of 12%.

[Justin Tseng]: This is 8-2-E.

[Justin Tseng]: 8-2-E, yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Just to align this with the citizen repeal referendum procedures, I think it can be really confusing to have different numbers and different bars for very similar things.

[Justin Tseng]: I know in committee we offered 15%, the mayor came back with 10%, 12% is a number that the Charter Study Committee came up with in the first place and seems like a fair compromise to me.

[Justin Tseng]: Yep.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, sorry Councilor Tseng, go ahead.

[Justin Tseng]: These are the arguments against what's your stance, right?

[Justin Tseng]: And, and I think with the budget, there's so many different, you know, pieces that we're looking at so many different facets that, um, that can be a little tough.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's why I prefer keeping things in short, short form format.

[Justin Tseng]: So it's like open-ended, um, but people also don't feel obligated to have to write an essay about stuff.

[Justin Tseng]: Similarly, residents who are really engaged in like

[Justin Tseng]: you know, the city, a lot of them might live in apartment blocks, which could be helpful as well, like asking them to help us.

[Justin Tseng]: So more informal ways of just getting the survey out.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I think what we've seen over the last few years is the real best way to do that is what a lot of us do, and just knock on the doors and ask.

[Justin Tseng]: But we don't know which doors.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, but we don't know which doors, yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: We don't have enough data about it.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I was just going to say, imagine we had a rental registry.

[Justin Tseng]: Well, not with polling, just with, uh,

[Justin Tseng]: with the way that we do surveys.

[Justin Tseng]: If the administration, like, I mean, I've passed a bunch of resolutions about this.

[Justin Tseng]: So if the administration would like to get polling data, that's not necessarily very hard.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's about right.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: That sounds about right.

[Justin Tseng]: It is what it is.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: $7,000 in the grand scheme of what a city budget.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is me like going on a tangent about what I would do differently if I were in a... This meeting will go on till midnight, I'm telling you.

[Justin Tseng]: No, I don't want to take this meeting in a certain direction, but

[Justin Tseng]: I do think $7,000 in the scheme of a $200-plus million budget is worth it to get residents input about what they want to see in that budget.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this one is a big project, but yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: Second.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you for your introduction of what this ordinance is.

[Justin Tseng]: This is, I believe, maybe the third time that our current form of this committee has worked on it so far.

[Justin Tseng]: I know we've met in prior sessions before we had this city council elected.

[Justin Tseng]: So this is something I'm really excited to get across the finish line, particularly at a time when we see such insecurity.

[Justin Tseng]: from the federal government with regards to the rights of people to practice what is legally possible in their own jurisdiction.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, needless to say that a lot of what people are doing is constitutionally protected, at least in Massachusetts, it's protected by the state constitution and state law.

[Justin Tseng]: And yet we still see instances where

[Justin Tseng]: there is law enforcement coming in and taking people away, locking people up for those activities.

[Justin Tseng]: When the Dobbs decision rolled around years ago, I think the big question for policymakers at the state and local level was how can we protect our residents, particularly from out-of-state efforts to impose their law on us, and to seek the arrest or the punishment of people who come to Massachusetts

[Justin Tseng]: for care and to Massachusetts doctors and medical professionals who provide that care as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And since that conversation, this effort, which is an effort that a lot of cities have pursued, has grown into an effort to also protect people seeking gender-affirming care and providing gender-affirming care as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's a matter of semantics, but this particular version of the ordinance in both forms derives from what a lot of municipalities and what the state government is doing to protect our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: And the language is pretty much one-to-one besides the references to Medford and making it a little bit Medford specific.

[Justin Tseng]: And that aspect, I think, is really important, because it's important for us to note that a lot of cities are pursuing trans-sanctuary city legislation, reproductive sanctuary city legislation.

[Justin Tseng]: That is this.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is actually stronger than a lot of those efforts.

[Justin Tseng]: Because some of those efforts are ordinances, but rather just resolutions, which means that it's non-binding, has no legal force, that the city wanted to revoke it at any time.

[Justin Tseng]: The city could do it even without a vote of the city council.

[Justin Tseng]: And this codifies those protections for a resident so they can know that they are safe from that behavior in Massachusetts.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, with regards to our meeting with legal representation, the second draft that Councilors have, the one with the red line edits, is a draft that aligns the text that we have been reviewing in this committee before to the text of the state law and to a lot of municipalities that are now passing these ordinances and aligning themselves with state law.

[Justin Tseng]: And now the big benefit of that

[Justin Tseng]: is that substantively, there's not much of a change in terms of what we're protecting.

[Justin Tseng]: But in the case of litigation, if that, God forbid, ever happens, this gives us more legal protection because we can work with other cities and the state government to protect ourselves in court.

[Justin Tseng]: And that means less pressure on our city's legal resources as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that there's a huge benefit to that because it's different.

[Justin Tseng]: It's harder for a single municipality to defend a single text versus when you have a bunch of municipalities, a bunch of lawyers working on this, plus the state government and AG's office working on this to defend the text.

[Justin Tseng]: I also want to underscore that this is a very much a legal effort and that this is in the wheelhouse of state and local governments.

[Justin Tseng]: There's been some questions raised about that.

[Justin Tseng]: The 10th Amendment is really clear that there are powers that are given to the state and to the local government, that the state has what we call police power.

[Justin Tseng]: So the power to make laws for the general welfare, particularly law enforcement and what law enforcement can and can't do is very much in that world.

[Justin Tseng]: of police power, which means that the state and local governments are the ones to make that decision.

[Justin Tseng]: And the federal government can't coerce state and local governments to change their policies to match the federal government.

[Justin Tseng]: That's been tried many, many times in the federal courts.

[Justin Tseng]: It's been tried with the Supreme Courts before.

[Justin Tseng]: And that principle holds very, very strongly.

[Justin Tseng]: And while litigation over

[Justin Tseng]: This particular ordinance and this, you know, the gender affirming care and the reproductive health care ordinances is still relatively young.

[Justin Tseng]: This has made it up to circuit courts, it's made it up, you know, the court chain, and it's been upheld in most, if not all cases.

[Justin Tseng]: except in jurisdictions with judges that are politically appointed, that are staffed against the effort, which is not a situation we face in Massachusetts, because the First Circuit, because of Massachusetts courts, are much more politically neutral and not like that.

[Justin Tseng]: So I wanted to give a bit of the legal argument for my fellow Councilors and for residents who asked me those questions over the last few weeks as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I look forward to discussing this text with everyone.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this is one of the examples where, so there are some edits in here where I don't think it's necessarily so important or so material to go one way or the other.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think I could see an argument for even combining the two.

[Justin Tseng]: you know, keeping the reference to the state law, and then also just keeping what we want to be the purpose and the policy of the of the ordinance, and then, you know, having another conversation with legal counsel, if they flag it.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes, I think my recommendation is that because we have someone online will have to take a roll call vote.

[Justin Tseng]: I would prefer that maybe we move section by section and then I can keep track of, no one's online?

[Justin Tseng]: Wonderful.

[Justin Tseng]: In that case, we can, I think, go section by section.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: So the conversation is about whether we include contractors.

[Justin Tseng]: Essentially it boils down to whether we include recipients of city funding grants, awards, or appropriations in the definition for city agent.

[Justin Tseng]: Now something I did notice in

[Justin Tseng]: comparing the two copies is that in the KP law suggested copy, the one that aligns our language with the state, there's actually no reference to agents, in which case that definition actually, we should probably take that definition out.

[Justin Tseng]: And actually, if there is a real big substantive change, I think that is one of them, is the

[Justin Tseng]: KP law's suggested version of the ordinance essentially takes out the enforceability or the kind of like the oversight that we would have over contractors and people who receive city funds or appropriations grants.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's something for us to think about.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, that's a policy thing.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think the pros are, I think it'd be nice to get something stronger.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the con is, does that take us out of alignment with the state?

[Justin Tseng]: Will we have to defend that separately in court?

[Justin Tseng]: Otherwise, the edits to the definition sections aren't really that big.

[Justin Tseng]: Essentially, any change to the definitions in the section are based on state law.

[Justin Tseng]: So it's just copying and pasting in how the state has defined certain terms.

[Justin Tseng]: and then making sure that we're defining the terms the same as how the state is defining the terms.

[Justin Tseng]: But the big one is city agent, I guess, which that's the whole other substantive debate that I just laid out.

[Justin Tseng]: City agent.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I guess.

[Justin Tseng]: So KP law actually didn't suggest, didn't make a solid recommendation about whether we change the definition of city agent.

[Justin Tseng]: Like they didn't, they didn't modify the language.

[Justin Tseng]: They just suggested that we look at it.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, but I can also see the argument being that we, we take it out if we choose to have this ordinance apply to city employees or officials.

[Justin Tseng]: if that makes sense.

[Justin Tseng]: If we want to expand the scope, if that's what we choose, then we might want to.

[Justin Tseng]: We will need this definition.

[Justin Tseng]: I guess I think that is a decent like, yeah, it's a vulnerability in the state's definition of gender identity, which doesn't really line up 100%, I think it's like 80%, maybe 70% there with what people conceive of as gender identity, but that last 20% isn't there.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's something worth considering, worth talking about.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I mean, I think,

[Justin Tseng]: Essentially, I think a lot of the edits that this committee could make today, I would say we would be fine making those edits, moving out of committee, and then getting legal counsel to have a second look at it, or just choosing to adopt what legal counsel did and to cut out that stuff.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think a lot of the edits today will fall in one or two, one or either one of the buckets.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: I did also want to make a point about city agents, since we were still talking about that, and there's that whole attached conversation of how expansive do we want this to be.

[Justin Tseng]: I think something to consider, not to say that this is the make or break, but I think something for us to consider is, do we realistically foresee that extra reach being very helpful?

[Justin Tseng]: I can see that breaking either way.

[Justin Tseng]: So let's take the recipients of city funding grants, awards, or appropriations.

[Justin Tseng]: I guess we should ask ourselves, what are those groups that are getting that money?

[Justin Tseng]: And is there even any way that they could break this ordinance, break this law?

[Justin Tseng]: Because they might, I mean,

[Justin Tseng]: They're not carrying out the warrants.

[Justin Tseng]: They're not carrying out the arrests.

[Justin Tseng]: They're not reporting the data.

[Justin Tseng]: And they don't have the image to report.

[Justin Tseng]: And so perhaps, even though we're technically narrowing the scope, practically, we're not making a change.

[Justin Tseng]: But you can see an argument where maybe there just happens to be a law enforcement-related grantee or recipient.

[Justin Tseng]: And we want this to extend to them as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Although I can't think of any of my mind, any groups in my mind with that power.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, although they would fall under what we originally have, they would fall under the definition of the same agent.

[Justin Tseng]: I would say, I think, contractors, where I kind of, like, think we should see if we can include contractors.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that is the like that's the one that's in the definition for an agent that's not in the rest of the ordinance, right?

[Justin Tseng]: Or as keep you all suggested that I think potentially I can see that overlap being there.

[Justin Tseng]: We might have data.

[Justin Tseng]: If I could.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes, please.

[Justin Tseng]: I agree with Councilor Callaghan here, that we should think about taking it out.

[Justin Tseng]: I think here's the situation, is I'm confident that the Constitution grants us the right to make this law and to have this law rule over other supposed federal laws that trample on states' rights.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think this creates almost like a inconsistency within the language of the statute.

[Justin Tseng]: to essentially, like, someone could point at that and say, well, they're not even trampling on states or, you know, your local rights to write your own ordinance because you've incorporated all federal law in this clause.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I, that's another question for council, but I would say we shouldn't adopt that.

[Justin Tseng]: because I think our loyalty to the Constitution is implied.

[Justin Tseng]: We all took oaths to that, right?

[Justin Tseng]: And that should rule above anything else.

[Justin Tseng]: Accidentally incorporating federal law, I worry that, I would just worry that that would nullify this ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: Is this what used to be number four?

[Justin Tseng]: I'm just trying to follow.

[Justin Tseng]: I propose this.

[Justin Tseng]: Further, it is contrary to the city of Medford's public policy to participate in the enforcement of another state's civil or criminal law when that law seeks to deny an individual's right to bodily autonomy and criminalize a person's effort to live as their full authentic self.

[Justin Tseng]: And thus, the city's resources should not be expended toward that end.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, yes.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's my last motion to add that to after the first paragraph.

[Justin Tseng]: But I understand.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, the desire to table and, um, I think just just to save us money, I'll vote no on tabling and yes on the question if it gets that.

[Justin Tseng]: This resolution is really quite a simple one, it goes back to our fund of one of our fundamental guiding principles that we want City Hall to be more accessible to all that we want to bring City Hall to the people and not force people to come to have to come to City Hall.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the budget process is a perfect encapsulation of that process.

[Justin Tseng]: where the budget is a statement of the city's values.

[Justin Tseng]: It is what runs our city, what makes us tick.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's really important, I believe, to me, and I believe to the city council, too, that we get as much input as we can and that people feel heard in this process.

[Justin Tseng]: Over the last few years, we've experimented doing different things with public engagement.

[Justin Tseng]: Years ago, I put out a survey, too, which I have thoughts about how to

[Justin Tseng]: how to make better this time around, asking for input from residents about what they would want to see in our city budget and then explaining some of the challenges that we see on the city council with getting what everyone wants.

[Justin Tseng]: in recent years on the Resident Services and Public Engagement Committee.

[Justin Tseng]: We have been doing more with actively going out into the community to hear from residents.

[Justin Tseng]: We've been doing more with publishing a newsletter that goes out every month detailing what we do on the City Council.

[Justin Tseng]: So there are more means by which we can gather feedback now.

[Justin Tseng]: I know there are Councilors who are very passionate about getting

[Justin Tseng]: public feedback and engaging more members of the public in our processes as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'm looking forward to a very fruitful discussion on the Resident Services Committee, and I'll motion to send this paper to that committee.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, this is something I always look forward to in the city council year when we get have that meeting committee the whole meeting get together and then sent over this letter to the mayor.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe that we are stronger when we negotiate together, when we work together to fight for the values that we want to see in the budget, to fight for the items that we want to see in the budget together.

[Justin Tseng]: I thank President Bears for his work on putting together this letter.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's very comprehensive.

[Justin Tseng]: It's very clear.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's very well done, so thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think folks who've been following this issue know I've been of two minds about it.

[Justin Tseng]: My instinct is with my fellow Councilors that we shouldn't sell public land.

[Justin Tseng]: affordability in the long term by telling us exactly how we can achieve the bigger picture goals that we've set out.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's why I'm inclined to support it, but I did want to take this off the table because I wanted to hear the discussion after we got that letter from the Affordable Housing Trust as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.
