[Justin Tseng]: There's the benefit to having two or three affordable units in that neighborhood, but does that is that outweighed by having an exit study that helps really advance affordable housing trusts work to get many more affordable units in Medford over a longer period of time.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, in my mind, it weighs in favor of that.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm not completely sure how many votes, this needs.

[Justin Tseng]: It's possible that we, it might be wiser to wait until Vice President Collins is online with us.

[Justin Tseng]: I know she was saying that she had some technical difficulties with their computers I don't.

[Justin Tseng]: if, you know, if it's important to have that last voice on the Council, I think it might be wise to retable this, but I did want to have this discussion tonight to hear from Councilors while this paper was still, while the response that we got was on our minds.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Hi, everyone.

[Justin Tseng]: It's really nice to hear all of my fellow Councilors bring in such important details and such important ideas from different walks of our city, from different facets of what our city government does.

[Justin Tseng]: And I would like to start from the basics.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'd love to co-assign my fellow Councilors

[Justin Tseng]: Recommendations, particularly with regards to public safety and our infrastructure, making sure that pedestrians, cyclists and drivers all have safe roads to operate on.

[Justin Tseng]: with regards to the investment in our accessibility and our inclusion when it comes to the activities that our children and teenagers have in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: And that means the therapeutic recreation specialist and full-time office manager for Medford Rec, which would also help a lot with the youth commission idea, which I'll talk about later.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I would also co-sign, um, Councilor Collins and Scarpelli's, um, idea.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, their recommendation to increase the budgeted amount for the city solicitor's salary to, um, make sure that we are competitive with neighbouring municipalities.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, general infrastructure spending when it comes, uh, I'd like to co-sign, um, ideas for general infrastructure spending as well.

[Justin Tseng]: to make sure that we're doing the basics of city government, making sure that we are filling our potholes, fixing our streets.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think with that being said, I would like to take this moment to also thank Bedford voters for passing

[Justin Tseng]: the prop two and a half question last year, which will allow us to get a step forward on that.

[Justin Tseng]: This budget process year after year really shows us as a city council and shows the city as a whole how budget constrained municipalities, including Medford are.

[Justin Tseng]: And that vote in the fall really helps us this year to maintain financial stability, even with ongoing challenges

[Justin Tseng]: that we face, including this random cuts to federal funding, and what most economists and what most business leaders predict will be rising cost of living.

[Justin Tseng]: We, I would also like to do support the council, what Councilor Collins said in her memo about meeting the school committee's budgetary requests for the Medford public schools and meeting the library department's budgetary requests as well.

[Justin Tseng]: We have these two amazing resources that so many Medford families rely on.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's really paramount that we keep that at the front of our bucket, our items, our priorities going into this budget.

[Justin Tseng]: And remember how crucial it is to our government's responsibility that we make sure that those services are well and up and running.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, with regards to some of the ideas that

[Justin Tseng]: that I brought up in my memo that haven't really been covered yet.

[Justin Tseng]: A number of our projects as a city council have been going through the Resident Services and Public Engagement Committee.

[Justin Tseng]: And the two biggest ideas that are reaching a decent amount of progress

[Justin Tseng]: For us to consider putting it in the budget would be the Human Rights Commission and the Youth Commission.

[Justin Tseng]: And in order to make sure that they operate well, to make sure that the representation on these two bodies are balanced, that we attract enough candidates of diverse experiences to serve on these commissions, and to make sure that they can carry out the day-to-day functions that we would expect

[Justin Tseng]: a human rights commission, a youth commission to do, such as community events, reports, studies, a youth summit.

[Justin Tseng]: I've suggested asking for $15,000 for the HRC and $20,000 for the youth commission.

[Justin Tseng]: And these numbers come from discussions with city staff, with community leaders, and

[Justin Tseng]: over the last two years about what our needs are and what logistically we need to get these two projects over the finish line.

[Justin Tseng]: With that being said, some other stuff that I put in was making sure that we had a plan to update our city's financial software.

[Justin Tseng]: I know Councilor Collins mentioned that in her memo as well.

[Justin Tseng]: in more detail than I did.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's a thank you Councilor Hollins for that.

[Justin Tseng]: To make sure that we have the financial and assessing staff that we need, if we're looking at the tax reforms like the residential exemption, which I know Councilors want to discuss more.

[Justin Tseng]: I think if we want to give ourselves that option, we need the staffing for it.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that

[Justin Tseng]: One of the complaints I hear from city staff, too, is about how the systems, in terms of tech systems that we have at City Hall, and don't ensure that departments do what they promise to do on time.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think a great example of that is oftentimes HR needs more modern resources and technologies to be able to do their job well.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why I put that in my memo as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And one issue I hear a lot from residents is the need for a real plan to address our child care crisis.

[Justin Tseng]: It's such a financial strain on Medford families who have to organize child care and to not be able to find it and to have to go to different communities and fight with different

[Justin Tseng]: and families from different communities on that issue.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know that we've been making some progress on it, but we really do need to be making more progress on that.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I view budget season as a time to also ask for more concrete plans for things.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think this is a good chance for us, even if it doesn't make this budget, to ask for more concrete plans for the city administration on this issue.

[Justin Tseng]: My last kind of bucket of recommendations centered more about maintaining funding.

[Justin Tseng]: So making sure that things aren't cut.

[Justin Tseng]: So maintaining our investments in the community liaisons program and potentially expanding it to include an Asian American community liaison.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that was talked about last year and I think we made some progress back then and it's kind of stalled out.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think that's one thing to raise during our budget meetings this season.

[Justin Tseng]: I also want to make sure that we are maintaining or improving our translation services and affordable housing trust because we know those two issues are going to be really paramount and really, really crucial in the next few years.

[Justin Tseng]: And a lot of Medford residents

[Justin Tseng]: worried who are worried about what's happening at the national level and how that's going to affect us, want our city to be providing the day-to-day resources and the day-to-day services that they can access, and to make sure that we are also just making progress on road prevention.

[Justin Tseng]: That's the last item on in my memo that hasn't been mentioned yet, but thank you all.

[Justin Tseng]: I'd second that.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Vice President Collins, for making this a lot clearer.

[Justin Tseng]: And thank you to Director Hans and the team for clarifying some stuff that was on the map.

[Justin Tseng]: I was a little bit confused about whether or I thought that the ADU wouldn't apply to the two-unit dwellings and three-unit dwellings and so on.

[Justin Tseng]: So it is helpful to know that the ADU

[Justin Tseng]: does apply to all the different types in the NR123 neighborhoods and I certainly support that.

[Justin Tseng]: I think in general what I hear from residents is that they want to be, folks want to be able to do more with their property, especially in terms of creating more housing.

[Justin Tseng]: There are a lot of folks who I, neighbors and residents I talk to who

[Justin Tseng]: Want to be able to turn, you know, something into an 80 you they want their kids have moved out and they want to be able to, you know, live in the house that they own, but also to do more with that property.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think 80 years are a great way to do that, which is why.

[Justin Tseng]: In general, my preference is to allow them would be to allow them in any residential neighborhood, even if there are not single family, single unit dwellings there.

[Justin Tseng]: I think in general, for example, if we're taking you are 1.

[Justin Tseng]: If we're looking at the 2 unit dwellings.

[Justin Tseng]: It wouldn't make a lot of sense, in my opinion, to not allow that for a two-unit dwelling in UR1, but to allow that in our neighborhoods.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think that's just my perspective on it, on question one.

[Justin Tseng]: I also, in general, I understand.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm not sure how this works.

[Justin Tseng]: Maybe this is a question for the zoning team, but I wonder if there's a way to allow, for example, in UR1, to allow ADUs by right for certain types of dwellings and then to make it by special permit for the multiplex.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm not sure if that's allowed or if we just have to decide it for the whole neighborhood.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll leave that up to the zoning team, but that's just a question that I had.

[Justin Tseng]: With regards to questions two and three, I am a little bit curious.

[Justin Tseng]: I know 900 square feet is the number that we've chosen.

[Justin Tseng]: I know it's a number that the state has said.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm curious what the rationale behind 900 is.

[Justin Tseng]: I wonder if there's a number that works better for Medford, or whether 900 is just the one that makes the most sense.

[Justin Tseng]: With regards to additional ADUs on the same lot, I think my thought is that if it makes sense for that lot, the special permit process, in my opinion, I think this is what Councilor Lazzaro was getting to, is that oftentimes it can just be an additional barrier to people who would otherwise want to create an ADU.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of folks don't exactly know how to go through the special permit process.

[Justin Tseng]: Maybe the weeks slash months it takes is just

[Justin Tseng]: a hindrance to them, and I think that's something to consider as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I generally leave it to this committee to make a lot of the discretionary decisions, and I have a lot of faith in this committee and in the zoning team.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to provide support for those things and to the sentiments from other councillors, from Councilor Lazzaro and Leming.

[Justin Tseng]: I realized that neglected number four I think I generally agree with President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, we, I think the goal with zoning in general is to get more units on the market to lower housing costs that way.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think, um,

[Justin Tseng]: If we, you know if if we didn't have restrictions or prohibitions on short term rentals that that cuts against our goal.

[Justin Tseng]: I did actually have a question for the staff.

[Justin Tseng]: Under this proposed zoning change, let's say you have a family with a non-conforming, let's take your one.

[Justin Tseng]: Your one is the easiest one to use as an example, I guess.

[Justin Tseng]: Let's say you have a non-conforming single-family unit, but they do want to create an ADU.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, let's say that we allow it either by special permit or by right.

[Justin Tseng]: Would they be able to get an ADU or to build an ADU even if they don't turn the main dwelling into a two-unit or a sort of conversion or whatnot?

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, I just said thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: Any combo works.

[Justin Tseng]: This will be on our agenda later tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: So I don't want to go too much in depth into it, but the committee of the whole reviewed the draft charter as amended by the governance committee.

[Justin Tseng]: We made a few more technical amendments.

[Justin Tseng]: We also had a very long three and a half hour conversation on board representation and what that looks like and sent the draft to this regular meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I've been diligently taking notes throughout this whole whole meeting about what people have been saying, the arguments for and against the concerns that residents have.

[Justin Tseng]: So pardon me if I take a bit because there's just a lot on the stage.

[Justin Tseng]: I want to situate us in the process, the greater zoning process first.

[Justin Tseng]: This is a part of a large rezoning project that seeks to transform how our city approaches affordability, how our city approaches business growth, and makes our city a more thriving, livable place.

[Justin Tseng]: We started this process, we did phase one during the last term, where we started out with basic changes, technical changes mostly.

[Justin Tseng]: We've passed a Mystic Avenue rezoning,

[Justin Tseng]: plan earlier in this term in December, as was noted before.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is the culmination of years and years of public participation and feedback of community engagement, especially reaching out to communities that don't always get their say.

[Justin Tseng]: And we see those ideas contained in our city's comprehensive plan, in our housing production plan, and in the climate action and adaptation plan.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, I think the public feedback part is important, and I have been really grateful that we've done more during the Salem Street project than before, you know, we held information sessions we heard from the public.

[Justin Tseng]: And like the changes that are not, NS Associates did respond to feedback and they made adjustments to things like medical definitions, the hotels, they added more regulations to make sure that the rear setbacks are better for lighting in the neighborhood and for curb appeal as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So that public engagement process I think is really important to note here tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: You know this isn't also also really important to note that this isn't the only neighborhood that we're working on, that there's a incremental that we're seeking incremental increases across the board making sure that all neighborhoods

[Justin Tseng]: are participating and contributing to our solution to the housing crisis here.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, I think to also mention in that grand scheme of things is that we have side projects meant to address a lot of concerns that people brought tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: For example, I know that we've communicated with the Planning Development Sustainability Office and Innes Associates

[Justin Tseng]: about traffic demand management, which could help us a lot when it comes to the traffic problem.

[Justin Tseng]: This reform also closes loopholes that would that allow us to build the equivalent of 15 story buildings and actually aligns us much more with what is currently informed in the neighborhood.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, there's so many reasons to consider with regards to this project.

[Justin Tseng]: And for me, at the core is the problem of affordability.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, I'm someone who is young, that's evident.

[Justin Tseng]: I think people made a point of that a lot.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'd like to say I'm Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: I feel like I've contributed a fair share to this community.

[Justin Tseng]: My family lives here, my friends live here.

[Justin Tseng]: my support network is here, my shopping is here, you know, I do my grocery runs here.

[Justin Tseng]: I have my appointments here.

[Justin Tseng]: And I want to be able to stay here.

[Justin Tseng]: But that prospect is threatened by the state of the cost of living crisis nowadays.

[Justin Tseng]: It's threatened by the housing crisis as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And we've it's not just me, right?

[Justin Tseng]: We've heard time and time again, from residents whose doors were knocking from participants, public participants at this podium, about how

[Justin Tseng]: They want to stay here, they want their family to stay here, they have cousins or aunts and uncles who also are feeling the pressure.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, I think it shouldn't go unnoticed that many of those folks who can't afford the privilege of being here at this meeting are the ones who feel it the hardest.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, this affordability crisis extends further to.

[Justin Tseng]: It's according to studies, the main reason why people are moving out of Massachusetts and why Massachusetts isn't reaching the economic growth that we want to be seeing because we're not maximizing the potential of people being able to live close to their jobs.

[Justin Tseng]: We are not recognizing that people want diversity in housing options.

[Justin Tseng]: I know this is really surprising, maybe really surprising to older folks, but I think this is a great example.

[Justin Tseng]: I was at a PowerPoint night a few weeks ago where we were designing or we were identifying dream homes for people.

[Justin Tseng]: And a number of those homes, at least a third of those homes were apartments.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's a generational change.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's a generational change that we have to account for in urban planning as well.

[Justin Tseng]: It's also really important to note that this zoning reform not only has affordable housing requirements, it actually strengthens those requirements by creating a really innovative dual track system where there are different tracks that you can take for incentives.

[Justin Tseng]: For example, you can believe it's 80% of area median income and 15% of area or 65% of area median income where

[Justin Tseng]: someone choosing to build can choose one of those tracks, and that broadens affordability for more people who've traditionally been just on the cusp of getting affordable housing but not enough to qualify.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's really important as well, and we're incentivizing that in this plan.

[Justin Tseng]: I've heard the used car analogy from Miss Cameron and I actually think that's very apt.

[Justin Tseng]: I understand the concern that maybe a lot of the units that will be built are luxury units but I think we think back to that analogy and the economics research has been super clear that even when you do build luxury housing, not that that's our preference, but even when you do that,

[Justin Tseng]: people who can afford that choose the better housing, right, or they choose luxury housing, so they move out of the market for people who need normal housing.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's something that data has shown time and time again this decade.

[Justin Tseng]: And speaking about data, it's really important to look at the success stories in our country where housing has gotten more affordable, where people have been able to stay.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Minneapolis is the best example of that, but there are multiple examples around this country where, you know, cities have kept housing, regions have kept housing prices down.

[Justin Tseng]: Every single one of them dramatically increases affordable units or housing units in general, even more than what we see here today.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe that this is good for business growth as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I've talked to people looking to open businesses in Medford, and a huge concern that they bring up is the lack of a consumer base that lives close to where they would open their shops.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's something that we really have to consider.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, it'd be great, too, to get cafes and entertainment.

[Justin Tseng]: I've heard, we've heard a lot about grocery stores to hopefully solve our food desert-like problem.

[Justin Tseng]: And I truly believe that folks who need food close to them and at a walkable distance will appreciate that this zoning law gives us the ability to open up that option for them.

[Justin Tseng]: Understand, you know, people

[Justin Tseng]: I'm upset that Johnny's Foodmaster isn't there anymore.

[Justin Tseng]: I used to go there too when I was growing up.

[Justin Tseng]: But government doesn't control whether a supermarket remains open or not.

[Justin Tseng]: But we can control where food is available to our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: This, I believe the zoning plan would put us on a path to more financial stability.

[Justin Tseng]: We've heard a lot about how this will grow, you know, not that this is the goal, but it will grow our revenue base, it will increase investment in our city, in our city services, which in turn, we can use that fund to make safer streets, to have better city services,

[Justin Tseng]: impact fees and studies and the fees that cover those will really help our city, in my opinion.

[Justin Tseng]: When it comes to walkability, even though it isn't walkable right now, it doesn't mean it can't be.

[Justin Tseng]: And it is really important too to note that with this whole, you know, environmental walkability traffic point that

[Justin Tseng]: The young people who we are targeting, the young people who we want to be able to stay in Medford, a huge bulk of them don't own cars and choose not to own cars.

[Justin Tseng]: The car ownership rates with people my generation are down over 25%.

[Justin Tseng]: That's a choice.

[Justin Tseng]: This zoning plan implements better energy efficiency standards and incentives to reach those standards.

[Justin Tseng]: 70% of our emissions in the city come from buildings and houses.

[Justin Tseng]: And studies again have shown time and time again, the way to reduce those emissions is to build denser housing.

[Justin Tseng]: And we can argue over what density is right, but that is the science.

[Justin Tseng]: So we have to account for that.

[Justin Tseng]: Furthermore,

[Justin Tseng]: when it comes to the traffic point, in maybe even a year, but at least two or three years, the MBTA will be running the 96 bus down and up this corridor during rush hours at a peak time of seven minutes, and even off rush hour within 15 minutes, I believe.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's gonna provide connections to the red line, to the orange line, and to the D and E lines of the Green Line Express.

[Justin Tseng]: The science shows that when you up zone like this, trip rates go down because life gets more convenient.

[Justin Tseng]: People choose to walk.

[Justin Tseng]: People choose to walk to things that are close to them.

[Justin Tseng]: There's lots to say with regards to accessibility.

[Justin Tseng]: I think a resident wrote me and was very compelling about how actually three or four story buildings aren't enough because there aren't, you know, people don't build elevators for those buildings.

[Justin Tseng]: But anything over that level, people will build elevators for them, which means that people who can't get around easily will have a place to live.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's something to consider as well.

[Justin Tseng]: In fact, if you prevent walkability, if you make this less walkable, it is more restrictive and keeps folks stuck in their homes as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's something that we're looking at with the transportation task force.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm going on way too long, but I just want to end with this.

[Justin Tseng]: This is a regional issue, I hear that you know there are residents who really do support this, who live nearby and residents who don't support this and live nearby as well.

[Justin Tseng]: But we all have stakes in this issue.

[Justin Tseng]: This is a regional issue we're all you know we are all affected by the lack of housing in one area.

[Justin Tseng]: And we're all affected by the lack of housing in Medford as a whole.

[Justin Tseng]: And so it does make sense for all of us to be commenting on this.

[Justin Tseng]: In fact,

[Justin Tseng]: You know, if you don't like this, you should go to Wayland.

[Justin Tseng]: You should go to Acton.

[Justin Tseng]: You should go to Haverhill.

[Justin Tseng]: You should go to those communities and ask them to build more housing as well, because that's going to help us reach our regional goal.

[Justin Tseng]: I find any comment asking people to move away because they don't like something despicable, but I have to note that the context in which we heard that tonight was asking young people who can't afford to live here to move away.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's really important to note as well.

[Justin Tseng]: We want young people to be able to stay.

[Justin Tseng]: We want all people to be able to stay.

[Justin Tseng]: And not addressing the housing crisis pushes all people out.

[Justin Tseng]: It pushes young people out.

[Justin Tseng]: I've talked about that here.

[Justin Tseng]: But it also pushes old people out.

[Justin Tseng]: It pushes middle-aged people out.

[Justin Tseng]: It pushes families out.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's something that we have to consider as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I do actually hear a lot of these concerns.

[Justin Tseng]: I think a lot of the concerns can be addressed in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: with greater resources, greater revenue.

[Justin Tseng]: But ultimately, I think what I have to say is that I got elected on a platform to increase housing, to invest in our communities, to work on environmental standards and raising those, and to make our city centers more lively and thriving.

[Justin Tseng]: And it would betray my platform to vote against this.

[Justin Tseng]: We can't,

[Justin Tseng]: help kicking this down the road.

[Justin Tseng]: We can't keep kicking this down the road.

[Justin Tseng]: I think if not us, then who?

[Justin Tseng]: If not now, then when?

[Justin Tseng]: And I'll leave it at that.

[Justin Tseng]: And I do want to thank Vice President Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: I want to thank Planning Development Sustainability staff and to NS Associates for working so hard on this.

[Justin Tseng]: I want to thank the members of the public on both sides of this issue for commenting, because it does, you know, even the criticism helps us identify things for the city to be working on in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Lazzaro.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: I have very similar sentiments to Councilor Callahan.

[Justin Tseng]: This was one of the core planks of my environmental platform running for this term.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think Vice President Collins did a superb job explaining it.

[Justin Tseng]: This is really meant to get us and get developers in Medford to be much more accountable and much more incentivized to be innovative in how they address environmental issues and in making our city more livable.

[Justin Tseng]: the numerous aspects of the green score with regards to vegetation, with regards to blue roofs and green walls, et cetera.

[Justin Tseng]: All of those things are things that 21st century cities should be doing, that Medford can be doing, that we can do by passing this.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll just end really quickly with a quick anecdote.

[Justin Tseng]: This kind of stuff, the stormwater, the vegetarian mutation, all of this is so important because many of us live in neighborhoods or have lived in neighborhoods where the flooding gets really crazy when there's a heavy rain, where heat islands are a particular problem.

[Justin Tseng]: These are all effects of climate change that we're seeing and facing now and today.

[Justin Tseng]: This global issue really does affect us locally.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is a core way for us to address this taken from our climate action adaptation plan.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: This might help get at Mr. Fiori's questions.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the simple answer is that it is very factor-based.

[Justin Tseng]: So the green score, the way it works is that it adjusts flexibly for different beneficial landscapes that might come up, which means that there are different requirements as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's something to factor into our thinking when we think about the economic concerns that were brought up.

[Justin Tseng]: Part of the way of doing this is to also make it way clearer to developers how we approach our environmental standards.

[Justin Tseng]: Instead of having to find all these things in different places, this makes it a really easy rubric and calculation.

[Justin Tseng]: There, I think it also depends on the baseline you're comparing this to the baseline we have in Medford is really low so I think I'm still optimistic that it's going to create housing units.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's also worth saying that much of this is incentives.

[Justin Tseng]: So there are a lot of things in here that developers aren't required to be building, but are ways for us to essentially give them the carrot and ask them to do the best for Redbird.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: President Bears, I think you covered the substantive changes very well.

[Justin Tseng]: Just to give a quick overview of the process, we as a governance committee received the recommendations from the mayor after her review from the Charter Study Commission who prepared a bunch of recommendations.

[Justin Tseng]: During this whole process, we have been doing our best to make sure that the stakeholders who have been working on this so much have been included in our discussions, including inviting members of the Charter Study Committee to our meetings.

[Justin Tseng]: The Collins Center was here at a number of governance committee meetings as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I've also been in contact with mayor's office throughout the process, even before we started in the governance committee.

[Justin Tseng]: In the Governance Committee, as President Bayer has acknowledged or noted, we made several edits, all in the spirit of the Charter, but after very long discussions about what we thought aligned with the values of Charter review, notably promoting equity.

[Justin Tseng]: In doing that, we made, in addition to the technical edits we made, we passed a new recommendation for what that more local representation would look like.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm ending up with a four district five at large model, as you said, and by removing the mayor's the school committee chair, which is a change that most residents in our community have been telling the people on the on the charter study committee and in governments that they wanted to see.

[Justin Tseng]: to quickly, there's been a lot of conversation and discourse over ward representation, what that looks like here.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know there are even Councilors who, myself included, have noted that there are even better systems out there that we would like to see, like ranked choice voting, like multiple member districts.

[Justin Tseng]: But

[Justin Tseng]: The charter as it stands today, I think is a fair distillation of the conversations that we had on the governance committee and in the committee the whole meeting last week.

[Justin Tseng]: And what is politically feasible for us to get something through the state house.

[Justin Tseng]: I think a quick note on equity, we've talked a lot about it.

[Justin Tseng]: I know there's been more conversations online about it.

[Justin Tseng]: I spent time today talking to, there's one article in particular that's become a subject of conversation or article written by my professor, my advising professor who I talked to today, whose recommendation, whose interpretation of what she wrote.

[Justin Tseng]: is the same as my interpretation of what was written, which is that we have to be careful not to take the easy way out.

[Justin Tseng]: We have to be careful to make sure that we're not incentivizing politicians to isolate certain voting groups and constituencies in the city, that it makes sense for us to keep politicians accountable to more diverse constituency groups.

[Justin Tseng]: There's a news article in God of Nomad for about the conversation that we had.

[Justin Tseng]: I know Tufts Daily is working on something as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'll leave that there.

[Justin Tseng]: I did get feedback from the school committee counsel, Howard Greenspan, Attorney Greenspan, about the two sections that our governance committee noted to ask for his feedback.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'll quickly

[Justin Tseng]: tell you guys, I've also sent this to the clerk and President Bears, who the clerk heard of these has distributed this to everyone.

[Justin Tseng]: So on the specific wording around appointment authority of positions under the superintendent in section 4-5, B1, we raised this for Attorney Greenspan to look at because

[Justin Tseng]: The state charter, DSEE regulations, and mass general law all say slightly different things.

[Justin Tseng]: His recommendation is that the specifics of the positions are removed from the charter, and the reference conferring all the authority of the MGL is sufficient.

[Justin Tseng]: He recommended against duplication where there could end up being discrepancy.

[Justin Tseng]: He further said that if that clause must remain, there are other additional positions that need to be included, which Vice Chair Graham included in her prior comments.

[Justin Tseng]: With that being the advice from Attorney Greenspan, I would make a motion to approve this, but strike section 4-5B1, and to renumber the rest of the section accordingly.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, yeah, the whole section.

[Justin Tseng]: So that is the main edit that Attorney Greenspan has recommended to us.

[Justin Tseng]: The other section that we had Attorney Greenspan look at was 8-43 about ineligible measures to be put on a referendum ballot.

[Justin Tseng]: We amended that in our last Committee of the Whole meeting to read in addition to the city budget or the school committee budget as a whole, we added the words or any part thereof.

[Justin Tseng]: And Attorney Greenspan said that the change that we made as the Committee of the Whole is sufficient.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, now I'll just.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to thank Councilor Callaghan for sharing what she wrote.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, what Councilor Callaghan wrote is about, you know, research that has been done for a very long time in this country, because, you know, we always seek to improve our electoral systems to better match both the identity, but also especially the policy objectives of our communities.

[Justin Tseng]: I think what Councilor Callaghan wrote is super meaningful.

[Justin Tseng]: It very much overlaps with a lot of the research I've done on this topic as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And a lot of the conversations that I've had with political scientists and lawyers who are working on electoral systems, trying to make them more equitable.

[Justin Tseng]: So I encourage everyone to read that post.

[Justin Tseng]: I think another thing that I've been talking about too that I haven't gotten to mention tonight is the need, again, returning to the policy argument, the need to align our greater objectives with our local desires as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we see that a lot tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: We've talked a lot about parochialism and how if we overly shift to another model of governance,

[Justin Tseng]: that can create unintended consequences as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And those consequences are what I've been phrasing as, it's really a democratic paradox, because you can have commitment to pro-housing policies, but yet still have a situation where every single neighborhood doesn't want that policy there.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, the I believe the 4-5 balance by making it more more closer to half and half, um, allows for both sides of the argument to be heard and to be expressed and to be voted on.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and to not, you know, overly weigh the conversations in favor of one over the other.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I'll leave it there because there might be more to say with, um, after, but I think a lot has been said already.

[Justin Tseng]: So thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Hold on.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to thank Jose for his dedication to our community.

[Justin Tseng]: We see you sitting there for how God knows how many hours.

[Justin Tseng]: I know you got school tomorrow too.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's not an easy task.

[Justin Tseng]: So thank you for holding in there and I'd like to motion to adjourn.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I echo my colleagues' comments.

[Justin Tseng]: You know,

[Justin Tseng]: even if you're not a cyclist, you almost definitely know one in your life.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's really important that we protect every single life that we can on our roads, that we have that safety.

[Justin Tseng]: I've been reading through the document that was circulated by the clerk.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is really, really helpful for us as Councilors to guide, you know, our thoughts going into budget season and to have concrete examples of what we can do.

[Justin Tseng]: And this will, I'm sure for,

[Justin Tseng]: us on the city council guide a lot of the questions we ask the directors in the departments as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I'd be really curious to know like in the future after, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: the commission and us on the City Council, we all talk through the budget items to see what we can advocate for, what seems like a realistic action plan to get these things done.

[Justin Tseng]: So this is super, super helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: And thank you so much for it.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I also want to remind folks at home that safety on the roads is not only an ethical issue, it's also a legal issue as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I've heard of a lot of cases in Medford where cyclists are harassed and threatened by drivers.

[Justin Tseng]: That's not OK.

[Justin Tseng]: And it actually is considered assault under Massachusetts law, both as a crime and a civil offense, and it can be punished.

[Justin Tseng]: So I just want to put that out there and say, this is something that state law, that our city takes really seriously.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's not a joking matter.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Hi there, could you give me just like two, three minutes?

[Justin Tseng]: Thanks.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you chair Leming.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, let me start again by just generally framing what we're trying to do here, give a little bit of context for where we are now.

[Justin Tseng]: And then I can walk through the draft changes, the new draft that I had circulated to the other members of this committee last week.

[Justin Tseng]: So essentially, this starts with reappraising where, you know, the type of work we're doing in our city when it comes to social justice, civil rights, human rights.

[Justin Tseng]: And something that I heard from former committee members of the HRC and sitting commissioners was that

[Justin Tseng]: was that essentially the original enabling ordinance hamstrung them so that they couldn't meet quorum to meet, they couldn't do a number of things that I think other cities very normally do within their HRC powers that our city hasn't done because we haven't reviewed or revised this ordinance substantively in such a long time.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I've been working over the last few months, it's getting close to a year, with members of the community who have experience on the HRC, members of the community who have experience in the field of advocating for social justice issues, and also working with members of the current HRC to draft an ordinance that makes our HRC more functional again.

[Justin Tseng]: The most recent updates is that the HRC hasn't been able to make a quorum for the last few months, so the HRC just hasn't been meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: Furthermore, Francis Noage, the RDEI director, has resigned as liaison to the HRC as well, and so there's no city staff member who is there to

[Justin Tseng]: help the HRC get off the ground.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that really underscores the need for us to pass an updated HRC ordinance as soon as we can.

[Justin Tseng]: I've been working with members of the city administration in the last few months as well to hear from them about what changes they'd like to see the ordinance and negotiating with them on that front.

[Justin Tseng]: and also continuing to work with community members to make sure that the proposed changes are in alignment with what members of the HRC and former members of the HRC would want to make sure that this ordinance gives them the ability to do that.

[Justin Tseng]: With that being said, I think my goals for this meeting is to get our committee generally behind a document.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm slated to meet with the mayor soon to discuss this ordinance further.

[Justin Tseng]: I think my goal, to be transparent, would be to get something out of this committee by next month.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's why I'd like to get us on the same page about these edits that we've made over the last few months together first.

[Justin Tseng]: Before I go into the document itself, are there any comments from councillors?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of these edits

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of these edits are somewhat technical, but there are some substantive edits as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So, as you can see in the establishment and purposes section, these are kind of more technical edits to make sure that we are including, to make sure that we're including parts of the,

[Justin Tseng]: Like, every sector of the community that we can think of, and to make sure that this language is tighter as well and more inclusive.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's technical with regards.

[Justin Tseng]: 1 of the big conversations that members of the city administration community advocates and I have been having is about the size of the.

[Justin Tseng]: and the previously proposed size.

[Justin Tseng]: So previously the ordinance language read for the HRC to have 12 to 18 members and a few, Francis brought this up as well as a number of current HRC members bringing up the worry that this might be too big of a size and if we set a lower bound of 12,

[Justin Tseng]: We might have a period of time where we aren't able to have the HRC meet because we haven't appointed up to 12 people yet.

[Justin Tseng]: We had, the community advocates and I have had a very long and extensive discussion about it because we want to make sure that there are as many voices as possible on the HRC.

[Justin Tseng]: The size here is, you know, there's a benefit to having a higher number so we have a diversity of voices, I think.

[Justin Tseng]: The if we read the purposes and you know the powers and duties of HRC in this ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: It's much more expansive than the current current ordinances.

[Justin Tseng]: And so the idea is having more people would help HRC get more stuff done as well.

[Justin Tseng]: But then we also have to balance that with

[Justin Tseng]: with the practical concerns too.

[Justin Tseng]: It was suggested to me from Francis that we do nine to 12 members.

[Justin Tseng]: In this draft, I think generally, I think nine to 15 makes sense to retain a lot of the flexibility that we initially wanted.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, if it gets to a point where 15 is unworkable, I think there's flexibility there to keep the slots open, but I think it's worth trying to get more members too.

[Justin Tseng]: So with that change,

[Justin Tseng]: we have basically reconfigured the appointment system as well to make it more even.

[Justin Tseng]: Basically, a third being the mayor, a third being the city council, and then appointing from different community groups.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is something that was also in the last draft, but to explain this again, since it's been a few months, the idea I think is for, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: I think the idea is that we would have members of different commissions that aren't the HRC but have interests in the HRC, where the work overlaps also sit on the HRC, to help facilitate cross-commission, cross-department, cross-organizational cooperation as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I know something that we have been talking about is potentially deleting this because we don't really need it.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's probably a decent recommendation, although we can talk about that later.

[Justin Tseng]: Another edit that we made to this section is in section B. So essentially,

[Justin Tseng]: Before the language read, no more than half should be of any one gender or racial identity.

[Justin Tseng]: We changed it to 60% for functionality, just because it's hard to guarantee half or less.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this gives us a little bit of wiggle room while still maintaining the spirit and the purpose of the original text.

[Justin Tseng]: And here, this is an adjustment to respond to the original, like the change in section A. In section E, we have clarified some language here about reimbursements.

[Justin Tseng]: We had a good conversation about how there are, number one, we should clarify that this is that

[Justin Tseng]: Sorry, I can't speak.

[Justin Tseng]: We should clarify that HRC commissioners who are spending their money on top of a stipend or whatever, if they're spending their personal money on getting a project done, they should be

[Justin Tseng]: The this ordinance should allow them to get compensation for that as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think a concrete example is if someone is buying, you know, posters for a community event to let them know about their rights, right?

[Justin Tseng]: I know your rights event, then they should be able to be compensated for printing those posters in the first place.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's really standard.

[Justin Tseng]: custom as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And we believe that that should extend to volunteers as well, just to make sure that they're being compensated for their time, effort, their money being spent.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's important to put that put this in.

[Justin Tseng]: I've been talking to some people who are more legally trained than I am.

[Justin Tseng]: And the idea is if we don't put this language in, then it actually might sound very restrictive.

[Justin Tseng]: And then the last edit to this section, as it stands right now, is just some clarification on the training that HRC members should receive.

[Justin Tseng]: There is some surplus language, I believe, especially in addition to later in the ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's what that is.

[Justin Tseng]: We've broken, upon the recommendation, I believe this is of a few people, a few, this is from a few community members, current HRC members, from Francis as well.

[Justin Tseng]: There's the recommendation that we should clarify a little bit what the officer's roles are.

[Justin Tseng]: So the original ordinance did put in that there should be a chair, a vice chair, and a clerk.

[Justin Tseng]: And as we saw during charter review, this is becoming more standard.

[Justin Tseng]: As we also saw during charter review, our charter review conversations, for us to be able to have that flexibility in terms of how a commission is structured, we need to talk about it a little bit more in ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: So I actually grabbed the language for most of this section from the draft charter.

[Justin Tseng]: So, you know, this is like quite standard vetted language it aligns with like the draft city charter, but then there's some more clarification as well as well as customization for the HRC.

[Justin Tseng]: I, because it's not very standard to have a treasurer for, well, it's not very, it's not always common for a treasurer to be an officer in a commission.

[Justin Tseng]: I've put the financial procedure aspects, the finance aspects under a joint responsibility of the officers.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's something, if this committee has different views on, we can talk about it.

[Justin Tseng]: Cool.

[Justin Tseng]: Another change that was suggested that we make was reducing the minimum number of meetings from 10 meetings to 8 meetings.

[Justin Tseng]: The intention isn't for us to have fewer meetings, but the intention is to give us more flexibility.

[Justin Tseng]: Legal wiggle room, essentially.

[Justin Tseng]: I suspect this will be a big conversation tonight as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Essentially, the administration has recommended that we adjust the language in section, subsection A here about legal counsel.

[Justin Tseng]: from if the city has no solicitor, the commission shall be provided adequate funding to retain its own, to the commission should have adequate access to council.

[Justin Tseng]: Because this is something I think we might be talking about a bit tonight, I just wanted to highlight the two arguments.

[Justin Tseng]: So the argument for keeping it as it was before, so the original language,

[Justin Tseng]: is that a lot of the work that the HRC might be doing might not always be in the interests, completely aligned with the interests of the city administration.

[Justin Tseng]: And so it makes some sense for the HRC to retain its own council in those instances so they can get more honest feedback.

[Justin Tseng]: and legal advice.

[Justin Tseng]: The counter to that is a worry from the administration that in general, it's not recommended practice for different parts of the municipal government to be having different legal representation.

[Justin Tseng]: And there's a worry about the legal consequences of that as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And it is not exactly, not very standard for that.

[Justin Tseng]: And then in the last section, the only real edit is to broaden B1 from discuss to review and discuss.

[Justin Tseng]: This is just to essentially give the HRC the power to look at city policy as it stands, and to engage with city bodies in that sense, to be able to work with them to review human rights problems, and not just talk about it in a vacuum.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, so with that being said, that's basically all the edits I, um, I've had.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I want to open this up, um, and hear feedback from Councilors and from residents.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, actually I can, I can also just keep this up.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, that might be it.

[Justin Tseng]: Like, yeah, I also just noticed that we can,

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's meant to read that.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay, gotcha.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Is there any- And I would actually suggest putting civil rights in there too.

[Justin Tseng]: Just the view right now, because sometimes human rights and civil rights are slightly different.

[Justin Tseng]: So I wanna make sure that we're catching as much as possible.

[Justin Tseng]: Gotcha.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Callahan.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I think that's a good point.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I know when we were crafting it, at least it wasn't my intention that we limit it to Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: really, you know, uh, talk about issues happening outside of our city as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's a good, good question.

[Justin Tseng]: you know, when they're working on something, a development project or something, they sometimes get advice from KP law.

[Justin Tseng]: So, and I believe that comes out of the legal budget and not the PDS budget.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's how I was thinking about it, the city providing that.

[Justin Tseng]: And I actually think the language of this ordinance would provide that reading in my opinion.

[Justin Tseng]: So because the part about the budget line for the MHRC,

[Justin Tseng]: is about accomplishing its purposes.

[Justin Tseng]: So roles, powers, duties.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that probably, essentially, I think this stuff in this section is what their own budget will handle.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think this falls outside of it.

[Justin Tseng]: That's my reading.

[Justin Tseng]: But we can also maybe get a wording that's a little bit tighter on that.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I'm curious to hear what people think.

[Justin Tseng]: I think with regards to the city solicitor part, this first sentence essentially says that when there is a city solicitor, they should serve as the counsel of the commission.

[Justin Tseng]: The difference obviously is, I guess, in the second part.

[Justin Tseng]: When the city has no solicitors, the original one is just very directly saying, if the city has no solicitor, they should retain their own legal counsel.

[Justin Tseng]: And the new version, this was suggested to me by the administration, is just to have adequate access to counsel.

[Justin Tseng]: So that guarantees that they'll have legal counsel.

[Justin Tseng]: It doesn't say anything about, um, making that they're, you know, the HRC's own legal counsel.

[Justin Tseng]: First sentence in C. The first sentence is state and federal.

[Justin Tseng]: So on this part, the mayor wasn't the one to suggest this part.

[Justin Tseng]: This came from the DEI department.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I think it's how you read it.

[Justin Tseng]: And what we talk about in this committee will actually shape how courts will read it.

[Justin Tseng]: I, the way I would read it is that this language is generally broad.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, so essentially just saying that they have to have some access to council, but I think the language that is suggested in this new updated version would basically give that authority to the mayor's office to decide, um, where the, whether the council they get is KP law or whether the council they get is someone else.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, whereas

[Justin Tseng]: this original language that wasn't there before, the way I read it is the commission should be the one to decide who to, you know, who to serve as council when there's no city solicitor.

[Justin Tseng]: So it's like an agency thing.

[Justin Tseng]: I think there, I think they'd be hesitant to language.

[Justin Tseng]: At this point, I'm starting to lean into speculation territory, so I don't want to speak for the mayor's office or for the administration.

[Justin Tseng]: I would guess that they would say that

[Justin Tseng]: Explicit references to independent legal counsel, I think they would be against.

[Justin Tseng]: I wonder if there's some wiggle room where we clarify that there's no preclusion.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think it's an art to do that.

[Justin Tseng]: So if people have suggested language that kind of goes, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: You know, there's that needle.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that aligns with how I see it.

[Justin Tseng]: Steve.

[Justin Tseng]: make sure what we're doing aligns with what's been said.

[Justin Tseng]: I think generally I still think that this is probably the best language because I think it leaves it open enough, but I could see it being construed that the city solicitor shall serve as the council of the commission.

[Justin Tseng]: Like I think there's a, to use legal terms, there's an ordinary meaning argument that

[Justin Tseng]: An ordinary person reading the ordinance would likely think that that restricts legal counsel to only the city solicitor and

[Justin Tseng]: But at the same time, I think you can also make the argument that that wouldn't align with the legislative intent here.

[Justin Tseng]: And it doesn't align with the record, which we'll see in the committee report when Adam finishes it.

[Justin Tseng]: So it could really cut both ways, I guess is what I'm saying.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I don't think any of this precludes informal legal advice.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the thing that it would preclude is a formal legal memo that an HRC might use to take legal action, which I don't think, in most cases, the HRC would have a cause of action anyways.

[Justin Tseng]: So I don't think it'd be relevant, like I don't think it'd be material to the conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: So I don't think, I think as long as like, we're, as long as people are okay with this potentially being cabined to, you know, informal legal advice, the type that we kind of see very, very often.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's at the very minimum with this allows for this current language.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I think there's so many great ideas floating around right now.

[Justin Tseng]: First, I just want to thank you to Chair Leming and Councilor Callahan for this report.

[Justin Tseng]: It's really helpful for us to hear about what's being discussed and the issues that people are bringing up and to think about best practices and how we can adjust how we're running these things.

[Justin Tseng]: It's such a

[Justin Tseng]: It's a new concept, so we're always working out how we implement it.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's really helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: I really like what Councilor Callaghan is thinking with regards to making these conversations, these forums, these spaces to be more inclusive and less intimidating for people who might want to bring something up and doesn't feel like they're able to say it.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm excited to see where that goes and if we find maybe down the road, it'd be great to work on a list of best practices for facilitating these meetings.

[Justin Tseng]: I know Councilor Callaghan had a document early on in the year that was really helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: Maybe if we keep working on something like that and if we have any new observations about how to best run these meetings,

[Justin Tseng]: collecting those and disseminating them to Councilors would be really, a really good idea.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think to Councilor Lazzaro's point, if we see, you know, issues come up again and again, collecting the resources beforehand, being ready for those meetings to disseminate that information, that'd be very helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: So yeah, Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you for working on this.

[Justin Tseng]: recommendation on compensation for elected officials compensation.

[Justin Tseng]: The other side of the rail.

[Justin Tseng]: Do we need a little bit of context here?

[Justin Tseng]: Because we did also discuss this for a while.

[Justin Tseng]: This is another- Yeah, I actually didn't realize the YouTube videos were linked, so that'd be really helpful to just say, and I think that would cover everything.
