[Justin Tseng]: You wouldn't always know it from a, you know, inbox.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Over the last two months, the governance committee has been reviewing a draft charter developed by the charter study committee and sent to us from the mayor's office.

[Justin Tseng]: This has been a really exciting process.

[Justin Tseng]: I know a lot of residents have been engaged in this process over a long time and especially in the last few weeks.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, this process really will change what

[Justin Tseng]: Rules underlie our governance, and as I've heard it being put multiple times before, the Charter is a reflection of who we are as a city.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's really important to thank the members of the Charter Study Committee for their work over the last few years.

[Justin Tseng]: Where the city council comes in is where the state law begins, which, you know, using the method that the mayor chose to do charter review.

[Justin Tseng]: The city council is the body that has to approve any proposal that we sent the state legislature on the text.

[Justin Tseng]: The legally binding text that the text that will send to the voters starts here and that's the work that we've been doing with our due diligence over the last few months.

[Justin Tseng]: During those meetings, I made sure to invite members of the Charter Study Committee, members of different bodies that would be affected, such as the School Committee and multiple member bodies to the meetings and to provide feedback, many of whom did provide feedback to us.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm proud to say that I think the Governance Committee really did consider

[Justin Tseng]: feedback from all different angles, from different perspectives.

[Justin Tseng]: We had some real debates in committee about what we bring to this committee, the whole meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that the conversation, the discourse that we had was very thoughtful.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, just to summarize, there are three main buckets of edits that the governance committee made.

[Justin Tseng]: There are two bigger substantive changes.

[Justin Tseng]: And then the last bucket are just technical edits to clarify language and to make sure that the language that we had in the draft city charter was legally airtight and wouldn't lead to any loopholes.

[Justin Tseng]: The two big substantive edits that we made was to adopt a district-based composition for city council to align it with the school committee model that was proposed, and to remove the mayor as the chair of the school committee, keeping the mayor on the school committee as a normal member.

[Justin Tseng]: I do have some more technical edits going through the city charter in communications with the Collins Center and also in working with folks at Harvard Law, just some technical edits to make sure that we don't slip into any situations where there might be litigation and to make sure that we're fully aligned with state law and that each part of the city charter aligns with each other as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I have a list of technical edits too.

[Justin Tseng]: So to start in section 1-3, I would suggest removing the words, not including the Medford public schools, specifically from the definitions of city agency and city office or department head.

[Justin Tseng]: That's a change that we made at the last meeting on the school committee.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's a change that was recommended to align us with CELAW.

[Justin Tseng]: I'd also suggest in section 1-7, the definition section, two edits.

[Justin Tseng]: One, to add the word new before initiative measure, and to add the words excluding repeal referendum measures at the end of the definition.

[Justin Tseng]: This brings us in alignment with the rest of the document which we edited.

[Justin Tseng]: at that last governance committee meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: It also just clarifies that we do have a new initiative measure process and a repeal referendum process, and those don't overlap.

[Justin Tseng]: So there's no loophole there.

[Justin Tseng]: The second edit that I would suggest making to section 1-7 would be to add the word repeal before referendum measure.

[Justin Tseng]: That's again, just to align what we have there.

[Justin Tseng]: A technical edit suggestion that I have for section article 3-8 would be to add the word temporarily before the word unable.

[Justin Tseng]: This is the section of the city charter about what happens with a temporary absence of the mayor in talking to lawyers.

[Justin Tseng]: It's pretty, there was a pretty

[Justin Tseng]: big red flag in this section about this potentially giving the city council the power to coup the mayor with a bunch of different legal rules, doctrines for why the section as is would do that.

[Justin Tseng]: This doesn't reflect the intent of the Charter Study Committee.

[Justin Tseng]: It doesn't, in our conversation at the Governance Committee, didn't reflect the intent of anyone at that meeting as well.

[Justin Tseng]: In section 3-10, I have two proposed edits.

[Justin Tseng]: The first one would be to add the words in bullet point A, so subsection A, add the words, and shall receive compensation as established by ordinance for the office of mayor.

[Justin Tseng]: That is to clarify something that we had discussed in the governance committee about making sure that someone doing the job of acting mayor for months on end would be paid for that.

[Justin Tseng]: There's a very similar edit I'd like to make in, I suggest that the committee of the whole make in part B to amend the final clause to end after the sentence

[Justin Tseng]: to end the sentence after the words section 3-1A and to insert the following.

[Justin Tseng]: Quote, such person shall not be entitled to have the words candidate for reelection printed against their name on the election ballot for the office of the mayor, but may have these words printed against their name on the election ballot for their original city council position.

[Justin Tseng]: Such person shall receive such compensation as established by ordinance for the office of mayor.

[Justin Tseng]: This is just to clarify a potential ambiguity that was raised to me just to make sure that we are keeping with the intentions that we had.

[Justin Tseng]: So this is just really clearing up a loophole.

[Justin Tseng]: In section 4-8B,

[Justin Tseng]: I would suggest replacing the words highest vote getter with candidate receiving the highest number of votes.

[Justin Tseng]: That's just to align us with legal language.

[Justin Tseng]: In section 6-4, I would suggest adding that the budget should be required to be posted on the city website.

[Justin Tseng]: In section 8-4, subsection 3, I would amend the language to read

[Justin Tseng]: the city budget or school committee budget as a whole or any portion thereof.

[Justin Tseng]: That also reflects some, the conversation that we had at our last governance committee meeting, just to make sure that the language there is airtight as well, because the language before read the other way.

[Justin Tseng]: And in Section 9-11, this is the final edit in Section 9-11, I would suggest replacing the words Board of Election Commissioners with City Clerk.

[Justin Tseng]: That's another, just a technical edit.

[Justin Tseng]: So with that all being said, and I can email this list around to the City Clerk and to Councilors if need be, I would motion to accept the recommendations of the Governance Committee with these technical edits.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng? President Bears?, sorry about that.

[Justin Tseng]: No worries.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: There's a lot to unpack there, but I wanted to start with, let's talk about equity.

[Justin Tseng]: Because this is a guiding decision behind so much of our city's policies, behind this charter reform in particular.

[Justin Tseng]: And let's make sure that equity isn't just treated like a slogan.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we agree about the concerns that there is just one elected person of color in the city, that for decades there's only been one elected person of color in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: I, you know what, I look in the mirror every morning after I get out of the shower and I see that.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think, you know what, I ran on a platform the first time I got elected and when I got reelected, I ran on a platform, not just to take the easy answer when it comes to equity, but to examine policies through the lens of equity.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's a much richer, much deeper, much more complicated conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: it is easy to say that if we draw smaller districts, that everyone will get represented.

[Justin Tseng]: But that's not where the conversation has to end with equity.

[Justin Tseng]: And actually, the conversation can't end there with equity.

[Justin Tseng]: The conversation has to end with whether the outcomes that a future city council makes reflects that equity in the first place.

[Justin Tseng]: Now,

[Justin Tseng]: Research from decades, 40 years of research, have been really loud in saying that it's not enough to draw a majority-minority district.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not enough to have a Black representative for a Black district or an Asian representative for an Asian district.

[Justin Tseng]: And that actually drives worse outcomes for minority interests.

[Justin Tseng]: It really does.

[Justin Tseng]: When we see that you have one person of color on the city council, and I'm not even talking about this city council, we see that that is the effect of tokenism, that we take the easy way out, that we say that's enough, that we have diversity, that we have equity, that we have inclusion.

[Justin Tseng]: And I implore the city council and I implore residents at home

[Justin Tseng]: So look at the research.

[Justin Tseng]: And there's quite a lot of papers on this.

[Justin Tseng]: I will break this down, the general concepts really quickly.

[Justin Tseng]: When you draw districts that are majority minority, the problem is that no one else is accountable to those voters or few people are accountable to those voters.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why political scientists and experts, sociologists suggest that we take a compromise approach to determining composition of elected bodies.

[Justin Tseng]: The idea is that if we want real equitable outcomes, we need to make politicians accountable to more voters, to more different types of voter bases.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we luck out with the district proposal.

[Justin Tseng]: We looked at the, in the governance committee, we looked at the percentages of majority minority, the majority minority share, especially in West Medford and Wellington.

[Justin Tseng]: between the district model and the word-based model.

[Justin Tseng]: And there truly is not a major statistical difference.

[Justin Tseng]: But what that means is if we go to a district model, a district Councilor will be accountable to more minority interests.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think if we're talking about equity, I think we need to trust the data.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to trust the science on that one.

[Justin Tseng]: We also see with equity, it's not just about race.

[Justin Tseng]: It's about income.

[Justin Tseng]: It's about the types of housing or

[Justin Tseng]: lack of housing.

[Justin Tseng]: And we also see that there is quite a lot of research.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not just one study that shows that an overfocus on ward representation can heighten those problems of lack of housing development, of a further segregation of housing outcomes.

[Justin Tseng]: with lower income and working class residents.

[Justin Tseng]: That's what the data says.

[Justin Tseng]: Look, I walked into this office, I walked into this situation, actually leaning towards supporting an 8-3 model for representation.

[Justin Tseng]: And I wasn't married to it.

[Justin Tseng]: And I was actually open to looking at other models.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think, as I'm sure councillors will discuss tonight, there are other models that are actually better than any of the proposals that we have on the table.

[Justin Tseng]: But our political process demands that we choose one of these ones.

[Justin Tseng]: This is the thing, is when you do more research about this, there is a muddier picture.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's not to say that district representation is what's going to solve the world.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not going to say that ward representation is what's going to solve the world.

[Justin Tseng]: The picture is really complicated.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, talking about the point of this is a political game, and if it quacks like a duck, it probably is a duck.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's funny, because we can also look at the data about that.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm not convinced that the proposal that we have here, the 4-5 split, is actually more expedient to

[Justin Tseng]: you know, the certain group of politicians in the city, I actually think the data backs the other way.

[Justin Tseng]: And so in supporting this amendment, I'm actually likely weakening my own position going forward.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's, you know, really important to also say the most politically expedient decision I could make tonight

[Justin Tseng]: is to revert to an 8-3 system.

[Justin Tseng]: But I'm not convinced that that system solves the problems that we see today in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm not convinced that that would be better than a 4-5 system.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm not saying that the 4-5 system, the district system is gonna solve all of our problems, but the 4-5 system has problems that we can solve using other measures.

[Justin Tseng]: through redistricting, through changing incentives, that we can't solve as easily with a ward-based system.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's my research.

[Justin Tseng]: I've spent all day on the phone with people who very strongly support a ward-based system.

[Justin Tseng]: And we've come to a consensus that there is no perfect system and that it should be my, it's incumbent upon me as an elected official to make the decision that I think is morally right for the city.

[Justin Tseng]: not the politically expedient one.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, there's a lot to be said.

[Justin Tseng]: We can delve more into the proposals, but I just wanted to put that out there.

[Justin Tseng]: No, I think that's, that's about it.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I thought someone else was in queue for me, but I'll go.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, you know, I hear what Councilor Lazzaro is hearing too.

[Justin Tseng]: That is something I've heard from people in different cities.

[Justin Tseng]: Although I have to say, I hear equally from people who live in cities with districts instead of wards that they also feel the same, that they also feel like they have a direct line to their Councilor.

[Justin Tseng]: Something that came up in a phone call today was that the wards don't necessarily align with the neighborhoods of the city as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And so at the edges, all in all, they make sense.

[Justin Tseng]: But at the edges, sometimes they can be arbitrary because we need to get the math to work out.

[Justin Tseng]: And then this was from someone you know this concern was from someone who is leaning towards word representation at the start of the call and you know he brought up the fact that.

[Justin Tseng]: he lives in one ward and feels like he's more of a resident of the other ward because that's where he goes to do his shopping and that's where things happen for him.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think a strength for me of the district system is that you at least have, and we can disagree about this, this is just an open conversation about policy, but strength of the district system for me is that I think most people will fall into a district that they feel a part of.

[Justin Tseng]: Whereas you risk, with ward representation people on the margins, feeling like they're not really a member of that ward because they live one street over.

[Justin Tseng]: And people who, certain wards might vote certain ways, and they might feel politically isolated in that sense as well, and not being able to run for office because of that.

[Justin Tseng]: It's just a complicated debate.

[Justin Tseng]: There's no right or wrong answer.

[Justin Tseng]: It's all imperfect answers.

[Justin Tseng]: I another concern I've heard, and I feel is compelling, and that ties to this is to is that the wind count for, you know, getting a Councilor elected in one ward might be dramatically different from getting a Councilor elected in another word.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, we've heard that perhaps moving toward representation will ease the problem, because, because there's more local engagement but

[Justin Tseng]: That Medford is a unique city to, we have one word that's essentially half the university.

[Justin Tseng]: We have a ward, that is half apartment blocks, and that in itself is a whole other challenge when it comes to campaigning to.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think part of what's affecting my decision.

[Justin Tseng]: leaning towards district over ward is that I don't think it's fair for one Councilor to be elected with, you know, 200 votes and another Councilor to need a thousand votes to get elected.

[Justin Tseng]: We actually see that happening at the Senate, right?

[Justin Tseng]: There's a lot of complaints about how the U.S.

[Justin Tseng]: Senate determines representation via geography more than representation via people who live and engage with the process.

[Justin Tseng]: And even though our wards and precincts are nominally drawn to be quite even a number, that's not reflected in other metrics in terms of who people are engaging for civic services, who's registered to vote, who's on the city census, right?

[Justin Tseng]: All those numbers are different.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's something I think our committee talked about in the governance committee, but something that we should consider as well.

[Justin Tseng]: moving forward.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, I mean, I've received constituent requests from top students, but by and large, their requests are with the Tufts administration, and not us.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think, you know, I've, I've heard about equity of workload.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's just, you know, Medford is a unique city in that sense.

[Justin Tseng]: There's much more to say.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I've heard a lot said about the survey that was conducted as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, I mean, I did surveys for a few years, for four years as a job.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, surveys are hard to design.

[Justin Tseng]: There's a very exact science to them.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, I appreciate that our Charter Study Committee did a survey.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's way better that they did a survey than not to have this information.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the risk is letting the survey dictate every decision that we make.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it can inform our decisions.

[Justin Tseng]: But as Councilor Callahan brought up, the questions aren't all precise, right?

[Justin Tseng]: There are 663 respondents.

[Justin Tseng]: Does that look like the city of Medford?

[Justin Tseng]: I know the Charter Study Committee did actually work really hard to try to reach constituencies that normally aren't reached in the political process.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, still, we see that the survey is very stacked towards homeowners in a way that is nowhere representative of our city as a whole.

[Justin Tseng]: It's stacked towards, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: It's stacked against people of color as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think those are, you know, things to consider when we talk about the survey you know it's important to me as someone who's worked in the field before to treat it with nuance.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, let's not throw it away.

[Justin Tseng]: It's helpful, but it's, we have to be careful when we analyze the data as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, something you know, Councilor Collins mentioned to to all of us how their residents who aren't completely in the know about charter review as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I've actually had

[Justin Tseng]: Those are a lot of the conversations that I've been having too, is me going to, for example, Asian community events and talking to residents about what I'm doing this year on the city council.

[Justin Tseng]: And obviously charter review has been the main thing on my docket for the last two months.

[Justin Tseng]: And when they hear about it, they're like, why are you changing it at all?

[Justin Tseng]: There's actually quite a lot of that.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of people don't understand that actually an all at large system isn't great.

[Justin Tseng]: And I still think it's not great.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think, actually, all at large, it's the worst system that we could have.

[Justin Tseng]: But there are people out there who aren't dissatisfied with things how they are and who we just have to have a real deep conversation about.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's something.

[Justin Tseng]: It's like when we talk about engaging the public on these issues, we need to engage with a deep conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: That's what democracy actually looks like, is when we have those roundtable discussions at community events.

[Justin Tseng]: And sometimes they might lead us to one answer.

[Justin Tseng]: Sometimes they might lead us to other answers.

[Justin Tseng]: That's natural.

[Justin Tseng]: And in democracy, not everyone agrees.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think those are just things to consider.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think on the role of it's been brought up that

[Justin Tseng]: what we're doing is not necessarily respectful of the Charter Study Committee, but I have to say, from the way I see it, is that we're adding to the product of the Charter Study Committee.

[Justin Tseng]: We haven't, as Councilor Collins noted earlier tonight, we haven't rewritten, but besides, you know, the proposals we've talked, the self-substantive edits that we're talking about tonight,

[Justin Tseng]: 90% of the charter is exactly the same document, if not 95%.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know that because I went through line by line last week and made red line edits.

[Justin Tseng]: And substantively, most of the ideas that are in there, again, 90% of the ideas that are in there are in the version of the document before us tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, where I see our role is coming in is due diligence.

[Justin Tseng]: It's us

[Justin Tseng]: doing the diligent review of the proposals, us adding in the really important experience of being city councilors ourselves, seeing the job in action and knowing how it works.

[Justin Tseng]: It is in reviewing the literature, again, the voting rights literature, the civil rights literature, the urban development, housing, suburban development literature out there that

[Justin Tseng]: that we heard from our governance committee didn't get covered in the charter study committees, you know, meeting in their discussions.

[Justin Tseng]: That's fine.

[Justin Tseng]: That's why we, you know, that's why we have a role in this as well.

[Justin Tseng]: That's why our governance committee reviewed the proposals so thoroughly, but there's lots to be said.

[Justin Tseng]: So I don't want to monopolize time.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll be very brief, just because I know we have more public comment.

[Justin Tseng]: My words were quoted.

[Justin Tseng]: They were quoted accurately.

[Justin Tseng]: They were quoted especially accurately when Mr. Givino said that I said Ward was better than At-Large as a system, because that's the context in which I said those things.

[Justin Tseng]: My words were quoted accurately when I said that we need a bigger council.

[Justin Tseng]: And that was actually one of the hesitations I had with the initial proposal as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I heard from constituents that they wanted more voices on the City Council, and I was happy that Councilor Leming made the suggestion to increase the seats from seven to nine at that first Governance Committee meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's really interesting to hear what I said in the meeting that wasn't quoted.

[Justin Tseng]: I really emphasized the need, my view, that we need to look at multi-member districts that rank choice.

[Justin Tseng]: I really emphasized the need for us to look at bigger districts in that meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: I remember that very crystal clear.

[Justin Tseng]: I remember bringing it up when I was canvassing around the same time and having a constituent who didn't see eye to eye on me on that.

[Justin Tseng]: I just looked at my campaign website.

[Justin Tseng]: It said that I could consider award representation.

[Justin Tseng]: And I very much still believe that this is moving towards pretty much a very similar model.

[Justin Tseng]: And I wanted, and I do think it should be said that maybe it's my age, but when I sat in that interview, I didn't get to any real content until the 30th minute.

[Justin Tseng]: And I've been giving the Charter Study Committee a lot of good faith, because I do think that they're doing their work in good faith, but

[Justin Tseng]: I don't I don't know if the best interview of a candidate are of an elected Councilors to not hear from them in the first not hear substance from them in the first 30 minutes.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng, I just wanted to quickly address the legal aspect of it makes sense for me because I'm a law student and I think about this all the time.

[Justin Tseng]: I just found case law where the Supreme Court explicitly backs a system like this.

[Justin Tseng]: where there was a merger of districts to make a larger district.

[Justin Tseng]: There was a mix of district in that large.

[Justin Tseng]: And the Supreme Court says that it is OK with the Voting Rights Act.

[Justin Tseng]: It says that that's not the test.

[Justin Tseng]: It says the test is an invidious discrimination.

[Justin Tseng]: And the case is Dutch v. Davis.

[Justin Tseng]: And this was settled in the 60s.

[Justin Tseng]: I have the data.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I think the

[Justin Tseng]: the speaker is misunderstanding the argument about racial justice.

[Justin Tseng]: The argument is that if we explicitly, if we go very small, we dilute, we end up hurting racial justice because we make politicians less accountable to different groups of voters.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why I'm positing that, and the literature posits, that a compromise model would be the best to handle the situation right now.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, so, with regards to the main minority majority majority minority district being being talked about, which is Wellington East Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: The district is the Ward seven is currently.

[Justin Tseng]: 55% white, oh, sorry, 48% white and the district would be 55%.

[Justin Tseng]: That's a difference of 7%, which, you know, I said earlier at a governance committee meeting, we can go back and forth about how significant that is.

[Justin Tseng]: One of the, I said earlier in this meeting that I think that we can remedy that problem because this draft charter actually gives us the power to redraw precincts and districts.

[Justin Tseng]: And so we can actually, having looked at the census block data, block by block in Medford, I think we can draw a district that is majority minority, even if that is the interest.

[Justin Tseng]: With regards to West Medford, this, give me one second.

[Justin Tseng]: West Medford is currently, so this is Ward 6.

[Justin Tseng]: Ward 6 is currently 72% white.

[Justin Tseng]: Under the district representation system, it would be 71% white.

[Justin Tseng]: So a difference of 1%.

[Justin Tseng]: I just have some technical things.

[Justin Tseng]: The first most important thing is I distributed the list of edits to the clerk.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes, yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: At the very start of the meeting, he then redistributed it to all the councilors.

[Justin Tseng]: So we'll have time to read it and we can walk through it if need be.

[Justin Tseng]: And I can explain the edits in even more detail to the councilors, but we're not on that part.

[Justin Tseng]: The motion on the table.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, it's the next motion.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not this one.

[Justin Tseng]: I, you know, I have a lot of respect for the call center people I've been working with them a lot, but it's true that there were also really important legal questions that.

[Justin Tseng]: they couldn't answer.

[Justin Tseng]: Right.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's important to note, there's one part of the charter, for example, that got a lot of scoffs in the audience when I brought it up.

[Justin Tseng]: But under temporary absence of the mayor, the text as is, the way you read it, does allow the city council by unanimous vote to remove the mayor permanently.

[Justin Tseng]: And I talked to a bunch of lawyers about it.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is the value of talking to lawyers about this kind of thing.

[Justin Tseng]: There are at least three legal rules that would support that reading, including the rule of surplusage, rule against titles, and the rejected proposal rule.

[Justin Tseng]: And these are three legal canons that judges use to interpret statutes.

[Justin Tseng]: So it's not, and the idea is,

[Justin Tseng]: The way that jurisprudence is moving in nowadays is that it's not enough to look at intention.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not enough to look at committee reports or what happened in a committee meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: The assumption is that the text rules.

[Justin Tseng]: So it's really important that we get the text right.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why I've suggested a bunch of those edits.

[Justin Tseng]: None of them are substantive.

[Justin Tseng]: None of them change anything that we talked about in this committee or in the governance committee.

[Justin Tseng]: They're just meant to align more with what both the Charter Study Committee and this in City Council wants.

[Justin Tseng]: And then on the Quincy proposals, or the Quincy comparison, I did look up the wards in Quincy are actually very large.

[Justin Tseng]: So they have six wards.

[Justin Tseng]: That's their representation on city council.

[Justin Tseng]: Each ward has about 16,000 to 17,000 people.

[Justin Tseng]: With the exact same proportion, we'd actually have less than four district Councilors in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: And so we're actually being more generous in there.

[Justin Tseng]: And some are both twice the size and yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll be brief.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, when I think about just taking a step back from this whole conversation, when I think about what people want in their elected officials, and look, I could be wrong about this, but I keep, I always hear about

[Justin Tseng]: people wanting their elected officials to act with integrity to do the thing that they think is right, even if it's politically unpopular, to follow data and to follow the law and not to disregard it.

[Justin Tseng]: And look, that's the ideal I grew up with.

[Justin Tseng]: And maybe that doesn't align with what people are feeling at home.

[Justin Tseng]: And to that, I apologize.

[Justin Tseng]: But

[Justin Tseng]: I can't not vote my conscience on this, and I urge all the Councilors to vote their conscience on it too, because I think what I said about morality was misconstrued.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think there is a right answer.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think this proposal or any proposal is perfect.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think we should vote our consciences.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's our job.

[Justin Tseng]: Look, we don't have to buy into every concern.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm concerned about some of the stuff that Councilor Collins brought up, the parochialism, about competitive elections.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm concerned also about what this means for racial justice.

[Justin Tseng]: And you don't have to find all those concerns compelling.

[Justin Tseng]: That's a democracy.

[Justin Tseng]: We live in a free world where we are going to disagree with each other.

[Justin Tseng]: That's not to say that those concerns don't exist.

[Justin Tseng]: And my voters voted for someone who is thinking about these issues and who is concerned about these things.

[Justin Tseng]: And if voters decide this fall that they don't agree with that, they're welcome not to vote for me.

[Justin Tseng]: I would love your vote, but look, if I'm not the right choice for you, then I'm not the right choice for you.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the last thing I want to say is that

[Justin Tseng]: This job isn't just being here on Tuesday night or Wednesday night.

[Justin Tseng]: I think there's a lot to this job about scheduling meetings about working on legislation about thinking through long term political impacts and long term social impacts and it's, it's not just that it's actually not just social politics, it's the economy, it's health, it's all these different things right.

[Justin Tseng]: the job is complicated.

[Justin Tseng]: And oftentimes, we see things that aren't really intuitive.

[Justin Tseng]: We see when, you know, certain structures that we think should be working actually lead to unintended consequences.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's our job, I think, as politicians and as elected, you know, public servants of this community to be able to respond to new information that we see, and to, to embody that in the decisions that we make.

[Justin Tseng]: I hope

[Justin Tseng]: that people in this community understand and want elected officials who will adjust their thoughts based on new information.

[Justin Tseng]: I can't say that that's true for everyone.

[Justin Tseng]: And maybe that's not exactly what all people want, but I think it's important to be said that when we encounter new information, we should be open-minded enough to adjust our priors.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that school committee council has looked at the school, the parts that would touch the school committee and school committee council is also looking, will be looking the next few days at it again.

[Justin Tseng]: I want to say I have no objections to having more, you know, council look at it, but yeah, we, we have it built it into the,

[Justin Tseng]: into the process.

[Justin Tseng]: If the question is whether the substantive edits are legal, there are actually two Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court cases that are quite parallel.

[Justin Tseng]: You just be Wellesley, and you will be rent bored.

[Justin Tseng]: of Peabody, I believe.

[Justin Tseng]: Those are similar cases with similar facts where the Supreme Court sided with their city or town councils.

[Justin Tseng]: I, what I understood from earlier this meeting was that we take the language and present it for the regular meeting, just to give Councilors days, a few days to look over.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that makes sense.

[Justin Tseng]: There's some, some language from the CFC, but it's not the call center language.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's unfortunate.

[Justin Tseng]: Right.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I think it goes to the point that several Councilors have made about, you know, in an ideal world, we would be able to do so much more.

[Justin Tseng]: And this, I believe, is a good product for a world where the state legislature does have, you know, restrictions on what cities can do.

[Justin Tseng]: I think part of what I'll say will depend on what we hear from the directors.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll hold that.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think in general, I just came in in person, but I was on Zoom the whole time.

[Justin Tseng]: It seems like this master plan is really important to making sure that we have a position that doesn't only work in one department, but can work cross departmentally.

[Justin Tseng]: Perhaps we look at job descriptions in that as well, making sure that we write

[Justin Tseng]: into the job description that this person will be collaborating with different departments.

[Justin Tseng]: Maybe there's some level of city council involvement too in ensuring some mechanisms that make sure that we can have that.

[Justin Tseng]: I think another, you know, when we talk about a master plan too, I think it'd be helpful for us as councillors to look into different municipalities that might have programs that

[Justin Tseng]: are more effective, that, you know, maybe they're not 100% what we're aspiring for, but programs that are closer to our end goal and to see how those municipalities got there in the first place, looking at, you know, what types of roles did they hire?

[Justin Tseng]: How did they structure it?

[Justin Tseng]: How can we acquire the resources and do that planning that we need to

[Justin Tseng]: over many years to reach that destination.

[Justin Tseng]: But I can't claim to know that much.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't profess to know the answers.

[Justin Tseng]: So I really do want to let the director and let the advocates really speak to this.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: The cards are something that I will cherish a lot.

[Justin Tseng]: Especially now going forward, there was a good few years where the only cards I really bought were Roots cards.

[Justin Tseng]: because they meant something more than a store-bought card.

[Justin Tseng]: I would see Ruth at West Bedford Community Center events, at artist fairs, and she was such a reliable, dependable presence at those places, and a really reliable, smiley face who I could talk to about issues that maybe I didn't understand because

[Justin Tseng]: of my life experience.

[Justin Tseng]: We grew up in very different places.

[Justin Tseng]: We talk about how West Medford has changed, how the community has changed, what makes the West Medford Community Center community stick together so close, what's ticking there.

[Justin Tseng]: And I've just learned so much from Ruth.

[Justin Tseng]: And every time I would look at the cards as they sent them out,

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, I would get reminded, you know, of the fact that I'm supporting a friend and supporting a local business, a local artist here in Medford too.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why for me, over those years, those were the cards I bought and those were the cards I really cherish.

[Justin Tseng]: is such a core presence in the West Medford community.

[Justin Tseng]: And when she passed, so many people talked to me about the experiences, the really happy experiences that they had with her.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm very grateful for you, President Bears, for putting this on the agenda and for giving us a chance to talk about our happy memories of her.

[Justin Tseng]: Go to Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: I really can't speak to Bob even, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: There's such a life that was lived and such a dedication to his community that we really ought to respect.

[Justin Tseng]: I can, however, speak to my short experience with Bob on the school committee, and I think that's a testament to how long he served our city.

[Justin Tseng]: I never intersected with Georgia on the school committee, but I did intersect with Bob.

[Justin Tseng]: And as a student rep for the school committee, he was always really

[Justin Tseng]: a great guide in showing me the ropes, showing me the ropes of how things worked on the school committee and what questions we should be asking of our leaders in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: So I wanted to send my condolences to his family as well, and to remember Bob for the great work that he did in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: But before we get there, are there any comments from city councilors either generally or on section four dash one on composition, term of office or eligibility?

[Justin Tseng]: Recognizing president

[Justin Tseng]: bears.

[Justin Tseng]: Recognizing Councilor Lazzaro.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Lazzaro, I see Councilor Scarpelli.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to note that we also have school committee member Nicole Branley here in the audience with us today.

[Justin Tseng]: I have been, and as I noted before, oh, okay.

[Justin Tseng]: I have been in talks and former school committee member Sharon Hayes too.

[Justin Tseng]: I have

[Justin Tseng]: been talking to members of our state delegation as well.

[Justin Tseng]: The general gist is that it is in the council's purview to make edits to the city charter, even if those edits are substantive.

[Justin Tseng]: When it comes to likelihood of passage or not, it's more about whether the model being proposed by the city council is something that the state legislature has seen and passed before.

[Justin Tseng]: Before I move on to comments, written comments from school committee members, are there any other Councilors who'd like to talk on this issue more specifically about the mayor being chair of the school committee?

[Justin Tseng]: seeing none on Zoom or in person, vice, I'm gonna read what vice chair Jenny Graham has written to me or in this committee about school committee structure.

[Justin Tseng]: One of the most concerning aspects of the proposed charter is the provision in article four that allows the mayor to serve as the chair and a voting member of the school committee.

[Justin Tseng]: The school committee's primary responsibility is to focus solely on the education needs of Medford's children.

[Justin Tseng]: allowing the mayor to continue to hold a voting role, but undermine this critical separation.

[Justin Tseng]: I agree, of course, that there needs to be a solid working relationship between the school committee and the chair and value my own relationship with the current mayor immensely.

[Justin Tseng]: Too often, though, there are clear signs of a conflict of interest between the role of the mayor of the city and the role of the mayor as the chair.

[Justin Tseng]: For practical purposes, I have observed this when it comes time to discussions of compensation and contracting, and most specifically at budget time.

[Justin Tseng]: For many years in Medford, the school committee never asked for a penny more than the city had to give.

[Justin Tseng]: Further, when I asked about the process and

[Justin Tseng]: how the school committee received the number from the city because surely that's how such complete alignment occurs in my mind.

[Justin Tseng]: I was met with seasoned members insisting that this wasn't how it worked at all.

[Justin Tseng]: In my five years, I've never once seen this alignment because the school committee has prioritized putting forward budget requests that reflect our need as the starting point.

[Justin Tseng]: This step was skipped entirely for many years to the detriment of our schools.

[Justin Tseng]: If I were a mayor, I can completely understand why such alignment would be desirable, but doing so undermines authority and responsibility of the committee.

[Justin Tseng]: This is perhaps the most important rationale for removing the mayor from the school committee.

[Justin Tseng]: The Charter Study Committee's own survey stated that only 20% of respondents believed that the mayor should be the chair of a school committee.

[Justin Tseng]: In addition, two-year terms are simply too short to cultivate the depth of experience and long-term vision necessary for effective governance in education.

[Justin Tseng]: Short terms without the stability of longer terms make it difficult to implement meaningful change and may introduce constant disruptions.

[Justin Tseng]: This next section is more about ward and district organizations, so I'm gonna move on to school committee member Rousseau's comment.

[Justin Tseng]: on the mayor being the chair of the school committee, the mayor should not serve as the chair of the school committee.

[Justin Tseng]: The rationale for maintaining this arrangement seems to downplay the significance of the school committee, treating it as just another committee to oversee.

[Justin Tseng]: In reality, being the chair of the school committee is a substantial responsibility.

[Justin Tseng]: Additionally, there is a widespread misunderstanding regarding the mayor's authority, with many from the public to other elected officials in school and municipal employees believing it exceeds that of other school committee members.

[Justin Tseng]: This misconception creates significant issues.

[Justin Tseng]: It's now crucial more than ever for elected officials to operate strictly within the legal authority granted to them rather than any authority they choose to assert.

[Justin Tseng]: the structure of the school committee and city council should be consistent.

[Justin Tseng]: Whether it is entirely at large, entirely ward based.

[Justin Tseng]: This is also about the ward district organization.

[Justin Tseng]: from a school committee member in Tapa.

[Justin Tseng]: I have the following comment in regards to the mayor's seat on the committee.

[Justin Tseng]: I am impartial.

[Justin Tseng]: I do see the benefit of both aspects as presented by some of my colleagues on social media.

[Justin Tseng]: I could very well see the benefit of having a seventh seat for someone to run for in the school committee race.

[Justin Tseng]: With that being said, I did come in seventh last election, so maybe I have a bias towards that proposition.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes, President Burrs, would you be able to?

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, he's not in the meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh.

[Justin Tseng]: Four in the affirmative, one in the negative.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, oh, sorry.

[Justin Tseng]: President Bears?

[Justin Tseng]: 4 in affirmative, 1 in the negative.

[Justin Tseng]: Motion passes.

[Justin Tseng]: Sorry, I just read your thing.

[Justin Tseng]: Do we have any comments from Councilors on ward representation for the schools?

[Justin Tseng]: I have some comments from sitting school committee members.

[Justin Tseng]: I saw President Bears first and then Councilor Lazzaro.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Recognizing council Zorro.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Lazzaro.

[Justin Tseng]: Do we have any other comments from council members before we move on to the comments from school committee members?

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing none, are there any sitting school committee members either in person or online who'd like to comment on ward versus district representation for a school committee?

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing none, I'm going to move to the sitting committee members' written comments first, and then I'll move on to public participation.

[Justin Tseng]: On ward representation, this is from Vice Chair Graham.

[Justin Tseng]: As the council considers their organization of the city into districts, I strongly urge that the boundaries for both the city council and school committee be aligned.

[Justin Tseng]: The government should work for its people.

[Justin Tseng]: The very first step in that process is in knowing who is there to support you.

[Justin Tseng]: Having two different structures will be confusing and I can't see the value it will provide to our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: I agree that the school committee should continue to be comprised of seven and would support such a size for the council as well.

[Justin Tseng]: The current proposal, with its focus on district-based school representation, does not fully account for the practical realities of our school system.

[Justin Tseng]: At the middle and high school levels, every school committee member is responsible for decisions affecting all students, regardless of district.

[Justin Tseng]: This effectively makes their role smaller to that of an at-large member, serving all students.

[Justin Tseng]: At the elementary school level, the reality is that students often attend schools that fall outside the boundaries of their proposed district, pushing the responsibility for those students onto at-large members.

[Justin Tseng]: This model does not reflect the interconnectedness of the issues we face across all grade levels and undermines the unity of the community.

[Justin Tseng]: Our community cannot afford to deepen the divisions between our schools.

[Justin Tseng]: Medford students deserve equal opportunities for high quality education regardless of where they live.

[Justin Tseng]: A district based approach could risk exacerbating existing tensions between our school communities, something we are actively working to bridge.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't have perfect answers here because I am very interested in increasing representation of our elected officials and ensuring all corners of our city are reflected in our school committee.

[Justin Tseng]: I am further interested in creating pathways to service that are not as prohibitively expensive for candidates.

[Justin Tseng]: I simply highlight that achieving the goals of representation will present other practical problems.

[Justin Tseng]: I have this following comment from member Rousseau.

[Justin Tseng]: The structure of the school committee and city council should be consistent, whether it is entirely at-large, entirely ward-based, or a combination of district, ward, plus at-large members.

[Justin Tseng]: While I do not have a strong preference for a specific model, the district two or plus three at large members model seems reasonable.

[Justin Tseng]: Regardless of the chosen model, it should mirror the council structure to avoid confusion among voters who already struggle to understand our government structure without multiple formats within a single city.

[Justin Tseng]: A child growing up next door to me will attend one elementary school, one middle school, and our one high school.

[Justin Tseng]: The physical location of these schools is irrelevant for representation.

[Justin Tseng]: What matters is where the resident lives.

[Justin Tseng]: A school located in my ward is no more, quote, my school than any other when it comes to representing my constituents.

[Justin Tseng]: There may be an instinctual belief that ward-based school committee representation offers something unique compared to at-large representation, but this does not hold up when considering a resident's perspective as their child progresses through the school system.

[Justin Tseng]: No elected official can reside in a ward or district encompassing all the schools a child will attend.

[Justin Tseng]: So there is no logical basis for arguments centered on the physical location of schools.

[Justin Tseng]: From member Intoppa, I have, in regards to the combined ward representation, I feel conflicted.

[Justin Tseng]: As an independent candidate, only having to campaign physically in my respective territory is a significant financial and time advantage.

[Justin Tseng]: That, however, should not be the driving factor in implementing ward or combined ward representation.

[Justin Tseng]: I only acknowledge this as fact and my immediate reaction to that change.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we also need to do important work to acknowledge that even though members may represent different word combinations.

[Justin Tseng]: that the members do not only represent those within that district that attend said schools.

[Justin Tseng]: Ward representation makes more sense to me for the city council.

[Justin Tseng]: However, I feel the implementation of a majority ward-based representation school committee could make it easier for community members to relay their concerns to at least one designated individual.

[Justin Tseng]: It almost feels more personalized.

[Justin Tseng]: I digress.

[Justin Tseng]: I also see member Olapade has his hand raised on Zoom.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'll ask you to unmute.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, member Olpade.

[Justin Tseng]: Moving on to public participation.

[Justin Tseng]: I know I saw some hands in the crowd.

[Justin Tseng]: If you're on Zoom again, please raise your hand so I can see it.

[Justin Tseng]: Name and address for the record, please.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, sorry.

[Justin Tseng]: No, I've done it.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Member Ranley.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Mr. Dixon.

[Justin Tseng]: Any other comments from the members of the public, either on Zoom or in person?

[Justin Tseng]: Any other comments from councillors?

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I see Councilor Holland said, do you still wanna speak?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, are there any other comments from Councilors, we, we don't have any motions on the floor, I see two hands raised, but I will.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to give Councilors a chance to speak.

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing none, I'll take these two comments, and then if there are no motions, we should move on to the next section.

[Justin Tseng]: Gaston Fiore, I'm gonna ask you to unmute.

[Justin Tseng]: When you unmute, can you give us your name and address for the record, please?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Zachary Chertok.

[Justin Tseng]: Let me ask you to unmute once you're on mute, name and address for the record, please.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Marie Izzo, I'm gonna ask you to unmute, name and address for the record, please, once you unmute.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Marie.

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing no other hands from Councilors or on Zoom from members of the public, there are no motions on the floor.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this is, I want to remind the public, the City Council as a whole has not made a final decision on the type of, the composition of the representation yet, and that we will be picking this up at the next committee, the whole meeting on this topic.

[Justin Tseng]: I do have one more comment that I neglected to read.

[Justin Tseng]: And then I think we can move on.

[Justin Tseng]: It seems like we can move on to the next section.

[Justin Tseng]: But this is part of Vice Chair Graham's comments on section 4.1.

[Justin Tseng]: Two-year terms are simply too short to cultivate the depth of experience and long-term vision necessary for effective governance and education.

[Justin Tseng]: Short terms without the stability of longer terms make it difficult to implement meaningful change and introduce constant disruptions.

[Justin Tseng]: If a district ward and at-large structure remains, perhaps the council should consider extending at-large terms to four years and align with the mayor's term and re-election pathway.

[Justin Tseng]: This could help foster stability, ensuring that school community members can focus on long-term educational goals, as importantly, with such short terms, a recall provision would be counterproductive, potentially politicizing our work.

[Justin Tseng]: That being said, I just wanted to make sure I didn't miss anything from comments that were sent in from elected officials.

[Justin Tseng]: Do we have any other comments on Section 4-1 before we move on to Section 4-2?

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing none, section 4-2, school committee organization, chair, vice chair, and clerk, secretary.

[Justin Tseng]: I have some comments from school committee members, but are there any comments from city council members before I get to those?

[Justin Tseng]: seeing none in person, seeing none on Zoom.

[Justin Tseng]: Let me read what Vice Chair Graham has sent.

[Justin Tseng]: She said, the current language in section 4-2, which seeks to dictate the structure of how our body operates and elects its leaders is another significant concern.

[Justin Tseng]: The school committee should have the autonomy to choose how its members are elected.

[Justin Tseng]: By dictating the manner of internal elections, the charter would intrude upon the committee's ability to organize itself to best meet the needs of Medford's children.

[Justin Tseng]: Our responsibility is to put students first and to do that, the school committee needs the flexibility to make decisions about our governance that will allow us to serve students best.

[Justin Tseng]: From member Rousseau, we have a few comments.

[Justin Tseng]: They're accompanied by some recommendations.

[Justin Tseng]: The first one is clerical.

[Justin Tseng]: He suggests a change to replace clerk parentheses secretary with secretary parentheses clerk to ensure consistency with the rest of the document.

[Justin Tseng]: The next comment is

[Justin Tseng]: to is on section subsection a of this of the draft charter and he suggests to add the word chair to the list of positions to be selected by school committee members.

[Justin Tseng]: His rationale is that the chair should be elected by the body as the chair is, by definition, the servant of the body.

[Justin Tseng]: This is another reason why the chair should not be the mayor if the mayor is not deemed a suitable chair or is not serving the body.

[Justin Tseng]: Effectively, there would be no recourse to select a different chair.

[Justin Tseng]: Electing the chair ensures accountability and responsiveness to the needs of the community.

[Justin Tseng]: He also suggests striking the phrase, who will serve for one year, which is at the very end of that subsection.

[Justin Tseng]: He says, the school committee should have the autonomy to determine the duration of service for its leadership positions rather than having it dictated by the charter.

[Justin Tseng]: Notably, the charter does not impose similar structural controls on the city council.

[Justin Tseng]: It seems inconsistent that one elected body is allowed to decide its organizational structure while another is not.

[Justin Tseng]: from member Intapa.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, I missed a few comments there.

[Justin Tseng]: When it comes to subsection B, member Ruseau, he is suggesting that we strike the words with the assistant of the superintendent of schools and replace it with the chair.

[Justin Tseng]: He said, basic to Robert's rules of order, the chair is responsible for setting the agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: Although the body can override it since the agenda ultimately belongs to the body.

[Justin Tseng]: The superintendent works for the committee and it is the school committee that sets the agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: He also suggests striking and to decide all questions of order.

[Justin Tseng]: In the same subsection, he said, Robert's rules of order makes clear that while the chair does decide all questions of order, the body may override the chair by questioning the ruling of the chair.

[Justin Tseng]: This language implies that the rulings of the questions of order belong only to the chair and removes the premise that the chair is a servant of the body.

[Justin Tseng]: He suggests also striking the sentence, the chair shall appoint members to various subcommittees after seeking each member's views regarding interest and availability, said subcommittee appointments are the responsibility of the entire school committee, not just one individual.

[Justin Tseng]: The chair is meant to serve the body, not to dictate its organization.

[Justin Tseng]: And with regards to subsection C, I believe, or this is also subsection B,

[Justin Tseng]: He's suggesting to strike the section that says provided, however, that a city of provided, however, that a city officer or other city employee who has vacated a position in order to

[Justin Tseng]: In order to return to the same office or position of city employment held at the same time, the position was vacated if it has remained vacant, but shall not be eligible for any other municipal position until at least one year after the end of service as a member of the school committee.

[Justin Tseng]: And he says that this restriction has not been applied to the city council, indicating an inconsistency in how the charter governs different elected bodies.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, I think that was under 4-3, prohibitions, but it was labeled to be under 4-2.

[Justin Tseng]: So apologies for that.

[Justin Tseng]: that section 4-2 seems like basic Roberts rules of order, and I see no needed adjustments.

[Justin Tseng]: That's all the written comments I have.

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing none, recognizing Councilor Lazzaro.

[Justin Tseng]: I do have written comments from school committee members on this provision, but I will defer to councilors first.

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing no, President Bears?

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: Going to Vice Chair Graham's comment on section 4-5.

[Justin Tseng]: Section 4-5 inaccurately describes the hiring process for key positions within the school committee.

[Justin Tseng]: The school committee under Massachusetts law holds the authority to directly hire the business manager, director of special education, school physician, and legal counsel.

[Justin Tseng]: These positions are not hired at the recommendation of the superintendent.

[Justin Tseng]: It is essential that this language be revised to reflect your legal authority and maintain clarity on the roles of both the school committee and the superintendent.

[Justin Tseng]: This distinction is critical to preserving the school committee's oversight and accountability in these areas.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's from Vice Chair Graham.

[Justin Tseng]: President Bears mentioned a comment from Member Ruseau, which I will read.

[Justin Tseng]: He says, in subsection B, sub-subsection B,

[Justin Tseng]: three, so the very end of the section, he is asking us to, it's a clerical change, to change the word department to system, saying that, he says, the school system is not a department of the city of Medford and this change will accurately reflect its status.

[Justin Tseng]: I could be corrected on this.

[Justin Tseng]: And the judges or juries, but this is a civil matter, whoever is deciding will probably use a standard of what seems most objective to determine reasonableness.

[Justin Tseng]: Moving on to section 4-6, filling of vacancies.

[Justin Tseng]: I do have some comments from members.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll defer to councilors first.

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing none.

[Justin Tseng]: Let me read what has been sent in on 4-6.

[Justin Tseng]: The member Rousseau, he's not making a recommendation, but he's pointing out, there's a comment about the point, the line that says vacancy shall be immediately sworn and shall serve for the remainder of the current term.

[Justin Tseng]: Just to give people context, because I know this is kind of a long paragraph, essentially this is saying that if a vacancy shows up on the school committee before the next election,

[Justin Tseng]: And I believe this is given a certain time frame.

[Justin Tseng]: So essentially what the current charter lets us do is the school committee in the city council would fill the vacancy.

[Justin Tseng]: But then when it comes time to the next regular election, we assume that someone's going to be elected to that position, could be the same person, could be someone different.

[Justin Tseng]: And so what the current charter asks us to do is swear in that person who's elected immediately.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, instead of with the rest of the school committee in the City Council and the issue that was identified is that, um, Member Ruseau says that the suggested process is inefficient and burdensome.

[Justin Tseng]: School community members undergo extensive orientation, including legal and or other training necessary for effectiveness.

[Justin Tseng]: State law mandates attendance at a course offered by our professional association early in our first term.

[Justin Tseng]: Having this process occur once in November and then again in January is wasteful.

[Justin Tseng]: and the superintendent of schools manages this process of orientation.

[Justin Tseng]: Additionally, having two separate inauguration slash swearing in timeframes lacks rationale and is unfair to those being sworn in immediately after the election.

[Justin Tseng]: So that was

[Justin Tseng]: from Member Ruseau.

[Justin Tseng]: We also have a comment from Member Intoppa and then I know Chair McDonald sent me a clarification.

[Justin Tseng]: So Member Intoppa says, I'm also delighted to see in addition to vacancies being filled,

[Justin Tseng]: As you may know, my appointment slash election to the committee was filled with uncertainties waving wavering past precedent and consistent back and forth without knowing proper order as the city current city charter does not define how vacancies are filled.

[Justin Tseng]: It led to a serious lag in my adoption to the committee, which, as you know, was rapidly approaching budget season.

[Justin Tseng]: Our member in Taupo notes to me right now that it's not stated in the charter what happens and that we have to go through past precedent to find out how to fill that slot.

[Justin Tseng]: He further adds

[Justin Tseng]: Does 4-6B have a typo in stating that they will be referred to as office of ward Councilor, 4-6A refers to them as office of school committee at large.

[Justin Tseng]: Maybe I did not read the definition section well enough.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is what Chair McDonald emailed me to say that there is a clerical error here.

[Justin Tseng]: So we should make a, I would recommend to the committee that someone make a motion to fix that error.

[Justin Tseng]: So in 4-6B, it says Office of Ward Councilor instead of Office of School Committee at large.

[Justin Tseng]: B as in boy.

[Justin Tseng]: He also said, I do however have slight issues with section four dash six see those who are appointed by the committee slash Council if no one else is willing or eligible in regards to the candidate filling the slot not being labeled as candidate for reelection, it feels a disservice to the work that they have been doing.

[Justin Tseng]: Of course, they weren't chosen by the voters.

[Justin Tseng]: targets a member of, let's not even say an elected official, but a member of the public or a member of the city staff, city or school staff, I guess.

[Justin Tseng]: Is that something that would be allowed with this vehicle?

[Justin Tseng]: And I, there's a followup from President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: OK.

[Justin Tseng]: I do have a follow-up on all of that, though.

[Justin Tseng]: How does this interact with the Supreme Judicial Court ruling that basically, it's, I mean, super expansive about public speech in the forum like this, basically just saying, I mean, the line is death threats, essentially, and hateful speech.

[Justin Tseng]: Which has happened, by the way.

[Justin Tseng]: What?

[Justin Tseng]: Which has happened.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes, yeah, which has happened.

[Justin Tseng]: Sorry?

[Justin Tseng]: I didn't hear that.

[Justin Tseng]: But the section doesn't say anything about being able to review free petitions or the Supreme Court judicial court ruling on free speech and in public forums.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay, yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I think we're just talking past each other.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm not even necessarily opposed to the free petition.

[Justin Tseng]: I just want to be able to sort out the legal logistics and hypotheticals that may come up.

[Justin Tseng]: Can we then be sued for limiting someone's free speech in a public forum?

[Justin Tseng]: But it seems like there are contradictory, and it could be wrong, but it seems like there are contradictory state laws in the state constitution about what is okay for free speech and what's okay for complaining about HR and everything.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, it could be that the state law is unconstitutional too.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Collins, I know you've been waiting a long time.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: For what reason?

[Justin Tseng]: I couldn't hear it.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't want to put words in the vice president's mouth.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes, yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: Can you repeat the rationale?

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think it's their fault.

[Justin Tseng]: That's good.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, yeah, that's good.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: Can you just summarize what you said?

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: I saw Councilor Lazzaro, Leming, and then Scarpelli.

[Justin Tseng]: I do see hands from a lot of people right now, but I do want to make sure that the other elected officials who would be affected by this petition get their comments read too.

[Justin Tseng]: Vice Chair Graham says, the inclusion of free petitions in section 8-1 presents a further challenge.

[Justin Tseng]: The school committee and I personally believe in the importance of public input.

[Justin Tseng]: However, the ability to obstruct the functioning of school community via free petitions would undermine the efficiency and effectiveness of the educational process.

[Justin Tseng]: Our responsibility to Medford's children requires us to make timely thoughtful decisions about budgets policies and educational initiatives, the introduction of national style politics and special interest group influence could push priorities that don't align with immediate needs of our students.

[Justin Tseng]: National politics aside, we are already seeing escalating rhetoric here in Medford that's dangerous.

[Justin Tseng]: Criticism of our elected officials is the bedrock of democracy, but personal attacks and threats are being normalized here in a way that is very concerning.

[Justin Tseng]: Adding this additional and escalated pathway to air disagreements will only escalate the rhetoric, and I fear that continuing to allow our discourse to escalate rather than allowing duly elected officials to do their work could lead to a physically dangerous situation.

[Justin Tseng]: We should take this risk very seriously.

[Justin Tseng]: Additionally, this dynamic could discourage qualified individuals from running for the school committee, as the constant interference from petitions would make it harder for those willing to serve with the focus on student needs to feel and to feel supported in the role.

[Justin Tseng]: The school committee needs to ensure that our focus remains on our students, and free petitions should not be allowed to distract from that critical goal.

[Justin Tseng]: from member Ruseau.

[Justin Tseng]: His recommendation is to strike the whole section, and his rationale is that he said, I do not believe the section should be included at all.

[Justin Tseng]: Elections occur every two years, which is a relatively short period.

[Justin Tseng]: The thresholds set here are low enough to potentially trap the school committee in a continuous cycle of responding to groups acting in bad faith.

[Justin Tseng]: aiming to disrupt the committee's work.

[Justin Tseng]: Additionally, there is no provision to halt a petition that is illegal or places the district in legal jeopardy, such as the one that targets district employees or students.

[Justin Tseng]: So those are the written comments I received.

[Justin Tseng]: I know Councilor Leming has been waiting a long time, and then Councilor Scarpelli.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Scarbone.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, President Bears I think to your point, I think much of this reads like it was written for like a four year mayoral term and then the two year aspect was added in after the fact so with the point that with the few lines that I just pointed out for me it reads like you know if the mayor.

[Justin Tseng]: faces a recall election, and it's two years into her term, or their term, and, you know, the city election is within 120 days, and you hold it with the municipal election with which you're electing everyone else.

[Justin Tseng]: That's, I think, what the purpose was for.

[Justin Tseng]: But then I think us, or I think Medford trying to shove in two-year offices to the recall process as well, has made that, those few lines really confusing.

[Justin Tseng]: Just, yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: Never say never.

[Justin Tseng]: If you want my opinion on it, I am worried that us being unspecific about this will be taken wrongly by the courts.

[Justin Tseng]: I think one of the most common rules of statutory interpretation by a judge is to render, it's called the rule against surplusage.

[Justin Tseng]: And basically, it assumes that as a legislature, whatever we pass, we mean.

[Justin Tseng]: And whatever extra words we might add, we mean those words as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And so us keeping the words as a whole in there very heavily implies to a judge that we want to allow.

[Justin Tseng]: We want to allow.

[Justin Tseng]: It could be inferred.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, it could be inferred.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think most court decisions I read fall that way.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, but I mean, the question is, has there been much litigation about that line and those charters?

[Justin Tseng]: Right.

[Justin Tseng]: We would be the precedent.

[Justin Tseng]: I do have written feedback from other elected officials on this stuff, but Councilor Leming, I recognize you first, and then we'll move on to that.

[Justin Tseng]: I think President Burr is the same, given that you already satisfied that hurdle.

[Justin Tseng]: I will say, I've kept my opinions pretty close, you know, just close to my chest since I'm running this meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: I do think there is a difference, even though there is a difference between getting the signatures in the first place and the vote actually being successful, I think it's worth the council talking about

[Justin Tseng]: potential political instability that comes around when you have that signature driving process in the first place that challenges the mandate of the person sitting in office.

[Justin Tseng]: Just wanted to make that point.

[Justin Tseng]: And I do fear that driving away potential candidates for office as well, particularly from marginalized backgrounds or female candidates, to be honest, because that's a group of people that are most affected by stuff like that.

[Justin Tseng]: Sorry, my computer.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not liking the long meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: Similarly, 8-4, specifically the inclusion of, quote, as a whole in item three, creates another potential disruption to the work of the school committee, allowing voters to strike parts of the budget could severely limit our ability to operate effectively, making it difficult to implement long-term plans or allocate resources appropriately.

[Justin Tseng]: A budget must support the needs of every student and breaking it apart at the discretion of voters could lead to significant instability.

[Justin Tseng]: I urge the removal of this language to protect the integrity of the budgeting process.

[Justin Tseng]: That's the only comment I haven't read from Vice Chair Graham on Article 8.

[Justin Tseng]: From Member Ruseau, I have

[Justin Tseng]: on, I've read the 8.1, 8-1 brief petition comment.

[Justin Tseng]: Section 8-4 in the eligible measures, very similar.

[Justin Tseng]: The member Ruseau is suggesting us to strike the words as a whole, the rationale being this suggests that measures to strike parts of the school committee budget would be permitted.

[Justin Tseng]: Allowing the public to alter our budget in this manner could lead to significant issues.

[Justin Tseng]: Such changes could have unintended consequences, including hindering our ability to meet obligations to our union partners.

[Justin Tseng]: This would create a chaotic situation, undermining the careful planning that goes into budget preparation.

[Justin Tseng]: Also applying to this section, he says, this is about subsection eight, or seven, he's asked,

[Justin Tseng]: He's suggesting that we strike that point.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'll read that point so people know what we're talking about.

[Justin Tseng]: The point is to make ineligible a proceeding providing for the submission or referral to the voters at an election.

[Justin Tseng]: Sorry, I read that wrong.

[Justin Tseng]: I read point eight.

[Justin Tseng]: A proceeding repealing or rescinding a measure or part of it that is protested by a referendum procedures.

[Justin Tseng]: His comment is that this approach seems anti-democratic.

[Justin Tseng]: If we allow one group of citizens the ability to change policy, it stands to reason that another group should have the same freedom to alter policy, even if it means reverting to a previous policy or shifting in a different direction.

[Justin Tseng]: on the recall.

[Justin Tseng]: On part B, he is suggesting that we strike the words for the office of mayor or councillor at large and at least 300 voters for any other elected officials.

[Justin Tseng]: The issue he's identified is that

[Justin Tseng]: The threshold for recalling school committee members is set lower than that of four city councilors.

[Justin Tseng]: This discrepancy makes no sense and lacks justification.

[Justin Tseng]: The thresholds for recall should be the same for all elected positions to ensure consistency and fairness.

[Justin Tseng]: Additionally, any other, quote, any other elected official can only mean school committee members as we are the only other elected officials in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe this next part comes from

[Justin Tseng]: lines eight to 11 on page 31, that would be point D. He's suggesting that we strike the sentence that says, should the person be a candidate in the subsequent election, that person will not be allowed to have, quote, candidate for reelection appear on the ballot at such election.

[Justin Tseng]: The rationale, he says, is that this provision is unnecessarily punitive.

[Justin Tseng]: If a recall effort fails and the individual is not unseated, it is unjust to impose the arbitrary consequence of losing their candidate for a re-election designation on the ballot.

[Justin Tseng]: This rule could be exploited by groups aiming to systematically strip the designation from candidates they dislike, even if they anticipate the recall will not succeed.

[Justin Tseng]: A failed recall should have no consequence for the elected official who succeeds in remaining in office.

[Justin Tseng]: Same page, line 15, so this is point E. He is suggesting us to replace the word recalled with the phrase removed from office, saying that he doesn't think most people would know what recalled means.

[Justin Tseng]: So suggesting that removed from office would be a clearer phrase to put on the ballot.

[Justin Tseng]: So those are the written comments I have.
