[Justin Tseng]: Vice Chair, Vice Chair Graham says on section nine dash five representation of the school committee.

[Justin Tseng]: Finally, it is imperative that Section 9-5 includes equal representation from the school committee, as we are the third branch of government in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: Our role in overseeing the education of Medford's children is of utmost importance, and we must have a voice in any decisions that impact the functioning of the city as a whole.

[Justin Tseng]: As an independent governing body with direct responsibility for the education and well-being of our students, it is critical that the school committee is adequately represented in these discussions.

[Justin Tseng]: Many of the items and issues I outlined in this memo could have been avoided with school committee representation during the development process.

[Justin Tseng]: And then the comments I have from Member Ruseau.

[Justin Tseng]: On the same section on the periodic review of the charter, he suggests a change from five appointees of the mayor, three appointees of the city council president, one appointee by the school committee vice chair, to three appointees of the mayor, three appointees of the city council, and three appointees of the school committee.

[Justin Tseng]: His rationale is that the school committee is a co-equal branch of government according to the organizational chart.

[Justin Tseng]: Additionally, this council president and school committee vice chair or chair, if not the mayor, should not hold such power.

[Justin Tseng]: These individuals are servants of the body.

[Justin Tseng]: These not to run the show, dictate policy or make unilateral decisions.

[Justin Tseng]: Decision-making authority should only be exercised by these leaders if explicitly authorized by the body.

[Justin Tseng]: He also notes that in this section of the charter, there's no provision for the replacement of members, whether they voluntarily leave or are asked to leave by a majority vote of the charter committee.

[Justin Tseng]: He also suggests striking the sentence appointing the mayor as chair of the special committee, saying that the chair is a servant of the body.

[Justin Tseng]: And in this case, the charter review committee should select their own chair and be able to replace said chair as they see fit.

[Justin Tseng]: No one person should appoint a chair ever.

[Justin Tseng]: I know the problem that you're referring to, and part of it is because we don't have a standardized process right now.

[Justin Tseng]: We have a motion

[Justin Tseng]: from President Bears on amendments to 9-5, seconded by Councilor Lazzaro.

[Justin Tseng]: Mr. Clerk, whenever you're ready.

[Justin Tseng]: Four in favor, one opposed motion passes.

[Justin Tseng]: Are there any comments on article 10?

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: To note for the Committee of the Whole, the City Council number of members thing, it's a clerical thing, but once we decide, once we make a final recommendation of the Committee of the Whole meeting, we should look to address that number.

[Justin Tseng]: I know, Councilor Bears, you mentioned an amendment for, to session one?

[Justin Tseng]: But essentially the gist of them, if I remember- They're school committee related definitions.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, right, right, right.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Black History in Medford goes back a long, long time to the founding of our city when

[Justin Tseng]: very unfortunately, slaves were brought here to work in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: We see from at the Brooks Estate, we have Pomp's Wall, a wall that was created that was built by an enslaved man.

[Justin Tseng]: We see that that black history reflected in the heroic work of Belinda Sutton.

[Justin Tseng]: who successfully sued, took the initiative and sued for her rights to reparations and received those reparations, forming the first known legal case in North America when it came to freed slaves, getting reparations for their time as slaves, and setting a legal guideline, a baseline for the rights of freed slaves.

[Justin Tseng]: This history continues through the last few centuries, we have the our historical black community and West Bedford who form such a rich tapestry of our life here in Medford mass.

[Justin Tseng]: the work of the West Medford Community Center and uplifting that community and bringing us all together and making sure that Black history isn't just something that we tokenize and something that we shove into a corner, but that Black history is something that we all celebrate and recognize.

[Justin Tseng]: And on that note, I do also want to note that our city on February 17th, Monday, February 17th, 2025, that's President's Day, I believe,

[Justin Tseng]: From 1030 to 1.30pm in these chambers, we will have a celebration for Black History Month focused on African Americans and labor.

[Justin Tseng]: And that event is also in conjunction with the West Medford Community Center.

[Justin Tseng]: I also wanted to note, I think it's the elephant in the room, the attacks on diversity happening nationally and from the federal government in particular, trying to wipe away, erase, delete the idea of black history, the idea that of the histories and struggles of different ethnic groups in this country who all form what we all are,

[Justin Tseng]: our story as Americans here.

[Justin Tseng]: I've been glad to talk to neighbors about this, to hear from different elected officials across the city and different offices about our commitment to diversity, to equity, and to inclusion, particularly in our policymaking process.

[Justin Tseng]: Considering racial equity in policymaking is something that's really complex.

[Justin Tseng]: something that's really nuanced, something that doesn't always you know the the policy that is the best for racial equity doesn't always seem like it at first and the easy solutions aren't always the best solutions.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's incumbent upon all of us as elected officials as policymakers in the city to ask critically, what, what are

[Justin Tseng]: our oppressed communities, our marginalized communities, our black communities, feeling, what are they seeing?

[Justin Tseng]: What are they experiencing?

[Justin Tseng]: And how can the policies we write and establish, the policies that we pass through the city council best address those needs?

[Justin Tseng]: And that takes a lot of listening, and it takes a lot of criticism and critical thinking.

[Justin Tseng]: So I wanted to thank my fellow Councilors for co-sponsoring this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Collins said, you know, she doesn't know how to wrap it up.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't know where to start.

[Justin Tseng]: I am going to be brief because I think my fellow Councilors have really articulated the frustration, the exasperation, the us asking over and over again for really basic things from the state government.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, I mean I think this is a really really clear example of, you know, a field where we keep asking for improvements, even for basic things like additional signs, clear lighting, fixing lighting, you know, a lot of the things that are talked about in the letter that Councilors are mentioned, and yet, nothing, and I it's just, I

[Justin Tseng]: I think we can all agree that safety is the bedrock of what the government should be doing like that's the reason we organize ourselves into a society and have a government right like.

[Justin Tseng]: this level of inaction and as as Councilor Collins put it, the gaslighting that we've had to say that you know we should just accept things like this is just mind boggling and it's really nonsensical.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I, when it comes to the policy I'll just leave it there because I think, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: I feel very strongly about it, and I think that's been articulated.

[Justin Tseng]: I did also want to thank Councilor Lazzaro from a personal level, including the link to Professor Dill's photography.

[Justin Tseng]: It was really touching to see the website and to see the really, really beautiful art that he was creating when he was with us here.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, and to lose that is such a loss.

[Justin Tseng]: I have no words for it.

[Justin Tseng]: It's really tough.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'm sending my deepest condolences to Professor Dill to his family as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Or to, yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: We continue to meet on the charter review process.

[Justin Tseng]: We reviewed a number of sections from the Charter Study Committee's recommendations, mostly focused around the executive branch, elections, and financial procedures administrative organization.

[Justin Tseng]: No worries.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Chair Lazzaro.

[Justin Tseng]: I think you put it very well, why we're doing this.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, we're hearing from residents that they're worried about what's happening nationally.

[Justin Tseng]: And they've been worried since the Dobbs decision years ago, that really put reproductive health care at stake.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, I think residents know that Massachusetts is a state where we do believe very strongly and affirmatively in women's rights in rights of, you know, our youth to get the care that they need in the rights of doctors to make the best recommendations that they can for their patients.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, with that being said, we also don't want Medford to be the site of conflict, right?

[Justin Tseng]: We don't want Medford to be where hospitals, you know, that provide this type of care are, you know, having to give up their doctors or having to give up their patients to police that's not from Massachusetts, you know, and putting their patients and their employees at risk.

[Justin Tseng]: And there have been a number of measures that the Healey administration has taken to protect and safeguard these rights, but that's not enough when we know that there's so much uncertainty about what could happen.

[Justin Tseng]: Just in the last few weeks, I think it's been really striking.

[Justin Tseng]: to see how the federal government is using its levers and its influence to make states, to make individuals, to make different levels of government and different branches of government succumb to its own will and to succumb to their view of how government should be run or not run.

[Justin Tseng]: it's really important that we do all we can to safeguard those liberties that we have.

[Justin Tseng]: It should be noted that a lot of what's happening nationally is actually illegal.

[Justin Tseng]: It goes against statutes that Congress has passed.

[Justin Tseng]: It goes against separation of powers.

[Justin Tseng]: But, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: that I think underscores how important it is for us to be taking every step and to make be responding to our residents who are reaching out and who are worried about what, you know, decisions nationally what the bills being introduced in the House and Senate, which proposed the banning criminalized abortion care, which proposed to, you know, restrict and ban on gender affirming care.

[Justin Tseng]: what that means for residents in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is what we can do as a city council to protect our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it underscores the, you know, the point that I've been making over the last few years that oftentimes what is national is local.

[Justin Tseng]: And that happens at so many levels, but those anxieties carry down as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's our job to respond to them.

[Justin Tseng]: With that being said, really quickly talking about what chair Lazzaro and I have done over the last few years, or last few weeks, it does cross into 2024, so I guess two years, two calendar years.

[Justin Tseng]: But what we've done is we've taken the discussions at the last public health committee meeting, we've basically cleaned up the draft text that we had at that meeting to become

[Justin Tseng]: more readable, more organized, to get rid of potential redundancies, to get rid of things that we might not need.

[Justin Tseng]: We also made sure that the language was all accurate when it came to Medford, that it best represented what we see in our city right now.

[Justin Tseng]: We made sure to add some language where it made sense.

[Justin Tseng]: And we chose to expand parts of it, although this is very much still content-wise tied or, you know, very much overlapping with what has already been passed by other municipalities in Massachusetts.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the other thing to note is that at that community discussion, we talked about potentially expanding the language to include prescription drugs at pharmacies.

[Justin Tseng]: That's something that a lot of Massachusetts municipalities are doing, although in doing more research about that, I think the model language that I found didn't completely capture, I think,

[Justin Tseng]: a realistic situation for Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: I think there was a lot of talk about DOH rules and Board of Health rules and a lot of talk about funding and us appropriating funds.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that's a whole separate discussion.

[Justin Tseng]: And with our city charter, the mayor is the one with the power to suggest where funds

[Justin Tseng]: go or and how they're spent and to make that decision pending about affirmative vote of the City Council.

[Justin Tseng]: So with that being said, I chose not to put that in the draft before us today.

[Justin Tseng]: However, I did ask Chair Al-Azhar to ask the Board of Health

[Justin Tseng]: about ways we could include those ideas in a way that better reflected what we have here in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: So whether that would make sense, it would make sense for us to put some version of that language in this ordinance or in an ordinance or for them to just explore that as department policy.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's basically the status of the draft that we have in front of us.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Vice President Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: for your impactful words about what's happening in this country, but also your kind words about this work that I've been doing alongside chair Lazzaro, who should definitely receive a lot of credit too.

[Justin Tseng]: When it comes to the last question you asked about whether we should, you know, we pass out a committee tonight and then make, you know, small adjustments if needed on the floor versus keeping a committee.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm happy to do either.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it

[Justin Tseng]: make sense to keep it in committee.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's something we could act pretty fast on once we get some guidance from AP law.

[Justin Tseng]: you know, trying to go against the city in any way, but they want to be, you know, members have expressed to me wanting to have some freedom in terms of how they, you know, talk about issues in those committees, talk about analyzing what's going on in City Hall policies, making policy recommendations.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I had a quick

[Justin Tseng]: question or two about logistics technicalities.

[Justin Tseng]: The first one is just statutory or charter language.

[Justin Tseng]: When it comes to that last sentence in part A, the mayor may at any point declare themselves able to perform the duties of office.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I understand where that applies, but because that's put at the very end of the paragraph,

[Justin Tseng]: I do have some worries that it might be, you know, it might be, there might be a situation where the city council by unanimous vote does determine that the mayor is unable to serve.

[Justin Tseng]: And then the mayor argues that that sentence should apply to the whole paragraph and says just unilaterally declares themselves mayor.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, is there, is that a,

[Justin Tseng]: Is that a worry that we should have?

[Justin Tseng]: And is there a clarifying language we could have put in there about this?

[Justin Tseng]: If that is the intention then of language like this, is there a worry or is there any worry that a city council could, you know, a future city council could abuse the language written here?

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, you know, if they don't like the mayor and everyone on the city council doesn't like whoever the mayor is, votes to... Oh, well, I think you're headed to court then.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: I see Councilor, Vice President Collins

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Vice President Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: I see President Bears is on Zoom.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's how I think I do read it that way, too.

[Justin Tseng]: But I just

[Justin Tseng]: statutory interpretation is something that is, you know, shifting a lot these days, going back and forth a lot these days.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think that's why I wanted to flag it.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think, you know, councillors can dwell on this.

[Justin Tseng]: We can take this back up at the committee, the whole meeting as well, if needed, if any councillors feel is needed.

[Justin Tseng]: President Bears, is your hand raised from before or do you have anything else?

[Justin Tseng]: Okay, great.

[Justin Tseng]: Do any other Councilors have questions on Section 3-8?

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing none, do any members of the public have any comments or questions on Section 3-8?

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing none as well, okay.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, I did have one more question for this section.

[Justin Tseng]: In part B, this was just a clarifying question, where a member of the city council is serving as acting mayor.

[Justin Tseng]: Let's say that that member of the city council is the president of the city council.

[Justin Tseng]: The last sentence is clear that they shouldn't vote as a member of the city council.

[Justin Tseng]: can they still preside over that meeting?

[Justin Tseng]: Or is the only power that's carved out the voting power?

[Justin Tseng]: So it would be expected that the vice president would take over?

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: OK.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that makes a lot of sense to me.

[Justin Tseng]: That's not entirely clear from the language in the charter itself.

[Justin Tseng]: Is this language that we have in front of us standard for different cities?

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: I guess one more question that just popped into my mind when it comes to

[Justin Tseng]: You guys mentioned that in a situation where this council is maybe abusing its power and the mayor comes back and says, that's what's happening, that might be litigated.

[Justin Tseng]: Is there any precedent for that?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: With that being said, those are my final thoughts on section 3-8.

[Justin Tseng]: Are there any other thoughts on 3-8 before we move on to 3-9?

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing none.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: Section 3-9, delegation of authority by the mayor.

[Justin Tseng]: Do any councilors have any questions on this section, questions or comments?

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing none.

[Justin Tseng]: Section 3-10, vacancy in the office of the mayor.

[Justin Tseng]: Do any Councilors have questions or comments on this section?

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing none.

[Justin Tseng]: Do any members of the public have any comments on this section or Article 3 about the mayor's office, the executive branch?

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing none, I did have a really quick question with regards to section 3-2.

[Justin Tseng]: I forgot this in the moment.

[Justin Tseng]: It relates back to Councilor Collins's point about the mayor being a member of every multiple member body of the city.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the following sentences are very clear on what the mayor's role is when it comes to multiple member bodies.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm wondering if there is any worry that the first sentence, just by saying a member instead of saying an ex-official member, if there's any statutory interpretation problem there.

[Justin Tseng]: I know it's evident in the second sentence, but I could see a court arguing that because we didn't put it in the first sentence, that signals some other intent.

[Justin Tseng]: Understood.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: had nine wards instead of eight.

[Justin Tseng]: you know we're kind of put in that position, how difficult would it be to change this.

[Justin Tseng]: But Councilor O'Trella, I mean, you know more about how this is gonna be formatted than I do.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Chair, let me, just one more thing.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we could just note that we are beginning work on developing an open data policy at today's meeting, just for the last point.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: Just like something like this.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: That's good.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: That's all I have.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, okay.

[Justin Tseng]: I guess we could, we could put in camera commemorations.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, uh, the lunar new year.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, yeah, it's just Lunar New Year.

[Justin Tseng]: I think other cultures also have Lunar New Years, but on different days.

[Justin Tseng]: Gotcha.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is also a motion to distribute the newsletter?

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I mean, just to give my fellow Councilors and anyone who might be watching at home, a general idea of what an open data policy is.

[Justin Tseng]: It's a modernizing practice that a lot of municipalities have adopted to let residents access data and information from the city quicker.

[Justin Tseng]: and to let them help us with policy development.

[Justin Tseng]: I know all of us know of residents who are really eager to help out and really excited that a lot of residents are so eager to help out with policy development here.

[Justin Tseng]: I know Councilor Callahan does a lot of work with residents on this as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this very much falls in line with the City Council's goals of greater transparency, greater modernization,

[Justin Tseng]: being more proactive and inclusive when it comes to developing policy too.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know, you know, members of the public have brought up that with the policy changes in the city, there are, you know, XYZ questions that they wish they could have asked or XYZ pieces of data they could have had before making decisions on those or before giving public feedback about different items, or even after with,

[Justin Tseng]: helping us generate, you know, how to make our processes better in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: This is something that Cambridge, Boston, I believe some other municipalities too,

[Justin Tseng]: have taken on themselves, onto themselves, of passing a policy or via ordinance or executive order to create some structure, some framework of doing that.

[Justin Tseng]: And so the Cambridge sample ordinance that we have in front of us and in our inboxes is an example of

[Justin Tseng]: of what this might look like in an ordinance form.

[Justin Tseng]: Of course, there are very different structures of government between Cambridge and Medford, so that's something to keep in mind while we're reading the draft.

[Justin Tseng]: But I thought it would be helpful to give Councilors some sample text to work off of to give us more concrete idea of what this policy might look like.

[Justin Tseng]: The Boston executive order is also in the document.

[Justin Tseng]: Obviously, executive order is very different from an ordinance, but it's still worth, you know, seeing what other municipalities are doing.

[Justin Tseng]: you know, giving us inspiration as to maybe like what goals we should aspire to, what possible paths policy-wise can we take to get there.

[Justin Tseng]: With the questions that, the bullet point questions that we have in front of us and in the inbox, and maybe I should read them real quick.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay, the chair can read them.

[Justin Tseng]: But to give context, Chair Lemme and I have been talking

[Justin Tseng]: for a bit about what kind of information we might wanna gather and put publicly on our website.

[Justin Tseng]: And these are the questions that we came up with.

[Justin Tseng]: We're happy to add more questions from other Councilors to this list.

[Justin Tseng]: And of course, as we develop this policy and as we work on this, we can keep asking more questions to the administration and to different city departments too.

[Justin Tseng]: Something I did forget to mention is that oftentimes an open data policy is,

[Justin Tseng]: is introduced alongside a committee to work through this data, to help clean up this data, to help think of more data in the future, to make sure that this is a recurring cycle, not just like we're doing this at once and then we have to revisit this as a city council every few years.

[Justin Tseng]: But obviously, also with putting data online, we also have to be aware and cognizant of security concerns with that conversation as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think that more or less captures what I was thinking.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think as we, as this becomes a bigger thing, as you know, once we've gotten past that step of low hanging fruit, I, I, I, this is something I haven't talked to councilor lending about, but I do envision in an ideal world, this becoming a bigger project after that step.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and I got, I alluded to this earlier.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, a lot of,

[Justin Tseng]: cities will do something called an open data review board.

[Justin Tseng]: And that might be staff members who get a stipend.

[Justin Tseng]: That might be community members who we appoint and who have some interest slash work experience dealing with this kind of stuff, organizing data and whatnot.

[Justin Tseng]: Perhaps that is the path that we

[Justin Tseng]: we reach, you know, that's the path that we take moving forward.

[Justin Tseng]: But I also think that, you know, that question is the kind of farther future thing.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it'd be a little premature to take on that discussion right now.

[Justin Tseng]: I guess something we could add to that question.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Lazzaro was... Oh, sorry, that was just writing.

[Justin Tseng]: Could I?

[Justin Tseng]: Sorry, Councilor Lazzaro, something we could add to that point is just in addition to the staff capacity and resources,

[Justin Tseng]: question.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, just like what?

[Justin Tseng]: Respectfully, I worry that we're putting the cart before the horse and missing the forest for the trees.

[Justin Tseng]: Is that how they're missing?

[Justin Tseng]: I had a long day working.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Councilor Leming and I are just really thinking big picture about this right now.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think a lot of your concerns are captured in the questions that we're asking, plus the one that I just added about like general capacity and resources that we need.

[Justin Tseng]: I will also say it is my view that this level of transparency should be the standard that municipal governments are putting out.

[Justin Tseng]: In fact, governments at all levels should be putting out and that

[Justin Tseng]: Part of the idea behind doing a policy like this is also that many hands make light work, which I also have a problem with that saying, but I think in this case is true.

[Justin Tseng]: work that I think our residents want to see our departments doing, but we don't have, our departments don't have that capacity right now.

[Justin Tseng]: But maybe if we put on, you know, put some of this data out in public, they could do that work and propose the policies for us.

[Justin Tseng]: And then we can, you know, enter these policy discussions at a level where, you know, residents have done the research and we can, we can start engaging with them.

[Justin Tseng]: Sorry?

[Justin Tseng]: Yep, yep, yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: Great.

[Justin Tseng]: Governance Committee, January 22nd, 2025.

[Justin Tseng]: Mr. Clerk, can you please call the roll?

[Justin Tseng]: chair say present five present non absent.

[Justin Tseng]: The meeting is called to order.

[Justin Tseng]: Today we'll be discussing resolution 24-468 resolution to discuss updates to the city charter.

[Justin Tseng]: This is one of three scheduled substantive charter.

[Justin Tseng]: charter review meetings where we will review the recommendations sent to us by the mayor's office of the work that the Charter Study Committee has done.

[Justin Tseng]: I know the chair of the Charter Study Committee is in the audience with us today.

[Justin Tseng]: I did send out an official invite to this meeting through the CSC email address.

[Justin Tseng]: I was thinking, because we have so much to work through, and just to remind folks at home, what we have to talk about today is the preamble, article one,

[Justin Tseng]: discussing incorporation, short title definitions, article two about the legislative branch, and article nine, general provisions, section 9-6, which concerns itself with ordinances and the legislative branch as well, which is why it's in this meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: Because there's so much to review and talk about today, I was thinking that we could cover the sections in order in the city charter draft that was sent to us.

[Justin Tseng]: and take composition and compensation at the end, because those, I expect, will be very substantive discussions with a lot of input and discussion required.

[Justin Tseng]: And I don't want the small but very important things to get lost in the substance.

[Justin Tseng]: With that being said, do councillors have any opening thoughts or thoughts on the preamble or article one of the draft city charter?

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Let me make sure I can see.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I know substantively a lot of that shows up later on and like in subjects will cover in future meetings, but seeing that they're going to be spread through two different meetings, I was, I'd be remiss not to ask if that is some language that we should align through the charter document local newspaper versus local news publication.

[Justin Tseng]: And in the definition itself for local newspaper it talks about newspapers with daily or weekly circulation and given the state of local news media.

[Justin Tseng]: I didn't know whether

[Justin Tseng]: Before I move to Councilor Callahan, I see a lot more hands raised here.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to correct the record on some things.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm not saying I agree or disagree with this proposal.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm still considering different perspectives.

[Justin Tseng]: On the quote from the Medford People's Platform, I could not actually find that exact quote.

[Justin Tseng]: What I did find instead was, we commit to implementing a city charter review process to change and expand the way

[Justin Tseng]: Medford elected officials to ward representation instead of just at-large seats.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's important not to leave out that last operative clause.

[Justin Tseng]: There are things said about what councilor said, what I do think there is a difference between saying that board representation is not the best way to serve a district, which is what I think the councilor was saying instead of that

[Justin Tseng]: Ward doesn't deserve representation.

[Justin Tseng]: Those are two very different statements.

[Justin Tseng]: With regards to the meeting times, I did actually do, I looked at the data about it, and when you take the meetings since 2020 that are more substantive rather than procedural,

[Justin Tseng]: are actually, after we went bi-weekly, our meeting lengths are pretty much exactly the same.

[Justin Tseng]: Only six minutes longer on average under the bi-weekly system.

[Justin Tseng]: So there's not a lot of difference there.

[Justin Tseng]: And I believe the call-in center is here to answer our questions and not to advocate for any particular policy or choice.

[Justin Tseng]: Although we do have members of the Charter Study Committee who are here to do that.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Callahan, Lazzaro, and then

[Justin Tseng]: saw President Bears and then Councilor Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: Also, I understand that there are people here for public comment.

[Justin Tseng]: We will get to that.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Now recognizing Councilor Lazzaro.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Lazzaro, I think I have President Bears and then Vice President Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor, Vice President Collins, and then Councilor Scarbell.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Collins, Councilor Scarpelli, and then Councilor Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: President Bears and then Vice President Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: Vice President Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: Vice President Collins, just to clarify, do you mean four districts and five at large?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I also want to move to public comment.

[Justin Tseng]: I do have a number of questions for the Collins Center, especially the members of the Charter Study Committee, who I think it's important to hear from.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes?

[Justin Tseng]: Okay, great.

[Justin Tseng]: In, I know a big goal behind going to a hybrid system, word representation system is this idea, this, you know, desire to get a more diverse city council.

[Justin Tseng]: In my research into word representation, into different types of representation, there's a big change, a shift in terms of how diversity is viewed as a result of making these structural changes.

[Justin Tseng]: I think pretty much everyone agrees that at large.

[Justin Tseng]: An all-at-large system is not good for diversity because it dilutes the votes of minority groups.

[Justin Tseng]: And we've seen municipalities across the state be challenged for that.

[Justin Tseng]: But there's also been a rising concern, and this is based on research in the American Political Science Review in the law of, I think it's politics, economics, and organization, where

[Justin Tseng]: people are worried that creating smaller districts.

[Justin Tseng]: districts that tend to be majority and minority actually cuts against racial equity in that it makes fewer politicians responsible for or accountable to minority voters.

[Justin Tseng]: And I was wondering if this is something that the Charter Study Committee discussed in its consideration of diversity, especially with regards to race.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, Chair McDonald did answer the question.

[Justin Tseng]: She said no.

[Justin Tseng]: It's just a concern to me because it is what political scientists now, I think, have found to be the main mover in terms of racial justice is voters' accountability, or politicians' accountability to voters.

[Justin Tseng]: So that is something I do want to consider strongly in my consideration of the different options that we have here at the table.

[Justin Tseng]: And one unseen strength of the alternative proposal, which I do have my questions about too,

[Justin Tseng]: is that you keep the racial proportions quite similar comparing, for example, the historically black community in West Medford in Ward 6.

[Justin Tseng]: Combining it with Ward 8 doesn't change the percentage much at all, and it makes an elected more accountable to those voters.

[Justin Tseng]: Similarly, in Ward 7, there is more of a difference.

[Justin Tseng]: And I am slightly more concerned about that one, but it does make

[Justin Tseng]: the Councilor serving Ward 1 also accountable to minority voters as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I did actually, I had some open-ended questions about the survey as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Could you, Chair McDonald, since you know the survey process better than I do, help run me through a little bit of what that process was like and what the results were?

[Justin Tseng]: Yes, both.

[Justin Tseng]: Both creating the survey, but mostly the results and what you got from the results.

[Justin Tseng]: I think broad strokes, I'm familiar with the policy recommendations of the survey results.

[Justin Tseng]: Could you remind me about the composition, what questions were asked, if you have that off the top of your mind?

[Justin Tseng]: Thanks for clarifying that.

[Justin Tseng]: So we didn't ask about the district system or?

[Justin Tseng]: One point I do find compelling is this idea that we should mix, standardize both sets, the city council and the school committee to use a similar election system.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm worried that, I mean, I think something big I hear when I knock on the doors of people who don't necessarily turn out in local elections is just general confusion with how local elections work, who's voting for who,

[Justin Tseng]: Who, you know, who's up.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, could you explain to me the reasoning behind making city council and school committee, like the compositions different.

[Justin Tseng]: I know Ms.

[Justin Tseng]: Van der Kloot is on the Zoom, but I know we also, Ms.

[Justin Tseng]: Van der Kloot, I see your hand raised, Mr. Clerk, if you can.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, very briefly.

[Justin Tseng]: I know we're covering this on a different day, but I was just wondering about the mismatch.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Ms.

[Justin Tseng]: Barracud.

[Justin Tseng]: And thank you for your service to the city.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: It's always a joy seeing you.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's a helpful explanation.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know you all looked at data about this.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't know if the call-in center is more to contribute about this.

[Justin Tseng]: Is there usually a big gulf between the number of candidates who run for city council and school committee?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: That's helpful, too.

[Justin Tseng]: Quickly, going back to the survey, I am curious about, because I used to work in survey research and public opinion polling,

[Justin Tseng]: I'm curious if you know the demographics or have that information, percentage like renter, homeowner, racial breakdown, income, anything like that.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I saw Jean earlier.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, yep.

[Justin Tseng]: I see Jean's hands raised.

[Justin Tseng]: Good.

[Justin Tseng]: Yep, that's correct.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to know what the breakdown was in terms of things like homeowner, renter, income, et cetera.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's helpful information.

[Justin Tseng]: I appreciate the outreach that the committee has done to reach groups that weren't represented in the survey.

[Justin Tseng]: I just also, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: As someone who's into polling, I want us to be careful with how we're assessing the data as well, especially given that the homeowner to renter ratio is so far off from what the city ratio is, which is 53% to 47% instead of what seemed like 80% to 20%.

[Justin Tseng]: But that's just to help me understand.

[Justin Tseng]: Could you outline for me a bit

[Justin Tseng]: I know we talked about in our interview a very long time ago, the idea of exploring different types of electoral systems, so multi-member districts, proportional representation, rank choice, and all of that.

[Justin Tseng]: Could you help us understand as a council where those conversations went and why those weren't chosen?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I know Councilor Call, or Councilor Callahan brought up the spreadsheet with comparing us to different municipalities around the country.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think a question that comes into my mind is just, what is, why are we choosing one over the other, right?

[Justin Tseng]: If we have a bigger data set, it seems to make sense to, to hew to that, but

[Justin Tseng]: Was there much consideration of different municipalities of similar size in different states?

[Justin Tseng]: And is there a reason why Massachusetts was the standard?

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Callaghan showed earlier the spreadsheet of different states, right, and of some in our state with the calculations of councillors per capita.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm curious.

[Justin Tseng]: Was that data considered in the committee's study of?

[Justin Tseng]: Thanks.

[Justin Tseng]: That's helpful to know.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that more or less, I have questions for President Bears, but I suspect in the public comment period, there are gonna be questions about that proposal as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So I wanted to get to public comment first.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes, President Bears has some questions.

[Justin Tseng]: It's my understanding that Daniel Bullocka, who was on the, Danielle, who was on the CSC has a comment about that question.

[Justin Tseng]: Mr. Bares.

[Justin Tseng]: President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: Danielle, give us one second.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, there we go.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Danielle.

[Justin Tseng]: Thanks.

[Justin Tseng]: I realized that I have two quick questions for the committee members who are here.

[Justin Tseng]: Was there much conversation about the prospect of gerrymandering?

[Justin Tseng]: Of gerrymandering wards.

[Justin Tseng]: I know in 2020 it was different because of the pandemic, but normally

[Justin Tseng]: wards are drawn at the local level, the maps move up to the national level, is my understanding of things.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know in 2020, this council did entertain three different maps to draw the wards.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes, it's based on census data, yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: I know a big concern at every level with these districts is the idea that we might gerrymander.

[Justin Tseng]: I think to me, an unspoken, something that we haven't brought up with alternative proposal on the table here is that we do have districts that are harder to gerrymander.

[Justin Tseng]: And I am slightly worried that with smaller districts, with a greater number of districts, we'd be able to

[Justin Tseng]: or politicians are more likely to gerrymander those districts?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I, yeah, I was just gonna say state representatives have offered to me to remain in contact about ideas that we might have as a city council too.

[Justin Tseng]: President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: One more question for the members of the Charter Study Committee.

[Justin Tseng]: A big discourse that in Medford for a while about moving towards a ward representation system is the studied, there are a lot of studies about how ward Councilors can oftentimes

[Justin Tseng]: putting it more ugly, become thieves of little fiefdoms, and determine how the success or failure of development projects in their neighborhood.

[Justin Tseng]: There's, I believe, a 20%

[Justin Tseng]: correlation with regards to 20% fewer projects being approved, permits being approved in ward-based systems.

[Justin Tseng]: I was wondering what kind of conversations the committee had about that.

[Justin Tseng]: Thanks for that summary.

[Justin Tseng]: If no one has, if no other Councilors have any questions for the call center or for the members of the CSC, I'd like to move to public comments.

[Justin Tseng]: I know there are folks here who've been here for a while.

[Justin Tseng]: And a candidate running for a ward-based seat or a district-based seat, whatever it may be, is only running for that election.

[Justin Tseng]: Are there any more folks either on Zoom or in person who wish to comment on this publicly?

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing none, are there any Councilors who wish to speak?

[Justin Tseng]: Seeing none, I just wanted to reiterate that I think that this has been, for the most part, for 99% of this discussion, a good faith discussion about the merits of the different proposals that we have on hand.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's important to recognize that the critiques that we might have as councillors of any system

[Justin Tseng]: and from the residents are based in good faith efforts to try to understand how politics works, period, but also how the decisions we make can create ripple effects and unintended consequences.

[Justin Tseng]: And as Councilors, it is, I think, in our thinking, in our line of work to think through deeply about these concepts and to bring our lived experience there.

[Justin Tseng]: That is to say, I really want us to hew away from personal attacks, either on this side of the rail, but especially from the public to that.

[Justin Tseng]: for councillors having a difference of opinions.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that there are a lot of councillors here who have very different opinions on this one topic.

[Justin Tseng]: And I just wanted to put that out there because I know that this is a deep, rich, and oftentimes tense conversation about something that's gonna be so impactful and so meaningful moving forward.

[Justin Tseng]: Speaking from the chair, there are a number of factors that I think

[Justin Tseng]: should be answered about the proposal we have right in front of us before I'm ready to support that one in full form.

[Justin Tseng]: And I do think that the proposed amendments, for the most part, address those concerns.

[Justin Tseng]: In particular, I'm the only person of color on this city council.

[Justin Tseng]: I was elected on a platform of racial justice and diversity.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I take that very, very heavily when I consider how I'm gonna vote on this.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's really important to me that the proposal that passes the city council at the final step is one that really does result in an effect of racial justice, rather than just tokenizing and saying, we have one, you know, one Councilor from the majority minority ward and that's, and we're all good.

[Justin Tseng]: Because that is something that happens.

[Justin Tseng]: And I do go back to my, this idea of,

[Justin Tseng]: This idea that when politicians are accountable to more voters in general, especially from minority groups and underrepresented groups, marginalized groups, that is truly the better way, the more effective way to reach racial justice.

[Justin Tseng]: That being said,

[Justin Tseng]: I am still open to word representation.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this is, this is, you know, the big substantive meeting that we're going to have on this.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think it's the end of the discussion, and I know that Councilor Callahan

[Justin Tseng]: and Councilor Leming have made it clear that they want to contribute to this conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, just by showing up, they've done that, but they also, I believe, want to vote on this as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm afraid that voting no on this tonight would foreclose that possibility of letting them have their chance to vote on it as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why tonight I'm gonna, I plan to vote in favor of it.

[Justin Tseng]: That's just me speaking as a councilor from the chair.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Mr. Clerk, do you have that?

[Justin Tseng]: Yes, President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: I keep seeing my name instead of yours, and I'm like, what?

[Justin Tseng]: Do we have any final words or motions?

[Justin Tseng]: We have a motion adjourned from President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: Do we have a second on that?

[Justin Tseng]: Seconded by Councilor Lazzaro.

[Justin Tseng]: As I give the clerk time to type, I want to thank everyone for staying on so late into this meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you to the Collins Center for answering so many questions.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you to the members of the Charter Study Committee.

[Justin Tseng]: I know we really grilled you.

[Justin Tseng]: And especially a deep thank you to Chair McDonald for the hard work, the difficult answers that you gave to us as well.

[Justin Tseng]: you know, looking forward to the next few meetings on this.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we can get a lot, a lot done.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: When you're ready to motion to adjourn.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: This is less of a question.

[Justin Tseng]: I think you have been very thorough, as my colleague acknowledges, between the last city council meeting and this one, and with watching a lot of school committee meetings and following the discussions there, I feel very confident voting to move this forward.

[Justin Tseng]: I know from talking to parents throughout the city how important it is

[Justin Tseng]: for their children to be learning in schools where there's a properly functioning HVAC system, where their kids aren't sweating to death or freezing to death, and where our teachers feel safe teaching and unencumbered in doing that role for our children and our families.

[Justin Tseng]: I think one really important thing

[Justin Tseng]: to to acknowledge here, at least from my perspective, is that there is a sense of fiscal responsibility and getting this project done now.

[Justin Tseng]: When we defer projects as we've seen throughout the city throughout the last few years, we really

[Justin Tseng]: We think that we're deferring costs, but we're not.

[Justin Tseng]: Those costs are going up all the time.

[Justin Tseng]: We've seen with inflation over the last few years, we've seen with increased labor costs, increased cost of materials, and we're expecting tariffs coming forward in the near future, including a 25% tax on anything coming from Canada, which is a place we get a lot of steel and metal from and a lot of materials for construction from.

[Justin Tseng]: I think

[Justin Tseng]: that that shows how important getting this project approved as soon as possible is and letting you guys move forward on it as soon as possible.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that there are differences on this council with regards to where we are financially in the city, but

[Justin Tseng]: I think that looking at this project today and applying the question that I've always applied on the city council, will this help our city at the end of the day?

[Justin Tseng]: I believe that the answer is a yes on this project.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe that our parents and teachers and students would say that it's a resounding yes.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why I'm really grateful for the work that you all have done and why I'm happy with this project.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: On Tuesday, January 7, we met as the governance committee to discuss the communications from the mayor and the receipt of the draft of the charter study committee's recommendations as sent to us and modified by the mayor's office.

[Justin Tseng]: We talked at that meeting generally about how we wanted to structure the charter review process going forward.

[Justin Tseng]: One slight, for folks watching at home, what the city charter is,

[Justin Tseng]: our city constitution, it sets the foundation of how our city government works.

[Justin Tseng]: And at that meeting, we laid out a roadmap for the next three meetings at which we'll have the call-in center there to help us understand the policy material, work with our ideas, with the ideas of the Charter Study Committee, and to create a draft that we can vote out of the committee

[Justin Tseng]: by hopefully the end of February or early March.

[Justin Tseng]: That way we can get it to the state house and get it before the voters this fall.

[Justin Tseng]: Being very quick, because I think this is a good opportunity to let the public know about how we're structuring these meetings.

[Justin Tseng]: We've decided that on Wednesday, January 22nd, the governance committee will work on issues related to the legislative branch.

[Justin Tseng]: If folks at home are following along with the process, the draft

[Justin Tseng]: is there.

[Justin Tseng]: We'll be talking about the preamble, article one.

[Justin Tseng]: Incorporation Short Title Definitions, Article 2, the legislative branch, and a section of Article 9, which also touches on the legislative branch.

[Justin Tseng]: Speeding through, Tuesday, February 4 will be the second substantive meeting on the city charter, at which we'll discuss Articles 3 about the executive branch to the mayor's office, Articles 5, 6, and 7 about administrative organization, financial procedures, and elections.

[Justin Tseng]: At our last scheduled substantive meeting on Wednesday, February 19th, we will be talking about the school committee.

[Justin Tseng]: We'll also be reaching out to relevant stakeholders for their feedback as well.

[Justin Tseng]: We'll be talking about citizen participation mechanisms, general provisions, and transitional provisions as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll be brief about this.

[Justin Tseng]: This is something that I know a few candidates ran on in the last election.

[Justin Tseng]: When we think about democracy in the 21st century, we think about the challenges.

[Justin Tseng]: We understand that to build trust, we must pursue a policy of transparency.

[Justin Tseng]: And I believe an open data policy will make data more accessible to our residents to understand what's shaping our policy debates in the city and how they can contribute to that debate as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe that pursuing an open data policy is in a proactive spirit.

[Justin Tseng]: I hope that we can come to answer questions with residents before they get to different levels as soon as possible.

[Justin Tseng]: And I believe that this maximally leverages opportunities for us to collaborate, for policymakers in this building to collaborate with our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: We know that there's so many bright minds here in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: We know that there's so many people eager to help us out on solving the big challenges that we're facing as a city, and that we can all work better together when this data is out there for people to use at home.

[Justin Tseng]: Chief among our priorities with crafting an open data policy will also be privacy and security, which we know will be a challenge in the next four years coming up.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Vice President Collins hit the nail on the on the head with it with this and I just wanted to add to what Councilor Lazzaro said about

[Justin Tseng]: services coming out of what parents and residents are advocating.

[Justin Tseng]: We know that oftentimes parents and students with disabilities have fallen way short of where that equitable advocacy is.

[Justin Tseng]: And as a government, we need to step up and be aware of

[Justin Tseng]: those shortfalls.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm really grateful for our Medford parents for advocating for their children, for our community, really, because investing in programs like this not only helps the students using those programs, but helps our community as a whole.

[Justin Tseng]: We are all dependent on each other, and we are all in this together.

[Justin Tseng]: Just really quickly,

[Justin Tseng]: I'm also working with our director Kevin Bailey on a youth commission, a youth council to really shape what our city does with recreation activities with policymaking in general.

[Justin Tseng]: And I like that to be an opportunity and a channel in the future for parents to use too and to come work with me on that in our future committee meetings to make sure that that is set up as equitable as possible too.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I am very excited for this project because it's a need that our city has had for a very long time.

[Justin Tseng]: I remember the first time I ran, I heard from parents about the need to develop a better HVAC system.

[Justin Tseng]: I remember when I was a student in that building, we needed better air conditioning and better heating, and the needs have only grown in the decades since I've left that building.

[Justin Tseng]: Like I said at our last meeting before this one,

[Justin Tseng]: Investing in HVAC is investing in student success.

[Justin Tseng]: It's investing in giving teachers an adequate labor, adequate work environment.

[Justin Tseng]: It's investing in making our school system as strong as it can be.

[Justin Tseng]: When I think about the fiscal parts of this project, I know

[Justin Tseng]: we've received an outline of how that the money on capital needs is going to be spent in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: There are lots of discussions to come.

[Justin Tseng]: I know Councilor or President Bears mentioned in our previous meeting, setting up a meeting with the city administration on that matter too.

[Justin Tseng]: But we have received all in all a picture of the big items that we have coming up in the next few years.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why that's one of the reasons why I feel comfortable voting for this.

[Justin Tseng]: Another reason why I think it's fiscally prudent to do this right now is because when we defer costs, we don't save money.

[Justin Tseng]: When we defer costs, those costs become more expensive.

[Justin Tseng]: We all know what inflation was like over the last few years.

[Justin Tseng]: We all know that

[Justin Tseng]: material costs and labor costs only go up.

[Justin Tseng]: And we now know a bit about what the tariff picture looks like in the next few years.

[Justin Tseng]: When we think about the materials that we'll need for a project like this, when we think about steel, when we think about construction, we get a lot of those materials from countries like Canada.

[Justin Tseng]: And our president-elect has announced a 25% or plans for a 25% tariff on all those products that we will be paying as consumers of those products.

[Justin Tseng]: That means increased construction costs.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think really epitomizes and highlights why it's more fiscally responsible, in my opinion, to spend on this project now, because I think we can save money in the long term compared to if we defer this into the future.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: This Welcoming City Ordinance is a project that our council and the last council I've been working on for years.

[Justin Tseng]: It is essentially a codification of our city's existing policy on non-cooperation with federal authorities on non-criminal immigration matters.

[Justin Tseng]: When we think about the impetus for this, when I think back to why I introduced this resolution in the first place,

[Justin Tseng]: It was really to protect residents who live in our city, our neighbors, our friends, our family, and to make sure that folks are feeling safe accessing city services.

[Justin Tseng]: And in doing so, in having more people access our city services, improve those city services themselves.

[Justin Tseng]: It's frustrating to me to hear stories from constituents, from friends and their family,

[Justin Tseng]: about being afraid to come into City Hall, being afraid to ask for something because they're afraid that we are working with federal authorities on immigration.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's really important to our residents to make sure that they feel safe at home here and in interacting with the Medford Police Department.

[Justin Tseng]: especially that, and I think that point is particularly important.

[Justin Tseng]: It's to build confidence in public safety here in Medford, and to let our police focus on their own jobs.

[Justin Tseng]: We have so much to do here in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: We have so many laws to enforce already.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to focus on Medford laws.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to focus on local laws, because that is the separation of federal, state, and local powers.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's really important to note that it was crucial for us to reach out to the city administration and to the police chief personally to see if there were comments on this draft ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: And we did receive a lot of comments.

[Justin Tseng]: We've accepted pretty much all of them.

[Justin Tseng]: And this ordinance was drafted with the spirit of collaboration and cooperation.

[Justin Tseng]: I also have to thank Councilor Leming and our advocates, many of whom are in the audience today, for fighting so hard to make sure that we had a very solid draft, drafted by a lawyer, to make sure that we're acting before January 20th and before the big sea change that's gonna come in terms of immigration policy federally and the pressures that are gonna come from higher ups imposed on the city of Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: At the end of the day, I see the welcoming city ordinance, and I know many folks at home, and I've received many emails and phone calls about this, see this ordinance as a statement of our values, a statement of where we stand as a city when it comes to embracing our neighbors, protecting our neighbors, and making sure that they feel like a part of our city.

[Justin Tseng]: With all of that being said, I do have one proposed amendment to strike the last sentence of subsection 103B from the edits we had accepted last time from KP law.

[Justin Tseng]: The sentence starts with, this prohibition also does not preclude the Medford Police Department, blah, blah, blah.

[Justin Tseng]: That was not in existing city policy that was added on later by KP law.

[Justin Tseng]: And in the spirit of keeping this in line with existing city policy, I've talked to, I've talked with Councilors, Councilor Leming about this.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know Councilor Leming has communicated with activists and advocates about this.

[Justin Tseng]: It would actually weaken the ordinance if we kept that in.

[Justin Tseng]: So I would propose that we take that sentence out.

[Justin Tseng]: When we started this effort up around two years ago, we also met with, or at least requested feedback for the police chief.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to thank you, Danielle, for your explanation of it, because I think that clarifies to us on this side of the rail a bit of what you guys are concerned about.

[Justin Tseng]: It seems to me that we're focusing a lot on who will be called onto the scene or not.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's an important question.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think when we think about

[Justin Tseng]: the change that the mayor's administration has made, it seems like there's an additional refocus question of whether the building commissioner or the former building commissioner would send someone out to the scene.

[Justin Tseng]: And I would be surprised if it's an emergency and they choose not to send someone out to the scene.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think

[Justin Tseng]: Your comment does help me understand where you guys are coming from.

[Justin Tseng]: I do think the former system, the old system, has some holes in it.

[Justin Tseng]: And I appreciate the mayor trying to patch those holes.

[Justin Tseng]: And I appreciate Councilor Collins's B paper that will get us more, I think will get us more answers about all of this.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: technical issues first.

[Justin Tseng]: 27 to 2025.

[Justin Tseng]: Welcome to our first meeting of 2025.

[Justin Tseng]: Mr. Clerk, can you please call the roll?

[Justin Tseng]: Present.

[Justin Tseng]: Five present, none absent.

[Justin Tseng]: We also have Councilor Callahan in attendance with us as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Resolution 24-468, Resolution to Discuss Updates to the City Charter.

[Justin Tseng]: We received from the mayor's office the Charter Study Committee's recommendations along with a letter from the mayor.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe that all councilors received this in their inboxes.

[Justin Tseng]: We also have printed copies in front of our councilors tonight, if you prefer to look at everything through print.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to use this meeting to set us up for success in the next few meetings.

[Justin Tseng]: There's some tasks that we have ahead of us.

[Justin Tseng]: First, I wanted to outline a

[Justin Tseng]: the upcoming meeting timelines and proposed topics for discussion and get all of your feedbacks on this proposed timeline.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanna note first that this is flexible.

[Justin Tseng]: We can move topics around based on what Councilors want to discuss most.

[Justin Tseng]: And I also want to note that the call-in center will graciously be present at our next three meetings.

[Justin Tseng]: So our next meeting is scheduled for Wednesday, January 22, 2025.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think for that meeting, it would make sense to talk about the preamble article one, which talks about, uh, which is the incorporation of the short title definitions, um, article two about the legislative branch.

[Justin Tseng]: So very much concerning the city council and what we do, um, and article, um, nine general provisions, section nine to six, which fall in line.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think pair wall with.

[Justin Tseng]: the other two topics that I mentioned.

[Justin Tseng]: The meeting following that will be Tuesday, February 4, 2025.

[Justin Tseng]: The topics I have listed for discussion then are articles

[Justin Tseng]: three, which concerns the executive branch.

[Justin Tseng]: So the mayor's office, article five, administrative organization, city departments, etc.

[Justin Tseng]: Article six, financial procedures for the city, and article seven elections.

[Justin Tseng]: So more focused, I was thinking that meeting could be more focused on the executive branch and, and those powers of the city.

[Justin Tseng]: And then for the final meeting for which we have the Collins Center with us, that would be Wednesday, February 19th, 2025.

[Justin Tseng]: And what I have listed down there are kind of the rest of the articles I haven't mentioned yet, but which are big topics that might need

[Justin Tseng]: a good amount of focus and a good amount of conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: Articles 4, which regards the school committee, Article 8, which is about citizen participation mechanisms, and Article 9, all the other sections of the general provisions that we won't have gotten to in the first deep dive meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: Let me pause there first and ask my fellow councillors if they have any ideas about that proposed timeline, if there's anything that they'd want to shift around, any topics they would want to cover in a different order or cover first.

[Justin Tseng]: Council President Bears, give me one sec.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, this is

[Justin Tseng]: an issue of urgency for a lot of our students for, as you said, for health, for safety, for student performance, for functionality, for our teachers sake.

[Justin Tseng]: I know a lot of, you know, things were, in my experience, they're having problems in the past with the HVAC system from what teachers and students have told me and parents have told me that things have only gotten worse.

[Justin Tseng]: And I do know that this is something that has been at the forefront of financial planning for our city.

[Justin Tseng]: We've known about this cost that was going to come before us for years.

[Justin Tseng]: for longer than I've been on the city council.

[Justin Tseng]: But you know what, there are questions.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think all of us behind the rail are in agreement that a committee, the whole meeting would be good and helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: The reason why I feel comfortable voting yes on the first reading is as you noted, votes can change.

[Justin Tseng]: We can decide to vote this down on the third reading if our answers aren't resolved or questions aren't resolved.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think, functionally voting yes on a first reading tonight and both voting for cancer, Scarf Ellie's motion on lead us to very similar places, the difference being the two week gap, the, the, the potentially even more than two weeks gap.

[Justin Tseng]: that pushing this off would be.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's really important to underscore to everyone watching at home and here that that time does matter.

[Justin Tseng]: That timeline does matter for the success of a city's project.

[Justin Tseng]: There are tons of projects out there that we've had to wait a cycle or put on hold because we weren't able to get the bids out in time.

[Justin Tseng]: We weren't able to do X, Y, Z. And it's really important that we meet the timelines as is.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it'd be helpful for the council going forward if we could submit some questions to city staff before the committee, the whole meeting, if we could see some of the slides before that meeting as well, just to expedite that conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we can have a very rich and deep conversation about, you know, the questions that my fellow councillors have raised about the need and urgency for this going forward.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we can have that depth of conversation as long as we're prepared for it.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you counsel is our.

[Justin Tseng]: second.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe Councilor Callaghan.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, if we, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: If the school committee, and that's up to their discretion, doesn't want to renew a contract with the superintendent, this is the process.

[Justin Tseng]: I understand that it's, in my view, this is

[Justin Tseng]: testing the waters with separation of powers.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's why I plan to vote no on this.

[Justin Tseng]: I agree with Councilor Callahan.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to chime in and request that.

[Justin Tseng]: I wasn't comfortable, and I am not, I'm not comfortable with

[Justin Tseng]: with language that I think is overstepped that line, the separation of powers line.
