[Justin Tseng]: And I agree with what you said about, we should have a very good reason for why we're doing things like this.

[Justin Tseng]: We should, but it's not our role as a council to step in and say what we can or can't do and compel a mayor to do something that's within her charter right to do.

[Justin Tseng]: We'll talk about charter review next year.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think we need to follow the letter of the law, and I'm much more comfortable with the amendment.

[Justin Tseng]: Just to quickly clarify, that's not completely correct.

[Justin Tseng]: I meant a compulsion order.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's over the line.

[Justin Tseng]: Then Councilor Scarpelli from my reading, from my legal reading and research into this, there are splits between different federal courts, state courts, circuit splits on this particular issue for when it comes to public employees.

[Justin Tseng]: There are public and private factors to weigh.

[Justin Tseng]: That's all to say it's actually very not clear-cut.

[Justin Tseng]: There are restrictions on the government's ability to do this, of course, but it's not very clear-cut.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I want to thank you for your hard work on this, to thank the team at Innes Associates for their hard work.

[Justin Tseng]: I know a lot of us on the City Council have been working really hard, but I do want to give a special shout out to our planning and permitting committee.

[Justin Tseng]: this is a huge, huge deal for our city.

[Justin Tseng]: Any zoning change is, but this one is one of many that are coming.

[Justin Tseng]: I know people in the neighborhood who are very excited about this, and especially with this being one of the corridors into the heart of our city, one of the gateways into our city, to have a more thriving scene there, to have more

[Justin Tseng]: business in Medford to have more residences in Medford, these are all good things.

[Justin Tseng]: When we consider the environmental impact that this will have, this is a really great thing for the environment.

[Justin Tseng]: When we make changes like this, and you know, this is a reckoning that a lot of cities have been having, is that we can actually win on housing, we can win on the environment, we can win on business development.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think this is one of those proposals that will move our city in the right direction.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'm very grateful for this.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this is something that we should celebrate as a city.

[Justin Tseng]: It's great to be ending the year with something like this, and I very happily support this.

[Justin Tseng]: If you, there we go.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll give a very brief summary and then Councilor Leming has some amendments that we got sent earlier before this meeting, technical amendments.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, first, I really just need to thank Councilor Leming and the resident advocates for our immigrant community here in Medford for all the hard work and persistence in trying to get this passed.

[Justin Tseng]: When I introduced this years ago, I introduced this because I had talked to a lot of friends and a lot of residents who feared for their safety and feared interacting with City Hall.

[Justin Tseng]: with our city government and with our institutions.

[Justin Tseng]: And they didn't know that we have an existing non-cooperative

[Justin Tseng]: a non-cooperation agreement policy with ICE when it comes to non-criminal matters.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, that's really technical language, but so many cities put it out there and codify it and make it clear where they stand when it comes to the fundamental truths and values of dignity, of community, and of compassion.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe then and I believe now that it's important for Medford to state where we lie, where we stand on these values, on these fundamental truths.

[Justin Tseng]: The next four years are going to be very trying for a lot of people who are so foundational to our community, to our neighbors, to our friends, to our family.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's important, in my opinion, to codify the policies and to give them that security that

[Justin Tseng]: We already one already have in place but to expand that secure that sense of safety and security for them and give residents a chance to feel safe in their own homes.

[Justin Tseng]: Being brief.

[Justin Tseng]: about the content of this resolution is really not that much different from what our city already has in place.

[Justin Tseng]: Our city administration has reviewed it.

[Justin Tseng]: We've met about it in committee.

[Justin Tseng]: This is essentially just codifying and making sure that in the future, this policy can't just be overturned, that residents can know that there is a formality, there is longevity to this policy, and that will be put on the books.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'll stop there and let Councilor Leming provide the amendments.

[Justin Tseng]: Going to Councilor Leming.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I also, um, I believe that in working with Councilor Leming, he wanted to motion to waive the three readings as well.

[Justin Tseng]: To respond to some of the points that have been brought up, both I and Councilor Leming have reached out to the police chief over the last few years about this.

[Justin Tseng]: when we were meeting about it years ago, and in the lead up to the recent meetings about it, I was DCed on an email.

[Justin Tseng]: I know Chair Leming reached out as chair of the committee this was in.

[Justin Tseng]: We didn't receive, or I hadn't received in my inbox any notes to the contrary.

[Justin Tseng]: That's why we felt comfortable moving forward with it.

[Justin Tseng]: As the executive branch that's in charge of community safety, policing, and the like, we did make sure to cooperate with the executive branch on this since they will be carrying out this policy.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's where Councilor Leming's proposed amendments come from tonight as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe there's another point I might be slightly forgetting.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, we did talk about the federal funding piece.

[Justin Tseng]: Lots of that was overturned in federal litigation.

[Justin Tseng]: Many components of the Trump, first Trump administration's course of policies against municipalities were overturned.

[Justin Tseng]: We also need to note that, you know, this is about values and to understand that there is a

[Justin Tseng]: even if there is a monetary impact that, number one, that that is limited.

[Justin Tseng]: During the first administration, they tried a lot to see what they could do to coerce municipalities to align with their federal agenda on this.

[Justin Tseng]: The answer was not a lot.

[Justin Tseng]: And the restrictions on funding were minimal.

[Justin Tseng]: And the second is just a realization that our values are worth more than that.

[Justin Tseng]: The federal impact is limited to certain, very, very certain streams of funding.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not limited, it's not so expansive as to include much of what we actually get from the federal government.

[Justin Tseng]: On Councilor Collins' points, I think it underscores one other thing, the importance of this to the taxpayer.

[Justin Tseng]: there's lots that our city is doing.

[Justin Tseng]: There's no doubt that there's more to do than we have the capacity for.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's the situation that we're in.

[Justin Tseng]: It shouldn't be on our local police department that is already working so hard on local safety.

[Justin Tseng]: to enforce federal laws, especially given the nature of federalism in our country, especially given the separation of powers on different levels of government.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's what I would say.

[Justin Tseng]: And I do appreciate the positive feedback and the strong support of our residents here.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'm also happy.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll be so brief because I think President Bears has captured a lot of what I think very well.

[Justin Tseng]: I think two things can be true.

[Justin Tseng]: There's a lot of, there are good things about this project, adding beds is something that our city has set as a goal.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know a lot of Councilors ran on and that's something that will alleviate housing costs and address much, much of the problems in the hillside.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, the things that energy efficiency is good and all of that to mixed use development is good.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the other thing can be true too, that there are real concerns about

[Justin Tseng]: shade about the for-profit management company that's going to come in, what that means for the students who are going to live there, their rights, and the accountability process there.

[Justin Tseng]: There's the process concerns that Councilor Bears mentioned, and the need for trust and social trust in a big institution like that, that many of us call neighbors.

[Justin Tseng]: And that means to patch up that trust and to work on that trust means doing things

[Justin Tseng]: that you don't have to do not do more than the bare minimum and doing being a good neighbor.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's the definition of being a good neighbor.

[Justin Tseng]: So engaging with community, addressing resident concerns and all of that.

[Justin Tseng]: Look, we don't have a lot, a lot of tools as a city.

[Justin Tseng]: And there isn't, as Councilor, as President Bears said, there's a power imbalance here.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's something that we all need to get innovative about.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think that's something that this council has been intent on with the many steps that President Perez lays out in this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: I think our residents deserve to be heard by a big institution.

[Justin Tseng]: They deserve to feel like they were heard and were engaged in the process.

[Justin Tseng]: Present.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I just, since I'm on Zoom, I wanted to gather my comments.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanna thank Councilor Collins for these edits and to thank the lawyers and the advocates that she's been liaising with, reaching out to.

[Justin Tseng]: for these amendments as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I think they're entirely logical.

[Justin Tseng]: If you look at the intent of this ordinance, what we're trying to do, what we tried to do as a city council, the edits that are in front of us today make complete sense and are coherent with

[Justin Tseng]: with those purposes, with that intent.

[Justin Tseng]: And they're not over overreaching, they're very in line with what you'd expect across municipalities from an ordinance like this.

[Justin Tseng]: It doesn't only clarify, but it also strengthens those purposes of protecting our civil liberties, of making sure that we're regulating surveillance in the city as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And it clears up any internal debates, inconsistencies that might've been there before.

[Justin Tseng]: And as Councilor Collins noted, some of this is stuff that we talked about when we drafted it first, we gave it some time leaning on more

[Justin Tseng]: on the more conservative side of things, and I think in review over the last

[Justin Tseng]: year and a bit, I believe, of when this ordinance has been in effect, these changes make a lot of sense.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'm excited to support them.

[Justin Tseng]: I hear the questions from my council colleagues.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that between the suggestions from legal and just how

[Justin Tseng]: how the rest of the ordinance is written and how it works in Massachusetts state law, I don't think we have to worry that much about those concerns.

[Justin Tseng]: Thanks.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm calling this committee meeting to order.

[Justin Tseng]: We're meeting on paper 24468, resolution to discuss updates to the city charter, be it resolved by the Metro City Council that the Governance Committee discuss updates to the city charter, including creating a timeline for action and reviewing proposals of the Charter Study Committee once finalized.

[Justin Tseng]: Representatives of the Edward J Collins jr center for public management at Boston are invited to provide an overview of the charter review process and the next steps for the city council.

[Justin Tseng]: Mr. Clerk may call the role.

[Justin Tseng]: Mr. Clerk, can you please hold the roll?

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Five and affirmative, none against.

[Justin Tseng]: Motion passes.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, this is an ordinance that, um, surrounding communities have passed.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and what exactly it is is it's a codification of our non-cooperation, um, uh, policy with federal authorities when it comes to, um, non-criminal immigration matters.

[Justin Tseng]: We've seen, um, in years past, um,

[Justin Tseng]: really difficult situations where cities are forced to upend people's human rights, people's sense of dignity, people's right to an existence in the city where they live.

[Justin Tseng]: And a lot of communities at the time, feeling under attack, feeling endangered during the first Trump presidency,

[Justin Tseng]: really wanted their local governments to protect their existence and their rights.

[Justin Tseng]: While Medford didn't pass a welcoming city ordinance at the time, we did pass an executive order under Mayor Burke that we would not cooperate, that our policy as a city was not to cooperate with ICE on non-criminal matters.

[Justin Tseng]: Now,

[Justin Tseng]: I put this I introduced this agenda item, a few years ago, to the General City Council, because I wanted to quantify that that agreement to make sure that as we move forward into the future that our residents have faith that

[Justin Tseng]: a mayor can't just take that away, and I'm not saying that this mayor will, I'm not saying that any person in particular will, but I know the fear is out there, having talked to friends who belong to the undocumented community here in Medford, which is such an integral part of our own community, that that fear is out there, that a lot of folks

[Justin Tseng]: don't know that this policy even exists in the first place.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's not something that they find read readily searchable.

[Justin Tseng]: And when they look to see the laws of our city, they don't see it as a law.

[Justin Tseng]: And

[Justin Tseng]: This is our chance as a council, I think, to pass this, to codify it, to enshrine it as law, to make sure that they have that feeling of security, that we are able to announce as a city, that we are welcoming of all of our residents, that people don't have to have fear when they interact with people at City Hall.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that this ordinance draft has been

[Justin Tseng]: floating around the committee for a while.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm very grateful to our activist community and to Chair Leming for bringing this back, for putting so much work into it.

[Justin Tseng]: I know Chair Leming really put a lot of work into making sure we had the draft for this meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: And I worked with him a little bit on that draft as well.

[Justin Tseng]: But I know the activist community, our lawyers, especially in the activist community have helped us draft the multiple successive versions of this.

[Justin Tseng]: Look, this I think for me is about fundamental human rights.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, it's about making sure that our residents feel safe and a part of our community.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm very happy to introduce it to the floor tonight I'm very grateful for a trail I mean for

[Justin Tseng]: Acting on the prior motions, I think that this committee or the previous committee passed to reach out to the police chief and to reach out to the school committee and get feedback on the language.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm really excited to see what we can get done on this because it is such an emergency at this point and because the challenges we face as a country in the next four years will be real and we'll have so much to deal with.

[Justin Tseng]: on the municipal level, especially, and every part that we can do as early as possible to mitigate the negative impacts of the incoming presidency, I think will be very, very crucial and very, very important.

[Justin Tseng]: So thank you for giving me this moment.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you for bringing this chair Leming to the committee.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe that in that case.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I believe in that case.

[Justin Tseng]: Um,

[Justin Tseng]: The, the police department can just tell us they don't they don't have a request or anything to give more context about the reporting parts of this.

[Justin Tseng]: the reporting and the complaints enforcement part of this ordinance, a lot of the language is taken straight from the CCOPS ordinance and is language that the police department themselves have already dealt with.

[Justin Tseng]: So nothing should be completely new to the department.

[Justin Tseng]: Nothing should be things that they haven't experienced or haven't done before.

[Justin Tseng]: I would motion to refer this to the City Council and to accept the edits that you have with the section numbers.

[Justin Tseng]: Perhaps a better thing, what we did this year was we tied them to state mechanisms to make sure that they're like tied to the cost of living.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, we can specify that.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, that was that was the internal debate in my mind.

[Justin Tseng]: Thanks.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I'm very happy to go.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, that was another conversation I had in my mind, because I saw that a lot of people online were talking about these two places in particular, and when I was going through the agenda, I was just thinking, okay, well, this might be a good place to get the word out.

[Justin Tseng]: It might be for a college sport, but to really keep up with it and keep making all of us proud.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to thank folks for giving us their input about this.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, these conversations can be contentious in different communities, but I think in Medford here, we really do value safety and we really do value, we see that it's not at conflict with having a good standard of living.

[Justin Tseng]: We know that safety is at the core of having a good standard of living here.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, I spend much of my life as a pedestrian.

[Justin Tseng]: I get made fun of a lot for it, but I do love walking around.

[Justin Tseng]: That includes crossing state roads.

[Justin Tseng]: I think anyone who, and I grew up near, very, a block away from the Felsway.

[Justin Tseng]: So anyone who has very regularly crossed those roads knows the mad dash, right?

[Justin Tseng]: The sprint that you make to avoid being hit.

[Justin Tseng]: It's really easy to pinpoint one or two anecdotes right here and there by all these different roads.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it tells us something when we have anecdotes about every single road in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's at the core why, for me, I'll be voting yes on this tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's just logical to bring our roads all in line with our citywide speed limit as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Test one, two test one, two.

[Justin Tseng]: Sorry, I think you had asked the main questions I had about the residential tax exemption.

[Justin Tseng]: Could you, I know you talked about how we would need more time to set it up if the council wanted to pursue this option.

[Justin Tseng]: Could you give us a more concrete idea, or just in general, how many, if you need more FDEs, more full-time staff working on something like this, what that process would look like?

[Justin Tseng]: I know a concern that some have with a residential tax exemption is that it would disproportionately affect renters.

[Justin Tseng]: Is that something that, could you explain that a little bit?

[Justin Tseng]: Sure.

[Justin Tseng]: And could you maybe explain that in the context of the cities around us that do do a residential tax exemption?

[Justin Tseng]: You mentioned that there's some things that they do that put them in a different spot than us.

[Justin Tseng]: And I was wondering if you could delve into a little bit of detail about that.

[Justin Tseng]: See, thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, the second part of that question.

[Justin Tseng]: Is there are there economic like, reasons why or contextual reasons why other cities around us have adopted the residential exemption?

[Justin Tseng]: Or is it mainly just political in your in your study of things?

[Justin Tseng]: Look, we could re-litigate an election that's already happened.

[Justin Tseng]: There's no need for that right now.

[Justin Tseng]: And I don't want this to, there are important policy questions that we have to vote on.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't want this to get sidetracked.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's important for us to acknowledge that much of the choices that we make as a community about fiscal policy, about budgets, about tax rates, about burdens are

[Justin Tseng]: larger normative questions about what we want the city to look like.

[Justin Tseng]: what this council has done is ask the public to vote on those questions for the first time in a very long time.

[Justin Tseng]: But that's all I'll say about the politics of the situation.

[Justin Tseng]: When it comes to questions like the residential tax exemption, I know this is something that you and your predecessors have come to the council before and talked about.

[Justin Tseng]: And while not all the councilors present may have been there for those meetings, I think a lot of the points that you brought up today

[Justin Tseng]: have been asked and answered at those meetings as well.

[Justin Tseng]: In my first council term, I know, I believe a resolution was introduced onto the floor to hold a meeting talking about the residential tax exemption.

[Justin Tseng]: While I think we can litigate whether

[Justin Tseng]: you know, the administration should be the one coming to us or we should be going to the administration.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that that's an equally important channel for the council to be the one stepping up and asking the questions.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know from this councillor and from a number of councillors who have already served on this council, we've had those questions and asked an answer before.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think I just want to take this moment and

[Justin Tseng]: advise my fellow Councilors that, you know, that's a possibility that we have, is to hold a meeting earlier in the year, as we've done before, to talk about these questions.

[Justin Tseng]: So I don't think this is a question of, are we ready, are we not ready?

[Justin Tseng]: I think for a lot of the Councilors here we've talked for a very long time about how all these moving pieces fit together and we've presented our vision, we understand that this is a policy question, we understand that this is a normative question.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's frankly a little exhausting to have this meeting be sidetracked.

[Justin Tseng]: So I would ask that we focus on the important questions at hand.

[Justin Tseng]: And I would second Councilor Collins' motion for the 175% shift.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Callahan.

[Justin Tseng]: I think something just worth thinking about going into the future is the goal with the youth members, just because working with youth can be just more complex.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think the question is, are we looking for young folks who are really interested in environmental matters?

[Justin Tseng]: Are we looking for just the general youth residents' perspective?

[Justin Tseng]: I think that will guide, that can help guide the language in this ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: I think one way in which that might come about where we might see a situation where we have to deal with that is if the goal is to get young people who are really interested in the environment in, it might make sense to have some tough students who are residents or tough students get involved, but given how the dorms work, they might not be,

[Justin Tseng]: They might spend their whole day in Medford and not have a Medford address, right?

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's just something for us to consider moving forward.

[Justin Tseng]: What is the goal and what support do they have in being integrated as part of the committee?

[Justin Tseng]: Do they get training?

[Justin Tseng]: Who's helping ease them in or tell them what their job is?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think the sit down makes a lot of sense.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I do want to thank trees Medford for all the work that they've done on this, and I do think that they've put a lot of research into it.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this is, you know, we're at the point where like.

[Justin Tseng]: The council's goal is to make sure that this is something that's actionable, that holds up legally as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And because this affects zoning, it is very much a different process, requires a different level of engagement with the material.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think if we can bring together

[Justin Tseng]: us and the department heads to have a sit down before we come back to the committee with another draft.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that would be very, very helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: I think my question would be, we mentioned

[Justin Tseng]: or Theresa Bedford mentioned trimming it down a little bit.

[Justin Tseng]: Does that happen before the sit-down happens?

[Justin Tseng]: I think that should be up to you all to work on it.

[Justin Tseng]: And again, I thank you, Councilor Kallion, for taking this on because this is a very complex ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: It's very involved.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's hard.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it would be too presumptive to give specific feedback on lines in here right now.

[Justin Tseng]: Given that sit down and to do that, to do that here right now.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that there was a letter sent in from former Councilor Knight.

[Justin Tseng]: that brought up some, I think, some pertinent points about how this intersects with our different climate goals and climate policies.

[Justin Tseng]: I wonder if the PDS department planning development sustainability would be helpful in helping us gather some resources and data on that.

[Justin Tseng]: I've done a little bit of digging into how the solar panel question and the tree question intersects.

[Justin Tseng]: There's some

[Justin Tseng]: from a very cursory glance, some mixed research out there.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think the answer is somewhere in the middle of what's been proposed by the former Councilor and what is here.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think that's very much, let's let the experts talk it out and then come back, review it, have us be another pair of eyes on this.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: As we know,

[Justin Tseng]: In the last few years, reproductive rights and gender affirming care, the rights to access those two forms of health care have been particularly at stake in our country.

[Justin Tseng]: Particularly worrying is that even though we live in a state that does a lot to protect these rights, much of what we're seeing nationally is

[Justin Tseng]: requests for municipalities and states to carry out out-of-state orders, so orders that are not from our own state, from authorities not here, to arrest, to get sent information, to prosecute individuals who are seeking or providing gender-affirming care or reproductive health care.

[Justin Tseng]: In the context of all of that happening in the country,

[Justin Tseng]: uh, Councilor Collins and I, as well as President Bears, then President Morell, and Councilor Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: We had a bunch of, um, resolutions on the City Council agenda to have our committee discuss what we can do to best safeguard those rights here, um, in Medford, um, and to make sure that, you know, we're following Massachusetts laws, that we're executing Massachusetts laws, that we're not, um,

[Justin Tseng]: putting ourselves in a situation where we're forced to carry out the laws of a state that we don't belong to.

[Justin Tseng]: There are a lot of different ways to go about it.

[Justin Tseng]: The main focus the last time that this committee met on this subject was focusing more on the police involvement with the issue.

[Justin Tseng]: And so really honing in on the question of arrests and cooperation in that process and essentially establishing a non-cooperation

[Justin Tseng]: process.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, at that meeting, I presented a draft.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the feedback that I got was mostly that it looked like a good draft.

[Justin Tseng]: There were some questions that Councilors had, some people that Councilors wanted me to reach out to.

[Justin Tseng]: So in the meantime, I updated the draft in responding to those questions, as well as reached out to the health care providers in Medford, notably Tufts and Harvard Vanguard.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe Harvard Vanguard was the one that didn't have anyone getting back to us.

[Justin Tseng]: I tried a bunch of times, but I actually did have a sit down with Tufts Medical and their public affairs team, public policy team, and they were fully in support of us having an ordinance like this.

[Justin Tseng]: I think on top of that, it's worth noting that

[Justin Tseng]: I don't know if all the Councilors received this.

[Justin Tseng]: This wasn't sent to the council as a whole.

[Justin Tseng]: I know this was just on an email list from the top reproductive equity rights group in Massachusetts.

[Justin Tseng]: They asked that even though there are state measures in place to defend reproductive health care and gender affirming care, they asked

[Justin Tseng]: municipalities like us to explore ways to stand up for reproductive freedom here in communities like Medford, particularly through ordinances and bylaws.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this draft that we have in front of us is essentially an extension of that effort to ensure safe and fair access to reproductive health care and gender equity care.

[Justin Tseng]: The draft that we have before us is a slight expansion upon what we had at our last committee meeting, particularly given the second resolution that you read out, which broadens the scope that this committee can work with, and in response to some suggestions from residents and activists in the area as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And so what I've done is I've

[Justin Tseng]: basically recrafted this draft with provisions about their access to information, because one of the other problems a lot of municipalities are seeing, especially with regards to abortion care, is the popping up of anti-abortion clinics, which essentially what they do is they sell themselves as reproductive health clinics, they get

[Justin Tseng]: the more vulnerable populations come in to use their services.

[Justin Tseng]: They don't recommend them for the necessary health care procedures, including abortion, but instead

[Justin Tseng]: preach a certain message.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is of a lot of concern because a lot of this behavior is quite predatory.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this is something that a lot of Massachusetts municipalities have started to take action on, to explore ways to put language in their ordinances about fair access, about seeing what we can do to prevent certain centers like this opening up, and to distribute good information, especially in conjunction with our Board of Health.

[Justin Tseng]: And so essentially that's the draft that we just got that Clark Herbie's just distributed via email and in print to us.

[Justin Tseng]: I, I wish I had a chance to get to the sooner so we could review the language here.

[Justin Tseng]: But I was thinking we could, we can take motions at the end, but I was thinking to move that Councilors send feedback to chair Lazzaro and me before our next public health committee meeting on the ordinance language here, as well as

[Justin Tseng]: Well, I'll just let that motion stand there.

[Justin Tseng]: And then I was thinking maybe we want to discuss who we want to consult further and if we want to send this draft out to anyone.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I think that's a great question.

[Justin Tseng]: Essentially, I've gotten a lot of this language from East Hampton, which is kind of the leading municipality on the anti-abortion stuff.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm taking a quick skim through now.

[Justin Tseng]: I think much of this is what they have regarding those centers.

[Justin Tseng]: I can study that further, and then if there is a way to do that, I can integrate it into a future draft.

[Justin Tseng]: I have more ideas to bounce around just as a committee before I dropped any further language.

[Justin Tseng]: But if people have comments on this ordinance, let's stay on this for now.

[Justin Tseng]: I can give you my copy.

[Justin Tseng]: Trailers are looking through the draft.

[Justin Tseng]: I do realize that I did actually about the few sentences on Yeah, I did find it so I can I can also redistribute a new copy an updated copy with that Yes, we can also just bundle or motions, yeah Okay, so

[Justin Tseng]: Aye.

[Justin Tseng]: I know the paper

[Justin Tseng]: from President Bears, then President Morell, and Councilor Collins is quite broad policy-wise on what our committee is authorized to do.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this is just one way of thinking about reproductive health rights.

[Justin Tseng]: I think there are other ways for us to consider, like, I mean, even things as basic as ensuring access to menstrual health products and bathrooms in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: So I just wanted to put that out there as something that our committee can discuss while this paper is still in committee.

[Justin Tseng]: There's also another thing that activists have reached out to us about potentially drafting an ordinance on is, give me one quick sec.

[Justin Tseng]: a local ordinance to ensure pharmacy compliance with the statewide standing order for emergency contraception.

[Justin Tseng]: And I was wondering if that's something that our committee would be interested in discussing while we have this paper in our committee.

[Justin Tseng]: And if so, I can come back to the model ordinance at the next meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: So I believe the state, um, the state action is actually via executive order.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and so it's just to make sure that we are, um, it's to make sure that we're aligning ourselves with the executive order, but also making sure that if that executive order is reversed one day, um, for God knows what reason, um, we still have the protection in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: In that case, I'll motion for me to present some draft language for an ordinance before our next meeting to this committee.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it fits under the second paper that you read out.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: For this paper, I just wanted to start with a broader conversation about the types of questions we want to be asking, the type of data we might want to collect with regards to this question.

[Justin Tseng]: Because I know there's so many different ways to go about it.

[Justin Tseng]: I know there are a lot of concerns with costs as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I was thinking it might be good for us to just meet, talk about some general questions we might want to be asking, and then

[Justin Tseng]: either me or Chair Lazzaro, we can reach out to department heads and community stakeholders to discuss these questions.

[Justin Tseng]: We can also create a list of people we might want to invite to a future meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: I think some specific parts were mentioned, but it was more of a general conversation that I was having, particularly with some moms.

[Justin Tseng]: But moms in that situation where they need to take care of their newborns.

[Justin Tseng]: But I've also recently talked to some people who are in charge of recreational groups in Medford who spend a lot of money on their own to bring in porta-potties.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, stuff like that.

[Justin Tseng]: And so, um, they're interested in seeing what the city can do to help them shift that cost as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm not sure that Commissioner McGibbon or Department Head Hunt or Director Hunt are in the best positions to provide the answers to that question, just because I don't think there is that much data out there right now about the cost and benefit.

[Justin Tseng]: The thing is we could go with a port-a-potty system, but we could also go with other models, which I know some other city staff have been kind of chatting about here and there.

[Justin Tseng]: I think maybe if you reword the motion just to be talking more about city staff in general, that'd be helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: Cause I'm just not sure that they're the ones in the best positions to answer.

[Justin Tseng]: I know we'll probably want to loop in the rec department as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So director Bailey,

[Justin Tseng]: on that effort too.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll second.

[Justin Tseng]: Before we end discussion though, I just wanted to say, um, um, I wanted to reiterate that this is, as other Councilors have said, this is just the start of a long process.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think right now, um, the question, there's a question of who has what information, what's the best way, um, to get all that information.

[Justin Tseng]: And one of the roles of the City Council that I see

[Justin Tseng]: just even broadly, not just with this issue, is that I think one of our jobs is to bring together that information where we can.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know a lot of this information lies outside of city departments as well, so I'll keep reaching out to non-city staff, members of the community who might be able to help us get some data, get some idea of where our priority parks are, how much they're already spending on stuff like this.

[Justin Tseng]: So I can keep working on that.

[Justin Tseng]: I think my vision for this is

[Justin Tseng]: even if this is not the most feasible project in the short term, if we can collect that data and if we can put together a roadmap to get to a place where we can implement it, maybe even get to the point where we can craft together a proposal to present to the mayor during budget season, I think that's my goal at least with this item.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I'm totally in agreement about the equity point.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, especially with so many groups in our city using stuff like this.

[Justin Tseng]: There are groups out there who also just can't afford to have a resource like this.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, even once I passed that just bigger picture.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you Chuck for hopping on this call.

[Justin Tseng]: I think government in general has a responsibility to figure out how we can lower the costs that private residents are spending on things as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And so, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: If one recreational group is spending that much and another recreational group is also spending a lot of money on this, I think it does make sense for government to step in and say, we're gonna provide this resource and it's gonna cost all of us as a society less.

[Justin Tseng]: Aye.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: It was really, really hard for me to see this news this morning, because I think, just

[Justin Tseng]: From my own perspective, Larry's been such a calming presence here on the city council.

[Justin Tseng]: He, you know, is such a good friend.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think above all it's that him being a friend.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm going to remember really well.

[Justin Tseng]: The first few weeks of my term when he really was that part part of that team that like welcome to me and to doing this job.

[Justin Tseng]: to making me feel comfortable to be myself, to speak up, to serve the people.

[Justin Tseng]: He really taught me a lot about who to talk to and, you know, who to ask questions to here.

[Justin Tseng]: But it's even outside of that work, after our council meetings, almost every council meeting, him and I

[Justin Tseng]: And a few other Councilors would stand around and chat, talk about life, talk about things outside of Medford politics, and then things about Medford politics, but mostly just about life.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think getting to know him that way was a real, real honor.

[Justin Tseng]: I wish everyone had the chance to spend that time with him.

[Justin Tseng]: It's really, really difficult, I think, for me to speak tonight, because this is a friend that we're losing.

[Justin Tseng]: and such a loyal public servant to our city.

[Justin Tseng]: A real mainstay of the city council, who's been here longer than any of us.

[Justin Tseng]: So I wanted to thank him for all of that service, for his friendship, and to send my condolences to his family.

[Justin Tseng]: And may he rest in peace.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Leming.

[Justin Tseng]: The questions have been resolved.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm ready to move.

[Justin Tseng]: I've talked to Owen about Director Wartola.

[Justin Tseng]: A little bit about the memos.

[Justin Tseng]: In reading the final National Grid memo and the KTL memo, I feel ready to move forward as a council.

[Justin Tseng]: Present.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I understand, you know, one of the council's main priorities going in before

[Justin Tseng]: Knowing that this might be an option in the coming years was to maximize this senior circuit breaker for the tax deferrals and to push for the senior work-off program to get more of that done.

[Justin Tseng]: It's my understanding that folks can find out more about the senior tax deferral from the assessor's office, is that correct?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: Sorry, Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Collins, I think, touched on a list of positions that, subject to the school committee talks, might be at stake.

[Justin Tseng]: Literacy specialists, school nurses, guidance, mental health specialists, increased class sizes.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, it's not fear-mongering when a lot of this stuff has already happened.

[Justin Tseng]: happening in our school districts.

[Justin Tseng]: We've already had to make a lot of these cuts.

[Justin Tseng]: We've already found it hard to retain our long-term teachers.

[Justin Tseng]: We also need to take a step back and look at this big picture-wise.

[Justin Tseng]: We know when we invest in our schools, your investment and your value of your property goes up as well, that your public safety around you, crime goes down and public safety goes up.

[Justin Tseng]: And so we, I think there are longer, bigger picture benefits to everyone, even if you don't have kids in the schools.

[Justin Tseng]: Touching on the roads real quick, because that's also a part of question seven.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we need to look at the opportunity we lose.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, the basic role of government, of local government is to fix your potholes and to send your kids to school.

[Justin Tseng]: And if we're not, if we can't do either of those, then we're not, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: we're not doing our jobs, but we were asking the voters to give us the tools to do our jobs.

[Justin Tseng]: And something about question seven with the roads and sidewalks is that it would give us a crew that would work full time on fixing our potholes and sidewalks in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: That's something that we don't have right now because our resources are too constrained.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's something that I believe if passed, will show, will give our residents a real benefit, a real benefit that you can see and live in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you for the question.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng, two minutes.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Touching very quickly on the topic of new growth, I think our council is very aware that new growth is the priority for Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: And so when we look at the last three years of new growth, so the last two years plus the estimates that we have right in front of us presented by the assessor,

[Justin Tseng]: It actually shows that our first round of zoning reform, which was the first round in almost 50 years of zoning reform, actually has led to the most new growth our city has seen in decades.

[Justin Tseng]: We are currently working on round two of zoning reform and we are very, very optimistic that that new growth will help us achieve more financial stability going into the future as long as these questions pass.

[Justin Tseng]: I think

[Justin Tseng]: I also have this chart right here.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll do what Councilor Callahan does.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not really easy to see, but you can see that the new growth is growing throughout the last few years with the reforms that we've instituted.

[Justin Tseng]: We are permitting more units as Councilor- Could you put that chart back up?

[Justin Tseng]: We're also permitting more new,

[Justin Tseng]: new units than ever before, as Councilor Scarpellioli states.

[Justin Tseng]: Here's the thing, because on the topic of new growth, we're getting a little bit away from the why now question.

[Justin Tseng]: We have a plan, that plan is being implemented, and the results are already bearing fruit.

[Justin Tseng]: We fell behind decades.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, that's just the truth.

[Justin Tseng]: We fell behind decades.

[Justin Tseng]: And I don't agree with every decision that the mayors previous have taken, but we are in a situation now where we need

[Justin Tseng]: to face the facts as they are now.

[Justin Tseng]: High inflation, lack of new growth over the last few decades means that we need to do a short-term plan, which is these three questions, and then a long-term plan, which is investing in new growth, which is what our zoning efforts are.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: two minutes.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I mean, continuing off of Councilor Leming's points, those conversations are ones that we're having in public.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe that there's an upcoming City Committee of the Whole meeting at some point that we're going to talk about some of how free cash is going to be used.

[Justin Tseng]: I know the mayor submitted a paper to us with her proposal and asking us for feedback.

[Justin Tseng]: That's all in the council records.

[Justin Tseng]: It's all online for folks to find as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Here's the thing about free cash, right, because it's a one time fund, we should be using it on one time expenses.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why we're using it on things like roads on the light poles that President Bears was talking about on HVAC systems and whatnot.

[Justin Tseng]: We all know that these are real things that affect how we experience living in our city, affects our kids in our public buildings, and so they are very important expenses.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, added on top of that is the conversation we would have if we didn't spend that money right now, right?

[Justin Tseng]: Because if we defer maintenance, which I think everyone in the audience today

[Justin Tseng]: acknowledges this has been happening in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: If we defer maintenance, those costs go up as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And so we need to basically map out all of our uses.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why our city has been implementing our capital improvement plans, why we've started to take registries of everything that

[Justin Tseng]: that we're falling behind on maintenance.

[Justin Tseng]: Our buildings director is really good with that work.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's why those funds should be allocated to things like that rather than being used one time on recurring expenses that we can't afford in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: So I feel very strongly about that.

[Justin Tseng]: The bond agencies feel very strongly about that.

[Justin Tseng]: And in fact, if we take the free cash and use that free cash on recurring expenses, it's widely known that the bond agencies would lower our credit rating, as Councilor Callahan mentioned, and our costs for borrowing to do that maintenance work in the future would actually go up.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's something that would be an increased cost on all of us as taxpayers in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: Mr. President.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll be very brief.

[Justin Tseng]: So I did say that we approve these because we saw that voting.

[Justin Tseng]: So two Councilors, but pay attention.

[Justin Tseng]: I am paying attention.

[Justin Tseng]: You didn't read the budget, but anyways.

[Justin Tseng]: It's embarrassing, man.

[Justin Tseng]: And I believe the financial task force has been pretty open in saying that we believe that with new growth coming in,

[Justin Tseng]: in talking to the developers who are looking to develop on the properties that we're rezoning for and looking at the projects that are coming into our city, we believe that we won't need to ask for another override until that exclusion for that school.

[Justin Tseng]: That's something that we, you know, are very open in conversations that we have with our planning department staff, with our assessing staff here in the city council chambers and in their offices as well.

[Justin Tseng]: you know, we can plan to a certain threshold, but then we need to find the source of revenue that we have to pay for that project before we move on that much further.

[Justin Tseng]: So it's premature.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, Councilor Tseng two minutes.

[Justin Tseng]: ability to do the basics.

[Justin Tseng]: But

[Justin Tseng]: we do need the money first to be able to engage in a real comprehensive renegotiation of what that school day looks like, of what programs we can offer.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is just the point of disagreement between me and my fellow Councilor.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Medford parents and Medford students know that our schools don't offer the same programming the other school districts do.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Medford parents, Medford students know that we're falling short and that we have a lot of programming that we need to catch up on.

[Justin Tseng]: It's, you know, we have great teachers doing arts programs, sports programs, coaches doing sports programs, et cetera.

[Justin Tseng]: That's great.

[Justin Tseng]: But the question is, are we where we should be comprehensively?

[Justin Tseng]: You know, we've already had to merge drama classes to cut offerings in the arts in the last budget.

[Justin Tseng]: The question is,

[Justin Tseng]: do we stay there, do we keep with that, or do we expand our offerings for our children?

[Justin Tseng]: Great, Councilor Tseng, two minutes.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to speak to the grant part of things.

[Justin Tseng]: I know, as President Bears said before, our city departments work very, very hard to apply to as many grants as possible.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think when we think about applying to grants, which I'm totally behind, I think we should do, we should maximize it.

[Justin Tseng]: We also have to keep in mind that

[Justin Tseng]: it takes a team of grant writers and grant managers after we get that grant to put that grant into practice and do all the reporting and counting that we need for that.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that actually takes a lot of staff capacity on the city hall end right now that we don't have that general fund capacity for either.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's, you know, another, I think, reason why

[Justin Tseng]: paying attention to like increasing the revenue for our city government is so, so important, because it allows us to eventually, eventually gives us the freedom to, to have people in place to be applying to those grants that make more money over, over time.

[Justin Tseng]: So it's kind of like a stone rolling down a mountain collecting dirt.

[Justin Tseng]: I, another thing about grants though, is that oftentimes they're not over a long enough period of time for us to be able to retain the staff that we want to, as Councilor Callahan mentioned, like if you're a teacher, you want to make sure that you can stay in that position next year, that you're, you're having that job or else you're, you're applying to other jobs.

[Justin Tseng]: Right?

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's the case when we apply for grants as well.

[Justin Tseng]: That's why, you know, we have great workers in city hall hired on grants, but a lot of them don't,

[Justin Tseng]: are looking for other jobs because they don't have that stability.

[Justin Tseng]: And so we need to give our city that financial, in my opinion, that financial stability.

[Justin Tseng]: On the points of competitive salaries, I think it's really important to also consider that our teachers are competing or our school systems competing with private schools as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And that there's this, there's a race to

[Justin Tseng]: to pay teachers more, to pay for diversity, all of that is affecting how our ability to retain our staff and to hire new staff as well.

[Justin Tseng]: That's not to mention the district-specific characteristics that come out in a union bargaining sessions.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Justin Tseng]: governance committee, October 9, 2024, paper 24-468, resolution to discuss updates to the city charter.

[Justin Tseng]: This is...

[Justin Tseng]: This is a meeting on just starting the whole charter review process from the city council's end.

[Justin Tseng]: I've prepared some slides, basically going through what charter review is, what our role in it is, and what types of issues we'll be thinking about over the next few months.

[Justin Tseng]: I've also invited the members of the Charter Study Committee to join our meeting as well, although these are two kind of different tracks of work.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm going to share my slides.

[Justin Tseng]: Give me one second.

[Justin Tseng]: Great.

[Justin Tseng]: Cool.

[Justin Tseng]: So,

[Justin Tseng]: What is the city charter?

[Justin Tseng]: I'm not gonna go through everything in my slides, but I did compile a bunch of information from the call-in centers, presentations to the charter study committee, mass general law and the state constitution in the slide deck.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm gonna send it out to everyone after.

[Justin Tseng]: So we have one central place of information for the members of this committee and for the public to refer back to as well.

[Justin Tseng]: That way, we don't have to pour through different Google Doc folders of information.

[Justin Tseng]: Essentially, the city charter is our mini constitution.

[Justin Tseng]: It creates our city as a legal entity.

[Justin Tseng]: It establishes our city's powers, defines our government's operational structures, like creating local offices, distributing powers and responsibilities, et cetera.

[Justin Tseng]: A little bit about our current charter.

[Justin Tseng]: We have a modified plan A form of government.

[Justin Tseng]: I put the definitions below.

[Justin Tseng]: Essentially, the plan system's not really used anymore.

[Justin Tseng]: Our city charter's also spread across documents, which is kind of a hassle and a bit of a problem, and it has not been comprehensively reviewed in decades.

[Justin Tseng]: Some reasons for why we're doing, why the city,

[Justin Tseng]: has been pursuing charter review, we want to be keeping up with a modern understanding of the best practices of local government, ensuring that our government's responsive to the needs and preferences of the current population, keeping consistent with changes in our state federal laws, values, cultural changes as well, clarifying any confusing or disputed text, and providing transparency on how we operate.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, all of these reasons are why Charter Review is maybe one of the more exciting projects that we're working on this term.

[Justin Tseng]: It's a very big picture project, and it's going to be all hands on deck.

[Justin Tseng]: So, I think this part is important to let all of us know what the charter review process is like.

[Justin Tseng]: There's essentially two main ways of doing charter review.

[Justin Tseng]: One, I don't know if folks remember, the city council took a vote last term on a home rule petition to start the charter review process that passed 4-3 and the state legislature asked for five votes on that, which at that time we didn't have.

[Justin Tseng]: The mayor,

[Justin Tseng]: created a charter study committee, and that kind of leads us into the second way of doing charter review, which is by special act.

[Justin Tseng]: And so special act as laid out in mass general law, first, there has to be a passage by majority vote at our city council of the text of the resolution proposing the special legislation.

[Justin Tseng]: It needs to go to the state legislature to enact the proposed legislation, then

[Justin Tseng]: They got it, the assigned committee in the state legislature has to hear it, they have to approve it, and the governor signs it.

[Justin Tseng]: Pretty standard process.

[Justin Tseng]: Even though it's done by special act, it has the force of a city charter.

[Justin Tseng]: So where does, you know, things like the charter study committee fit into this, um, for our charter review process done through special act, it's pretty regular to have a preliminary study committee, make proposals to us, the city council and to the mayor as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, that's what we're going to be doing over the next few months, reviewing the different, um, parts of the city charter that, um, proposals that were handed.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and oftentimes, um, a non-binding vote of the public is held on the proposed charter as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So substance-wise, forms of government, this is kind of one of the big questions.

[Justin Tseng]: You have mayor council as one major option.

[Justin Tseng]: That's the current form we have.

[Justin Tseng]: Some cities have a council manager system.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll give you the spoilers and tell you that I don't think the Charter Study Committee has chosen to switch a form of government.

[Justin Tseng]: But if you're interested in reading the options,

[Justin Tseng]: Because, you know, we are going to be reviewing this, I've laid out the bullet points comparing contrast.

[Justin Tseng]: These are from the Collins Center, I believe.

[Justin Tseng]: And then I have more bullet points for your own reference on other slides, if you want to look at the difference between the different systems.

[Justin Tseng]: it's probably gonna be something we talk about too.

[Justin Tseng]: There's also differences between a strong mayor or weaker mayor system.

[Justin Tseng]: That's all done via like different parts of the charter and not necessarily by plan.

[Justin Tseng]: At least that's not the best practices now.

[Justin Tseng]: So what does the charter establish for elected officials, kind of relevant to people like us?

[Justin Tseng]: Term length, term limits, powers, duties, how we fill vacancies, compensation for elected positions, and the composition of the city council and the school committee, including the mayor's roles.

[Justin Tseng]: some different, I know there's been a lot of talk in the city about ward rep, ward representation, so electing, having city councilors elected by district.

[Justin Tseng]: There are a few different, you know, different compositions of ward representation as well, different formulations of, you know, how many people do what, what types of wards you have, sizes of wards that we have, sizes of districts that we're drawing for city council school committee elections.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know the,

[Justin Tseng]: study committee has looked at that as well.

[Justin Tseng]: That's something that I think we're going to probably be spending a lot of time thinking about.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm not going to go through this, but the Collins Center has provided a generic modern charter.

[Justin Tseng]: In looking at the minutes of the study commission's meetings and in looking at how to structure all these different conversations that we might have, separating into these 10 articles seems to be quite helpful, and I would suggest

[Justin Tseng]: Just as the chair of the committee, I think it makes sense that we in thinking about how to set up a timeline, which is one of my goals for this meeting, we think about how like dividing it up into articles as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and these, yep.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: The charter, the charter study committee's recommendations will use, um, this format.

[Justin Tseng]: And, um, there are, there are sections that will basically.

[Justin Tseng]: be very, very similar to what the generic charter says.

[Justin Tseng]: The generic charter is put, they've uploaded it into the Google Drive folder of the Charter Study Committee's presentation.

[Justin Tseng]: So you can check it out there.

[Justin Tseng]: It's about 20 pages.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's like this, broken up into these 10 sections in this order.

[Justin Tseng]: There seems to be some sections that

[Justin Tseng]: are really up to us in general, the public, to fill in.

[Justin Tseng]: Some of them are much more like there is established practice for the language in there.

[Justin Tseng]: And then these are just some other topics that we might consider outside of the 10 drawn out in the generic modern charter.

[Justin Tseng]: There are places for in the modern charter by they didn't fit in the column centers descriptions of each article.

[Justin Tseng]: So I just pulled them out separately.

[Justin Tseng]: But yeah, no.

[Justin Tseng]: we will be looking at things like financial procedures and how we do budgeting in the city, how we rules for elections, citizen participation.

[Justin Tseng]: So petitions, initiatives, referendums, that all has to fall under the constraints of state law as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Periodic reviews of the charter of ordinances as well, looking at appointments, confirmations to multi-member boards,

[Justin Tseng]: seeing, you know, do we, who's appointing, who's confirming, is there confirming power there as well?

[Justin Tseng]: And public comment as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I guess the point of this meeting that I wanted to go after was just developing a general timeline we can work with and also developing any questions we have at this point for the mayor's office, for legal, for the study committee members as well.

[Justin Tseng]: or any general comments, too, to help us structure, like, because this is such a big project, how we're going to go forward.

[Justin Tseng]: Could you jump back to the slide with the different sections?

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll do this slide first, and then if you want me to, if members want me to change over, I can change over.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Lazzaro?

[Justin Tseng]: Exactly.

[Justin Tseng]: We could invite them to the meeting, although they might want separate meetings with different languages, so that might be more of a community-zone thing.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think it's very natural have nuanced takes on standardized tests, um, you know, there there's so many, there are different levels, there are different occasions where these questions apply to.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's really important when we're looking at a ballot referendum question to look at the text right there and the text right there is about MCAS's graduation requirement.

[Justin Tseng]: the MCAS will still exist.

[Justin Tseng]: And in fact, something that a lot of residents, not just the Medford, but a lot of residents across the state don't know is that there are other ways that teachers are using now that, you know, some of them are state run, some of them are from schools, but there are ways that teachers are tracking student growth and student progress.

[Justin Tseng]: There's a test, an alternative test.

[Justin Tseng]: It's pretty different from MCAS, but it is still a standardized way to measure growth.

[Justin Tseng]: being offered in our schools, offered, I believe, three times a year, at least in middle schools.

[Justin Tseng]: This is from my conversation with middle school teachers.

[Justin Tseng]: So that, you know, that rigor is still very much there.

[Justin Tseng]: When we look at who exactly is being denied graduation from MCAS,

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's important to note that 75% of those who failed MCAS are people who are also not meeting standards already set by their school district.

[Justin Tseng]: And so, you know, rigor is the worry, then that's a major data point to consider.

[Justin Tseng]: But then the question leads to what is that other 25%?

[Justin Tseng]: And we see very clearly in the data that that other 25% actually tends to be English as second language students who actually, when they sit down with a translator, work through the exams, actually pass the exams very well, but aren't accustomed to how we do

[Justin Tseng]: high stakes testing here in Massachusetts or in this country.

[Justin Tseng]: And so there's a cultural barrier there, a language barrier.

[Justin Tseng]: What's great is that our teachers, and I know you know this, won't let anyone fall behind.

[Justin Tseng]: It's a dedication to them, it's a duty, it's a vocation.

[Justin Tseng]: It's also part of their job description.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this is a measure I feel comfortable supporting, and I would urge our residents to vote for it as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, I just wanted to note, I had a comment after we finished talking about rodents.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to note that I have a comment after we talked about rodents.

[Justin Tseng]: Very close.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, this is such a grave matter.

[Justin Tseng]: facing, you know, I think this is one of the examples where something national can really have local impacts on the national conversation that we've been having about immigration about race about, you know, about acceptance and inclusion does have local results and we see that in Springfield, Ohio, and you know, well Springfield, Ohio is not meant for Massachusetts.

[Justin Tseng]: The lessons that Springfield imports to us, I think, are real lessons for Medford and a real wake-up call for municipalities around the country.

[Justin Tseng]: There's been really wild, extreme accusations being launched against Haitian migrants who've moved to Ohio

[Justin Tseng]: who've moved to Springfield, Ohio, in search of work and a life away from, you know, difficult and dangerous living situations back in Haiti.

[Justin Tseng]: This is a story I think that Haitian Americans here in Medford relate to and know a lot about.

[Justin Tseng]: And what's been said has

[Justin Tseng]: You know, the accusations being launched have been really difficult and led to really dangerous outcomes for people just trying to live a normal life in the ground.

[Justin Tseng]: We've seen that schools have been canceled because of bomb threats and because of threats against Haitian students, against kindergartners trying to go to picture day.

[Justin Tseng]: We've seen the windows of cars, of homes of Haitian immigrants in Ohio being smashed, and we've seen both the dangerous rhetoric but dangerous results spread outside of Ohio as well.

[Justin Tseng]: The Haitian community is so important to Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: It's so important to all of us.

[Justin Tseng]: I couldn't imagine our city without that.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think this is, the last few weeks have been a particularly difficult time for Haitian Americans and Haitian Medford residents as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I wanted them to know that we stand with them as well.

[Justin Tseng]: It's a difficult subject for me to speak about because the racist tropes that have been peddled

[Justin Tseng]: which I don't want to repeat, have been things that I've heard growing up here as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, to people, it might seem like a joke, and it might seem like, you know, something that they've heard from someone else before, or something that just seems funny to say about someone, but I think this serves as a constant reminder that jokes and insensitive rhetoric can lead to real

[Justin Tseng]: threats to personal safety, to people just trying to live their everyday life, to contribute to our society, to give to our country.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's important for us to stand up for all of our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: I just realized that we actually submitted this together, and I was wondering if we could get Vice President Collins' name added to this resolution as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm trying to review is one of those topics that has been a great excitement in our community.

[Justin Tseng]: I know there are lots of folks who are very interested in talking about improving our electoral system improving the balance between different branches of our government.

[Justin Tseng]: and talking about how we can modernize our city.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that this is a chance to take a wonderful step forward in moving our city forward and to modernize our institutions to make sure that they're more responsive, that they're more representative of our city and more cooperative, that everyone is acting more cooperatively with each other.

[Justin Tseng]: Now the charter really underlies everything we do as a city.

[Justin Tseng]: It's essentially our mini constitution.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and so the process of updating our charter, um, as people who have been really interested now has taken a while.

[Justin Tseng]: It's a natural, natural step when it comes to such a big project, but this is, uh, we're getting close to when the city council has to act on it.

[Justin Tseng]: really shake up the city and to also give Councilors enough time to contemplate what we're voting on before something theoretically could pass the city council.

[Justin Tseng]: be introduced to this topic and to get everyone up to speed with the basics of the conversations we might be having going forward.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, this resolution comes out of discussions I've had, um, with community members of the last few years, um, around the city about having access to sanitary facilities, um, while in our, in our public spaces and

[Justin Tseng]: you know, public spaces owned by the city and in commercial spaces that we really want people to frequent like Medford Square.

[Justin Tseng]: This, you know, having sanitary facilities in public is both a public health issue, and it's also a quality of life issue.

[Justin Tseng]: I've also heard, particularly recently, but I've heard from in the past two from community members who've spoken about high costs that they bear for

[Justin Tseng]: having to hire to rent porta potties for sports events or community events that they hold in our parks as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I've heard from some people with the numbers that they've been paying over the years and

[Justin Tseng]: It looks like it really might make much more economic sense if our city takes the lead on this one and saves everyone a little bit more money and if we make the investment now.

[Justin Tseng]: But, you know, this is a big project, it's going to require a lot of thinking through logistics, it's going to require a lot of thinking through concerns as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I have been talking to some city staff

[Justin Tseng]: who have some views and proposals about how we could do this at a lower cost and how we can make sure that we keep up with the maintenance of this idea.

[Justin Tseng]: But again, this will require discussion, walking through the logistics, and that's why I want to motion to refer this to the Committee on Public Health, because I think if we can hold a committee meeting on this and invite stakeholders to talk about benefits and concerns, we can really craft a pretty solid proposal here.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to thank both Councilor Scarpelli and President Bears for the resolutions on this.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we all know that this is a really important issue for public health, for quality of living here in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: It's, as Councilor Scarpelli said, it's not just Fulton Heights.

[Justin Tseng]: but this happening in Fulton Heights is particularly concerning because it's not the place that's used to this.

[Justin Tseng]: South Medford and Wellington have been particularly hit hard by the rodent infestation over the last few years.

[Justin Tseng]: Anecdotally, talking to neighbors, some of the methods we have employed seem to have been working.

[Justin Tseng]: There is a slight decrease anecdotally talking to my neighbors about this.

[Justin Tseng]: However, rodents are still there.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's really important to note that we did hold a Committee of the Whole on this a few months ago, where we had a long conversation with the Director of the Board of Health about methods that we could employ to combat this.

[Justin Tseng]: this problem.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, Councilor Collins has alluded to the public education piece, which really has to be a very, very big part of it.

[Justin Tseng]: That message was reinforced over and over again at that meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: It would be lovely to get this resolution passed, to sit down with the Director of the Board of Health and other stakeholders to get an update on those strategies, to see how we're doing,

[Justin Tseng]: are there, what are the metrics that we're using to measure and how are we doing on those metrics?

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's also really important to note that the council has been working really hard on this.

[Justin Tseng]: We have a resolution coming to our, an ordinance coming to our next meeting about wildlife feeding, reduce, basically

[Justin Tseng]: regulating that so that we're discouraging rodent behavior.

[Justin Tseng]: Past councils have also passed ordinances tackling rodent infestations as well, which city staff have reported back with metrics showing that they have been useful.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to quickly thank everyone for coming up and speaking about this.

[Justin Tseng]: I think everyone had something super productive to add to the conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: I think in the future, with this resolution passed, with more meetings about this, the more voices we can get, the more advice that we can get.

[Justin Tseng]: will be able to make some positive progress on this.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Mr. Benedetto's statements actually reminded me of something I wanted to say, which is that I think we have to think in terms of our messaging and our strategy, we need to go in two new directions with this.

[Justin Tseng]: One is to

[Justin Tseng]: go more local.

[Justin Tseng]: I know my own neighborhood held a road in control meeting, basically neighbors educating each other about the best ways to get rid of road in control now.

[Justin Tseng]: That's something that should be less neighbors doing it and city coming in and

[Justin Tseng]: City leaders coming in and helping organize those meetings.

[Justin Tseng]: So the local aspect is very, very important.

[Justin Tseng]: And as much as we can harness that organic momentum, the better.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we also need to think bigger too and recognize that the road control problem is also a regional problem.

[Justin Tseng]: And so the more that we can do to set up institutions where Councilors like us, city employees from Medford are working with city employees and Councilors in neighboring municipalities to deal with projects that are on the border, I think the better we can serve our residents too.

[Justin Tseng]: So building those channels of communication I think will be really important.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, I like Vice President Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: I disagree with a lot of the premises put out there and to the best effort of Councilors to get me to vote no on this, I do intend to vote yes on this.

[Justin Tseng]: I, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: I do believe that the text of the resolution that's in front of us is what we have to debate.

[Justin Tseng]: And I agree with what's being said in the resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: I agree with greater transparency.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's good when we as the city council have more oversight over these issues, when we are much more to know about these issues, when we can inform our residents about what's going on.

[Justin Tseng]: any motion that I think, any motion or resolution that reasonably increases transparency in our community is something that I would support.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I do plan on voting yes on this.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Calderon.

[Justin Tseng]: with my fellow Councilors' statement that this has maybe gone astray, I'd like to move the question.

[Justin Tseng]: All right.

[Justin Tseng]: Present.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's neither here nor there.

[Justin Tseng]: I think

[Justin Tseng]: the enforcement, I should say, everything is very clear, I think, and fair and just.

[Justin Tseng]: She knew what every student needed.

[Justin Tseng]: memories of Ms.

[Justin Tseng]: Irving as a teacher is how much she trusted her students to handle responsibility and to do adult tasks.

[Justin Tseng]: doing those tasks that seemed really difficult to a seventh grader.

[Justin Tseng]: Ms.

[Justin Tseng]: Irving will be someone I think Medford will miss a lot.
