[Justin Tseng]: And again, I thank Councilor Scarpelli for putting this on the agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: Sorry, could you repeat that once more?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: Lots being said tonight, and I think we need to unpack this resolution a little bit.

[Justin Tseng]: ultimately seems like there's a legal question and political question here.

[Justin Tseng]: And the resolution put in front of us, and the way it was put in front of us, I think, presented it as a legal question.

[Justin Tseng]: But the comments from the Councilor proposing this resolution tonight seem to have taken it in a political direction.

[Justin Tseng]: And

[Justin Tseng]: You know, when it comes to that political direction, that political question, I think we've been very clear that we are audited regularly, annually by an independent auditor.

[Justin Tseng]: And it would be quite an ask to take this one step further, given what we all know about the budget.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, what the text of this resolution is, is a legal question.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's how I will be making my vote tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, I think the rhetoric from some folks seems to want to back the council into a yes vote with some questions framed to get us to vote a certain way.

[Justin Tseng]: But ultimately, because this is a legal matter, I think what truly matters here, the first question we have to ask is about the legitimacy of the allegations being charged.

[Justin Tseng]: Is this a legitimate question?

[Justin Tseng]: Is this the path forward, if that is the legitimate question?

[Justin Tseng]: And why don't we just ask the AG for a legal opinion, right?

[Justin Tseng]: I think, furthermore, on the topic of legitimacy, let's unpack this one step further.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we've been very clear that the council rules can be suspended.

[Justin Tseng]: This is regularly, we do this at almost every single meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, I wanna speak from my perspective, why I've voted to suspend this, because I come from a different position or I actually don't know where my other councillors stand on this, but I don't think rule 21 is a rule that pursues transparency or accountability.

[Justin Tseng]: Let's just take that budget meeting that we're talking about.

[Justin Tseng]: Hundreds of people attended that budget meeting in person and on Zoom, expecting us to take those votes, the budget votes and the proposition votes that night.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, oftentimes, when we suspend rules, when we table items, I get emails and phone calls asking why we've done that, why they haven't seen a final vote on it.

[Justin Tseng]: Residents first get confused, and then they get frustrated, and then they feel cut out of the political process because they don't understand what's going on.

[Justin Tseng]: They've taken this time to come to a meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: They've hired a babysitter to come in for that night.

[Justin Tseng]: they're expected to do that two weeks later, to do that another week, to do that on and on and on.

[Justin Tseng]: And that is not a fair ask of our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: Now on top of that, the letter that the councilor sent to the attorney general and the state auditor didn't only mention Rule 21, but also mentioned vast general law, a certain section which I don't know off the top of my head, but has been said over and over tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, at our previous meeting, we read out that section of the law.

[Justin Tseng]: We walked through it, clause by clause, explained it, and it was evident from the language of the law itself that it applied to getting three vote items, or three items that required three readings, voted in one night.

[Justin Tseng]: That's what that law applies to.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not any willy nilly thing that we pass on to the agenda that shows up as a resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: It applies to resolutions and papers that require three votes.

[Justin Tseng]: And that law gives city councils, it empowers city councils to pass those three reading items in one night.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, that wasn't what the Councilor tried to apply that state law for.

[Justin Tseng]: We tried to explain that to my fellow Councilor.

[Justin Tseng]: And understandably, it was not heard.

[Justin Tseng]: But I can't change what the law says.

[Justin Tseng]: The law says what it says.

[Justin Tseng]: It applies to that very specific case.

[Justin Tseng]: And so ultimately, this then becomes null.

[Justin Tseng]: It becomes void.

[Justin Tseng]: It becomes illegitimate.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, I think on going back to some of the questions about finances and whatnot, if we have personal questions, and Councilor Lummi explained this at the last meeting, and this is what I do, and this is what I know other councilors do.

[Justin Tseng]: If we have questions as a city councilor about the things that we are voting on, it behooves us.

[Justin Tseng]: We have the power to pick up our phone, to dial a number of city staff and call in and ask those questions about our city staff.

[Justin Tseng]: And that is just part of the political process.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, if there was a legitimate legal question here, I would be happy to vote yes.

[Justin Tseng]: But we cannot go down the path of indecision and logjamming ourselves because of bad faith attempts to stall simple work that city councils have regularly done and regularly do, including the city council before any of us were elected.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, if there was a real violation of the First Amendment right to free speech, I would take that as an affront to democracy.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think folks who tune in week in and week out will find that there is no shortage of free speech in the city council, especially from my fellow city councilor.

[Justin Tseng]: I worry that a vote forward on this would open a Pandora's box of allegations and rhetoric and tools.

[Justin Tseng]: The spying work being done in any direction from the city council and

[Justin Tseng]: You know, my hope is, especially given the events of the last few weeks, that we tone down our political tenor and tone down our political rhetoric to stop the finger pointing, to take a step back and learn how to disagree respectfully.

[Justin Tseng]: No.

[Justin Tseng]: The three points we put one and then like parentheses, two parentheses, three parentheses.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: Mrs. Lasky was my fourth grade teacher.

[Justin Tseng]: She is such a legendary teacher that even before I made it to fourth grade, she was the cool teacher that everyone wanted to be in her class.

[Justin Tseng]: She did so many creative activities with students.

[Justin Tseng]: I remember

[Justin Tseng]: she used to run classroom elections, and everyone got really excited and involved.

[Justin Tseng]: And even if you didn't get a spot, I think you felt a buy-in into the classroom.

[Justin Tseng]: You felt like you were part of a group of people working together and building a community.

[Justin Tseng]: That's something that she did so, so well.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I remember

[Justin Tseng]: It's so funny.

[Justin Tseng]: I remember after a parent-teacher meeting that I wasn't at, she gave my parents really outside-of-the-box tips for how to get me out of my shell and how to get me more comfortable just making friends and speaking out for myself.

[Justin Tseng]: And those tips, I think, have carried through with me through the years.

[Justin Tseng]: And I hope I've done you well.

[Justin Tseng]: Another, I think, amazing moment was when Mrs. Lasky brought in her husband, Fred, to teach us about the MWRA and to teach us so much about how the water system works here in Medford and why water conservation is important.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's small memories like that that I think really lead to the happiness of a childhood.

[Justin Tseng]: It's all those nostalgic memories that we look

[Justin Tseng]: At least I'm looking back on a lot recently with all these retirements.

[Justin Tseng]: Mrs. Lasky, thank you for your service.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you for your 25 years of service to the Medford Public Schools and for helping them since 2001.

[Justin Tseng]: You mean so, so much, not just to me, but to so many members of our community.

[Justin Tseng]: I really want to both celebrate

[Justin Tseng]: this moment, and to say that I will be sad that when I go back to the McGlynn, I won't see you there.

[Justin Tseng]: But I know I will see you around Medford, and I look forward to seeing you around a lot more often now.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to bolster, you know, you had mentioned that I think it's really important to say that we shouldn't mistake caution for support.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, I think a number of us on the city council have been really cautious with what we've said in the last two weeks because of what our legal counsel and because what our policy experts have advised us to be careful to say in a public forum.

[Justin Tseng]: But I have, you know, encouraged folks to,

[Justin Tseng]: make phone calls to me to discuss this issue, because I think that you'd be surprised to find that I see this issue very similarly as a lot of you all.

[Justin Tseng]: I came in planning to support, and I did, you know, by a 6-1 vote, we did pass Councilor Scarpelli's resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: I agree with Councilor Berrios' comment that this wasn't the best location for this project and it wasn't the best process for the project, and I appreciate that Councilor Scarpelli put forward a resolution to help us reform the process.

[Justin Tseng]: There's been a lot said about the notifications and the transparency and the outreach of the process.

[Justin Tseng]: I spent hours on phone calls last week with city staff, including with the director of planning, who promised soon a better outreach and transparency process, particularly involving the city council, so we can help get out the word better too.

[Justin Tseng]: Something that we are meeting tomorrow night in resident services, the resident services committee is creating a user guide for city council to make our rules clearer and more accessible, especially if this is your first time coming to a city council meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: So those are just some points I wanted to bring up just to clarify and to bolster.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Name and address for the record please, you have three minutes.

[Justin Tseng]: Any other comments, Councilor Tseng, um, I just wanted to thank you for your patience tonight and for coming here.

[Justin Tseng]: So, you know, with so much, so many materials for us to review before the meeting and to look at during the meeting as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And for being so prepared for our questions, um, I don't look for at all, um, five minute walk at most, if not three minute walk,

[Justin Tseng]: I'm quite excited about this because I've always believed that our history in Medford is something that makes us unique and makes us stand out as a city even in such a historic area.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Medford's history is so rich and to be able to protect it in the physical manner I think is so important.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'm happy to support.

[Justin Tseng]: I understand that there are concerns to talk through and I would

[Justin Tseng]: respect that as well.

[Justin Tseng]: But I wanted to thank you for your work.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanna say I'm excited for it.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng, sorry.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm excited for this.

[Justin Tseng]: I think our community needs this.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to assess our needs and the feasibility of a project that so many residents have been asking for.

[Justin Tseng]: Great, motion's on the floor.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: And Councilor Callahan.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Chief of Staff Nazarian.

[Justin Tseng]: Agree or disagree with the specifics of the plan, I have to say it's really quite remarkable that in my time following it for politics, this is the first time I've seen a free cash plan laid out for the next few years like this in such a transparent manner, inviting us as a city council to take part in that.

[Justin Tseng]: I really appreciate that effort.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it really needs to be said.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the plan also exemplifies the fact that we are spending this on one-time expenses, right?

[Justin Tseng]: This is the sustainable way to do it.

[Justin Tseng]: I know Councilors have been reiterating that message all night.

[Justin Tseng]: It also highlights the fact that as much as I've advocated for using parts of it on recurring costs to cover one year, if we followed certain proposals, we would just be pushing the deadline, the cliff off by a year, right?

[Justin Tseng]: And we need to make difficult decisions now.

[Justin Tseng]: Very shortly, I think there are two core lessons that we've been hearing tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: These lessons are why I would support this.

[Justin Tseng]: The first one is being, you know, free cash should be used on one time expenses, rather than recurring because we can't count on them.

[Justin Tseng]: We can't count on the number for the future.

[Justin Tseng]: The second lesson being that, um,

[Justin Tseng]: free cash needs to be certified, and oftentimes that process can take many, many months, usually until the spring, but we can't say for sure.

[Justin Tseng]: God forbid something awful happens in our city that we need that free cash for, we need to put money into the Stable Legislation Fund for us to take, to be able to cover that expense, for us to fix that problem.

[Justin Tseng]: And if we don't vote this through tonight, we don't have that money.

[Justin Tseng]: So that problem could be left, we could be left out to dry for a very long time.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think one additional note for the city council is that this actually gives us more say in how the money is spent as well.

[Justin Tseng]: When we take money from the stabilization fund, the city council will have to approve that.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that gives us an additional level of oversight that we haven't had before.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'm in support of this.

[Justin Tseng]: That's why I seconded both the BPAPE and the paper.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng?

[Justin Tseng]: I'm in favor of it for many of the reasons that Councilor Collins, Vice President Collins mentioned.

[Justin Tseng]: I was curious if you had any clear departments or positions that you had in mind for now, or if those is just like a proactive.

[Justin Tseng]: Any further comments, Councilor Tseng?

[Justin Tseng]: I have to say I'm still making my mind up, but to your point, if you're thinking about it that way, then we should recognize that the raised cost for the school committee is basically just a little bit over 2% over those last almost 20 years.

[Justin Tseng]: And

[Justin Tseng]: it's off of a baseline that's much smaller, right?

[Justin Tseng]: And so it's still 2%, right?

[Justin Tseng]: And she's still doing whoever the mayor is, the mayor, whoever serves in that position is still doing those two legally separate roles.

[Justin Tseng]: So if you're thinking about it like that, I would just urge you to

[Justin Tseng]: use that logic to apply if I don't know if I'm making sense to you, but I'm just saying the baseline, the base number is different.

[Justin Tseng]: And so, you know, whilst we can say that the chair of the school committee did receive a raise.

[Justin Tseng]: we should think of that as separate from the mayoral role, because they are just two completely separate entities with two completely different salaries.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm just putting that out there.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm still making my mind up on it, but if I'm understanding your line of thinking, I would urge you to think that way as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Let's call the roll.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: As everyone I think in this room knows, this has not been an easy budget season, not an easy budget year.

[Justin Tseng]: We knew about this for many, many years now.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll be frank with you, this budget is imperfect.

[Justin Tseng]: As I think, as you acknowledge in your statements, and before we got your final proposal, before we got the additional context, which Vice President Collins reminded us about, I was ready to vote no on it if I was uncomfortable with it.

[Justin Tseng]: The additional papers that you've sent that have been put on the agenda, I think provide the context that I need to feel more comfortable voting for this budget.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not enough, like you said.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to do better by our schools.

[Justin Tseng]: I ran on a platform that was mostly around increasing school funding.

[Justin Tseng]: It's one of the two core reasons why I got into local politics in the first place.

[Justin Tseng]: As a student, I really benefited from a lot of the programs that we have been talking about for the last few months that have been at risk of being cut.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm happy that the ARPA supplement in this budget helps us keep a lot of those programs, or at least gives us the option to keep a lot of those programs.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think maybe even more importantly, the override questions chart a long-term stable path towards financial health for our school system.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's really important to mention.

[Justin Tseng]: I think you and I, we've had a lot of conversations about using free cash, one-time funds.

[Justin Tseng]: Sometimes we've agreed, sometimes we haven't.

[Justin Tseng]: And to explain to the residents, a lot of our conversations go along the lines of, I'm trying to push you to spend more in free cash, and you're pushing back against it.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think you do actually have a reason.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's important to tell the public that.

[Justin Tseng]: When we use free cash, that's a one-time fund for recurring positions.

[Justin Tseng]: And we need to find a way to wean off of those one-time funds, particularly in order to keep our bond rating high.

[Justin Tseng]: We know that we are on a path to build a new high school.

[Justin Tseng]: We have a lot of big projects coming up and we need better bond ratings to save money for our city in the long term for those projects.

[Justin Tseng]: And so it's reasonable to me, and it's not fun, but it's reasonable to me to use the ARPA supplement that you proposed and to pair it with the override questions.

[Justin Tseng]: I think oftentimes reasonable governance, rational governance, and responsible governance isn't fun.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not sexy.

[Justin Tseng]: It's oftentimes really, you know, forces us to make really difficult decisions.

[Justin Tseng]: I think in those circumstances, it's really important to return the right of

[Justin Tseng]: those decisions to the voters.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that gets back to the override question.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we have to remember that the question that we're facing as a council today is whether we present these questions to the voters in November.

[Justin Tseng]: We're not voting on the increase, right?

[Justin Tseng]: We're sending it to the voters.

[Justin Tseng]: And I've always told the residents whose doors I've knocked on, whose phones I've called, and I actually got this the first day it was canvassing about four years ago in Wellington.

[Justin Tseng]: What would you do about a prop two and a half override?

[Justin Tseng]: And I said back then, agree or disagree with it, the most just decision is the democratic decision.

[Justin Tseng]: It's to leave it to the voters.

[Justin Tseng]: I have my feelings on it.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm sure you do.

[Justin Tseng]: But it's the responsibility of the electorate to make that decision ultimately.

[Justin Tseng]: As you acknowledged, it's a difficult choice for a lot of folks to make.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think governance is about making difficult choices.

[Justin Tseng]: It's about making choices that

[Justin Tseng]: cause debate and debate is a part of democracy.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, we can't avoid it and we shouldn't avoid it because avoiding it is what got us here in the first place.

[Justin Tseng]: The health of our city financially is not due to one budget.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not due to any one budget or any one council, any one mayor.

[Justin Tseng]: It's due to a general approach that we've taken as a city for decades.

[Justin Tseng]: We found ourselves in a position that's difficult to, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: focus on new growth and have that plug in all the holes that we need.

[Justin Tseng]: And that is what our council is doing.

[Justin Tseng]: Earlier tonight, we passed our first step in our zoning recodification phase.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's focused, like you said, on the new growth, on bringing in a larger tax base for our city so that we won't have to be forced to make decisions like this.

[Justin Tseng]: I've also always told residents that the override is the last option that we have to resort to.

[Justin Tseng]: But the facts of the economic reality of the situation is that we've been cutting budgets to the bone and then some.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think this year's budget conversations really exemplify that.

[Justin Tseng]: Our skeleton budget's been cut so much that it can't really stand up on its own.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's why we need to make these difficult decisions and to pose these questions to the voters, to have them choose.

[Justin Tseng]: I, you also mentioned, I think really importantly, this idea that our residents are demanding more, and I think they're right to demand more.

[Justin Tseng]: Every conversation I have on the doors, you know, we're talking about problems our city is facing, and it's heartbreaking to go budget season after budget season, door after door, to tell them we don't have the money for that, we're working on a plan, but it'll take years for that new growth money to come in.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, we have to be realistic about the timeline of new growth.

[Justin Tseng]: It takes more than one day for a building to be built.

[Justin Tseng]: And we need this money to plug the hole now.

[Justin Tseng]: You've also mentioned a lot of the growth that is happening in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll push back a little.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we can be doing more as a city.

[Justin Tseng]: But the fact of the matter, according to the Boston Foundation, we have, as a percentage of prior permits, Medford is by far the leader in the Boston area for permitting new housing.

[Justin Tseng]: That is something to keep in mind.

[Justin Tseng]: We are working on it.

[Justin Tseng]: We're not where we need to be, but we are working on it.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, you know, ultimately every budget conversation revolves around the question of fiscal responsibility.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not fiscally responsible when we're cutting budgets so much that we have city departments that aren't operating at the level that they need to be operating at.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not fiscal responsibility when parents have to decide whether to send their kids to private school and to spend thousands on tuition because they can't get the specialists, the programs, the teachers that they need for their kids to succeed in our public school system.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not fiscally responsible when our firefighters are operating out of really the dilapidated fire headquarters

[Justin Tseng]: in Medford Square.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not fiscally responsible when residents have to spend hundreds of dollars every year, year after year, because our potholes are so bad that they feel like a roller coaster.

[Justin Tseng]: And the whole budget process in the last few years, this year has been calmer because of the collaboration, but the whole budget process oftentimes feels like a rollercoaster ride.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that these override questions do stabilize our city a bit.

[Justin Tseng]: And they give us a chance, a fighting chance to not only succeed, but to thrive as a city.

[Justin Tseng]: So to all the residents who are tuning in tonight, you may have the override questions, the choice is yours.

[Justin Tseng]: But I ask you to consider one thing.

[Justin Tseng]: I ask you to vote for someone you don't know.

[Justin Tseng]: Vote for the kid who needs the literacy coaches.

[Justin Tseng]: Vote for the drivers who need

[Justin Tseng]: better roads.

[Justin Tseng]: Vote for the parents that need to talk to guidance staff, the school nurses, the arts, the families that need the arts programs to have their kids thrive.

[Justin Tseng]: Vote for a future where our city

[Justin Tseng]: shares and saves costs where we share our burdens and save money in the long run.

[Justin Tseng]: And where our finances are more stable and where I can go to you, our residents and say, yes, we can work on that project.

[Justin Tseng]: So I yield my time.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Director.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Sainte.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the director's comments lead me to the next question is, you know, even if we have worries about unintended consequences with this, with the proposed new system, I think it's clear that one of the unintended consequences of the current system is, is landlords keeping their properties vacant, storefronts vacant.

[Justin Tseng]: for tax write-off purposes, and I think we would all agree that that's an unintended consequence.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I do see this as a potential way to address that by changing costs and addressing negative externalities.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm curious what the director would have to say to other policy tools that we might use to address that problem of

[Justin Tseng]: landlords keeping their storefronts vacant for tax write-off purposes.

[Justin Tseng]: So that was very, very helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm, I think, very ecstatic to see that this is so comprehensive.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's very well done.

[Justin Tseng]: particularly important legal language to put in, that language is in there, is in this draft.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this is very helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's very clear, which is what we need if we are to have a social media account.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you for your work.

[Justin Tseng]: I would concur with Councilor Palahan.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we have a similar understanding of open meeting law, and I would be worried that something like that would constrain what we can say, and you know, oftentimes residents do want to hear from most, if not all of us on an issue.

[Justin Tseng]: As long as we're not debating it, it should be fine.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm also thinking the circumstances in which maybe we share something about a city event that will happen.

[Justin Tseng]: And there are people asking what time or what place that will be.

[Justin Tseng]: And let's just say in a given five minutes, just four of us choose to respond to that.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't want that to be a problem as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Also, given the fact that I think most of our postings will be retrospectives on what we have already done, I don't think OML is necessarily applicable in that situation.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think open meeting law stands for itself.

[Justin Tseng]: That obviously overrides everything.

[Justin Tseng]: And so as long as we follow the law itself, we should be fine without having to hamstring ourselves unnecessarily.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: I have some slides to share.

[Justin Tseng]: But before I start, I wanted to preface that this is the beginning of a process.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm not expecting that we'll pass anything tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: This will take a few months to work on.

[Justin Tseng]: And I want to make sure that we're doing it comprehensively.

[Justin Tseng]: I know many of you are seeing this draft for the first time today or over the weekend.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm not really sure when it was sent out to folks.

[Justin Tseng]: And I want to make sure that people have the time they need to digest everything.

[Justin Tseng]: And so today, what I'm going to do today is give people context about why residents have reached out to me about initiating this process and to also give a cursory glance at a proposal that I'm putting out that addresses a lot of those concerns.

[Justin Tseng]: So with that being said, and I believe there are residents here to speak in favor of some reforms as well.

[Justin Tseng]: But with that being said, let me do this quick, quick PowerPoint that walks through the draft that you have in front of you guys.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I just wanted to, again, give context for why modernize this ordinance, walk quickly section by section to give you a quick introduction of how the structure is, and propose some motions to moving forward.

[Justin Tseng]: So from talking to current and previous human rights commissioners, there have been a number of issues, actually quite a litany of issues that have come up with how the ordinance is drafted.

[Justin Tseng]: a lot of it stemming from the fact that this ordinance uses language for HRCs that date back decades, whereas the needs of communities have changed in the last few decades as well.

[Justin Tseng]: The first big thing that's more procedural is just unclear language that constricts the HRC's work.

[Justin Tseng]: Two very glaring examples are in the current draft that says that

[Justin Tseng]: there must be 10 meetings held.

[Justin Tseng]: But it's not entirely clear whether you can hold more than 10 meetings.

[Justin Tseng]: And given the amount of work the HRC is tasked with doing and the amount of time that the HRC has to hold a single meeting, oftentimes the work doesn't get done.

[Justin Tseng]: And so a lot of commissioners have reached out to me saying that they would like more time to work on issues.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, with the language that's currently in there, it's not clear.

[Justin Tseng]: It's, you know, some lawyers' understandings that they can, some lawyers' understandings that they cannot.

[Justin Tseng]: And so we need to clarify that language.

[Justin Tseng]: The other big layering procedural problem is the quorum for meetings.

[Justin Tseng]: We've been finding it very difficult to fill HRCE seats, partially because our retention rate is very low and a lot of commissioners are leaving in the middle of their terms.

[Justin Tseng]: But with that being said,

[Justin Tseng]: without being at max members, the way that the current ordinance is written is that they need, I believe, five members to call a meeting to form quorum.

[Justin Tseng]: And oftentimes they're not at that because they only have six or seven members.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe there's one new commissioner there.

[Justin Tseng]: And so just as long as one or two of them are absent, meetings cannot be held.

[Justin Tseng]: And that really hamstrings the HRC's ability to do work.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the next big bucket, which I've heard a lot from previous commissioners and is a very big problem when it comes to retention, is just the duties that are assigned to the HRC and the interpretation of whether the HRC can do things beyond that duty that fulfill the purpose of the HRC.

[Justin Tseng]: So in other words,

[Justin Tseng]: In the current ordinance, there's a purpose section.

[Justin Tseng]: And there are a lot of things that the HRC could be doing that fulfill that purpose section.

[Justin Tseng]: So there is a legal argument that they can do that.

[Justin Tseng]: But also, there's a duty section as well that's very restrictive and really strongly focuses on housing discrimination and enforcing decisions in housing discrimination cases.

[Justin Tseng]: And that obviously is one subset of what the HRC could be doing.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of what the HRC currently, what they're hearing from residents that they want to do, it falls outside of housing discrimination.

[Justin Tseng]: And on top of that, a lot of HRC members don't feel equipped to deal with housing discrimination issues because they're not lawyers and because these are very deep, complex legal issues.

[Justin Tseng]: I, the other 2 points I basically covered within that.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the 3rd major thing is just some additional concerns.

[Justin Tseng]: More generally, the commission has not been historically the most diverse.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of that is due to structural parts of this ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: There's as we've.

[Justin Tseng]: delved into the Youth Commission Ordinance and the Gender Equity Ordinance in a last City Council term.

[Justin Tseng]: These are ideas from Councilor Scarpelli is one of our advocates, Councilor Knight, Councilor Morell, they've been leaders on those issues.

[Justin Tseng]: It became clear to us that there's a need to rethink the organizational structure of

[Justin Tseng]: the HRC in context with those organizations as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Hearing from city staff, there's a very strong desire to have members of those commissions, at least one member of those commissions sit on the HRC as well.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to enable that in some way.

[Justin Tseng]: There's also been a lack of a chair.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, in the HRC for many months, the current ordinance says that the chair has to be elected in June.

[Justin Tseng]: And that means for the last few months, there has, I believe there has been no chair.

[Justin Tseng]: And on top of that, there's a question of resources.

[Justin Tseng]: The city is expecting that the HRC throws a lot of city events, like the Lunar New Year celebration, Black History Month celebrations, Juneteenth celebrations.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of that money is currently coming out of the DAI budget, which is fine.

[Justin Tseng]: But it really hamstrings the HRC's ability to decide which events to hold.

[Justin Tseng]: the current process is just much more bureaucratic and less democratic.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, I think all that context is really important, so that's why I went slower through it.

[Justin Tseng]: These next few sections, I've just basically separated out the ordinance into different sections.

[Justin Tseng]: So the establishment and purpose, this is largely the same as the current ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: We eventually may need to make some small updates, but that really depends on the duty section later on and what we put in there.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I didn't want to touch it for now.

[Justin Tseng]: The next section is about membership, appointments, terms, removal, and organization.

[Justin Tseng]: For context, I worked on this ordinance draft with previous HRC commissioners and residents who have worked really closely with the HRC, community groups that have worked really closely with the HRC to get the work they need done.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, this draft is a product of that of working with them.

[Justin Tseng]: And to make sure, you know, this is responsive to the needs.

[Justin Tseng]: And I wanted to bring this before the council in an introductory manner, because in the air transparency, essentially.

[Justin Tseng]: there's a desire to slightly expand the HRC, but to do so basically by working more closely with existing city commissions, new proposed city commissions, and community-based organizations, some of which the examples of are the Disabilities Commission, the Council on Aging.

[Justin Tseng]: If we create a Youth Commission or a Gender Equity Commission, members of those commissions

[Justin Tseng]: community groups like the West Bedford Community Center, different religious groups, possibly housing-related groups, MHA, for example.

[Justin Tseng]: And so instead of because we know that there's a problem with recruiting right now, there might be a fear that we're expanding.

[Justin Tseng]: But much of the expansion comes from existing groups.

[Justin Tseng]: We also recognize that we need to increase diversity.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why there's language in here about creating a rotation of commissioners and leadership and providing stipends, all of which are things that studies have proven to work at the municipal level for increasing diversity, income-wise, gender, race, class, everything, profession-wise.

[Justin Tseng]: on municipal boards and commissions.

[Justin Tseng]: There's language in here that's equity-focused about receiving training on meeting operation and parliamentary procedure.

[Justin Tseng]: These are things that often scare away folks who aren't as experienced with city government from working in city government on boards and commissions.

[Justin Tseng]: And that would be something very simple, like a half-hour module at the start of a HRC term.

[Justin Tseng]: There's also language, I think I basically covered everything.

[Justin Tseng]: Everything that I haven't covered is essentially just aligning the HRC with current city commission ordinances that we have for other commissions.

[Justin Tseng]: So just language that wasn't put in there in the first place, but since we've passed that, we've started to put in every, the city council has started to put in every commission ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: The next section, as I talked about quite a lot previously, there's a problem with meetings and quorums.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, so this aligns HRC with most City Commission ordinances.

[Justin Tseng]: It addresses those problems with scheduling and quorums, and it allows for some flexibility.

[Justin Tseng]: The 10-meeting-per-year thing, that's to ensure regularity of meetings to make sure the Commission is doing its work.

[Justin Tseng]: though this next sentence basically gives the commission flexibility to have more meetings to finish that work.

[Justin Tseng]: This next section about independence, resources, counsel.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of this language is actually just taken from the current ordinance, but there is some additional language in here about addressing the resource problem.

[Justin Tseng]: Essentially, this is something that

[Justin Tseng]: The previous iteration of this committee that worked on the Youth Commission and the Gender Equity Commission ordinances which haven't been passed yet.

[Justin Tseng]: This is language that they approved of when it came to creating a small budget line item for them.

[Justin Tseng]: This is basically just to let them hold events like

[Justin Tseng]: the Lunar New Year celebration and stuff like that.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this will require some talking with the city administration to see how we divvy up between the HRC and between the DEI office.

[Justin Tseng]: But I imagine the funds would basically be under the same umbrella and so we're not really increasing funds.

[Justin Tseng]: per se, to the HRC.

[Justin Tseng]: We're just redistributing to give them a little bit more easier of a time to spend those funds, whereas right now it's, again, quite bureaucratic.

[Justin Tseng]: This is the longest section, but it is the last section, the roles, powers, and duties section.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, much of the current ordinance focuses on housing discrimination.

[Justin Tseng]: This addresses that.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, I think this is the section that maybe we would want to read through and edit the most.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, I'm not expecting anything to change today or anything to be passed today.

[Justin Tseng]: I want to give Councilors and commissioners the time to read this and reflect and give written feedback on it.

[Justin Tseng]: But this comes out of a lot of work that I've done

[Justin Tseng]: talking to that I've done with previous commissioners and community members that have worked with HRC about what types of powers and duties they would like to see explicitly laid out.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of, again, actually most of this language comes from neighboring municipalities HRC ordinances.

[Justin Tseng]: It also removes duties that commissioners have articulated that they aren't qualified to do.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, the current ordinance really expects them to do quite a lot of legal responsibilities that they shouldn't be doing because they're not lawyers and could end up putting our city in a dangerous position with our law department.

[Justin Tseng]: more or less averts that by shifting that responsibility to offices that actually have that legal staff and that capacity, particularly at the state level, to deal with situations like that.

[Justin Tseng]: And with that being said, I believe the next steps are, I would move to ask Councilors to submit feedback

[Justin Tseng]: to the chair and me before the next resident services and public engagement committee meeting on the current draft that we have in front of us.

[Justin Tseng]: I would also move to ask HRC members, relevant city staff and legal staff for feedback.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that we have some residents here with us that potentially would want to speak on this, but I would be happy to hear from councillors first.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you Councilor Scapelli for your kind comments.

[Justin Tseng]: I would actually agree with that point.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's a good note.

[Justin Tseng]: I'd be happy to make that amendment.

[Justin Tseng]: Of course, there's, you know, we have a lot of time to do this as well, but I think that makes a lot of sense.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll be brief.

[Justin Tseng]: I would agree with Councilor Lazzaro.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's the point of the listening sessions, although I think there's back and forth is natural.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the point of it should be to listen.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, if there is something that we can help clarify, because sometimes, you know, we're

[Justin Tseng]: you know, residents want us to do something that we're already doing.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's fair game for us to say, oh, like, here's here's this.

[Justin Tseng]: Here's this thing that we're doing.

[Justin Tseng]: Here's how you get plugged in.

[Justin Tseng]: These are we're holding a meeting about this on, you know, May 8th, for example.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's fair.

[Justin Tseng]: But I yeah, I would think the main part of it is just to note down what folks are saying and asking and then bring it back to this group or

[Justin Tseng]: to the city council regular meeting as a whole.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I would say by record, I wouldn't necessarily say we should record with a camera or recorder because that may scare some people away, but we should definitely have at least one councilor jotting down the notes to bring back.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I so I was also thinking about that Councilor Callahan and I have a different proposal.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I still think it could be valuable to have a subcommittee to help organize these things and to, you know, after, for example, after the senior center listening session to have subcommittee meeting to quickly review what went right.

[Justin Tseng]: What went wrong?

[Justin Tseng]: What are best practices?

[Justin Tseng]: What should we do next time?

[Justin Tseng]: And so I almost think would be more useful to have.

[Justin Tseng]: to keep that subcommittee, but to have meetings organized where out of the two Councilors who are there, one of them is a member of the subcommittee and one of them isn't.

[Justin Tseng]: And that way, you have basically a subcommittee liaison who can help organize and, you know, come back to the subcommittee and say, okay, this went right at the session, this went wrong, handle emergencies that way.

[Justin Tseng]: And one, you know, other Councilor invited.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I think with regards to legal questions, I think oftentimes Councilor Scarpelli and I have very similar questions.

[Justin Tseng]: In this case, I would disagree because I think as long as we're playing it safe, there should be no question about the legality of any of this.

[Justin Tseng]: This is something that happens.

[Justin Tseng]: It is innovative for Medford, but it isn't something that is unheard of.

[Justin Tseng]: And essentially, again, as long as we play it safe with open meeting law, we make sure that no two members of a subcommittee, no three members of a regular committee, and no four members of the city council are meeting, I think we should be all right.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think the two figure then is very, very safe.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you all for joining.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to thank everyone for coming in today and presenting their projects.

[Justin Tseng]: I know it's not easy to come before the city council.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of these projects we have heard before, but we also have new folks here, and I wanted to welcome everyone to the city council.

[Justin Tseng]: Hopefully we're not as scary as we might seem.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the kind words from the previous two councilors are super well-deserved.

[Justin Tseng]: I always love the heat praise on you and the work that you and our commissions that work with you do.

[Justin Tseng]: It's really, I think, very underrated work, but it's work that raises the standards of living and working in the city of Bedford.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that there's been quite a lot of, you know, there's always competition for resources, and we always have a finite amount of resources.

[Justin Tseng]: I know you've done very well to find funds.

[Justin Tseng]: I was wondering, you know, have there been any moments in the last year where you've found, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: where you might have wanted to sponsor an event but you weren't able to and will the line item increase in the events help you?

[Justin Tseng]: Do you think this increase is enough to help you fund the events that are sitting should be sponsoring?

[Justin Tseng]: Present.

[Justin Tseng]: This item in particular, I think, really exemplifies the proactive spirit and the innovative spirit that we see from so many of our students.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it really goes,

[Justin Tseng]: it's, I think it should be noticed, right, that these are our young folks, our young students at the Brooks Elementary School, which kind of like shows us that no matter what age you are, Medford students are stepping up and stepping up to meet the demands of the moment.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's also really important to

[Justin Tseng]: celebrate the CCSR, such a wonderful organization that we have in our schools that allow our young folks to get stuff like this done and to get experience about how to make change and to respond so quickly to events in our community.

[Justin Tseng]: So really,

[Justin Tseng]: I think it really, I mean, I think all community members can really see how much Rick.

[Justin Tseng]: former councilor is given to our community, both in his capacity as a city councilor, but also just as a private citizen in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: His leadership really speaks volumes, especially when you look at the effects of his leadership.

[Justin Tseng]: When you look at the people that he's helped.

[Justin Tseng]: For me, Rick means a lot to me, because he was such a mentor to me in the council chambers and in getting involved in Medford politics.

[Justin Tseng]: He really, I think, showed me what leadership looks like.

[Justin Tseng]: saying words, he showed me the actions, and he showed me how you build those connections, how you get to know folks who live at home and all the business owners, and how you listen to them more empathetically.

[Justin Tseng]: And really, I think that spirit is something that's so important to the jobs that we do as city councillors.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you so much President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: As many of us know, Medford is home to one of our state's strongest music and arts programs in our public school system.

[Justin Tseng]: Thanks to the leadership of many teachers, one of whom

[Justin Tseng]: I know very personally, Miss Sophia Chang, she has developed this program at the middle school and high school levels of a string ensemble and the string orchestra program where students are really learning top level skills in arts and in strings playing.

[Justin Tseng]: I've had the opportunity to listen to high school players from around the state, working with a lot of them, teaching them, playing with them, and truly Medford has something very, very special.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm so, so happy that our orchestras won awards at the MICA Festival, which is a festival I played in a long, long time ago.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's a very difficult stage to perform on.

[Justin Tseng]: You're performing in front of a crowd of judges, a crowd of music professionals who are all very well renowned in their fields.

[Justin Tseng]: And to be able to overcome those nerves, and not only just overcome those nerves, but to win gold and silver medals with a very strict scoring system, I think speaks really highly to the level of our students to compete and to perform on such a really high level.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to amend this resolution to invite the students into our next regular meeting on May 14th to receive citations and to invite them for a short performance for the City Council if the Council will indulge the orchestra.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this has been really well described, so I'll be pretty brief.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, this is really asking big institutions like Tufts to pay their fair share in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, these institutions, they use our police, fire, medical services, they use infrastructure, water, sewer, and

[Justin Tseng]: all we ask is for them to pay something a little closer to their fair share instead of $0.

[Justin Tseng]: The Massachusetts Municipal Association, which is a group that represents local governments from across the state, from across the Commonwealth, all 351 municipalities, this organization has asked

[Justin Tseng]: local electives like all of us to send in letters of support to pass resolutions on the City Council to support this bill.

[Justin Tseng]: And they believe that doing so will be important at the State House.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I will very happily support this.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to say really quickly two quick things.

[Justin Tseng]: Kit, are you not cooking for all of us?

[Justin Tseng]: Oh no, that was a very like, that was a military attack.

[Justin Tseng]: I find them in order and move to approve.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think there's wording changing on it.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it was summarized with different words.

[Justin Tseng]: very briefly because I think a lot of what I would say has been covered by the three councillors who've spoken.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: When past administrations were looking at the water infrastructure in the city, it was easy, since everything was built around the same time, to say that we didn't need to make these investments.

[Justin Tseng]: But we always do need a longer-term outlook about how we're going to fund projects, even decades in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: It was disappointing, and it is disappointing to us that that wasn't done decades prior.

[Justin Tseng]: But it is, I think, a good step for us to start with that study about the rates going forward, because

[Justin Tseng]: that.

[Justin Tseng]: Such a large scale of infrastructure improvement will need a lot of communication with our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: And if you know, and I think it's becoming clear through this discussion through discussions in the past during the budget seasons that.

[Justin Tseng]: Money is a huge factor here.

[Justin Tseng]: And so if money is a big question here, we need to

[Justin Tseng]: something like that rate study is important.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, another thing can also be true that I think Councilor Scarpelli raised.

[Justin Tseng]: we need better follow through on these reports, on these committees that are created from the administration.

[Justin Tseng]: For example, the classification study is something that we still haven't seen over years.

[Justin Tseng]: We were promised this years ago.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's something that affects the items on our agenda, like the CAF amendment.

[Justin Tseng]: to the superintendent of water role.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to follow up on these things.

[Justin Tseng]: Now as a city council, I think we've done better.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we've worked together, especially Councilor Scarpelli and us, we've worked together to push the administration to keep them accountable on those issues.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to keep doing that.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to keep making the historic investments that we haven't been making as a city council that we made for the first time last year in the water system.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's very, very clear.

[Justin Tseng]: I know there's lots to be said.

[Justin Tseng]: There's this is a very complex issue.

[Justin Tseng]: I think.

[Justin Tseng]: a commission to begin Burns letter does actually point to a lot of substantive steps being taken in terms of, um, physical improvements to the system.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, not just the monetary side of things, but there's lots of follow through to, uh, to for us to hold to account.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to thank both you, President Bears, and Councilor Scarpelli for putting this on the agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: I was going through my inbox, and the first time we heard about this issue as a council actually was in June last year, where we did actually get a resolution on it, a temporary resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: Back then, similar to what you were describing now, there was a lot of back and forth from residents, city staff.

[Justin Tseng]: I made calls, I know you made calls, a number of councillors made calls at the time, and we got a temporary solution.

[Justin Tseng]: But then this issue came back.

[Justin Tseng]: And it seems like the number of ties there is higher than ever.

[Justin Tseng]: One resident did actually, I think, bring out a pretty decent idea in asking.

[Justin Tseng]: I had to make sure I had the language for it.

[Justin Tseng]: It's somewhere deep in the email chain.

[Justin Tseng]: But to ask for the actual material safety data sheet for the creosote.

[Justin Tseng]: that was applied to the ties.

[Justin Tseng]: I was wondering if either of you would be amenable to adding that into the resolution as well to ask for that material safety data sheet.

[Justin Tseng]: This is a serious issue.

[Justin Tseng]: I know you in particular have worked really tirelessly on this.

[Justin Tseng]: Our state rep, Sean Garvely, has worked very hard on this as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this is a pattern that we see from the MBTA of non-response.

[Justin Tseng]: We give them so much money, we contribute, we benefit from them, and yet we want to be partners, and yet there is this non-response.

[Justin Tseng]: When we were looking at the accessibility improvements for the bus stops, that took a year.

[Justin Tseng]: When we were thinking about the Orange Line shutdown years back, our city was proactive in reaching out and saying, what can we do to facilitate traffic, and we got posted.

[Justin Tseng]: and so we really need to keep working on this.

[Justin Tseng]: We have had times in the past where we were unified as a council and reached out and worked with the city staff as well and actually did get concessions from the MBTA.

[Justin Tseng]: So I hope this is the case this time.

[Justin Tseng]: Any further comments Councilor Tseng?

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to thank you guys for being so proactive on it.

[Justin Tseng]: I would love to read the grants.

[Justin Tseng]: What happened on one Boston day so many years ago was such a tragedy in our community.

[Justin Tseng]: And I really felt it very strongly.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I would really like to thank Councilor Callahan for introducing this.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this is an idea that most residents assume we already do as a city, but we don't.

[Justin Tseng]: And it is something that, you know, it's information that the city should really have in order to communicate its message better.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that kind of touches at two of the arcs that we're trying to work on this term in the city of Medford with the city government communication modernization.

[Justin Tseng]: we're ambitious as a city council and as a city when it comes to our climate goals, housing goals, but also the very basis of just having our existing laws be carried out and enforced.

[Justin Tseng]: And this registry would allow us to do that.

[Justin Tseng]: It would allow us to be more responsive to a lot of constituent concerns and a lot of resident concerns like what you mentioned about absentee landlords.

[Justin Tseng]: and it would help us restructure some of the ideas that we have.

[Justin Tseng]: For example, with the good landlord tax credit, which I know a lot of people are really excited about, this idea allows us to reach out to them.

[Justin Tseng]: So thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I can also speak to some of Councilor Lazzaro and Councilor Leming's questions, because I happened to hold a meeting on this a few weeks ago with some city staff.

[Justin Tseng]: It seems like most of the work would fall within the purview of the building department.

[Justin Tseng]: Actually, the new building commissioner that we have here in Medford set up the rental registry system for their last municipality, and so they're very well-versed.

[Justin Tseng]: how to create the system.

[Justin Tseng]: They've created an online system that really maintains itself.

[Justin Tseng]: And so it wouldn't, you know, the setup would take time for the staff to manage.

[Justin Tseng]: But once the system is in place, they expect the system to be quite self-containing.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I respect my colleagues viewpoint, I think that I think what you're saying actually is in a bigger scheme, you know, we have, we should rethink how we, you know, when we have items introduced on the agenda, we send them to committee.

[Justin Tseng]: This is how other municipalities in the state do it.

[Justin Tseng]: If there are other avenues to just, you know, send it.

[Justin Tseng]: to committee have a developed proposal before we create, you know, before we introduce it bring us to the regular meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that would be appropriate but I think that's something for us to investigate down the line, I would disagree on the conclusion with my fellow Councilor.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, I have been listening and taking a lot of notes during this during the last few, the last

[Justin Tseng]: comments.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think there are a few buckets of questions for us.

[Justin Tseng]: And I, you know, I think we do have the answers for them.

[Justin Tseng]: I think on the question of privacy, as Councilor Callahan has stated, as is done in municipalities around the state, we wouldn't ask for tenant information that's just not done in other states or in other cities.

[Justin Tseng]: The

[Justin Tseng]: Here's an example of what information is collected usually.

[Justin Tseng]: Contact information for the property owner, property manager, number of units you're registering, and number of units at the property, dates of buying property, because there are certain laws that exempt properties because of age, and the city wouldn't want to overcharge landlords, and some fire code related items.

[Justin Tseng]: That's all.

[Justin Tseng]: That's it.

[Justin Tseng]: That's what's usually collected.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think, you know...

[Justin Tseng]: There's there's some questions another bucket of questions is, why do we need to collect this information, why do we need to create this registry.

[Justin Tseng]: Right now, you know, given that we might have some information but I think that's the point is we only have some of this information.

[Justin Tseng]: There are a lot of their landlords in the city who they might own property but that property is registered under their spouse's name right because their spouse about that property or their spouse was was a primary sign on that.

[Justin Tseng]: And we wouldn't be able to tell if that's a primary residence or a secondary property.

[Justin Tseng]: There are a lot of cases like that.

[Justin Tseng]: There are also just more generally cases where we can't tell based on the tax bill whether it's owner-occupied or non-owner-occupied, whether it's a primary or secondary residence.

[Justin Tseng]: And this would help us identify a lot of that.

[Justin Tseng]: I will say another...

[Justin Tseng]: Another reason that I think we need to, another question about the functionality, about the feasibility of this that we should correct the record on is whether this is legal or not.

[Justin Tseng]: This is very clearly legal, done in many municipalities around the state.

[Justin Tseng]: And there are legal, we can create legal methods to have

[Justin Tseng]: people register.

[Justin Tseng]: Now that answers the question of, you know, when you have these already, you have these landlords that aren't responding yet, how can we expect them to participate, we can use legal methods.

[Justin Tseng]: Now the last, I think the last bucket is less about the policy itself, and more about this idea of listening and sympathy.

[Justin Tseng]: And I actually do have sympathy for landlords.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I close family members who are small landlords,

[Justin Tseng]: And when I put myself in their shoes, I want them to know about the rebates and the tax credits they can get.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's something that, given how they're registered on the tax bill right now, the city doesn't know that they're landlords.

[Justin Tseng]: And they don't have a problem with the city knowing that they're a landlord, but because the city doesn't know that they're a landlord, they can't get that information about rebates and tax credits and subsidies.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think for that reason, I would move the question.

[Justin Tseng]: For all those reasons, I would move the question.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I really want to highlight again that there are three changes with this.

[Justin Tseng]: The first one is the switch to a three minute speaking period per person.

[Justin Tseng]: As you've amended on the floor, the resolution says two minutes.

[Justin Tseng]: We've heard feedback from the public.

[Justin Tseng]: There's been extensive discussions about what is an appropriate time.

[Justin Tseng]: And a lot of folks who have asked us, reached out to us and contacted us to ask us to consider lengthening it.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I'm very happy that you've been open to changing it to three minutes.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the second change is the 90 minute upper limit, which you mentioned.

[Justin Tseng]: And the third change is creating a new channel for people to get their records entered into the public, the formal record.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think a lot of folks don't realize what they call us or email us before a meeting that's not entered into the official record on something, but unless they ask us to read that into record or enter that into the record, this would create an easier mechanism

[Justin Tseng]: both in person and online to enter their comments into the formal record.

[Justin Tseng]: And so we're creating an online form and an in-person form to be put into the clerk's office.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this idea of new channels is really important because it goes to the idea of restructuring.

[Justin Tseng]: There are some things that won't change.

[Justin Tseng]: We will still have the general public participation.

[Justin Tseng]: We would still have the general public participation section at the end of the meetings where folks are free to say whatever they want and free to speak for the times they desire.

[Justin Tseng]: But we also recognize the need to restructure because of the need to democratize the process.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, I've done quite a lot of work for a professor at the Kennedy School who's working on democratizing local government and state governments and working on ideas of how to restructure public participation processes.

[Justin Tseng]: There's been a lot of formal critiques and research out there that shows that

[Justin Tseng]: The way that public participation is done, especially in Massachusetts, there's a very lengthy thesis about this, a very lengthy published paper from Harvard Law and from the American Bar Association that shows that how public participation is often done in Massachusetts disadvantages those who support ideas, who support the ideas put on the agenda, disadvantages those who aren't able to make a meeting time,

[Justin Tseng]: who aren't able to come to a 7pm meeting on a Tuesday because they might be working or they need to wake up early, they have children to take care of and they can't participate.

[Justin Tseng]: The way that it's done right now also disadvantages folks who want to speak on an issue.

[Justin Tseng]: but don't feel like they're empowered to because many folks in the room might oppose their viewpoint.

[Justin Tseng]: Leading actually, in fact, to a limitation of their First Amendment right to free speech because it

[Justin Tseng]: it limits their ability to speak up without feeling threatened by a member of the public.

[Justin Tseng]: We're empowered by numerous federal court cases to do this.

[Justin Tseng]: The Minnesota State Board for Community Colleges versus Knight.

[Justin Tseng]: There's a Chesterfield City Planning Commission court case as well, where the courts actually ask

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and I would urge, um, city

[Justin Tseng]: to be wise in designing their public participation processes and empower the city to do that and ask us to create alternative channels, which we are doing.

[Justin Tseng]: And I forgot to mention one really important alternative channel that we are creating.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Callahan and Lazzaro and I have been working on a resolution on this agenda to create listening sessions for the city council through the public engagement committee.

[Justin Tseng]: And so what we're saying is you can still speak up about these issues.

[Justin Tseng]: You can still get your comment entered on the record.

[Justin Tseng]: We're going to restructure how that's done so that other folks who want to speak on an item can speak, and they don't have to wait till too too late in the night to speak.

[Justin Tseng]: That's not how it works.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng thank you President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, you know, having heard a lot of the feedback tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: I think there I think there was a lot of nuance.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Having heard a lot of the opinions tonight, I think that there's a lot of nuance in what people want and, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: I take the criticism in stride, and I, you know, I want to engage in good faith, and that's why I would, I want to amend this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: There's a lot of folks who have talked about their support for three minutes, but not the 90 minute.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng had the floor.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: As I was saying, I think there's a lot of nuance to the conversation that we've had tonight, particularly in the critiques.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think there's a wide spectrum of views on what folks don't like about it and how much they don't like it.

[Justin Tseng]: In good faith, I want to amend the resolution on the floor.

[Justin Tseng]: Instead of having a 90-minute hard cap, I would like to move that we have 90 minutes of discussion with participants having three minutes to speak each, and then after that, one minute per resident to speak on a topic.

[Justin Tseng]: I know this isn't, you know, this isn't a compromise that everyone will love, but it is a good faith attempt to respond to what residents have been saying.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I've heard residents whose main critique is that what happens to the person who speaks after that, who wants to speak after the 90th minute, and they haven't had a chance to speak.

[Justin Tseng]: And I do sympathize with that quite a bit.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's why I want to offer that amendment.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I would support that B paper.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it makes a lot of sense.

[Justin Tseng]: It goes, it speaks to what Councilor Lazzaro and I had talked about earlier tonight in that there seems to be a way to clarify things so that we caught, so that we are clear as a council that things are being brought up for discussion and rather not being decided on that night of.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I would second the B paper.

[Justin Tseng]: Um okay, Councilor say.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um I really wanted to thank Councilor Collins for introducing this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: We think of the in broad strokes and yes the impact of climate change is in broad strokes, but the effects of climate change affect every single one of us living here living on the ground.

[Justin Tseng]: We see it very clearly with the mystic river which you brought up, and the potential for flooding, and we I think we can recognize how.

[Justin Tseng]: Climate change disproportionately affects communities that haven't been super well off, that haven't been represented in the traditional political process, that have been traditionally overlooked.

[Justin Tseng]: Communities of color, poor communities, immigrant communities.

[Justin Tseng]: This resolution has another local angle to it, which is that it brings money back into the city.

[Justin Tseng]: We talk about the need for revenue, we talk about the need to fund resiliency projects and nature projects and parks and flood protection.

[Justin Tseng]: This is if past the state at the state level, this would be a mechanism to do it.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Sen.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: First of all, I want to thank you, President Bears, for leading this project.

[Justin Tseng]: I want to thank the administration for negotiating with us and good faith about it.

[Justin Tseng]: I know a lot of these, a lot of the stuff in this ordinance is not easy for any administration to stomach.

[Justin Tseng]: It represents a massive shift in power away from the administration and towards the grassroots.

[Justin Tseng]: The budgeting in Massachusetts and budgeting in Medford in particular has traditionally been very top down.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's been really, truly an honor to be able to work so closely with you, with Vice President Collins and subcommittee over many months, many long months to get us to a draft where everyone can agree that this moves our city forward and in a way that is feasible.

[Justin Tseng]: I think what is most striking to me about this budget ordinance is that it's a true commitment to our values of transparency.

[Justin Tseng]: It's a true testimony that our city council is working really hard to bring transparency into the things that matter the most.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think the budget forming the backbone of the city's operations is really truly a significant place for that to be happening.

[Justin Tseng]: the budget.

[Justin Tseng]: Um when we think about what this includes quarterly financial reports, um, breakdowns of fixed costs versus new expenses, um, annual budget needs assessment, um, more logical and reasonable schedule for, um, working on this budget as a city council.

[Justin Tseng]: I think all of these are steps that really, um, give us more time and give us

[Justin Tseng]: And to engage department heads to see what they actually want in their departments rather than being handed a version of the budget that has already been pre negotiated for us.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, in addition to that transparency.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's very logical.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I think.

[Justin Tseng]: we need to be setting higher standards for how government operates, and this ordinance does that.

[Justin Tseng]: It is clearer to residents, it will make the budget process clearer to residents as to what that few hundred page document actually means, what the numbers mean, and what that number, what those numbers mean

[Justin Tseng]: in relation to their lives, to their lived experiences as residents of the city.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'm very, very happy to support this.

[Justin Tseng]: I urge my colleagues to do the same.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think this is something that is truly, truly nonpartisan and really, really revolutionary.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm very grateful for my fellow Councilor for introducing this.

[Justin Tseng]: I think when it comes to something that hasn't been updated since 1990, that should be updated regularly, it makes a lot of sense.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we need to show our residents that we're trying to find

[Justin Tseng]: revenue wherever we can, and especially in ways that don't overburden folks.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is definitely one of those paths.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I'm very grateful that you've introduced this and started a really important conversation about linkage fees, about updating ordinances, about tying different things to it.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's very helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think your ideas are very strong here.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh yes, Councilor Tseng, sorry.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, so from last week's discussion and from my discussion with Steve, the, um.

[Justin Tseng]: The monthly summaries basically would be created by a rotating group of Councilors who sign up for this duty.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it would be best if Chair Leming created the schedule of Councilors who were interested.

[Justin Tseng]: And essentially each month, this committee at the beginning of our meeting, we would vote and approve a summary of that month's city council activities to go out to the public.

[Justin Tseng]: So basically just a summary as some Councilors are already doing.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, the reason why we have decided on the rotating structure is that a lot of our Councilors have individually started newsletters at some point.

[Justin Tseng]: And because it gets to be a lot, we all kind of drop off after a few months.

[Justin Tseng]: And sometimes we go back into it, but it's really difficult to sustain over a long period of time.

[Justin Tseng]: And so we believe that creating the system where we have

[Justin Tseng]: a duty to bring something in on a calendar system, but also something that's not too demanding on councillors is the best system, and I think the rotating system is that solution.

[Justin Tseng]: So I would actually move.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think these are all questions to keep considering.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe the second motion that I introduced would empower Matt or Matt's, Chair Leming or Chair Leming's designated work, keep working with Steve and Adam to work out if we can get on an official platform or if there's a better way to build out.

[Justin Tseng]: I think a lot of this future action is already there's already a motion for it.

[Justin Tseng]: Right.

[Justin Tseng]: But I was wondering if the Board of Health should consider publishing best practice guidelines for gardens and vegetable community

[Justin Tseng]: community gardens where vegetables are being grown that could attract rodents.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the reason why I would separate this from the ordinance is it would be difficult to regulate this behavior, but it would be helpful to disseminate best practices in my opinion.

[Justin Tseng]: Motion to suspend the rules and take 24-055 out of order.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's really important for us to recognize what question exactly is on our desk today.

[Justin Tseng]: When we last looked at the stabilization fund idea, as Councilor Collins referred to, it was both to create a fund and to put money in it.

[Justin Tseng]: Today's item is different.

[Justin Tseng]: Today's item is just to create the fund and not to put money in it, which is traditionally where the sticking point with the city council has been.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, when it comes to creating the fund, I am in support of it because of the rainy day aspect.

[Justin Tseng]: The way that our finances work right now, if, God forbid, an emergency happened in the city where a roof fell in on a school or a major repair was needed to a public facility, we would not be able to access the funds needed to fix those problems until free cash is certified by the state, which can often take many, many, many months.

[Justin Tseng]: oftentimes closer to a year, and creating the stabilization fund gives us the opportunity to have that money ready to fix emergencies when needed.

[Justin Tseng]: So I support this idea.

[Justin Tseng]: I will second Councilor Collins' motion.

[Justin Tseng]: I move to move this, uh, to extend this hearing until continue until a date certain of April 2nd.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: On the former council, I've heard this project before.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm particularly excited about it.
