[Justin Tseng]: Any questions for members of the council Councilor Tseng not a question but being very quick for my other for the new Councilors here the history of this is the MBTA is this project where they want to improve pedestrian infrastructure for bus stops.

[Justin Tseng]: At the same time, Medford has a higher concentration of bus stops and other cities, a lot of them go pretty much unused.

[Justin Tseng]: We don't have any powers of city council to stop bus stops being taken away but the last council leveraged a lot of that.

[Justin Tseng]: are the approvals that we need to do for the infrastructure projects to keep bus stops to make improvements to the bus stops that they were talking about.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I would move approval.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng, Thank you, President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, this is especially for the folks watching at home but I wanted to explain a little bit about where I'm where I stand on this issue because I think all voters deserve to know what I'm thinking right now.

[Justin Tseng]: I have to be very clear about what's before us tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: We're merely debating whether to send this idea to a subcommittee for further study, and we do this with essentially any issue, whether we support it or oppose it as a council.

[Justin Tseng]: This is a first step in a multi-month process that, as my colleagues have alluded to, would have to be approved by the mayor, the state house, and the governor.

[Justin Tseng]: And even during that process, we will have lots of public meetings.

[Justin Tseng]: this committee process is, in my eyes, really crucial to what gets voted on at the end of the day and where I will stand on it at the end of the day.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that we need to discuss exemptions for owner-occupants, seniors, family members, and talk about a threshold with which, under that amount, we wouldn't be setting that tax.

[Justin Tseng]: When we talk about this real estate transfer fee, I think it's really important to note that we can discuss it as a 2% tax, but that wouldn't be the most honest way of discussing it, especially if there's a threshold.

[Justin Tseng]: If there's a threshold, for example, set at $1 million, if the property is $1.2 million, the tax is actually effectively only 0.17%.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, the it's also I think important to note that, yes, we do have CPA funding but at our last public open CPA meeting, the staff has been very clear that we need much more money to set up a successful affordable housing trust that that funding is not nearly enough.

[Justin Tseng]: to fund affordable housing, and that they broke down how they're spending that money, and there has been very widespread support of how that money is being spent, including a 7-0 vote on City Council.

[Justin Tseng]: With regards to going back to this idea of the committee process, I spent the last few days doing a lot of deep diving into long, long economic research papers and policy reports about transfer fee and economic research from

[Justin Tseng]: scholars at schools like Columbia, U Michigan, from national government economic research bodies, Institute of Public Studies, the Boston Globe, have all emphasized that the effect on this tax on economic growth and housing affordability hinges on this design process and committee, where we can design the fee to largely affect large developers building luxury housing,

[Justin Tseng]: and we can actually use levers to relieve other economic burdens on home ownership.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, rather regrettably, I think some folks have misunderstood or mischaracterized this policy issue by making it sound like we're doing something we're not doing.

[Justin Tseng]: That's not how we operate.

[Justin Tseng]: We have rules that we need to follow, and we follow procedure on big issues like this because we know that oftentimes they can be controversial.

[Justin Tseng]: in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: As a young and lifelong Medford resident as someone who wants to stay in the city, but is worried of being priced out.

[Justin Tseng]: I understand that perspective.

[Justin Tseng]: I understand that we are in a housing crisis.

[Justin Tseng]: I also understand that the economic growth of our city in our state is lacking because people can't afford to stay here.

[Justin Tseng]: Think Matt referred to the letter that we received from many residents, longtime residents of Medford, who are now being

[Justin Tseng]: who use our services and who contribute to our city as well, who volunteer.

[Justin Tseng]: But, you know, as a son of long-time Etrovert homeowners, I also see that side of the discourse intimately as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And ultimately, you know, I would probably, my family and I contribute to my parents' fund as well, which they use to pay taxes and property taxes.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, I,

[Justin Tseng]: This might not be the best policy for me as a person, but ultimately my vote hinges on what is best in a well-rounded sense for a city.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, our job as elected officials is to balance interests, to balance not just one constituency's needs or ideas or propositions, but to marry them with all others.

[Justin Tseng]: That's why my vote will ultimately hinge on the final product that we produce in committee, which will only come after a months-long process, a public process that takes into account the value perspectives from people in our city, be it angry, happy, supportive, opposing.

[Justin Tseng]: And I invite everyone to stay engaged with this process over the next few months, but I do ask for that discourse to be respectful,

[Justin Tseng]: to be understanding, and we might disagree, but we cannot be disagreeable.

[Justin Tseng]: Any further comments from members of the council Councilor say, I just wanted to thank the last speaker for for his tone, and it, you know, I support President Bears is and Councilor Lazzaros, what what what they said about it I don't think this is the one tool I don't think it's a be all, and all I think a lot of it depends on the design of the program.

[Justin Tseng]: And thank you everyone for bearing with

[Justin Tseng]: On the budget item, we know that we have to be more transparent and that's why on the agenda for tonight I don't know if we'll get to it but on an agenda for tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: There is a brand new get to it.

[Justin Tseng]: I'd love to get to it.

[Justin Tseng]: We have a brand new budget ordinance that lays out more clearly what developing our city budget will look like it will have more opportunities for people to contribute feedback, and for people to see more information.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: And a special thank you to all my colleagues for bearing with me.

[Justin Tseng]: I was in memo writing mode last week, writing legal memos, so I figured it would be easier for me just to continue with the memo writing.

[Justin Tseng]: Essentially, thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I appreciate it.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm glad my teacher gave me a name.

[Justin Tseng]: So essentially my idea is well down to three big categories.

[Justin Tseng]: One is small dollar increases, investments to help our city improve its public services.

[Justin Tseng]: The second category is preserving spending, important spending projects that we have right now, which I think many of my colleagues have already alluded to.

[Justin Tseng]: The last bucket is long-term plans.

[Justin Tseng]: So essentially spending items I think for me personally as a Councilor, I don't need to see in this budget because I know the constraints on this budget are real, but I really would like the administration to commit to putting plans forward, at least the next few months to show us how we might get to a place where we can fund those important priorities.

[Justin Tseng]: So going one by one.

[Justin Tseng]: The first bucket, I really is much shorter so I've sat down with some of our city staff and the prevention outreach department, recreation department as well.

[Justin Tseng]: We've basically been working on the youth.

[Justin Tseng]: commission ordinance that I know Councilor Scarpelli is also big into.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we've made a lot of progress, but we've also identified that we will need a real budget if we want the project to succeed.

[Justin Tseng]: And so sitting down, doing the calculations, thinking about the number of members that we need to be paying for that commission and also the event costs, the cost for a secretary or lead organizer for the commission, it boils down to about $20,000.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the number is somewhat adjustable, but that's about the number we need.

[Justin Tseng]: And this includes $800 stipends for members.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, the stipend, because it includes youth, it should be $800 or less, because when you go over $800, there are special reports that

[Justin Tseng]: folks under 18 have to file.

[Justin Tseng]: I think a similar logic is behind the Gender Equity Commission, which I think because there will likely be less programming and less secretarial kind of work needed, clerical work needed, $9,000 is an

[Justin Tseng]: appropriate amount for that.

[Justin Tseng]: I've also talked to member city staff in the planning and DW department, something that we talked about earlier this year when we were working through the governing agenda when I was sitting with them and going through the governing agenda was

[Justin Tseng]: to help our city meet our priorities when it comes to safe streets and bicycle lanes, repaving streets.

[Justin Tseng]: We have a series of policies that dictate what types of signage and markings we need before we can repave a street.

[Justin Tseng]: That's oftentimes a constraint to us actually getting the repaving done.

[Justin Tseng]: And so they've mentioned that

[Justin Tseng]: increasing the line item spending for road signages slash road markings can be really helpful in getting us to repave streets faster and in a safer manner.

[Justin Tseng]: Very similarly in kind of the raising spending category, increasing staffing for our elections department I think is something that's already been said a few times.

[Justin Tseng]: We have noted I think it's really noteworthy the

[Justin Tseng]: the change in the elections department going from more FDs to fewer FDs and how that really constrains what our city government can do and the quality of the service that we can give our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: And given that this year we have a very contentious presidential election, given the political atmosphere, both municipally and nationally, increasing the capacity of our elections office I think is very paramount.

[Justin Tseng]: In the second bucket, essentially, we have the items where I think we need to fight hard on preserving spending.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Councilor Scarpelli really made a very important point in saying that the victims of

[Justin Tseng]: government, cutting government spending are oftentimes and usually the less advantaged in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not necessarily going to affect every single resident, but it will affect a large number of residents who can't afford to replace those services with their own budget.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's why maintaining our spending in our public schools, in our library, maintaining the community liaisons program, which is grant funded, maintaining our health equity and outreach positions are really important priorities for us, for me at least, and from what I hear for the rest of the council as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And these are essentially

[Justin Tseng]: essentially roles that we need to make sure don't get lost and don't become victim to cuts in government spending.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, there's also the economic development plan I've also put in this bucket.

[Justin Tseng]: This is a really, really, really important position that's been helping Medford open up a lot of new businesses that folks in the community have been really excited for.

[Justin Tseng]: We've just hired a new one, and I think it's very much a priority of mine to make sure that we can keep developing our local economy, and hopefully that will help us improve our revenues over a longer term as well.

[Justin Tseng]: to be able to do that.

[Justin Tseng]: Now the last bucket about long term plans.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, um, for me, the real focus is one of the types of investments our city can make early on that will reap us rewards and benefits and especially more revenue in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: And so updating our city's

[Justin Tseng]: assist us in the reforms that we want to make is really important to me, and I think it's something that the City Council should be pushing for more.

[Justin Tseng]: Ensuring that our HR department has the capacity they need to complete their work, I think is something that will make working in Medford more of a draw.

[Justin Tseng]: for city staff as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And well, some of the dissatisfaction that we hear from improving childcare access is something that tons of residents write me about throughout the term, no matter what time of the year it is.

[Justin Tseng]: And in Councilor Collins' vein, raising the salaries of vacant positions to meet regional pay standards is, I think, really important.

[Justin Tseng]: And it sounds like there's appetite for us to push hard for this cycle, which I would be happy in joining as well.

[Justin Tseng]: We've heard a lot about how difficult it is to fill some of our positions because there's a shortage in the labor force.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, because of market demands, we just have to be willing to pay for what we want.

[Justin Tseng]: and I agree that a city solicitor is really, really important to helping our city council get as much work done as possible, and to help the city save costs from outsourcing.

[Justin Tseng]: And I would be very happy to support any action to bring those salaries up to where our neighboring municipalities are at to draw candidates.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng, then Councilor Callahan.

[Justin Tseng]: I concur with Vice President Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that, in my opinion, to do it right now without letting it sit with us for a little bit might be a little too rushed.

[Justin Tseng]: I know there are great ideas that my colleagues had that I didn't necessarily jot down, and I think it would be great to give, and I think a lot of us are in that same position, so it would be great for us to sit down and have that time to think about the proposals that have been laid out on the table.

[Justin Tseng]: I also have noticed just scanning through what you presented, I think we have a lot of ideas that are basically the same idea, but just worded in slightly different ways.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Lazzaro.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Levin.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Vice President Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Zang.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think to my fellow Councilors points, um, I think this is meant to be a lot more, I guess, more informative and less scary than it sounds.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, the.

[Justin Tseng]: I, I believe that the council is already.

[Justin Tseng]: Taking a step back when it comes to what exactly this report entails and the details that has to entail.

[Justin Tseng]: I think where we've become over the last few months, much more open minded as to what the broad definition of a report and what types of information we're seeing.

[Justin Tseng]: And as President Bears said, the.

[Justin Tseng]: the committee at the very least.

[Justin Tseng]: As a councilor on this committee, I would be also amenable to the report just saying, the city does not have the resources to do this at this moment.

[Justin Tseng]: This is not a feasible option.

[Justin Tseng]: I wonder if there is a way to reduce maybe any hesitation or fear that the administration might have and yet need a compromise on this topic.

[Justin Tseng]: Along the lines of what Councilor Ilazaro said about finding dates of effectiveness that work for the section that work for the administration for the section, maybe delaying it a year or putting in the words.

[Justin Tseng]: Instead of saying just a report to council regarding progress towards and resources necessary to do X, Y, and Z, to say a report to council regarding progress towards, resources necessary for, and the feasibility of including.

[Justin Tseng]: x, y, z. And I think that would be maybe slightly broader and yet still get at the same spirit of what the council is looking for.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know as Director Dickinson, you said, you don't know what council we're going to be working with in five years or 10 years.

[Justin Tseng]: Maybe that adjustment in wording will give you guys more leeway in terms of what you can do legally with an ordinance like this in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: In the spirit of the work that we've been doing on this committee,

[Justin Tseng]: I know there are two new members here too, so I wanted to recap a little bit.

[Justin Tseng]: But when we first had a meeting on this, we had a draft that I think everyone in the room agreed was the model of what a budget assessment ordinance should look like.

[Justin Tseng]: And there was contention over what was realistic and what was possible.

[Justin Tseng]: And I believe this draft that we see in front of us today,

[Justin Tseng]: It's the result of good faith negotiations from all parties on all of those points.

[Justin Tseng]: And we haven't really thrown anything out of the window.

[Justin Tseng]: We've just come to work point by point and come to places of consensus and agreement on this.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we've also operated with the assumption that the committee wants to see all these things in it.

[Justin Tseng]: and is not ready to move forward with an ordinance without a lot of the components.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think with that assumption, with that understanding of this draft ordinance, that's where a lot of that good faith negotiation came from.

[Justin Tseng]: I just want to make sure that, you know, it seems from my read of what we're talking about, what we've been talking about over the last 20 minutes, it doesn't sound like the committee is ready to just toss out this section.

[Justin Tseng]: of the of the ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: And I would, I know Councilor Lazzaro, Councilor Collins, myself, we've all presented ways for us to, on this point, reach that point of consensus, that shared understanding of how do we balance, you know, the administration's concerns and understandings of our

[Justin Tseng]: are the feasibility of doing a lot of this stuff with the ideals and the moral, I guess, the needs of our community to get this information transparently and for our council to get the information so we can make better financial decisions as a city.

[Justin Tseng]: And I guess what I'm saying is, I would love if we can engage in that discourse with the administration as to how can we make the section work better.

[Justin Tseng]: Let's not assume that we're throwing this out of the window.

[Justin Tseng]: What language changes can we make to get everyone on the same page here?

[Justin Tseng]: I would also like to echo those sentiments.

[Justin Tseng]: I know Councilor Collins, President Bears, and I have sat through many of these meetings on this ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: I just can't overstate how important this is for Medford, how much time we spent on this.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we've created a product that our city can be really proud of.

[Justin Tseng]: our residents can be very proud of as well.

[Justin Tseng]: That really moves us forward as a team, all of us, in our goals of reaching more transparency, making better decisions for our city, creating more reform.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this is the kind of positive spirit that so many residents have invested their faith in our government for, and I really want to thank you, Director Dickinson, our Chief of Staff, for working so hard with our committee on this.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Lazzaro.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I think a lot has been said in this meeting and in meetings past about the environmental effects of leaf blowers and the quality of life effects with the festival levels that we're seeing in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's the reason why we've seen so many letters and emails into the council, at least to the previous councils, about quality of life with leaf blowers.

[Justin Tseng]: in the city and the need to act on it, and I know that's the spirit with which former Council President Morell introduced this.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, with that being said, we also recognize that as a council back then, that we needed to reach out to other stakeholders, too, who had different perspectives on the issue, who might not agree with the final product that we passed, but we recognize that in good faith, we needed to make adjustments that would let them

[Justin Tseng]: you know, continue in a reasonable manner and to let residents who want to use certain types of leaf blowers, especially electric leaf blowers, to function and live as they want to.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, you know, oftentimes we're pulled in many different directions on issues like this, but it's our job as a council to sit down and figure out how we balance those interests and how we create a compromise that is reasonable,

[Justin Tseng]: accessible and just in a policy manner speaking, good.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe that this draft, having read through it before coming to this meeting, reflects that.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's in a much, much better shape than what we saw late last year, which I know a lot of residents had concerns about.

[Justin Tseng]: We integrated those concerns and feedback and

[Justin Tseng]: changed quite a lot in between these versions of the draft.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's just important to set out that the history of this piece of text and the compromises that have come with it as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think it really matter.

[Justin Tseng]: I think each year would open the question up to each calendar year or each, um, each block of 365 days.

[Justin Tseng]: So annually is just clear in that sense.

[Justin Tseng]: But any further thoughts?

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's, you know, I want to reiterate Councilor Collins' point that we've talked, we have considered the question of lithium batteries throughout the creation of this process.

[Justin Tseng]: Looking at reports from the EPA, from UPenn, from Wash U in St.

[Justin Tseng]: Louis, from Yale University.

[Justin Tseng]: they all ask us to think about, yes, there is an environmental impact to creating batteries and destroying them.

[Justin Tseng]: But we also have to think of the lifetime of that use.

[Justin Tseng]: And so it's not only the inception and the getting rid of the product.

[Justin Tseng]: It's all the time in between the emissions that are produced in between as well, where gas-powered leaf blowers really do exceed electric.

[Justin Tseng]: battery-powered leaf blowers by quite a bit in terms of emissions.

[Justin Tseng]: We have to look at the whole picture.

[Justin Tseng]: And while there might be one part of the picture we don't like as much, we should consider the lifetime of the project as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Very similarly, we shouldn't let this one point dictate the whole debate.

[Justin Tseng]: I would also like to remind the council that a number of us have been working on this ordinance for a while in the public eye, with it being posted on Facebook, with people having chances to chime in in favor and against.

[Justin Tseng]: And we were re-elected.

[Justin Tseng]: This is a representative democracy.

[Justin Tseng]: And we were elected by a majority of the voters.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng?

[Justin Tseng]: Not a question, but as you noted, we've been funding this for a while and there have been no complaints.

[Justin Tseng]: It's gone pretty smoothly, so I feel very comfortable with this.

[Justin Tseng]: General question.

[Justin Tseng]: So could you give us some ideas to, when you're going through these every year, how many applicants do you get versus how much money are you able to award?

[Justin Tseng]: But I'm hearing that sometimes there's a delay in how quickly people can inquire.

[Justin Tseng]: That's really helpful to hear.

[Justin Tseng]: And in the future, if we have projects coming on board, like what we anticipate some projects that we've already mentioned in this meeting, seems like we might not be able to meet the full need of those projects through CPA funding.

[Justin Tseng]: Thanks.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng, Councilor Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think what I'm hearing from that is the need is deeper than just the applicants themselves.

[Justin Tseng]: Oftentimes there are projects that aren't even applied for or aren't considered great enough just because we don't have the money for that in the first place.

[Justin Tseng]: And the city departments know and applicants know that it's not realistic to get that money at this point in the project process.

[Justin Tseng]: Would that be correct?

[Justin Tseng]: So for big projects, oftentimes, most times, we need multiple revenue sources.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's helpful to know, I think, as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think when we think about the parks that are on our list, if we have other strong revenue channels to fund certain projects that cover some of these, that might free up funding to do some of the other really important work.

[Justin Tseng]: Would that be accurate?

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's helpful context.

[Justin Tseng]: I think like the CPA projects are all excellent, that they really help our community know that, you know, this isn't the end all be all.

[Justin Tseng]: And there's so much more need than what we see on the paper.

[Justin Tseng]: It's really helpful context for us to consider other policies going forward.

[Justin Tseng]: Motion.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Mr. Costigan.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to check and make sure, are we maxing out the exemption for seniors and vets?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, that's helpful, and I think good for the residents of our city.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll be brief as well because I know a lot of people want to speak.

[Justin Tseng]: I want to echo Councilor Collins' sentiment.

[Justin Tseng]: I've spent a lot of the last few days talking to people, catching up on emails and phone calls and haven't been able to reach everyone, especially since I was sick for a few days last week.

[Justin Tseng]: I think my job here tonight is to listen.

[Justin Tseng]: and to listen to the perspectives in the room and give you all a chance to speak.

[Justin Tseng]: And I have myself questions about this policy, concerns as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's important just to recognize that my job tonight is to listen.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Talking to people coming in here today, I said that I had, as I said to the union reps, I have questions about this proposal.

[Justin Tseng]: I have points where I'm not very happy with how it's presented.

[Justin Tseng]: I think coming out of here tonight, hearing from the perspectives,

[Justin Tseng]: those questions still exist.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Councilor Callaghan is making important points about how reform has to be complete, comprehensive, that we need to take our time with

[Justin Tseng]: any policy issue that comes before us.

[Justin Tseng]: There are really great questions that the union reps have brought up tonight, legal questions, technical questions that I think need to be answered with time.

[Justin Tseng]: And as residents have stated, this particular timing is

[Justin Tseng]: questionable, it's difficult.

[Justin Tseng]: But taking our time with it, as a resident supporting the firefighters said, tabling it, postponing it, moving it to committee is something I would be comfortable with.

[Justin Tseng]: I, in a very similar manner as Council Columns and Councilor Scarpelli, want to thank you for the time that you've put into this project, I know it's been years.

[Justin Tseng]: I think very importantly, you've put a lot of time to get to know the community to talk to the residents.

[Justin Tseng]: to, you know, sometimes you don't see eye to eye with them on things, but you talk and compromise and have made adjustments.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's really important.

[Justin Tseng]: You've coordinated a lot with city staff in a way that we wish every project were done in that manner.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's really important to underscore how rare it is for our city to have this opportunity.

[Justin Tseng]: I think any municipality in Massachusetts would be kicking its heels to get at this opportunity and the opportunity like this to increase its affordable housing stock.

[Justin Tseng]: to better the living conditions of the seniors.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's really important to talk about how there'll be better ventilation in these buildings, there's better noise guards against outside noise in these buildings as well.

[Justin Tseng]: There's more space, there are elevators.

[Justin Tseng]: seniors can get the care that they need.

[Justin Tseng]: When, you know, Walken Court, when it was first designed, was state of its art.

[Justin Tseng]: But, you know, time changes, and needs change.

[Justin Tseng]: And as those needs have changed, I'm very happy to see that the MHA has taken that into account.

[Justin Tseng]: I know it's not been the easiest process, and I know that, as Councilor Scarpell mentioned, there are still residents with some concerns, but I think you have negotiated in good faith.

[Justin Tseng]: to address those concerns.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm also very happy to see that, to see the 50,000 in tree mitigation agreement that you've reached with trees, which I think speaks to that good faith negotiations.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: The meeting is now adjourned.

[Justin Tseng]: If I can, I think the intention of that resolution was just for us to discuss it within our own committee without the Council President or Council Vice President needing to be present.

[Justin Tseng]: So just to generally talk through timeline and just the kind of specific items in there if there was anything we wanted to prioritize.

[Justin Tseng]: I think they're quite similar, too, given how much my presentation will overlap with the items in 24-006.

[Justin Tseng]: I think you have to call.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: If the committee will indulge me in a short presentation of a lot of the ideas that I had for modernizing our city council communications outreach, I have a short presentation for everyone with some questions for the committee to think about as we talk about these different proposals.

[Justin Tseng]: Most of them are also already in the governing agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: That's why I said there was an overlap with 24-06.

[Justin Tseng]: My intention for this meeting is to move forward things that we think we might be ready for as a committee, and to just start discussions on things that we think might need more time, which is probably most of these ideas.

[Justin Tseng]: With that being said, let me go to the slides.

[Justin Tseng]: Can folks see them?

[Justin Tseng]: Great.

[Justin Tseng]: And so, okay, so these are just some proposals for our committee to consider.

[Justin Tseng]: Following what I had in the governing agenda, I put in press releases, short-form videos, social media content, city website updates, input surveys and forums, and meetings with underrepresented groups.

[Justin Tseng]: This isn't meant to be a deep dive into... I know there are some of these that I've talked with

[Justin Tseng]: individual Councilors about that, especially the meetings with other representative groups.

[Justin Tseng]: This isn't to start that process necessarily, but just to talk about and get feedback from this committee about where things are, where we think things are at.

[Justin Tseng]: And so for us to move in future meetings on it.

[Justin Tseng]: Going to our first slide, I think the big thing that I was thinking for our committee was that we could create press releases in order to update residents about our work generally, to keep residents informed about opportunities where they can provide feedback on resolutions, ordinances, our work, ahead of big meetings, and in response to our work as well.

[Justin Tseng]: To keep residents up to date about news in Medford, we know that oftentimes there is a gap between what we know as Councilors and what is released out to the public.

[Justin Tseng]: In terms of public information, most of that's not intentional.

[Justin Tseng]: This is to bridge that gap.

[Justin Tseng]: And so in terms of execution, I think it'd be realistic for our committee to approve monthly updates, essentially monthly summaries of what we've done as a city council in the last month.

[Justin Tseng]: And so basically the idea is that we would rotate this responsibility among members.

[Justin Tseng]: Every month, a different one of us would create that summary and bring it to our committee meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: We would review it quickly together and vote it out to be published.

[Justin Tseng]: The idea behind rotating responsibilities among members is that

[Justin Tseng]: We know that a lot of us, Councilor Bears, Councilor Collins, Councilor Leming, me, we've tried at different times to do these regular updates.

[Justin Tseng]: It can be a lot for a singular councilor to do it repeatedly, regularly across different months.

[Justin Tseng]: And so the idea is that by dispersing the responsibility, it would be less pressure for us, less of a workload for us.

[Justin Tseng]: yet still give all of us a chance to write something, all of us a chance to communicate with the public.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think having us bring it to this committee meeting would essentially

[Justin Tseng]: essentially be like a work responsibility for us to keep us to make sure we're doing this.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, there are some, I think, questions I had for the committee around the execution of this.

[Justin Tseng]: So essentially, I think the first big question is, do we do this as a resident services public engagement committee as a complete committee?

[Justin Tseng]: Um, where each of us are rotating responsibilities, or do we form a special committee, a subcommittee for this that meets at a separate time very quickly, maybe a 30 minute meeting 15 minute 30 minute meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: I think another question is, I know there are.

[Justin Tseng]: um, Councilors who aren't standing members of this committee who have been working on updates as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Should we invite them to join our rotating group of Councilors?

[Justin Tseng]: And I think in the same vein of questions, I know that certain Councilors are busy at different times of the year.

[Justin Tseng]: Should we create a system where Councilors can pass off their responsibilities to the next Councilor or to another Councilor?

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and then the final questions are around distribution.

[Justin Tseng]: I know the clerk has an email list for the city council.

[Justin Tseng]: Maybe you could use that with the clerk could chime in as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I know we.

[Justin Tseng]: Carol Leming invited Steve Schmierdi, our communications director, to this meeting as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I think there's a question about whether we can use the city email list for some of this, for some of these regular press releases, maybe including it as a shorter section in the mayor's regular updates.

[Justin Tseng]: In order, we also know that the formats in which we reach people have to be accessible as well.

[Justin Tseng]: For example, for younger folks, social media might be a better way to do that.

[Justin Tseng]: So there's a whole section later in this presentation about social media, creating social media.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know that a lot of seniors might not be subscribed to the email list as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So wondering if we could get a print version to be a shortened print version to be put in the senior center newsletter.

[Justin Tseng]: But with that being said, open to remarks, feedbacks, ideas.

[Justin Tseng]: Thanks, Councilor.

[Justin Tseng]: Chair, let me, if I can respond.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, respond and then Councilor Lazzaro.

[Justin Tseng]: um, so I I did think through a lot of those concerns beforehand, um, The intent behind these releases would be to be a compliment basically to the mayors now the way that our comms department is set up in medford Is that it's a really it's really a one-person department falling under the mayor's office.

[Justin Tseng]: And so oftentimes the publications are more relevant to what the mayor is doing specifically like with

[Justin Tseng]: Mayor Lungo-Koehn specifically is doing and to do items that are originating from her office.

[Justin Tseng]: Now going forward, we have zoning, we have budgeting, a lot of these bigger processes going forward that are much more council specific rather than mayor specific, and it's currently not in the responsibilities of the comms director.

[Justin Tseng]: uh, to put out releases that speak to any of that.

[Justin Tseng]: And as we've seen in the last few years, there hasn't been any of it.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this is the idea is that this isn't to, um, bought heads with any city messaging, but this is basically to let residents know when things are coming up and what, when we are working on things, um, separate from what the mayor's office in the city departments are working on.

[Justin Tseng]: Um,

[Justin Tseng]: And we can talk about which lists this goes out to.

[Justin Tseng]: Maybe we just keep it on the clerk's email list.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think the essence of this is keep it simple.

[Justin Tseng]: Basically, just summarize what we've done and what's coming ahead in terms of meetings that we have.

[Justin Tseng]: Just things like posting the meeting schedule that we have.

[Justin Tseng]: And we can coordinate with the president and the vice president of the council to see when these releases go out.

[Justin Tseng]: Is that directed to me?

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: So to Yeah, it doesn't have to be long.

[Justin Tseng]: We did.

[Justin Tseng]: So essentially, at a previous meeting, we, I think, decided to combine this ordinance, or these two different ordinance ideas, because a lot of communities around us have done it that way, and their ordinances have gone through legal reviews.

[Justin Tseng]: Essentially, we have a draft that we reviewed already.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's in a place where folks are pretty alright with it.

[Justin Tseng]: We only didn't move forward on it because we were busy getting feedback from the mayor's office about whether we had

[Justin Tseng]: basically checking with Mayor Lungo-Koehn to see if we had already passed an ordinance like this, which then Councilor Caraviello said we did, but the mayor's office responded to the council saying that we didn't, so we should move forward on it.

[Justin Tseng]: that it would be helpful for the city to move alongside the state on it.

[Justin Tseng]: a town, a city.

[Justin Tseng]: And when we think about what has brought us up to this moment, Black Medfordians, and especially the historically Black community in West Medford, has played such a pivotal and integral role to shaping who we are today, the discourse that shapes our politics today, and just the joy, the memories, the happiness of growing up in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: I was reminded of this, especially on Martin Luther King's Day.

[Justin Tseng]: When I got this book, Place, Race, and Memory, the West Medford Afro-American Remembrance Project, which talks about a bunch of icons that have lived in our city, been a vital part of our West Medford community.

[Justin Tseng]: And I was really touched reading a lot of these stories and at the same time, a bit sad that I didn't grow up learning about a lot of these folks.

[Justin Tseng]: There's such a long way to go when it comes to racial reconciliation in the city, when it comes to making sure that all of our neighbors, our black neighbors included feel welcome and engaged as part of our city.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, my focus as a city councilor in this job as a candidate who ran for city council who first ran for city council, um, just over two years ago, um, who started the campaign almost three years ago.

[Justin Tseng]: The

[Justin Tseng]: biggest issue going up at going in my brain at that time was fighting to make sure that our residents that all of our residents felt safe and not only just safe, but welcome and included and engaged in our city government.

[Justin Tseng]: I grew up, obviously, my

[Justin Tseng]: My skin color makes me look different from other people.

[Justin Tseng]: I grew up oftentimes as someone who felt excluded, as someone who didn't necessarily feel completely represented in government.

[Justin Tseng]: And for me, that was a driving factor to get involved in government and to make sure that we built a local government that reflected the desires of its people, that the

[Justin Tseng]: push for equity and for justice, and to make sure that that push was reflected in our actions as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And at the end of the day, to make sure that all of our residents feel safe and welcome here in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: It's with that spirit that after the horrifying attacks on October 7th, I reached out to Jewish, Arab, and Muslim community leaders to make sure that, at least from my office, that they

[Justin Tseng]: felt safe, that they felt welcomed and included, and knowing that there were growing incidents of anti-Semitic and Islamophobic and xenophobic attacks and incidents in this community to make sure that they have the resources they need and needed and still need to feel safe and welcome in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, as situations on the ground, um, have developed, uh, more residents of various backgrounds, including a large number of, uh, Jewish, personally very close Jewish friends begged me as a city councilor to vote yes, um, when a ceasefire resolution, if a ceasefire resolution came across my desk.

[Justin Tseng]: And through those discussions, I realized that not voting, not doing anything is, um, an action in itself.

[Justin Tseng]: And so, and for so many of our residents, they need to see that their elected officials align with the values that we espouse as candidates and that we espouse as politicians.

[Justin Tseng]: When I look at this resolution, I look at the first and last lines.

[Justin Tseng]: recognizing and celebrating the sanctity, the preciousness, the equality of human life.

[Justin Tseng]: Looking at the last line cites the core purpose of this resolution as to reaffirm that we stand with protecting and honoring all human life.

[Justin Tseng]: This is undoubtedly a difficult situation, but I really do commend Councilor Collins for keeping the focus in this resolution on the sanctity of life.

[Justin Tseng]: for keeping the focus of this resolution through hope on equality, bringing in stakeholders from many, many different parts of this community, hearing opposition to different drafts of this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: I know the vice president has worked really, really hard on a product that best captures that inclusive energy and spirit that we want to see in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: For me, again, the local aspect of this is that, is just that.

[Justin Tseng]: It is the quality of letting our residents know that we stand with these values.

[Justin Tseng]: when I also think about why this resolution is necessary.

[Justin Tseng]: I realize that, you know, while this isn't necessarily, you know, obviously, I don't think anyone is under the illusion that we ourselves as Medford City Council is going to stop war in the Middle East, but

[Justin Tseng]: I do think that many, many folks, many residents, neighbors, activists have felt disillusioned, disheartened, and in despair after various and numerous attempts to reach out to federal and state level stakeholders on this issue, people with influence.

[Justin Tseng]: And they're coming to the Medford City Council, they're coming to City Hall tonight, because they recognize that there aren't many avenues left.

[Justin Tseng]: We are, in many ways, one of the last stops that people are going to, to ask us, to beg us to help them get their message across to our federal electeds.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we really need to try, in any case, be it Gaza, be it a local issue about a park or a street or a sidewalk.

[Justin Tseng]: We as elected officials, as the Medford City Council, have a responsibility to amplify the community's desires to speak to federal elected officials.

[Justin Tseng]: That's our job.

[Justin Tseng]: We do it on different issues.

[Justin Tseng]: We reach out to Congress people.

[Justin Tseng]: We reach out to state reps to help us resolve things.

[Justin Tseng]: This is our job.

[Justin Tseng]: I, you know, I think there's a crisis of faith in democracy when people don't feel hurt by their elected officials, and I think we need to work to restore that faith in our country.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to thank everyone who spoke, no matter what viewpoint of this resolution they have.

[Justin Tseng]: It really means a lot to our city and our democracy that you're willing to take time out of your evening to do this.

[Justin Tseng]: In that spirit, we also owe you, at least in my opinion, I owe you your faith, and me as your city councilor, to let you know that I care.

[Justin Tseng]: I care about the stories.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that many of you, as you've said tonight, have family who've been in the area, who are currently still in the area, who are trapped there, who are suffering.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think this is a moment where people need to know that their local electeds care, that they not only hear them, but they, I think, deeply, deeply, that this deeply matters to them.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think it's wrong at all to say that the context is complex, that there's misinformation, and there's violence and tragedy that civilians take the brunt of.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think it's wrong to say that

[Justin Tseng]: a lot of the rhetoric in the debate has been challenging for others to hear.

[Justin Tseng]: But I have to thank you as a councillor that you've kept this conversation, this discourse tonight so cordial, so respectful, that you've followed the rules that the council president has set out.

[Justin Tseng]: But you know, even given this, the complex history and context behind this issue, I think the question before us, the heart of this resolution is simple.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think the big question is, do we affirm the sanctity, the preciousness, and the equality of all human life?

[Justin Tseng]: And do we

[Justin Tseng]: condemn the bloodshed going on.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's not wrong to say that war begets war.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we should listen to the hostages' pleas to the Israeli government, that their government not do anything that worsens the outcome of people living in Israel and Palestine, of the civilians.

[Justin Tseng]: And their pleas not to drive more people into extremism.

[Justin Tseng]: I was struck by the word precedent earlier in public comment.

[Justin Tseng]: Because even though we can't, as a city council, we can't stop what's going on from becoming precedent, I think we can stop normalizing it.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we have a moral duty to stop normalizing violence.

[Justin Tseng]: We have to speak out against it, even if we can't stop it.

[Justin Tseng]: On the issue of precedence, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: thought during the debate about my own family.

[Justin Tseng]: For those of you who don't know, my family comes from Taiwan.

[Justin Tseng]: Pretty much everyone in my family lives in Taiwan.

[Justin Tseng]: And if you've been following the news, we talk about war, the possibility of war every day in Taiwan.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think about if this were happening over there right now,

[Justin Tseng]: Number one, if we set this precedent, what that would mean for my family.

[Justin Tseng]: I also think about what it would mean to me if I were watching and my community didn't support my family and didn't hear my family.

[Justin Tseng]: And while Taiwan is a hypothetical for me, it's emotionally close to me, Palestine is now.

[Justin Tseng]: And Palestine is now for so many of our community.

[Justin Tseng]: This resolution I think is measured.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's reasonable.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, yes, it is ideal.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it is nuanced.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it speaks to the complexities on the ground.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it condemns terrorism.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it condemns Hamas.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think it supports life.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it uplifts life.

[Justin Tseng]: I think

[Justin Tseng]: This is a moral duty to say to our residents, no matter if you're Arab, Muslim, Jewish, Israeli-American, right?

[Justin Tseng]: You belong in our community.

[Justin Tseng]: You deserve to be heard.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why I'll plan to vote yes on this tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know there are a lot of folks at home watching who

[Justin Tseng]: are just getting into activism, there are small steps that we can all take to help.

[Justin Tseng]: While this is symbolic, donating an eSIM is not.

[Justin Tseng]: Helping people in Gaza stay connected for just up to $5 a month is not symbolic.

[Justin Tseng]: These are actions that we can take to help people on the ground, to stay connected to the world, and donations to human rights organizations, relief organizations, will really help people on the ground.

[Justin Tseng]: No.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll be brief.

[Justin Tseng]: I also talked to Director Nwaje about this.

[Justin Tseng]: Obviously, I think we're all very excited about it.

[Justin Tseng]: An idea that we had started to talk about before we got pulled away from each other was including boards and commissions in this as well.

[Justin Tseng]: There's a feeling in the office that perhaps we could do more to align everyone with how DEI works in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: especially given that there are a lot of updates in recent years, and there haven't been many, if any, trainings on this for boards and commissions.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I would love, if you were amenable, for this to be amended to add exploring doing this for boards and commissions.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Bears, for introducing this.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to lend my support.

[Justin Tseng]: I talked about the sanctity of life earlier.

[Justin Tseng]: Giving people food, medicine, water, that very much is in line with the sanctity of life and preserving it.

[Justin Tseng]: We might not agree with the country for political reasons, but we can't hold its people hostage.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm kidding.

[Justin Tseng]: I appreciate Councilor Lemons, I think appreciation of the nuance of this issue.

[Justin Tseng]: We definitely have a need to revitalize our squares.

[Justin Tseng]: There are items later on in the agenda that will help us get at that as well.

[Justin Tseng]: We have passed as a city council last term, numerous items to help us get there and implementing mechanisms to get there.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not wrong to say that we need to do more on the issue, especially of commercial vacancies.

[Justin Tseng]: We want to be bringing people into the square, into all of our squares, if we don't have populated storefronts.

[Justin Tseng]: we disincentivize that.

[Justin Tseng]: At the same time, the nuances of the questions of turnover and the types of businesses that you'll want to see are extremely relevant in discussing this matter as well, which Councilor Leming has noted.

[Justin Tseng]: I've sat down with the city staff on a few occasions before, both this term and last term, to talk about

[Justin Tseng]: this idea and there are different views of it, but I think broadly the consensus is we should also as a council consider what carrots we want to accompany the stick.

[Justin Tseng]: There are some potential state mechanisms that we could look into in terms of giving new starting businesses funding to pay for physical improvements, to pay for

[Justin Tseng]: basically capital costs to operate a new business.

[Justin Tseng]: It will take a lot of talking to the potential business owners, the landlords, to see why things are the way they are.

[Justin Tseng]: But if we identify the problems as such, there are different mechanisms that we might be able to introduce as carrots going along with this.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to thank Councilor Scarpelli for introducing this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to second it as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Scarpelli and I talked, I think on Wednesday, about how we both called the building department staff over to notify, to talk to them, get some sort of solution out.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Councilor Scarpelli has really gotten to the root of everything.

[Justin Tseng]: We were promised a liaison.

[Justin Tseng]: We don't know who the liaison is.

[Justin Tseng]: We haven't been, who they report to.

[Justin Tseng]: the upcoming budget.

[Justin Tseng]: The emphasis of this is basically to try to get developers incentivize renters living there and businesses and employees who work there to use bikes and public transit where possible.

[Justin Tseng]: Regulate this behavior on the green score.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, transit signal priority is basically when you modify traffic signals to basically implement a strategy where we cause less delay to transit vehicles like buses to make sure that

[Justin Tseng]: people can rely better on bus schedules and that buses can travel quicker to incentivize people to take public transit.

[Justin Tseng]: Essentially, there's also appetite for this in City Hall, but the big problem, as always, is revenue, making sure that we have the money to buy the physical infrastructure we need to modify traffic lights.

[Justin Tseng]: So the mini bonds program that Councilor Caraviello-Viello introduced, the intention behind that was essentially

[Justin Tseng]: Some of them in Cambridge have these programs where they work with a company called Neighborly to provide $1,000 bonds for residents to borrow money, basically partake in buying those bonds and essentially use that money for home repairs, sidewalk repairs, infrastructure related stuff mostly.

[Justin Tseng]: Theoretically, you could use it for other things, but the company that they do it through, so the precedent that is set in Massachusetts is basically very much focused on small repairs along that scale.

[Justin Tseng]: The second paper listed, Accepting the Provisions of Mass General Loss, 71, Section 37M, that one is about consolidating

[Justin Tseng]: giving the city option to consolidate administration across the school side of things, the Bedford public schools and the city side of things.

[Justin Tseng]: That one would require a vote of the school committee, the city council and the mayor's approval on it.

[Justin Tseng]: So that one's much more involved and would require, essentially would require us to work with the school committee on the issue and to get everyone to a place where we agree.

[Justin Tseng]: It was introduced back then because there was a desire to essentially make, to have the security director of the public schools the same as the security director of the city.

[Justin Tseng]: So essentially to combine, like, kind of building security administration.

[Justin Tseng]: Obviously, it just never got moved forward, maybe because of how involved the idea is, but that's just a bit of context on those two, on these two points.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: I think my thoughts are in line with the councilors who have spoken already.

[Justin Tseng]: I want to first thank you all for putting together this report.

[Justin Tseng]: I know oftentimes we request reports and they kind of go into the ether to have an

[Justin Tseng]: I think, um.

[Justin Tseng]: Pretty thorough report back is helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: Um that being said, you know, there's still some questions that we have that aren't necessarily settled in this report.

[Justin Tseng]: It might be better and wiser to, um to meet and subcommittee about it.

[Justin Tseng]: Um that way we can give you all time.

[Justin Tseng]: We can come up with our list of, um of more specific questions that we have.

[Justin Tseng]: I think to restore that confidence, it's helpful to have some document as kind of like a guide for someone who doesn't know how elections are run.

[Justin Tseng]: I think reading this part of the gap in terms of what we're perceiving and maybe what the intention was comes from the fact that you all just understand how elections are run.

[Justin Tseng]: And so there are basic underlying

[Justin Tseng]: I think underlying steps, procedures that are just very obvious to the Elections Commission that aren't very obvious to us as residents.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think we can work together to think through what those questions might be.

[Justin Tseng]: Something in my mind is the question of central tabulation,

[Justin Tseng]: and what seems like a shift from an old system where we used to count at polling booths to now this mixed system where we have some votes, some ballots counted at polling locations, some ballots counted here as a central tab.

[Justin Tseng]: I think further clarification on what determines what's counted where, why have we made that decision versus why have we changed this new system would be helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: I think

[Justin Tseng]: There are outstanding questions I've heard from constituents about even though the numbers ultimately did add up, a lot of these numbers were found on different sheets.

[Justin Tseng]: And so why was that the case?

[Justin Tseng]: How can we make sure going forward that the sheets that are published by the city

[Justin Tseng]: the numbers all add up and are final.

[Justin Tseng]: I think some over the last few election cycles, some residents have been a little confused as to why we're giving an update at 9 p.m., let's say, and another update, a final update at 1 a.m.

[Justin Tseng]: instead of doing it in one complete batch.

[Justin Tseng]: I think these are just some of the larger questions that residents might have that you might know the answers to that maybe are

[Justin Tseng]: a bit evidence to you all but not as evident to us and would be helpful to uh to have in a report or to talk about in the South.

[Justin Tseng]: to introduce this proposal.

[Justin Tseng]: Let me give some background about how I arrived at these numbers.

[Justin Tseng]: I reached out to, I looked at what former and current school committee members have said in their statements about their thoughts on the original proposal by former President Morell in December of last year.

[Justin Tseng]: I also reached out to various teachers,

[Justin Tseng]: and school staff to see what people were willing to compromise to.

[Justin Tseng]: And at the end of the day, I arrived at this, this proposal, which essentially increases over two years, the salary of school community members to approximately $22,100.

[Justin Tseng]: which is in line with the research I've done with Medford Teacher Association contracts over the last 25 years, going year by year, line by line, and matching their pay increases.

[Justin Tseng]: This proposal would essentially stop

[Justin Tseng]: in 2025 and so there would be no increase after that.

[Justin Tseng]: It also, in contrast to the original proposal, phases in this increase over two years instead of having it start immediately upon passage.

[Justin Tseng]: This is time, I believe, will give us a chance to finalize our financial picture and make sure it's in line with the information that we're hearing from finance staff currently.

[Justin Tseng]: It also gives us

[Justin Tseng]: a chance to start paraprofessional negotiations throughout the process to make sure that we address that part of the criticism with the original proposal.

[Justin Tseng]: I have to emphasize that this is a compromise that we arrived at after engaging stakeholders, and that I believe that this is a compromise built off some logical ground, which is that of the previous MTA contract increases.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe that this is a reasonable compromise.

[Justin Tseng]: Not everyone will be happy with this, surely, and I'm sure that there are folks who would have liked this number to be higher, would have liked this number to be lower.

[Justin Tseng]: This compromise, I know, also doesn't live up to all of the ideals that we may hold both on this side of the rail and on the other side of the rail.

[Justin Tseng]: But

[Justin Tseng]: So goes compromise.

[Justin Tseng]: This is the nature of work.

[Justin Tseng]: And we must be politically responsible actors here.

[Justin Tseng]: We must also, instead of viewing this as a compromise that we can live with,

[Justin Tseng]: understand that this compromise can be a win-win if we take advantage of it.

[Justin Tseng]: If stakeholders can take advantage of it, we can lift up by lifting up one set of workers for schools, all workers for schools as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why I believe that we should pass this tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: As I said at the meeting in December, there's a lot about this proposal.

[Justin Tseng]: At the very least, the core of this proposal, I very much agree with the principles behind it, the principles of parity, equity, the experience that

[Justin Tseng]: The experience and time that the school committee puts into their work vis-a-vis compared to ours, and especially this idea of giving folks a chance to take part in running for and serving on the school committee, not just because of the money itself, but

[Justin Tseng]: because it makes, not because of the money itself, but because it makes doing school can be a justifiable decision economically.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it pays attention to economic realities.

[Justin Tseng]: I said at that meeting, however, that we needed to talk through the details that, you know, I really appreciated former President Morales.

[Justin Tseng]: amendments to have us look at amounts and timing.

[Justin Tseng]: And in that spirit, I've collected some data, and in talking to folks, put together a range of different proposals as to different amounts that we could arrive at.

[Justin Tseng]: I sent the chart over to President Bears, if he can show it on the screen.

[Justin Tseng]: And we've also have printed copies for all the Councilors here.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Ferris.

[Justin Tseng]: I know the text is a little small.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll read out the most important numbers.

[Justin Tseng]: But essentially, this is a

[Justin Tseng]: a listing of four alternative proposals for the school committee pay increase.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, I think it's really important to underscore that we're looking at a current pay of about $12,000 a year, which has not gone up since the year 2000.

[Justin Tseng]: And so the very first column is just the fiscal years.

[Justin Tseng]: The second and third columns are basically, historically, the school committee pay versus the city council member pay, which was brought up at the last meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, as you can see, the city council pay in the year 2000 was about $13,785.

[Justin Tseng]: compared to $12,000 for school committee members.

[Justin Tseng]: And over time, that disparity has grown.

[Justin Tseng]: And that was a big kind of topic of discussion at our last meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: The first proposal is just simply following the council.

[Justin Tseng]: So this first proposal is different from what was on the agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: The first proposal is following the percentage increases that the city council received in those years.

[Justin Tseng]: And so what I did was got the data for all the years, went through year by year, looked at the percentage increase, the percentage change, and then did calculations from the starting point of 12,000 off that.

[Justin Tseng]: which would land us at approximately $25,000 and 500, a little bit over that.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, the average annual percent change with that would be 3.3% compounded.

[Justin Tseng]: The total percent change is about 130%.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's if we follow the city council pay increase.

[Justin Tseng]: The third set of numbers is, so basically I went and requested the teacher contracts, the MTA contracts, and in talking to some teachers, this was an idea that came up was if we, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: the school committee pay increase should look somewhat like more akin to what teachers see.

[Justin Tseng]: And so with that proposal, again, went through the years, did all the calculations, you end up at $22,000, 100, or $22,000, or 22,000, sorry, I'm too tired, $22,105.60.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's using what the numbers I found in the teacher contracts.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, obviously there's some nuance to that.

[Justin Tseng]: I know a school committee member put out a post talking about how we look at those numbers and how we calculate and how steps work, but this is just kind of a neutral setting.

[Justin Tseng]: I also collected the numbers for the flat 2% cost of living adjustment.

[Justin Tseng]: which would basically have us end up at $19,687.27.

[Justin Tseng]: So about $2,500 lower.

[Justin Tseng]: I was also curious about inflation and what that $12,000 would look like if we use the Department of Labor's data on the change in the consumer price index in Boston.

[Justin Tseng]: And it actually ends up very, very, very close to the Medford Teachers Association cost of living adjustments, actually just off by $3.30.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that would basically have us end up at $22,108.69.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, there's some numbers at the bottom for different, um, different positions, chair, secretary, vice chair.

[Justin Tseng]: But, um, I think for the sake of this discussion, um, I think the focus should be on just the normal school committee members pay and then we can get to get those positions as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, just some food for thought, some ideas, some different ideas, um, some alternate, uh, alternate proposals to consider.

[Justin Tseng]: There are a lot of arguments that are, I think, fairly being raised, some that I don't disagree, that I don't agree as much with, but I still do believe that there's a lot of this that needs to be balanced.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think Councilor Scarpelli's core ask,

[Justin Tseng]: that we look at the timing so that we have a better picture of what things look like financially is not an unreasonable ask.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's why I would personally be in favor and I will motion

[Justin Tseng]: later to have this, instead of having this be implemented immediately, have a proposal be implemented over the two years, which would give us time.

[Justin Tseng]: So basically, July 1st, 2024, July 1st, 2025.

[Justin Tseng]: This would basically give us time to go through the budget process to have a better picture of what things look like at the schools before we move forward with a proposal.

[Justin Tseng]: In the first year, I don't think that we should do the full amount.

[Justin Tseng]: That's my take.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I would have this be spread over a few years as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And that will hopefully give us more time to solidify our understanding of the picture.

[Justin Tseng]: I have also taken time to talk to people with a better financial picture.

[Justin Tseng]: And the financial picture is nuanced.

[Justin Tseng]: It basically says that we have a small, small chunk of money that we can spend, but little consensus about what that money should be spent on.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: it would be more ideal to give people across the board raises, but it's not enough money to do that structurally.

[Justin Tseng]: And so the question is, what do we do with that surplus, with that tiny surplus?

[Justin Tseng]: So that's a consideration.

[Justin Tseng]: Ultimately, I grew up close to my teachers.

[Justin Tseng]: I ran for city council because during the pandemic, the school's budget got cut in real terms of close to 9%.

[Justin Tseng]: I fought hard for more money for our schools successfully, but we also have to be fair to all our staff, and that includes people who run the schools as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Councilor Leming makes a great point that I see in my real life.

[Justin Tseng]: When I say that this makes running for office justifiable, right?

[Justin Tseng]: I think the service argument is important.

[Justin Tseng]: But there are tons of people who want to serve, but can't because they have to put food on their table.

[Justin Tseng]: They have to pay their rents.

[Justin Tseng]: And so they ultimately don't make that choice.

[Justin Tseng]: Nat cited a

[Justin Tseng]: an example here in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: But it's a story that more often than not ends in people deciding not to run for office than to run for office.

[Justin Tseng]: With that being said, again, so in summary, I think we should discuss the phase-in over two years.

[Justin Tseng]: And I agree with Matt that I think we should end up around where the teachers end up.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's only fair.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the logic is more sound.

[Justin Tseng]: the data is there, and so I believe that we should end up basically raising school committee pay to $22,105.60, which is basically the same increased rates as MTA cost leveling adjustments, phased over two years, going into effect July 1st of 2024 and July 1st of 2025.

[Justin Tseng]: It seems to me like the most reasonable approach.

[Justin Tseng]: It's a compromise that not many people are going to be happy with, but that's the nature of compromises, and I think everyone can find some progress in that deal being made.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and I think we should discuss that proposal.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's more palatable.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it gives us more room to, um, to look at our picture and look at what, um, what the picture looks like going forward.

[Justin Tseng]: And I would be happy to motion now, but I am also happy to have a discussion first about it.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng, um, I think, Oh, given given the fact that Councilor Collins made a motion, I also just wanted to make a motion to

[Justin Tseng]: to basically do the MTA, to have the cost of living adjustment reflect the MTA raised over those years.

[Justin Tseng]: Over which years?

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, do you want formal language?

[Justin Tseng]: Over which years, sorry?

[Justin Tseng]: From fiscal 2000 to fiscal 2025.

[Justin Tseng]: Right, and then over how long?

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, to have it go to $17,000 by July 1st, 2024, and up to $22,105.60 by July 1st, 2025.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay, so it would be the 24 and 25.

[Justin Tseng]: Right, it would be that one.

[Justin Tseng]: Sorry, I misunderstood your question.

[Justin Tseng]: That's fine.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, this is all about balance.

[Justin Tseng]: This is not a proposal.

[Justin Tseng]: This motion is not a proposal that was put out in the first place by either side of this argument, but I think it's

[Justin Tseng]: As I told people coming into this meeting, I think this meeting is about finding a reasonable compromise.

[Justin Tseng]: And I believe that motion brings us there.

[Justin Tseng]: And I believe very strongly that we should

[Justin Tseng]: take advantage of this opportunity to set a precedent and to ensure that rising tides actually lifts all boats and lifts all boats into the future and that we can hold ourselves to account with that statement as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe that this specific proposal with the MTA cost of living adjustment rates brings us most closest to that idea.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Bears, and thank you for all the feedback, for the public participation, even if we don't see eye to eye with the proposals I put forward on the floor.

[Justin Tseng]: I do think it's really important to clarify some things for the audience watching, and the audience online as well, which I should note, which is just to clarify the proposal, at least that I put forward on the floor, and to really get a better grasp of it.

[Justin Tseng]: So the first thing is,

[Justin Tseng]: My proposal follows the rates of the increases over the years.

[Justin Tseng]: It doesn't follow the amount increase over the years.

[Justin Tseng]: And because the school committee pay starts at a lower amount, this is actually a smaller total amount than what we would see for the average teacher.

[Justin Tseng]: But this is the same percentage rate.

[Justin Tseng]: And I keep hearing

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, maybe it's not about this proposal, but the percentage change figures of things in the hundreds, which is not true.

[Justin Tseng]: This proposal that I put forward is a 2.48% annual increase, or a percentage annual increase, which I've heard 3% be standard for some unions.

[Justin Tseng]: I've heard other percentages.

[Justin Tseng]: This is the MTA, what's standard for the MTA over that period of time, which tracks very,

[Justin Tseng]: closely to inflation.

[Justin Tseng]: I also took a second to calculate the actual dollar impact of this proposal as well by fiscal 2026.

[Justin Tseng]: And so in fiscal 26, the proposal I've laid on the floor will cost taxpayers $35,472.40, which is not that much.

[Justin Tseng]: And to be completely clear, we can't fill empty positions at that rate.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we should be careful of false equivalencies we're taking.

[Justin Tseng]: from some people and giving to others because that's number one, not how the budget works.

[Justin Tseng]: And number two, we're talking about $35,472.40.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think the conversations that we're having tonight that we've had over the last month really underscores a bigger question of underfunding in the terms of millions.

[Justin Tseng]: not thousands of dollars or thousand dollars.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to have a conversation about business districts and about

[Justin Tseng]: ballot measures and about zoning, right?

[Justin Tseng]: We need to have a conversation about those things.

[Justin Tseng]: For example, the council recently passed, or the last council passed at the end of the year, a Medford Square ordinance change that would redevelop Medford Square and bring business and investment money in, right?

[Justin Tseng]: That's stuff over the longer term that we can use for our schools.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's also really important to note that we also can't legally break a contract to give a raise as much as I personally would want to.

[Justin Tseng]: And sadly, $35,000 probably doesn't split great over the amount of staff that we have.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, you know, to the point that about the living wage.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the living wage is an ideal, and I want to be very clear that neither the proposal I've laid out on the floor or the proposal that Councilor Collins has on the floor would make this job necessarily a living wage.

[Justin Tseng]: It would just make it more justifiable to take.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think it's important to clarify all those points as well.

[Justin Tseng]: particularly sympathetic towards, that of the paraprofessionals.

[Justin Tseng]: I have the paraprofessional salary chart

[Justin Tseng]: in front of me.

[Justin Tseng]: And they're being mispaid.

[Justin Tseng]: um, for for kindergarten needs, which is again definitely way too low.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's they're saying Councilor living.

[Justin Tseng]: Really, I think

[Justin Tseng]: taking this time, this precious time that Medford has, where we have so much potential and where so much is moving and changing in the greater Boston area right now, to take advantage of that and to bring our city into the 21st century.

[Justin Tseng]: To do this, I think it's not blind to our residents that there's a lot of work that we need to catch up on, a lot of big projects that we can be taking on, a lot of projects that we can convince people to take on.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think, and I know that a lot of us, a lot of, if not all of us were elected on platforms to tackle affordability in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: This, another kind of maxim that I always say, specifically when it comes to the housing crisis, is that inaction has been so pervasive for such a long time that we now need to use all the tools in the toolbox, or at least consider all the tools in the toolbox.

[Justin Tseng]: And with the state giving us a local option, we should be proactive in exercising our local rights.

[Justin Tseng]: I also think, and the economic data supports this, that incentives can be a very useful economic tool to incentivize

[Justin Tseng]: better behavior.

[Justin Tseng]: lower rents, hopefully, at the margins, and help those in our community who happen to be in those situations.
