[Justin Tseng]: I think you know that.

[Justin Tseng]: I think a lot's been said about your honor and grace.

[Justin Tseng]: I remember when before I even thought about running for office when there was so much going on with the pandemic and with Black Lives Matter.

[Justin Tseng]: I remember watching all those very contentious city council meetings and I didn't know you at the time but I was like huh this like Nicole Morell person gets where I'm coming from like what my experience growing up in Medford was and

[Justin Tseng]: You know, I think like it surprised me so much because it's just so rare for people like me to see your views being represented and your perspective being considered, especially by people who didn't come from the same background as me.

[Justin Tseng]: And it was just, I think, so cool.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think

[Justin Tseng]: Beyond just honor and grace, for me, it was seeing you stay true to your convictions as well, even when the conversations were heated and difficult and when it would be easier to back out.

[Justin Tseng]: As George has mentioned, you've always stayed in the fight and you've led with your convictions as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think you've shown us that you can lead with your convictions and also build civility and unity and harmony here.

[Justin Tseng]: behind the rail.

[Justin Tseng]: And I, you know, it's not an easy job when I wouldn't want it.

[Justin Tseng]: But and you've had to stand up here through some really difficult meetings.

[Justin Tseng]: But the grace, the kind of the poise that you've led with is something that I think people at home, especially girls and young mothers at home, really look at politics and see that you can do a good job even when it gets tough.

[Justin Tseng]: and can really be inspired by.

[Justin Tseng]: You also, I think, have laid out a path for our city and for progressives especially, that shows us that you can have a progressive vision that's tailored to our local needs and addressing what we need street by street.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that kind of attitude has really been leading the city council in the last few years.

[Justin Tseng]: And Kit talked a lot about the achievements of this council from zoning to all the ordinances to

[Justin Tseng]: a lot of projects that were kickstarting.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's a testament to you that, to your leadership that, you know, we have been able to really pursue progressive change in a way that touches people personally.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's furthermore, another testament upon you that candidates are running and I'm looking forward to carrying a lot of the ideas that you set in place in the first, in your four years here on City Council.

[Justin Tseng]: I think beyond that, I'm going to miss just having a friend to look up to.

[Justin Tseng]: um literally look up to um i think it it's always nice to talk to you when things get heated because i think i can i can trust you to have a rational viewpoint of things and i i can trust you to make a millennial joke that i don't 100% get and i can i can trust you that we'll have we'll banter around about millennial and gen z slang and

[Justin Tseng]: You know, it's just like those funny moments that take you out of the heat and out of the seriousness and make all of us sing.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know this will not be the end.

[Justin Tseng]: I know you're gonna stay involved.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm looking forward to the days when you're back here.

[Justin Tseng]: And if you're not back here in the council chambers, I'm looking forward to being at Jackson on vacation this May.

[Justin Tseng]: I know many of you all taught me just a few years ago.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm sure you'll know that I'm a fan of nuance, but that not everyone's a fan of nuance.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I just wanted to preface my remarks with that.

[Justin Tseng]: I do actually agree with the principles of this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: I think in execution, we need to tailor it.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to improve it.

[Justin Tseng]: But I do appreciate that President Morell has

[Justin Tseng]: put out a proposal to address a problem that we have in our city, a can that's been kicked down the road since the year I was born.

[Justin Tseng]: And I understand how politically difficult it is for the president to introduce this motion and to take so much flack on it.

[Justin Tseng]: It's never easy to discuss the salaries of elected officials.

[Justin Tseng]: And whether you agree or disagree with it,

[Justin Tseng]: we were always bound to have this conversation at some point, and so I do have to give President Morell props for having the courage to bring this out.

[Justin Tseng]: I also need to note that procedurally, I've heard a lot about, you know, why haven't you talked to other members of the council or other members of the school committee about it?

[Justin Tseng]: We do have

[Justin Tseng]: laws that govern how we introduce ideas, and the most transparent way to introduce an idea is to put it on the City Council agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: It doesn't mean it's going to be passed tonight and it's an ordinance, so it would require three readings anyways.

[Justin Tseng]: But usually it's the most transparent approach because we can hear from you, we can hear whether you agree or disagree, we can send it to subcommittee and work on it even more.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's procedurally how it usually works.

[Justin Tseng]: I did say I support the principles of this, especially given the fact that school committees being paid a wage or a salary that few in the private sector would ever pay for any job, really.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm sympathetic to the argument that school committees and schools in general are seen as female institutions and treated accordingly.

[Justin Tseng]: And in other words, there's societal expectations to lower pay outcomes.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is really what the crux of the gender pay gap is.

[Justin Tseng]: I will say my first reaction to this resolution was, why is the school committee being paid the same as city council?

[Justin Tseng]: But I had to reconsider why I even asked that question in the first place, especially given what we know as people who engage with the law, that school committee exercises, you know, city council exercises purview over city hall, which is about

[Justin Tseng]: two-thirds of the budget, and the school committee exercises authority over one-third of the city budget.

[Justin Tseng]: And in addition, state law does give the school committees many more powers and authorities that we don't have as a city council.

[Justin Tseng]: I do know from personal experience, whether you like the job that they're doing or you dislike the job that they're doing, they do spend a lot of hours on their job.

[Justin Tseng]: I think in addition to that, as a young person, as a person of color, and as a recent student of social sciences, I know from both my personal experience and from the numerous studies from top researchers that better pay for public officials does increase the quality, diversity, and experience of candidates who run for public office.

[Justin Tseng]: Too often, low pay doesn't justify the time that we spend being public officials, and the negativity and hostility of politics in recent years only exacerbates that problem.

[Justin Tseng]: Those, you know, we can, I do agree in principle that people running for office should run out of service.

[Justin Tseng]: And I, you know, everyone who runs does run out of service, but we can't ignore the economic reality that for people who aren't as economically well off, like students or people of color, we can't just take time out of our days to do political stuff like this instead of working another part-time job.

[Justin Tseng]: It's just, it's just economic reality.

[Justin Tseng]: We, you know, there are experienced folks who can't justify taking on higher paying projects and research after research shows that government that pays better moves more efficiently.

[Justin Tseng]: I hear a lot, and I totally agree with teachers generally, about wanting more young people to run for office, because we have more, especially for school community, because we have more recent experience at the schools.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's a reason why I ran for this office in the first place, because the schools, I believe, should be the number one budget issue.

[Justin Tseng]: And in the last few budgets, I've sat down with the mayor to negotiate millions more for our schools, successfully.

[Justin Tseng]: It's been the number one conversation when I walked into the office.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, okay, that being said, I am sympathetic to all the ideas in opposition to this.

[Justin Tseng]: I've spent a good amount of time these last few days talking to teachers, and I agree in principle that the school committee should pay, should reflect pay increases that teachers get.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, we should also keep in mind that the committee hasn't had an increase since 2000, and using a salary calculator, if we compare the percentage increases, this proposal is somewhere in the ballpark of

[Justin Tseng]: where that pay has grown in the last 25 years.

[Justin Tseng]: But, you know, that's all details.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we need to have, again, nuance matters.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we need to have a conversation about what that looks like.

[Justin Tseng]: We should also keep in mind that we do face large structural challenges when it comes to problems in the city and in our schools.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's obvious to everyone who goes into the schools, and I have been into the schools.

[Justin Tseng]: But we have to consider amounts, and we have to consider percentages.

[Justin Tseng]: This proposal takes up

[Justin Tseng]: 0.05% of the city budget, and we have $25 million in free cash that we keep pressuring the mayor to use and spend, and she has.

[Justin Tseng]: She has spent that.

[Justin Tseng]: We've talked to the CFO about this, and the money does exist for it without pulling out of the budget for schools.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the logical trap here isn't that this isn't an either or situation, it's a yes and.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this brings me to maybe the most pressing point for me, why I would be amenable to an idea like this.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's not really any of the reasons listed in the whereas section of this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: It's because I'm a strong believer that government should push ourselves to make better decisions in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: make decisions now that put us in tougher positions in the future, that force our hand and make us, that force us to make better decisions.

[Justin Tseng]: I think when we send this to committee, I think we can craft a good deal that's better in execution, but also pushes us in a political direction where we have to accept demands for better for our teachers in Paris.

[Justin Tseng]: It's a little bit different thinking.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not a reason I've heard online or from anyone in the last few days.

[Justin Tseng]: But that's how I see the political picture of this, is this forces the city government to be more accountable to our teachers and paraprofessionals.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, again, considering all these principles makes me sympathetic to this resolution, but I do think that there can be tinkering done in committee, and that's why I'm particularly grateful.

[Justin Tseng]: that President Morell amended her paper before introducing it to us.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it would be especially reasonable to discuss changes in timing or phasing in, even though, again, the money that we need to solve large structural challenges citywide in our schools far exceeds the amount that's proposed.

[Justin Tseng]: Do you think it would be prudent to phase this in as we get more information about the greater financial picture with the FY25 budget and with the new budget ordinance that we're

[Justin Tseng]: intent on passing soon.

[Justin Tseng]: That way, we can make sure that this is additive and not subtractive.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, you know, I already discussed it a little bit, but I just wanted to reiterate I know many of you will be disappointed with my, you know, when I vote to move this into subcommittee of the whole.

[Justin Tseng]: But my whole take on this is I wouldn't, ultimately, I won't vote for this if it does detract from the students, right?

[Justin Tseng]: I think we all agree on that value.

[Justin Tseng]: Everyone behind this rail agrees on that value, but only by moving into subcommittee can we have those meetings and conversations with financial folks to give us that better picture.

[Justin Tseng]: We also, as Councilor Collins alluded to it,

[Justin Tseng]: have to consider the different magnitudes of this proposal versus the actual needs for our schools, which I completely agree.

[Justin Tseng]: And I do agree that, you know, with huge raises for teachers in Paris.

[Justin Tseng]: I really do.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'll stand by you with that.

[Justin Tseng]: Before this meeting, I encouraged it.

[Justin Tseng]: I encouraged you guys to push for more future negotiations.

[Justin Tseng]: But again, we can't have these conversations without moving forward on this.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I know again, a lot of you will be disappointed.

[Justin Tseng]: I hope that

[Justin Tseng]: you guys will call me, email me, that we can have a conversation about this.

[Justin Tseng]: I know a lot of you know me personally, and a lot of you have friends who taught me as well, and I really encourage more conversation about this, and it'll help inform my views on this going forward, what a compromise looks like, because I think we can broker a better compromise, and that's really my priority.

[Justin Tseng]: So please reach out, please talk to me, and we'll have an open discussion about it.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll be super brief, but I wanted to thank you for coming and sharing all these concerns.

[Justin Tseng]: Like what Councilor Collins said, this is a top priority for us going on into the next term.

[Justin Tseng]: And we have the whole zoning reform process going on, phase two of that.

[Justin Tseng]: And we'll be looking at a lot of policy ideas that might touch it.

[Justin Tseng]: I would, again, encourage you to stay in contact.

[Justin Tseng]: Please let us know.

[Justin Tseng]: what's going on in their neighborhood as well, and we'll try our best to refer to the code enforcement officers in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: And if there's anything policy-wise, any ideas that you might have, feel free to reach out to us as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to keep it simple and reiterate how grateful I am for all the work that you guys and Emily has been doing for our city.

[Justin Tseng]: We know it's not been easy to work with the state government when it comes to getting the details about how we can be in compliance with the MTA Communities Act.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think this solution is something for people in Wellington to be very excited about, for residents of our city to be very excited about.

[Justin Tseng]: I know there's some excited chatter about potentially having more commercial or more people in the area, making it more walkable and bringing our attention to the walkability of the area as well, forcing us again into action.

[Justin Tseng]: And I just wanted to thank you for your hard work on this.

[Justin Tseng]: Present.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we're lucky that we have two very solid proposals in front of us today.

[Justin Tseng]: I think like all of what my colleagues have said, the NSRFP speaks to me, especially in that, what Councilor Baer said, we have experience working with this group of people, with the staff that they're offering us.

[Justin Tseng]: There's, you know, when we look to all these plans that we have right now, the comprehensive plan, the climate plan, everything, you know, we on when we and when we look at the RFP, we can see that there's overlap there, which I think is really invaluable.

[Justin Tseng]: It means that we're bringing that expertise on all the public engagement in that process on to and carrying it over to ours rezoning project.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, as Councilor Collins acknowledged, there are a lot of Massachusetts-specific projects in this RFP, which I think is very notable.

[Justin Tseng]: And there are projects like the Helping a Bunch of Municipalities Come in Compliance with the MBTA Communities Act, which I think shows a familiarity with our state's regulations and laws when it comes to

[Justin Tseng]: when it comes to zoning and what we can do.

[Justin Tseng]: I think something, a small note that I found pretty helpful here is there in this RFP they mention proposed like

[Justin Tseng]: The possibility of giving city councilors like us recommended training for best practices to engage with the community, giving us a lot of tools to engage residents.

[Justin Tseng]: It's just something that I think would be really interesting in the zoning process, which is pretty unique in the NSRFP as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And just, I could be wrong, but when we just count out the number of meetings, there seems to be just slightly more opportunities for our city council to engage with NSS group as well, which I think is invaluable time.

[Justin Tseng]: I'd be interested to hear what Alicia, what Director Hunt has to say, but I feel pretty good about this proposal.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I also just wanted to thank you, Commissioner McGivern, for coming and providing clarity on a lot of these issues.

[Justin Tseng]: I think as we see from the questions and the conversation tonight, you know, once it's, you know, these questions come up every few months, but once you wait, it gets pretty deep.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's helpful to have this kind of

[Justin Tseng]: this forum where we can answer those questions, but also see how those questions link into other questions about our capacities, our resources, our vision.

[Justin Tseng]: you know, trying to put out more information.

[Justin Tseng]: you know, that's it's something that we worked so hard on.

[Justin Tseng]: I found them in order and moved to approve.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Motion to waive the reading in favor of summary.

[Justin Tseng]: I, there was a point in here about sidewalks.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to make sure that when we redo the sidewalks that we're doing them with concrete and not asphalt, I see.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: I think what's been said here really encapsulates what what went wrong process really does matter.

[Justin Tseng]: Um I think we all agree that the results wouldn't have changed, but the process really doesn't matter.

[Justin Tseng]: And Councilor

[Justin Tseng]: Scarpelli is absolutely right when he says that perception is reality.

[Justin Tseng]: We know that this is a really difficult time for democracy in our country.

[Justin Tseng]: We know that there's a lot of questions about elections.

[Justin Tseng]: And we know that we need to build trust in our election system.

[Justin Tseng]: And that trust, it's not just about trusting the election system.

[Justin Tseng]: It's about having unimpeachable trust in the election system.

[Justin Tseng]: Elections are the holiest part of our democracy.

[Justin Tseng]: And our democracy is a sacred system in itself.

[Justin Tseng]: And we need to really we need to defend it.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to make sure the process works.

[Justin Tseng]: I, we, you know, we, the other Councilors have really, I think, well enumerated the number of issues that we saw before election day and on election day.

[Justin Tseng]: And we gave, and before this election as well, we gave the administration a fair chance to fix their mistakes.

[Justin Tseng]: We passed resolutions.

[Justin Tseng]: We demanded scrutiny.

[Justin Tseng]: We went through those items line by line.

[Justin Tseng]: We got assurances that they would be fixed for future elections.

[Justin Tseng]: And we see what the product is today.

[Justin Tseng]: We need...

[Justin Tseng]: We need not only to know why what went wrong went wrong.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to know what accountability looks like.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to demand that accountability as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's good that we've had safeguards in our system to fall back on, like the barcodes that guarantee that each person only has one vote.

[Justin Tseng]: But we shouldn't have to rely on our safeguards to have faith in our system.

[Justin Tseng]: We should have faith just because the process has done well.

[Justin Tseng]: and so there's not much I can add on to what's been said because I think what's been said encapsulates pretty well what we need to fix, the accountability we need to demand, but I just wanted to put my thoughts and statements on the record as well.

[Justin Tseng]: just more, this is more of a detail, but I would like to see what, if there is a report that comes out of this, I would like to see analysis of the low staffing levels, the funding problem, very specific about those questions.

[Justin Tseng]: I would also like to see, I believe that we had talked about, or the mayor's administration has decided that we would rely on some seasonal

[Justin Tseng]: more seasonal employment of employees.

[Justin Tseng]: And we talked at length back then when we were reviewing the budget about how we needed full-time staff for that department.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'd like to see reference to that in the report.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes, please.

[Justin Tseng]: Motion to waive the reading of paper summary.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I wanted to thank you guys for your work on this as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I know it's really difficult working within the parameters of a state mandate that keeps changing, um, and to get us product before the deadline, I think is an achievement that we should acknowledge.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I, I think there's, there'll be some time for people to comment on this and for adjustments to be made.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think we understand the council understands our tasks tonight, um, and what our vote means and the way that

[Justin Tseng]: in my opinion it should go.

[Justin Tseng]: But I also wanted to say as a resident or as a former resident of Wellington, I am excited to see more action happening there.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that we've had

[Justin Tseng]: a lot of conversations about safety and walkability there.

[Justin Tseng]: And a more comprehensive plan like this with more incentives built into it creates, I think, an ideal vision, a more ideal vision in that sense.

[Justin Tseng]: Maybe we make some tweaks, but a more ideal version of what we have that creates a safer neighborhood by making it more walkable and more to incentivize attention to that behavior.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm really grateful for your work on this.

[Justin Tseng]: I know there have been folks writing me about reducing parking minimums even more given the proximity to the station.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's something worthy of being talked about.

[Justin Tseng]: But in any case, we'll get into the details with the CD board and with what they recommend, but I'm just very grateful for your work.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Collins, for initiating this, and thank you to my fellow co-sponsors on this.

[Justin Tseng]: This is something that is really important to me personally, as someone who's grown up with a lot of transgender friends who've been bullied and attacked on the streets, not in Medford, but in general.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, it's important, I think, to really shed light, bring attention to this, because everyone deserves to live in dignity.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's also particularly important to acknowledge the intersectionality of transgender violence in our country as well, especially the higher rates at which Black transgender folks and Indigenous transgender folks face violence and bigotry in public.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I'm really grateful for the Council for taking this up.

[Justin Tseng]: And there's still so much more work to do, but I'm very proud to be a co-sponsor of this one.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to send my deepest condolences and sympathies to his family.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm grateful for Councilor Scarpelli for introducing this.

[Justin Tseng]: I was one of his students and I've been reflecting over the weekend about that year in chemistry and how much fun it was.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's something that will stay in my NHS experience forever when I think about my time there.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, Mr. Lazzaro would tell, he would tell so many stories, and he was so proud of his family.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, in every story that he told, there was wisdom.

[Justin Tseng]: There was, you know, these nuggets of wisdom that we really valued.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, we laughed about the stories, but we also talk about, you know, what we learned from those stories in his life.

[Justin Tseng]: He also had the funniest, the wittiest one-liners and comebacks.

[Justin Tseng]: So funny, in fact, and actually so wise, in fact, that we started this Google Doc of quotes of what he would say as a teacher.

[Justin Tseng]: And this doc became so legendary that I checked it yesterday, and people were still adding to it last year.

[Justin Tseng]: And I had the opportunity to stop by his wake before this and to talk to Kay and the rest of his family.

[Justin Tseng]: And we joked around a little bit about the document and about his wit.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's something that I felt like will be part of his students forever, that experience.

[Justin Tseng]: We really did love him, and I'll miss him really well.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll be quick.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, as a, as a high grad, I am so ready for this match.

[Justin Tseng]: Uh, I'm just so ready for it.

[Justin Tseng]: I, I, I, you know what?

[Justin Tseng]: I, you, you mentioned the record this year, but every time I go on Twitter and I see, um, uh, MHS athletics tweet out the results of how our, how our kids are doing.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, it just makes me so proud to be from this community.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we talk a lot, we're always proud of you all and proud of your kids and the service they give back to the community.

[Justin Tseng]: But, you know, we're always talking about what we can do to make, you know, make people more proud of Medford, make people more united in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: And as you said it, as my fellow councillors have said it,

[Justin Tseng]: You know, our football team is really, really shining the way right now.

[Justin Tseng]: And just wanted to give you my thanks, my support, and go Mustangs.

[Justin Tseng]: On a slightly different topic, but going back to what was mentioned, I know folks here mentioned the meals tax, the local meals tax.

[Justin Tseng]: In looking at the Massachusetts state government website on meals taxes, it does seem like food trucks are included or local excise taxes on meals are included in what food trucks should be paying.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's something that we should confirm.

[Justin Tseng]: But that's what I read from these documents, from the Massachusetts state government website and the Harvard Law School think tank document on food trucks in the greater Boston area.

[Justin Tseng]: I would be open to asking for language about that in this ordinance or in the regulations, just to make that clear.

[Justin Tseng]: Great.

[Justin Tseng]: Present.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Henry and Evelyn,

[Justin Tseng]: I was Councilor various that we all know for their dedication and care for Medford for our residents for the goings on of our city.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's, I think, just in general there's just so much to talk about with their dedication to Medford and to our residents but

[Justin Tseng]: you know, every time I learn something new about Henry, it's truly inspiring that level of care that he's willing to give to people around him.

[Justin Tseng]: And to see that, you know, this, I think they're, you know, I'm just so happy that they're being honored for their work.

[Justin Tseng]: especially with improving the lives of those with intellectual and developmental disabilities, because I think it's a realm that needs so much care.

[Justin Tseng]: It needs so much attention.

[Justin Tseng]: And just to know that someone like Henry and Evelyn, to know that people like them are there, I think, makes me feel better about this world.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm very grateful that Vice President Bears has put this on the agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: I think a year ago, I put on the agenda something about cut-throughs

[Justin Tseng]: perpendicular to Willis, between Main and Mystic.

[Justin Tseng]: This is something that I think folks, neighbors in the area talked about for a while, something that came up, that's always come up on Doorknocking in the area, and something that I've also talked to Director Blake about as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I know he's working hard on it, but there needs to be more action being taken.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'm very grateful.

[Justin Tseng]: to my fellow Councilor for putting this on the agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: I was in the neighborhood recently and it was just so hard even to cross the neighborhood street because cars were driving by so quickly.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's just for families in the area with kids, that's just not safe at all.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I'd really want us to see the city do something about it.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm grateful to the Councilor for kind of pushing this forward again, putting this back on the agenda again.

[Justin Tseng]: I never got the chance to meet Boddy, but...

[Justin Tseng]: when you, I think, look through City Hall, when you look at what's the hard work being achieved here, a lot of it is built on the backs of the greats who came before.

[Justin Tseng]: And someone like Dottie, whose work has meant so much to Medford and really has pushed our city forward, I think it's an honor to be able to recognize her, even if I didn't get to know her personally, to know her through all of you all.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Caravallo and Councilor Scarcelli for putting this on the agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: It's also really great to get two Italian Americans to be able to put this on the agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: I said this last year, but one of the most interesting experiences for me going to college was that I realized that not everyone had the chance to learn Italian in school.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, unfortunate.

[Justin Tseng]: And we're really fortunate to have that in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: And I do think that makes us really unique and our history really unique.

[Justin Tseng]: And I, you know, I think there's so many ways, as a son of immigrants, I know how important it is to celebrate your heritage.

[Justin Tseng]: And there's so many ways to celebrate Italian American heritage here that we really can

[Justin Tseng]: do more to embrace that.

[Justin Tseng]: I know Councilor Knight has said time and time again, creating a zone in South Medford where we can capture that heritage and maybe even take advantage of state grants and funds for that.

[Justin Tseng]: When I went to San Diego,

[Justin Tseng]: There's the little Italy over there does a great job in terms of honoring its Italian American residents, there's such a rich history there so many so much work that telling Americans have put into shape our community.

[Justin Tseng]: The way it is today and.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think this is something that came across a few years ago when this was a hot button issue.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we really need to do more to acknowledge the fact that it was a really difficult time for Italian-Americans who came here.

[Justin Tseng]: They did face a lot of discrimination.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we can do more to celebrate the triumph of Italian-Americans and face that discrimination as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I'd be very happy to support, you know, a flag raising or some ceremony festival here.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm really happy to see that we were able to get the Italian festival here in Medford this year.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, I think this is one of the ways that we can bring our community back together.

[Justin Tseng]: Well, I'll make that motion after it's taken up.

[Justin Tseng]: On the motion of Councilor Tseng to take 23-433 out of order, seconded by... Second.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, thank you for presenting today.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you for coming to us with the with this project.

[Justin Tseng]: rather a project that's the beginning of a bigger project, which I'm very happy with.

[Justin Tseng]: like timings in Medford and getting that to match our traffic patterns better.

[Justin Tseng]: because we knew that projects like this were going to come in.

[Justin Tseng]: And because of those, because of our actions as a council, because of community members, we have pretty regular bus access coming in to connect this property with Malden Square, Malden Center Station, with Sullivan Square Station.

[Justin Tseng]: Hopefully with the shuttle, we'll have it better connected to the Green Line as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's really important to mention.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm the son of life scientists.

[Justin Tseng]: And I can definitely back up the statement that most life scientists are especially environmentally aware, and they want to really make an effort to drive less.

[Justin Tseng]: It's something that we don't only see in Cambridge, it's something that we see as in general with life scientists, even across the country.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I, you know, I, I

[Justin Tseng]: like that part of this project.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that makes sense.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's sensible.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think, if anything, we should be spurring and pushing our workers in Medford to be taking public transit and to be biking.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think the only way we can do that is to make it easier to really incentivize that behavior.

[Justin Tseng]: I was going to mention one last thing.

[Justin Tseng]: It's slipping my mind.

[Justin Tseng]: We want Medford to be put on the map.

[Justin Tseng]: if that's to be the case.

[Justin Tseng]: we're in a difficult situation right now with our long term finances, and we need to embrace

[Justin Tseng]: amendments that we can discuss as a council.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'm totally in agreement.

[Justin Tseng]: I'd like to second it.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: I hear my fellow councilors points, and I think honestly, I agree with most everything that's been said tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: I totally agree that we need development in other parts of the city as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I agree that we can't be privileging one part of the city above another, and that we need comprehensive plans to tie the whole city together.

[Justin Tseng]: I also want to acknowledge that we do have a comprehensive plan in the city that many, many, and by many, I mean hundreds, if not thousands of people gave feedback on.

[Justin Tseng]: We've had time to review those plans, to give feedback as councillors, as members of the public.

[Justin Tseng]: I also have had time to read those plans, to read the different press releases that I've come from the mayor's office and from the planning office about these plots, these lots and what we're gonna do with them.

[Justin Tseng]: And I've had that time to talk to Director Hunt, to talk to Victoria Storrs about what the city is envisioning for these plots.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think Councilor Bears more or less has said it, but,

[Justin Tseng]: what we're hearing from the business community, from folks who would want to come to Medford, what we're hearing from people who work in housing and from people who work in planning and development is that Medford Square needs a jolt.

[Justin Tseng]: And we need more housing to grow our consumer base.

[Justin Tseng]: We need better traffic patterns.

[Justin Tseng]: We need better infrastructure, and especially when it comes to water and sewer, which the DIF allows for that investment.

[Justin Tseng]: And we can't just assume that private developers will come to Medford Square and be willing to invest that much in changing Medford for their own ends.

[Justin Tseng]: That's not something we've seen anywhere else.

[Justin Tseng]: It's just not cost effective for them.

[Justin Tseng]: When it comes to the, you know, the idea that we might be privileging one part of the city I think I took this very to heart, especially since, you know, so much of my first campaign running for this was for city council is about making sure that you know we build a city that's working for everyone across our neighborhoods.

[Justin Tseng]: And when I think about it, I think one important thing to realize is the potential for us to increase the pie, increase the coffers when it comes to our city revenue.

[Justin Tseng]: And as Councilor Collins has referred to, I don't think it's lost on anyone that certain neighborhoods have especially strong high needs for better streets, for more social services, for more trees.

[Justin Tseng]: The big question is where that money is going to come from.

[Justin Tseng]: And this tool gives us the potential to grow that pie, to grow revenue, to create that new growth that we all keep talking about, to invest in those services and to invest in that infrastructure.

[Justin Tseng]: It's also, I think, a reinvestment in a central neighborhood in the city that

[Justin Tseng]: really binds all of Medford together.

[Justin Tseng]: To get from any part of Medford to another, this is one of the neighborhoods that you're more likely to pass by.

[Justin Tseng]: If I'm going from South Medford to North Medford, if I'm going from Wellington to West Medford, this is the heart of our city.

[Justin Tseng]: to reinvest, to revitalize this neighborhood, I think is a strategic choice to revitalize something that I think we can all benefit from no matter what neighborhood we live in.

[Justin Tseng]: I think another plus I see to the DIF is this idea of democratizing development and to give

[Justin Tseng]: the budget.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think it's going to give us as a city council more say, um and more scrutiny when it comes to how the city and the mayor spending the budget.

[Justin Tseng]: Um you know any I think an important fact to state is that any spending from the deaths, um, from the funds has to be appropriated each year by the city

[Justin Tseng]: We don't necessarily have that level of scrutiny, but by adopting the DIFs, that would give us that ability to have that level of transparency, to have that level of democracy, to have those discussions about how we're spending our money.

[Justin Tseng]: Each year, we can also have a recommendation.

[Justin Tseng]: to sweep the unused funds from the debt funds, the unspent funds, back into the general fund, which I think should allay some of our fears as well.

[Justin Tseng]: At the end of the day, I think it's important to

[Justin Tseng]: to reiterate Councilor Baer's point that this is an experiment.

[Justin Tseng]: This is us trying to provide that impetus, that stimulus to revitalize Medford Square, the thing that we haven't seen so far in Medford Square.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we can disagree as to where that impetus is gonna come from.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's totally fair.

[Justin Tseng]: This is a tool that I'm willing to try.

[Justin Tseng]: And if it doesn't work,

[Justin Tseng]: I think we can all be mature enough to admit our faults and to admit that it's not working.

[Justin Tseng]: And as Ms.

[Justin Tseng]: Storrs said, it's easy to reverse this decision.

[Justin Tseng]: But I also have optimism that this tool is something that can help our city grow.

[Justin Tseng]: I would just like to echo the same sentiments as Councilor Caravielloville.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that this is the ordinance that we passed on short-term rentals is one of the most meaningful things that this council has done.

[Justin Tseng]: It's something that I think many people here had a personal involvement in, particularly Councilor Bears in crafting.

[Justin Tseng]: And it is something that I think we really should be enforcing.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think there's things that have been coming across our desks as a city council in the last few weeks that have really emphasized the need for our city to invest in enforcement.

[Justin Tseng]: Because we have good laws in place, we need to make sure that they're carried out.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's really important to note the distortionary effect that short-term rentals has on housing affordability and rents, both in terms of property values and in terms of rental prices in neighborhoods.

[Justin Tseng]: The National Bureau of Economic Research has been pretty unequivocal in

[Justin Tseng]: in what it's saying in the economic analyses with how this hurts regular working folks like residents of Medford, like people who are renting in our community, and people who want to buy property in our community, who want to stay in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think it's really important.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the proposed solutions from Councilor Bears, I think, would be a very important first step in making sure that we're patching up those holes.

[Justin Tseng]: working in the spirit of cooperation to make our city better.

[Justin Tseng]: They'll come in once for inspection and a second time to treat.

[Justin Tseng]: The rat trap boxes that they have in Malden and Somerville, she said that that was maybe an option.

[Justin Tseng]: And ones with locks are just much stronger than ones without.

[Justin Tseng]: Thanks.

[Justin Tseng]: And another quick point I think should be made, and this might be beating a dead drum, but there are good ideas out there that are being tested and implemented, even in municipalities around us, like Councilor Scarpelli said.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of it just requires money and resources, and we need to figure out how we're gonna fund all these programs.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, that's the perennial challenge of our city.

[Justin Tseng]: We have a lot facing us in the next budget season, and we need a concrete plan to do that.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: I want to thank Councilor Collins for introducing this with me, and also thank school committee member Melanie McLaughlin for giving us for helping us with this liaising and with giving us the idea for it.

[Justin Tseng]: It's so important to make sure that all members of our community are not only seen but celebrated.

[Justin Tseng]: I think for too long, folks with disabilities who lived in Medford haven't always felt like part of the community, and folks who have disabilities might have felt that.

[Justin Tseng]: even felt that they couldn't completely be themselves in public or they had to hide something.

[Justin Tseng]: And, or even that disability was something to be shameful about.

[Justin Tseng]: And we know that's not true.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's really important for all of us to take a forceful stand to let people be proud of who they are.

[Justin Tseng]: And even if that means, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: Changing how we work at City Hall, if that means taking a deep look at our policies, if that means making sure that things are ADA compliant in Medford, those are really important steps that we need to take.

[Justin Tseng]: And Disability Pride Month gives us a chance for us to talk about those needed changes in our community and those needed investments.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'm very happy to introduce this with Councilor Collins and very much looking forward to what we can do in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: to address the needs of all of our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: Thanks, I don't need to repeat what we heard last meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, it's certainly very concerning for the folks who live in that neighborhood.

[Justin Tseng]: I thank Councilor Bears for introducing this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's important to put on record the need, at least that I see, that to redistribute

[Justin Tseng]: truck traffic in the city to find better paths and especially to basically encourage, find ways to encourage trucks to take bigger main roads rather than cutting through residential neighborhoods.

[Justin Tseng]: So be it through maybe a more general conversation on the traffic commission or some task force to develop a policy, policy suggestions.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's a conversation to be had.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I, I totally sympathize with what you're saying.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and agree.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think I it seems like we all agree that the should have been negotiated part of that we should have tried to get something out of it.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, of course, it's, it's easy to

[Justin Tseng]: go on counterfactuals and to think about the what-ifs.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think given the situation right now with the resources that we have right now, it's a temporary solution that I think we understand why it looks like this.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we need to set a goal in the future of making that a place that looks nicer.

[Justin Tseng]: Honestly, I think it'd be ideal to put a few benches there to have that be a more community-based space now instead of being an empty space that doesn't have anything.

[Justin Tseng]: But this is part of why the traffic was redesigned.

[Justin Tseng]: And look, we hold plenty of city events there.

[Justin Tseng]: I normally never park around there.

[Justin Tseng]: I usually am taking the bus and walking around the area and that intersection is lethal.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, it's scary.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's scary to see cars drive down so quickly.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I'm grateful that we've made some changes and interventions to make that place safer,

[Justin Tseng]: especially given the fact that in the last five years, there were 300 car accidents in that area.

[Justin Tseng]: I think with the new interventions, I know they're very controversial.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that there are tons of residents who aren't very happy with what's been put in place.

[Justin Tseng]: But I will say that safety is always, at the end of the day, the most important function of government.

[Justin Tseng]: And this does keep pedestrians safe.

[Justin Tseng]: Just quickly before we adjourn tonight, since we're having a forecasted heat wave the next few days, we just wanted to announce that we will have some cooling centers open for residents over the next few days until July 28th.

[Justin Tseng]: So we have three three cooling sensors announced there's on the Metro Police Department community room, which will be at 100 Main Street that's available 24 hours a day.

[Justin Tseng]: The Medford Senior Center at 101 Riverside have will be open from 8am to 6pm.

[Justin Tseng]: And the Metro Public Library at 111 High Street will be open from 9am to 9pm on the 26th and 27th, which is Wednesday and Thursday, and then it's from 9am to 6pm on Friday on the 28th.

[Justin Tseng]: If you want more information about it, this info is on the city website.

[Justin Tseng]: But I hope everyone stays cool, stays safe.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it speaks to the impact of climate change at the local level when we need to make announcements like this and make measures like this.

[Justin Tseng]: And hopefully this really kicks us into gear with more aggressive climate action and with things like just planting more trees and preventing heat islands in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you for having Councilor Bears and I on this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: a little bit less than two or three days in Wellington a week.

[Justin Tseng]: But

[Justin Tseng]: is promising for our city.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think you made the excellent point that waiting is shooting ourselves in the foot.

[Justin Tseng]: It's been a mistake in the past.

[Justin Tseng]: People expect us to work together.

[Justin Tseng]: They expect the legislative branch to have a role in these things.

[Justin Tseng]: may be unfortunate, but it is impossible to prove, given that there are other businesses open in that in that neighborhood at the same time impossible to prove that oasis is the problem.

[Justin Tseng]: The problem is what you guys are saying, but it's impossible to make that connection.

[Justin Tseng]: And I don't want, as Councilor care of yellow mentioned I because it's impossible to prove that I don't want to be seen as taking a criticism arbitrary decision on this issue.

[Justin Tseng]: It's also we also have to keep in mind that the past, it's possible that because the businesses closes earlier than it needs to.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of folks are congregating outside and doing things outside when if the business was open longer, they would have the ability to do that inside the business, where we have more control over the noise.

[Justin Tseng]: We also have to, I understand the point about revenue that was made.

[Justin Tseng]: In this specific case, there's an opportunity cost with the revenue that applies here with restaurants and businesses.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's not just the taxes that come from meals and liquor sold at Oasis, it's also the taxes that we would get

[Justin Tseng]: from other businesses in South Medford Square thriving.

[Justin Tseng]: And we have to keep that in mind because we keep talking about revenue and the need to find ways to raise revenue, preferably without an override.

[Justin Tseng]: But look, I made a promise to the voters that I would try to find as many ways to raise revenue before we had to do an override.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is unfortunately one of those ways.

[Justin Tseng]: And that speaks to a bigger budget revenue situation that has been long and systemic.

[Justin Tseng]: needs addressing.

[Justin Tseng]: But unfortunately, because of the tough situation that we're in revenue wise, we have to make some tough decisions as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And with regards to the budget, I in the last week, we put out a survey about people's desires for Medford and the budget and over 20% of people did actually bring up the need.

[Justin Tseng]: the thought that businesses in Medford need to thrive.

[Justin Tseng]: And and I understand that that often comes in conflict with quality of living and as Councilor Collins mentioned a lot of our businesses are located very close to our residences.

[Justin Tseng]: I would support some kind of compromise to make sure that the businesses are surviving and that residents are heard.

[Justin Tseng]: And so something like a 90 day review, I think would would be very helpful in that regard, and also calling upon our administration to do more work in that neighborhood to pay attention and to monitor it.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that would be, I think that would be the way to address that.

[Justin Tseng]: look, a lot of people want businesses to be open later as well.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of people stay up late at night, people have different work schedules.

[Justin Tseng]: We have a young and thriving population as well here.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Knight, one moment.

[Justin Tseng]: And so we need to address those needs.

[Justin Tseng]: And look, I go back to the idea of regulate the problems.

[Justin Tseng]: Regulate the problems, it would be unfair and unwise to it seemed, I think it would be unfair and unwise to tear down the whole thing.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we've explained why we voted this way and we are in support of the various compromises that have been offered, right?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll try to keep it brief.

[Justin Tseng]: I actually had written this resolution up a while ago before Commissioner McGivern posted on Facebook a response to a similar question.

[Justin Tseng]: Riverside Avenue is a very heavily trafficked street in our city and I think we all know how awful the state of that road is.

[Justin Tseng]: I spent a lot of time in Wellington visiting my parents, and every time I have to get over there, it's like you're riding a roller coaster.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's not good for anyone.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think a lot of residents in that neighborhood think it's a sign of being overlooked.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's important for us as a city council and as a local government to say, no, every single street is important, every neighborhood is important, and we have a plan for that street.

[Justin Tseng]: And so Tim McGivern did get back to me on this, and he told me that there are plans to resurface that road this season.

[Justin Tseng]: They did a pavement valuation a couple of years ago, and they've been hard at work prioritizing and coordinating work there.

[Justin Tseng]: They've started a crack sealing program, a box out patching program, and more programs.

[Justin Tseng]: And they're, they're going to plan to resurface as much as the budget allows, but part of the problem that we're facing here is that the evaluation that our city received was that we should be spending at least $3.5 million in resurfacing roads every year.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, but for the past in for, um, for many decades, we've only been spending, uh, less than $1 million.

[Justin Tseng]: And so there's a lot of, um, a lot of work that we'll have to do to catch up in terms of our repairs.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, he did ask me to convey to people watching this meeting, um, to ask our state reps to advocate for more chapter 90 funding, which is the primary source

[Justin Tseng]: that we use as municipalities to maintain our roadways and improve our roadways.

[Justin Tseng]: And he did ask that if anyone did have any more specific questions about Riverside Ave to contact him, to email him or to call him.

[Justin Tseng]: He did tell me also that they have put this out to bid.

[Justin Tseng]: And so he's hopeful that this can get done this year.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, so this this resolution comes from talking to a lot of, particularly on Spanish and Creole speaking, I'm residents who find it particularly intimidating to go to City Hall because they find it a little confusing to find which office to go to where to navigate.

[Justin Tseng]: As we keep talking about the beautification of City Hall I think this is something to keep in mind, obviously we can't

[Justin Tseng]: translate into every single language spoken in our community.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think we can make more of an effort as a city to translate to the most commonly spoken languages.

[Justin Tseng]: And just to have the basic, even a basic guide at the door or a small sign to translate the word, which number of room numbers offices are in that would be helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll be extremely brief because I think we've talked about these two items for months now.

[Justin Tseng]: I very much respect my colleagues' ways of seeing this, and I think it's not unreasonable to see it that way.

[Justin Tseng]: But I do think it is a false choice, especially when the mayor's announced that we have $25 million in free cash.

[Justin Tseng]: And look, that's not going to fix all of our problems, but it's a starting point for a conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, we also have to look at the size of the decisions that we're making and as Councilor bears has referred has has talked about, um, it's voting no on these items won't save any particular program voting yes on these items won't kill any particular program.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's a false way of, I think,

[Justin Tseng]: Maybe false is a strong way of putting it, but it's not the way I believe that we should look at this problem.

[Justin Tseng]: Instead, I think we need also a bigger picture lens as well.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to pay attention to employee retention.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to pay attention to

[Justin Tseng]: how much things cost in the long run.

[Justin Tseng]: And if we look at these items, these items speak to those worries and those goals that we have as a city.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that all of us do share the sidewalk bond, you know, part of that is for bringing machinery to the city for us to bring projects in-house.

[Justin Tseng]: And that requires investment, but that investment is going to pay off in the long run with better roads and with cheaper solutions to our infrastructure problems.

[Justin Tseng]: And so for me, it's about making an investment in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: I do respect my colleagues' ways of seeing this, and I think we've hashed it out and we've talked about it for weeks now.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think I'm ready to vote on it.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think it's fairly clear where we all stand on it.

[Justin Tseng]: We've talked about this for probably more meetings than I can count on my hand.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think, um, I think we should move the question.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to first reiterate some points from last year when this came before us.

[Justin Tseng]: Back then, I mentioned a lot of the needs that I saw when I was a student there about five years ago, so not that long ago.

[Justin Tseng]: where a building had flood and their needs in their heating problems and overpasses and a lot of different heat, I mean, even heating problems in their classrooms, sunlight problems and all of that.

[Justin Tseng]: I encourage anyone who's not, who wants to learn more about why this is important to read the application itself.

[Justin Tseng]: You guys have, your team has put together, I think, in very clear language,

[Justin Tseng]: many of the problems that we're seeing in the high school that doesn't match the education that we're providing today.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we're seeing that the physical building doesn't match the quality of the instruction that's in the building.

[Justin Tseng]: And that by improving the physical building itself, we can hopefully bring more pride to Medford and shine a light to the good work that's happening inside the high school.

[Justin Tseng]: And to

[Justin Tseng]: As a student there I know that it can be a very bluntly said drab and depressing environment to study in, and I would want for future students at Medford a happier place and a more encouraging environment to work in, a physical environment to work in.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's important for residents.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, this is an issue that came up on the doorstep time and time again, especially from parents, but even the parents of graduates, of students who've already left Medford High.

[Justin Tseng]: This is, I think, an issue that much of the community can unite around.

[Justin Tseng]: given the importance that everyone sees, there might be different approaches to what we do with the building exactly, but it's really important to take the steps that allow us to have as many options on the table as possible.

[Justin Tseng]: And a yes vote on the council tonight allows that.

[Justin Tseng]: And as we were chatting before this meeting, we mentioned, you know, it's super encouraging that they asked us to reapply.

[Justin Tseng]: It's great to see that there have been even more improvements made to the application this time.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, it's about trying.

[Justin Tseng]: It's about trying whenever we can and keep pushing for it, because we don't know what year it's gonna happen.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I agree with what's being said.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, we last year we asked the city also also to pay attention to cut through traffic.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, we did get a report back.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, but, um, I just wanted to note to the audience to people watching out there that, um, this this is important to us on the council.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and that, um, it's it's in addition to Harvard Street.

[Justin Tseng]: It's also all the other parallel streets that are facing a lot of increased traffic and people were just speeding right right through as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to make sure to speak because this is an issue I'm particularly passionate about.

[Justin Tseng]: I know I wrote a resolution that was supported by my fellow Councilors here asking our city about exploring ways to clarify the plans to train to develop that pipeline and to find new people to join our city.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think the most important point here is what Paul talked about with the lack of resources.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not just school districts but

[Justin Tseng]: Governments all across the country are seeing the importance of having diverse lived experiences and how that ties into good decent public services and how we provide that to our residents and Medford we're not again like Paul said we're not competing with our neighbors.

[Justin Tseng]: We're competing with everyone else and I have a lot of friends from diverse backgrounds who you know have

[Justin Tseng]: have taken well-paying jobs that pay double what they would in the public sector.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's a problem that we need to fix at all levels, from federal, state, and local levels.

[Justin Tseng]: But that brings us back to the need to have an open and honest and transparent discussion about our budget as well.

[Justin Tseng]: But we can also, in the meantime, talk about what we can do to address the little problems that come up and to capture some of the benefits of that lived experience with the resources that we have right now.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I've worked really closely with the diversity director and with the mayor to look at ways that we can expand language access in City Hall and in our city services.

[Justin Tseng]: If we can get more translators in, if we can

[Justin Tseng]: Yes, the diversity director especially has been working really hard to do more in sign language, which is super important.

[Justin Tseng]: And that doesn't make up for the lack of diversity.

[Justin Tseng]: It doesn't make up for the lack of lived experience.

[Justin Tseng]: But it's something that we can do to capture the benefits that we would from lived experience.

[Justin Tseng]: work in terms of reparations last year or two years ago.

[Justin Tseng]: more accountability, the idea that more accountability is better between different arms of government, more transparency is better, giving residents more of an opportunity to participate in the whole budget process in the running of our city, giving them a chance to speak up about what they want to see in our budget,

[Justin Tseng]: and not just to see a budget come back with two or two and a half percent slapped slapped on every department right.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this is this is about getting residents in us involved in giving us more of a balance in our relationship with the city.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's fairly fairly obvious anyone watching the council meetings and

[Justin Tseng]: who's been paying attention to city politics in the last, maybe even decades.

[Justin Tseng]: Sometimes, you know, our relationship with the executive office isn't the most collaborative.

[Justin Tseng]: might be an understatement, but when that relationship isn't as collaborative as we want it to be, I think we also need to take up the steps to build the structure that will force us to collaborate with each other.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think at the end of the day, this is what this resolution is about, about building those structures to have us talk to each other and to force us to have those conversations and to build that forum for residents to participate.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Councilor Bears' last point about, is really important.
