[Justin Tseng]: have more oversight residents are asking us to do X, Y, and Z. How do we have that conversation about what needs to change and what we need to put forward to voters to have that change take place?

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think this is, I'm very much looking forward to this committee of the whole and to the whole process that hopefully happens after it is all.

[Justin Tseng]: I was gonna make the point, but I believe that you were gonna answer something.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: I just, I wanted to get across my way of thinking with this in front of me tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we've discussed a lot about our approach to money papers coming in front of us and generally how we maybe agree to disagree on how we kind of treat these papers.

[Justin Tseng]: For me personally, I am pretty concerned with the state of the sidewalks as is and concerned with quality of life here in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: I, I understand the frustrations that perhaps, you know, with the previous loan order we've only done x, x amount of sidewalks but I would also be very skeptical and you might be able to confirm this I'd be skeptical that cost goes down in the future if we keep holding out and waiting, just because of inflation because of rising costs in general for projects like this.

[Justin Tseng]: And so with, with the problem at hand, you know, it's, it's, if it's not going to be cheaper to solve it over time, it makes sense for me to make the investments now in, in terms of the cost effective, the more cost effective solutions that I think you've been pretty transparent with us that you plan for.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we all kind of we all agree that sidewalks are a priority here.

[Justin Tseng]: It's, I, you know, we disagree on many issues but this is one of one of the many issues I think almost everyone in the city can agree on.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we also agree with the approach that bringing things in-house will be more cost effective.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the evidence is out there.

[Justin Tseng]: And so for me, this is a question of, you know, fiscally, I think it makes more sense in the long run to invest in the resources and the technology we need to bring things in-house.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it sounds like you would agree with that perspective on the issue as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And another kind of way that I think about it is, you know, if we hold out on this, right?

[Justin Tseng]: Well, what are the consequences?

[Justin Tseng]: And it sounded like from previous meetings that because of supply chain issues, and we see this with fire trucks as well, will take a longer time.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not just we put in the order, we get the equipment.

[Justin Tseng]: We have to wait a certain amount of time.

[Justin Tseng]: And we've already been waiting and waiting and waiting.

[Justin Tseng]: The city's been waiting, the residents have been waiting.

[Justin Tseng]: And so for me, it does seem like a matter of urgency and accessibility, right?

[Justin Tseng]: We don't want someone tripping and falling.

[Justin Tseng]: We want people to be able to move around town.

[Justin Tseng]: And if we keep waiting on it, not only is the problem gonna be more expensive to deal with, we're gonna have more people hindered

[Justin Tseng]: in their transportation as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Right, we can't, even though it might be more cost effective to do things in-house, it's unrealistic to assume that, you know, we can just do it overnight.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I'm also, you know, I think, reflecting the sentiment of my colleagues here.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think the idea of a stabilization fund is a great idea.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and certainly we talk about, um, needing to plan ahead fiscally, but, um, to commit to $5 million tonight, you know, that's big money.

[Justin Tseng]: It's a significant sum that we really can't divorce from our conversation about the budget as a whole.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and

[Justin Tseng]: Because it's such a big sum, we need to pay particular attention to open and public community discussion on the issue.

[Justin Tseng]: This was on the agenda, but I think a committee of the whole, for example, especially one that's tied closer to the budget, I think would be a more appropriate form for us to talk about the issue first before we approve it.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think underscores the need for us to serve as a democratic forum for that.

[Justin Tseng]: When we think about the 25 million certified and free cash that was confirmed today.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Collins's sentiment that I think we need to be a little bit more critical when we think of whether it's a good or a bad thing.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, it's nuanced.

[Justin Tseng]: It's certainly good to have a lot of free cash, but we have to keep in mind that there is a cost

[Justin Tseng]: to this as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And we need to talk about the long term investments that we want to make as a city.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to talk about the, I mean, tonight was, I think a prime example of the need to invest in things now before they become cost ineffective in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: And that requires some big picture thinking.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm not saying that we don't fund the stabilization fund and we don't invest this money into it.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm just saying we need a committee of the whole meeting and a comprehensive budget process to talk about this.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't want us to be under the illusion that more money in free cash is always a good thing.

[Justin Tseng]: When we look at what's recommended by DLS, we are above that, actually.

[Justin Tseng]: We are above the upper limit.

[Justin Tseng]: recommended by DLS and I find the finance director may have his own opinion which I think we should value and I would like to hear in that committee the whole meeting if that's the case.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think we also need to look at the needs of the city and what residents are asking us for.

[Justin Tseng]: and taking a more holistic approach to looking at how we do budget, how we do finances and how we approach the stabilization fund.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, I'm not opposed to it.

[Justin Tseng]: I think there's just questions about

[Justin Tseng]: looking at the big picture of it all, how we fund it, and I, in doing research for this, I did see some towns said that they preferred not to put free cash in and they preferred to take the other funding mechanisms that Vice President Bears referred to.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think we need to also have a discussion about why we're choosing this approach rather than those other approaches.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm sure there's a justification for it, but I think we need to have a longer meeting about it and a meeting that's more focused on this.

[Justin Tseng]: Thanks, I was, I just wanted to put on the record that when I see my time I was actually going to ask the same question.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm also, it's fun.

[Justin Tseng]: It happens all the time.

[Justin Tseng]: something along the lines of what you said, we're open to the option of 10 years, you know, we, I would be happy to vote for that.

[Justin Tseng]: It's just that I don't want to give up our oversight power automatically.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: This, the Affordable Housing Trust Fund is something that experts and residents have been working on and clamoring for for a very long time in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: I've, especially in the last few weeks.

[Justin Tseng]: There's been a lot of pressure on us rightfully so to get this done and dusted, and this ordinance, you know, has has been in the works for many years as Councilor Collins has stated.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's finally time to do something about it.

[Justin Tseng]: I think when we think about the crises that are immediate to our, to our city.

[Justin Tseng]: There are many, but housing is first and foremost for many if not for many residents and it touches many if not all of our residents here as a young person who wants to stay in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: This is, you know, the type of action that we need to see our city government investing in doing to make sure that young folks can stay in Medford to make sure that people who want to buy houses can buy houses.

[Justin Tseng]: and to really tackle the regional housing crisis challenge.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'm happy to support this.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm glad that we were able to iron out a lot of the details, and while I think, and we said this last week about the ordinances that we passed last week, you know, there are going to be small things that people want to see changed.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this represents

[Justin Tseng]: us as a council, listening to the experts, listening to the unions, listening to our stakeholders in this project, really giving them time to work out the kinks and the details, and coming back with a product that I think we can be proud of.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Councilor Caraviello makes a great point there that pro-housing policies are pro-business and pro-growth as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And if we wanna see a more vibrant economy, this is the type of stuff we need to be doing.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think that's a great point and I just wanted to reinforce it.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Burrell.

[Justin Tseng]: I hear my fellow colleagues and their different viewpoints on this issue.

[Justin Tseng]: I, however, do plan to vote yes on this because, as for the same reasons, Councilor Bears has elaborated.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe the legal reasoning is pretty sound here.

[Justin Tseng]: It's pretty clear.

[Justin Tseng]: We've been through this before.

[Justin Tseng]: We've talked about this exact procedure before, and it is a new position.

[Justin Tseng]: When I approach a vote like this, I also think about what the practical everyday effects are.

[Justin Tseng]: And I do fear, as, as we, you know, we're always talking about the difficulty of hiring city staff and the difficulty of retaining city staff.

[Justin Tseng]: that we would lose staff to different communities that are willing to pay more to the state agencies who are willing to pay more.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think this role is so vital to the everyday functioning of our city and as Councilor Collins referred to the constituents requests for their city government to serve them.

[Justin Tseng]: And

[Justin Tseng]: I just, I just believe that we would be severely harmed if we don't move forward with this.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: Well, I guess there's a small typo in here.

[Justin Tseng]: I would just amend it to strike labeled and.

[Justin Tseng]: This is one of three resolutions I have on the agenda tonight that are in the spirit of Black History Month and having gone to a few of the city's events, you know, a recurring theme is what can we do to advance social justice and racial justice in Medford?

[Justin Tseng]: And what can we do as a city government to meet the high standards that we're setting for ourselves and to listen to our residents?

[Justin Tseng]: And

[Justin Tseng]: A few years ago, our city published a social justice roadmap, which detailed a bunch of steps that our administration and our city would take to even out the scales and to pursue a policy of equity in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's been about three years since the last update, and I've worked with the diversity director to kind of put this on an agenda and to kind of just

[Justin Tseng]: talk to the administration a little bit and ask for an update and to ask for updated steps about what action steps we still need to do to reach those lofty goals.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: This one is slightly different.

[Justin Tseng]: Having talked with the diversity director feels that this is something that is standard and different municipalities that we don't miss, we haven't necessarily done here.

[Justin Tseng]: It will require not a dramatic increase increase of resources but a little bit of help up her end, which is why I'm passing this resolution from the city council side showing that there's support for me here is important.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, it's not something that would really take that much more money it's just, it's just something that.

[Justin Tseng]: we again need to poke the administration a little bit and to get them to try to do.

[Justin Tseng]: The main difference between a racial equity study and a social justice roadmap is social justice roadmap is much broader.

[Justin Tseng]: It lays, as many have read the document, lays out general steps and policies that we need to consider.

[Justin Tseng]: The racial equity study is looking more at this very specific topic and looking at what

[Justin Tseng]: what data we need to collect, what actions we need to take within City Hall to make a better environment for our staff, very specific, very concrete, much narrower actions.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: This one sounds a bit more ambitious than it actually is really what this is is codifying are the legal language we already have right now city policy regarding interactions with immigrants and our non cooperation policy with ice.

[Justin Tseng]: This is something that the police department already backs already has legal language from our past solicitors on.

[Justin Tseng]: This, this is really more about starting the process because a lot of, in particular, Latino and Haitian residents have reached out to me, and to see staff here, afraid to really engage with city services because they don't know if how they're

[Justin Tseng]: know the repercussions of engaging with the city government.

[Justin Tseng]: We know that it's safe for them, but this is something that could be used to

[Justin Tseng]: to get the word out that it is safe for them, to guarantee them their rights and safety in our community.

[Justin Tseng]: And some residents have come up to me with the worry that because it is policy, it could change at any point in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: Whereas if we codify it right now, even just the language that we have written and approved, that would mean a lot to them and mean a lot for them to feel safe about engaging city services.

[Justin Tseng]: So again, this is not something that's meant to be very ambitious.

[Justin Tseng]: This is something that's meant to take the legal language we have right now that we're enforcing right now, put it into our code.

[Justin Tseng]: I did forget to note that this is something that the Diversity Director and I have been working on as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: This February is Black History Month, and Medford, as many may know, has a very rich history when it comes to African Americans in the Northeast.

[Justin Tseng]: When we look at our West Bedford community in particular, that's a community that's been there for a very, very, very long time, pretty much since the city was founded.

[Justin Tseng]: I personally have learned a lot by following on the West Bedford Community Center's Twitter account, where I believe every, it might be every day, but every few days they're tweeting out some, you know, something short and readable about a black Bedford resident who shaped

[Justin Tseng]: Medford and the surrounding region somehow.

[Justin Tseng]: The count has talked about Black Medford residents who've served in our army, who fought for the Union, it's talked about athletes and their contributions to

[Justin Tseng]: to our society as well.

[Justin Tseng]: There will be music, there will be dance performances and guest speakers as well.

[Justin Tseng]: to 4 p.m., where you can look at artisans and crafts and gifts that you can buy and gift the family as well.

[Justin Tseng]: they want to get more involved in municipal politics.

[Justin Tseng]: It's a feature of democracy.

[Justin Tseng]: According to the presentation from OPDS to the City Council and it's stated in the Medford Climate Action and Adaptation Report, buildings account for 67% of carbon dioxide equivalents in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: I have reached out to the mayor and the health department here, and they're still looking into it.

[Justin Tseng]: They haven't gotten back to me on that point yet.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, um, you know, increasing access to disposal in our city only would reduce waste, you know this.

[Justin Tseng]: We don't want to see sharps around our city.

[Justin Tseng]: resolution increasing access would give residents a chance to dispose of their sharps safely, in a safe manner, in a clean manner, in a healthy manner, without necessarily, in their convenience, I guess.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this also underscores the need for our city to be better at our communications when it comes to changes that might affect people's everyday lives.

[Justin Tseng]: If a parent needs to dispose of their kid's EpiPens, they should know where to go without having to run across town.

[Justin Tseng]: And even in this building, the only available one right now is on the third floor, and that also can pose an accessibility problem as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So this proposal is really about

[Justin Tseng]: accessibility, it's really about convenience for our residents, about communication and also about beautifying our city.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to offer this resolution as a way to start a conversation about nipple litter in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: I saw, when I was doing research on it, I saw that Councilor Knight had proposed resolution 19-516, which I quoted here, which I was interested where that discussion went, because I couldn't find a record of that.

[Justin Tseng]: I put this on the agenda because I received quite a few messages on social media from younger folks, especially, and some emails about this issue.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of younger folks, I guess they've seen the TikTok going around.

[Justin Tseng]: I guess Medford talk has become a thing.

[Justin Tseng]: So there are quite a lot of TikToks about this issue now.

[Justin Tseng]: And I figured that this was, it was important to address this issue to get ahead of the spring and summer seasons, the warmer weather when we might see more of the slitter around.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is an image issue as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And so to make sure that our city is beautified and that this isn't the impression that we give our city.

[Justin Tseng]: I also heard from some pet owners who walked their dogs in the park who are concerned by the litter as well.

[Justin Tseng]: But again, this is really just to start a conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: I've included a whole range of ideas in here, some of which I prefer.

[Justin Tseng]: The way I personally see this is that it's an externality issue.

[Justin Tseng]: The market only goes so far.

[Justin Tseng]: The free market only goes so far.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we can all acknowledge that net litter is bad.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I personally would like to address or like to see if legally we could levy a per bottle fee on this issue like we often do with plastic bags and stuff like that.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, I'm open to advice and feedback from councillors.

[Justin Tseng]: I have heard from residents who have noted that nips are important for liquor usage as well in terms of regulating their consumption as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think perhaps the ban might go too far, but again, this is to really start a conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I'm really grateful for your for your comments.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that would be a good idea.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, yeah, I mean, I don't want the government regulating personal behavior as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And it isn't I recognize it's important for package stores as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Nicole Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Farrell.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Councilor Caraviello kind of read my mind.

[Justin Tseng]: The talking about arts and how we find a space for arts was one of the things that Councilmarks and I actually talked about a long time ago before I even ran for office, and I wanted to make sure that you got a proper shout out for the work that he's done and the tremendous amount of effort that Councilmarks put into making sure the arts as a space and effort as well.

[Justin Tseng]: The arts, I think it's not controversial to say, is a benefit to all Medford residents, from youth to adulthood to retirement.

[Justin Tseng]: The arts really, I think, brings out creativity and brings out community.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm someone who benefited from investment in the arts back at Medford High, back in the Medford public schools,

[Justin Tseng]: I miss, I miss the art classes and the music classes.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think, you know, as someone who just graduated from school, finding a way to kind of continue to be connected to an arts community is something that I think is at the heart of the front of mind.

[Justin Tseng]: for a lot of Medford residents.

[Justin Tseng]: When we talk about mental health, which is obviously so important, this is one of the ways that we can work together as a community to address the issue.

[Justin Tseng]: So I'm very excited for this, and I thank Councilor Collins for putting this on the agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: I think a lot of the points on either side of the debate have already been said so I'll keep my statement short.

[Justin Tseng]: I would love.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this is a, this is an important issue.

[Justin Tseng]: I do think that, you know, we have a responsibility as a city to make sure our residents are well informed about what goes on in our community and how to avoid being ticketed, and I would really

[Justin Tseng]: I think on issues like this, I think it's important to bring in the stakeholders to the table and see what, as Councilor Collins said, we're not experts on this issue, but I do think that this is a valid idea, and it'd be good to hear about what the city administration has to say about it.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I'm cancer caravilas suggestion is good one and I would, it would be great to see that in the housing stability notification ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: I think another aspect that I would like to add to it is adding it onto the city website making sure that it's an easy place to find.

[Justin Tseng]: I've been a big proponent of having a welcome to Medford part of the website, a resource where all the most important documents are all in one place, especially for younger residents who are moving in.

[Justin Tseng]: Oftentimes, internet is the first place that we go to to find information.

[Justin Tseng]: And so when it's easy to find on the internet, I think that would be a benefit to our community.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell, and thank you, Councilor Collins, for introducing this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, as you said, almost every, if not every councillor that sat in this chamber in recent years has done something to complain to, in effect, done something to try to resolve this issue.

[Justin Tseng]: Although, as you also acknowledged, the people with power are far removed from us.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, you know, this goes without saying to everyone who lives in Medford, but I think it's a particularly important point to make is, you know, why is Medford suffering the brunt of this?

[Justin Tseng]: Why don't we see this in other communities?

[Justin Tseng]: It's not for a lack of complaining, and it's not for want of trying.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think when we talk to the federal delegation, we need to make that clear that this is an equity issue as well.

[Justin Tseng]: This is an issue of respect to our community.

[Justin Tseng]: And we need to work hard and work as a united front to tackle this issue and to make sure that there is that accountability for the people that are making these decisions who have the power.

[Justin Tseng]: We did receive that email from the city administration that they're meeting with Congresswoman Clark's office on January 26th, and that senators, the two senators from Massachusetts, Senator Warren, Senator Markey are co-sponsoring a piece of legislation in Congress.

[Justin Tseng]: My personal take is that it would have been good for the city administration to inform us before so that we could pass a resolution or express our support for the conversations that they're having with the Congresswoman's office.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm personally a believer that when all branches of our city government work together, that's more influential and more impactful than if one branch of the city government was to walk into a meeting alone.

[Justin Tseng]: and it would have been good to solicit our feedback and to solicit a statement from either from our city council as a whole or from councillors individually for this meeting, as we did with the MBTA bus network redesign, which did win back several bus lines service to Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: That's my take on this issue.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think going forward,

[Justin Tseng]: I think this council wants to be partners with the city administration when it comes to working to get better results for Metro residents.

[Justin Tseng]: And I wish that in the future, when it comes to cases like this, we can unite forces.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I just wanted to echo what Councilor Collins said.

[Justin Tseng]: From my conversations with people in the city, I think people most want us all to work together to develop a solution.

[Justin Tseng]: And when we work together, that's when we find a more sustainable solution.

[Justin Tseng]: And that includes more voices, more stakeholders, and keeps in mind the fact that we're all elected

[Justin Tseng]: or we're all hired to do a job and that we are really on the same team.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, I think, I hope that this is the start of a fruitful collaboration with the school committee going forward.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think, you know, I hope this is the start of a respectful and collaborative relationship between all of our bodies.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to, first and foremost, say, again, how excited I am about this project.

[Justin Tseng]: As someone who went to the McGlynn for nine years and was a part of the McGlynn afterschool program for a very long time, you know, what you were saying about the slides and the rubber and the infrastructure and the flooding, I think that, I mean, that all,

[Justin Tseng]: All those were problems when I was there and it's only gotten worse.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, with your advocacy and with all the work that you guys have been doing, you know, we're finally seeing, you know, something substantive that can make our children's experiences on the playground, much, much better.

[Justin Tseng]: I think Councilor Bears asked what I wanted to ask about the budget.

[Justin Tseng]: And it seems like you guys have, you know, have taken all of that into account.

[Justin Tseng]: It's the presentation was really, really comprehensive.

[Justin Tseng]: And I really appreciate that you guys have thought, you know, long-term to the future about how do we save money over time?

[Justin Tseng]: What are the investments we have to make now to do that?

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's something that every taxpayer in Medford can really appreciate.

[Justin Tseng]: I had the pleasure of talking to you at the Harvest Your Energy Festival.

[Justin Tseng]: And I saw you guys engage the kids and ask them for feedback and look at the different simulations and see what aspects of all the different drawings that they liked.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think seeing that, I think really epitomized how much feedback has gone into this project, which I really wanted to commend you guys for.

[Justin Tseng]: It's really been, I think it's a model

[Justin Tseng]: for our city to look at when it comes to engaging stakeholders, which I really appreciate.

[Justin Tseng]: I also appreciated the environmental lens on this project, how you're salvaging living trees, but also planting more trees for shade, thinking about how to make the whole playground cooler.

[Justin Tseng]: It's kind of a meme that I bang on about heat islands, but I think this is something that our city can do to reduce, to mitigate the heat island effect.

[Justin Tseng]: And as you guys, you know alluded to in the summer it's, it's a place where kids can go and where families can go to cool down when we have those heat waves that are, you know, only we're only seeing more of.

[Justin Tseng]: And again, the equity lens of it.

[Justin Tseng]: McLean, when we look at the income aspect of that neighborhood, when we look at where we're making investments in our physical infrastructure in our city I think it's really meaningful that we're doing work at the McLean and trying to make it better.

[Justin Tseng]: and that we're really focusing on accessibility, which I know you're a huge advocate for.

[Justin Tseng]: But really, I think we've seen with this project, how much work, how much thinking you've been putting into the very specific kind of aspects of accessibility, which I think I'm particularly touched by.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think you guys have also touched on something that we don't always think about when it comes to playground design, which was point four in the project goals, considering whether

[Justin Tseng]: considering how we could create a park with a wider benefit to our community.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think the Harvester Energy Festival kind of shows that there is potential for that space to be a community space, to have more city events there.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's something that I've talked with our DEI director about, which is, you know, how can our city hold events outside of the normal places where we hold events, engage more residents?

[Justin Tseng]: And we know that, you know, there are certain parts of our community that are usually less, that see less events like this and see less engagement.

[Justin Tseng]: And to be able to hold, to have a venue where we can hold community events like that, I think can really expand the Medford community and really bring more people back together, which I'm, again, I find really touching.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the only question I had out of curiosity was,

[Justin Tseng]: What's the plan for kids whilst the playground is being constructed?

[Justin Tseng]: Thanks.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, I really appreciate the presentation.

[Justin Tseng]: I appreciate you guys coming before the public and building that support.

[Justin Tseng]: And I hope, you know, God forbid that we come into difficulty with the budget when it comes to maintenance fees.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the work that you're doing right now, building community support for it is super important in making sure that we have the capability.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I just wanted to wish you the best of luck.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, my friends and I have always wanted a bubble tea shop in Medford and it's, um, it's a, it's a great honor for us to be able to have one to call our own.

[Justin Tseng]: So thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: All right.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: First of all, I just wanted to thank you and your department for all this work that you're doing.

[Justin Tseng]: I think something that a few of us, many of us on this side of the rail have been talking about, a lot of community leaders have been talking about is the importance of bringing government to the people and not just expecting people to show up.

[Justin Tseng]: We all know that there are real equity access barriers when it comes to meetings, even meetings like this.

[Justin Tseng]: any city meeting, any coming to city events, and your department's, I think, philosophical approach to outreach, I think is something that we should be proud that we're doing as a city.

[Justin Tseng]: I know it can be really tough to do that outreach, and so I was wondering what some of the challenges that you've found were.

[Justin Tseng]: Maybe, I know the community liaisons have been doing a great job,

[Justin Tseng]: but I'm wondering what are some of the barriers that you guys have faced and what are some of the ways that you're gonna address that with the Medford Connectors program in terms of outreach and getting to more people?

[Justin Tseng]: You guys have been doing incredible work.

[Justin Tseng]: I really appreciate that answer.

[Justin Tseng]: And what you were talking about, and I think the work you guys are doing, I think, lays out a foundation for what other departments in the city can do, including the city council, maybe in the further future.

[Justin Tseng]: I think you guys are testing the waters, seeing what works, and perhaps in the future, our city council and other branches of government, other departments of the government can look towards you guys and see

[Justin Tseng]: what we can do to be more inclusive to get more of those voices that haven't been included in city government to help us come to our meetings and help us, you know, give us feedback and shape our agendas.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: I think my question was slightly, slightly more about

[Justin Tseng]: How are we reaching the residents that we haven't reached yet, which I know can be a really difficult question to answer and I'm sure you guys are already working on it.

[Justin Tseng]: I was wondering if you guys partner with other city departments to, you know, keep track of who comes in for city services already or

[Justin Tseng]: In terms of maybe a city, the work that we do collecting server data with our city city census type things, seeing if I think who moves into the city, pays our taxes perhaps there's a way to, even in, I know this can be costly but putting, putting

[Justin Tseng]: even a short flyer in our water bills or something like that to try to get more people aware that your department exists, that the work that you guys are doing exists.

[Justin Tseng]: And maybe that will reach more people, but you are the expert here, so.

[Justin Tseng]: That's excellent.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think to what you've been saying, you know, as a son of immigrant parents, I've had to translate a lot of things, find out a lot of things about city services.

[Justin Tseng]: It would be super helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: The things that you're describing will be super helpful.

[Justin Tseng]: So thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's important to thank first the teachers and the school staff and the parents who were there

[Justin Tseng]: who are helping the students through the ordeal, who themselves had to deal with the emotional side of everything.

[Justin Tseng]: It's really important not to forget about that.

[Justin Tseng]: This hurts.

[Justin Tseng]: This hurts emotionally.

[Justin Tseng]: It hurts physically.

[Justin Tseng]: It's important to deal with it.

[Justin Tseng]: And it matters.

[Justin Tseng]: It matters to all of us.

[Justin Tseng]: in this room, everyone online on Zoom is upset, is frustrated, is saddened.

[Justin Tseng]: I will say I am relieved to hear

[Justin Tseng]: that the student is in stable condition, but that doesn't mean that everything is over.

[Justin Tseng]: I really appreciate the talk from Councilors of all backgrounds about the importance of finding solutions.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think to that effect, I wanna thank President Morell and Vice President Bears for opening up the city council agenda to allow us to put resolutions on the agenda to have this conversation tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: And to allow us to act fast and to allow us to have this conversation tonight to my parents in the room on in on zoom.

[Justin Tseng]: Look, school violence, and I've said this before, and it's in the news, there's tons of research out there.

[Justin Tseng]: It's an international problem.

[Justin Tseng]: It's a domestic problem.

[Justin Tseng]: It's a Medford problem.

[Justin Tseng]: And that actually means that we have to deal with it.

[Justin Tseng]: And we do have to address it here at home.

[Justin Tseng]: School violence has been around for a while.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Bears has spoken to his experience.

[Justin Tseng]: I went to Medford High School just five years ago.

[Justin Tseng]: I know what it's like there.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's a wonderful institution to learn.

[Justin Tseng]: There are blemishes on it as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And this work, these are all issues that school leaders, teachers, students, everyone has been working together to address over the last few years.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's evident that we need to put even more energy towards it.

[Justin Tseng]: And as I've said before as well, until our schools are safe for everyone, for all, we still have more work to do.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to find sustainable solutions, and that means engaging stakeholders from students to parents to teachers.

[Justin Tseng]: I know people aren't gonna like this, but the school committee who have been elected to govern our schools, to oversee our schools, and we need to engage school leaders as well.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to enforce the existing policies on violence and on anti-bullying.

[Justin Tseng]: And we need accountability to make sure that we're enforcing these policies.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to think through the actions that we can take to protect all kids carefully.

[Justin Tseng]: and quickly, I will add, but we need to make sure that they're equitable and reasonable and that they really truly do protect every kid in the classroom and in the hallways.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's also evidence that there's a major communications problem that we as a city council have been bringing up in the city, the communications problem in the city when it comes to not just in an incident like this, but just in general, getting the message out to residents.

[Justin Tseng]: But when it comes to this incident as well, we need to know.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think President Morell and I have written a resolution to this effect.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to know about the incident.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to know the details.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to know authority and rules and who has authority over what.

[Justin Tseng]: And we need to prevent misinformation from being spread.

[Justin Tseng]: And school committee members at yesterday's meeting have also acknowledged that as a city, we need to do better on communications and on engaging families as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Bears is right.

[Justin Tseng]: The funding problem is real.

[Justin Tseng]: It's one of the reasons why I decided to run for office in the first place, watching the budget conversation years ago when

[Justin Tseng]: We made major cuts to guidance and to mental health and counseling at our schools.

[Justin Tseng]: And now we're seeing the effects of it.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to be serious about that.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to be serious about funding and to realize that there is a funding issue.

[Justin Tseng]: And that effect, that problem is trickling down to our hallways and to our classrooms.

[Justin Tseng]: and that particularly after COVID and after remote learning, there has been an epidemic of poor mental health in the city and in this country.

[Justin Tseng]: I asked the city and the city council joined me in passing a resolution months ago, asking the city to do a general survey on youth mental health and to look at the effects of that and to see what we can do to invest more in it and to prevent

[Justin Tseng]: things like this from happening.

[Justin Tseng]: And it is upsetting as a Councilor to see that we haven't done enough on it.

[Justin Tseng]: This council has been responsible in doing that and we have been proactive in addressing youth mental health.

[Justin Tseng]: I want us to do as much as possible, as quickly as possible.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's something that everyone behind the reel would agree on.

[Justin Tseng]: But I also do wanna make sure that we are creating lasting solutions within our purview.

[Justin Tseng]: I know not everyone will agree with my approach on this issue and my ideas, but I am open-minded to hear more ideas, to hear feedback, both positive and negative.

[Justin Tseng]: And I understand, as Councilor Collins has mentioned, that many members of our community weren't able to make it to this meeting for scheduling reasons, for family reasons, and many members of our community aren't joining us today because they're afraid to talk and talking in public is not for everyone.

[Justin Tseng]: And to those people, my inbox and my voicemail box and my text message inbox is also open to everyone.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's really important to emphasize that regardless of the tone of this conversation, regardless of the points that people have brought up, regardless of the feedback that we're going to hear, and I think people in our community, there are many, many different ways of thinking about this issue and about the solutions for this issue.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's been evident to me in the conversations that I've had.

[Justin Tseng]: with neighbors, with residents, with young folks in the last 24 hours.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's important to acknowledge the differences, but to also acknowledge the points of unity that I think we see on this agenda tonight, because those points of unity, those are the seeds, I think, for more lasting, more substantive policy changes in the future that will better, I think, create a school environment for our children.

[Justin Tseng]: and that particularly after COVID and after remote learning, there has been an epidemic of poor mental health in the city and in this country.

[Justin Tseng]: I asked the city and the city council joined me in passing a resolution months ago

[Justin Tseng]: asking the city to do a general survey on youth mental health and to look at the effects of that and to see what we can do to invest more in it and to prevent things like this from happening.

[Justin Tseng]: And it is upsetting as a Councilor to see that we haven't done enough on it.

[Justin Tseng]: This council has been responsible in doing that and we have been proactive in addressing youth mental health.

[Justin Tseng]: I want us to do as much as possible, as quickly as possible.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's something that everyone behind the reel would agree on.

[Justin Tseng]: But I also do want to make sure that we are creating lasting solutions within our purview.

[Justin Tseng]: I know not everyone will agree with my approach on this issue and my ideas, but I am open-minded to hear more ideas, to hear feedback, both positive and negative.

[Justin Tseng]: And I understand, as Councilor Collins has mentioned, that many members of our community weren't able to make it to this meeting for scheduling reasons, for family reasons, and many members of our community aren't joining us today because they're afraid to talk and talking in public is not for everyone.

[Justin Tseng]: And to those people, my inbox and my voicemail box and my text message inbox is also open to everyone.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's really important to emphasize that regardless of the tone of this conversation, regardless of the points that people have brought up, regardless of the feedback that we're going to hear.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think people in our community, there are many, many different ways of thinking about this issue and about the solutions for this issue.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's been evident to me in the conversations that I've had.

[Justin Tseng]: with neighbors, with residents, with young folks in the last 24 hours.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's important to acknowledge the differences, but to also acknowledge the points of unity that I think we see on this agenda tonight, because those points of unity, those are the seeds, I think, for more lasting, more substantive policy changes in the future that will better, I think, create a school environment for our children.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I also wanted to, uh, thank, um, the parents for coming up and telling you the stories.

[Justin Tseng]: And, um, I hadn't heard the story before, and I think president Morello, you put it well that even though.

[Justin Tseng]: even though I was there five years ago, I think things have, you know, things are slightly different now and smartphones and COVID and all of that changes everything as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So it's actually, it's really helpful to hear that perspective.

[Justin Tseng]: all of them.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: I find them in order and move for approval.

[Justin Tseng]: I was just going to mention, I think last week the interim chief inspector also mentioned that this would not be the right time to adopt it because of the logistics associated with it, but that if we do choose to adopt it, we should have a conversation early next year about it.

[Justin Tseng]: So there's been a lot of discussion about means and methods and comparing our community to other communities.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it might be helpful for us all to sit down sometime next year, maybe in a committee of the whole, invite you and invite some other people involved in the decision making to really make it more transparent and see what are the things that we could change.

[Justin Tseng]: both at the city level but also at the ordinance kind of city council level to make your work easier and to make projects like this more of a success, so it's less of a question more of a, I think this is something that our council could do next year.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think it's noble and valiant that this city administration's using surveys so much.

[Justin Tseng]: I worked in survey research for four years.

[Justin Tseng]: I certainly believe in its role in maintaining trust in the citizenry and getting feedback for ideas and policies.

[Justin Tseng]: I think from that experience, I've also learned a few things.

[Justin Tseng]: The first of which is you gotta have a plan.

[Justin Tseng]: The survey has to slot into a bigger plan in general, and I think it would have been more prudent, especially given that the city council has jurisdiction of ordinances, that the administration should have come to us and asked us about what ideas we were open to, what we were hearing from our residents talking to us,

[Justin Tseng]: and what possibilities that we were open to.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that could have informed the survey creation itself.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I have another concern from the public opinion survey research perspective, which is that I'm afraid that our city surveys aren't representative of our population.

[Justin Tseng]: It's one thing to conduct a survey.

[Justin Tseng]: It's another thing to post a Google link on Facebook and ask people to fill it out.

[Justin Tseng]: We saw with the ARPA survey that that survey was skewed very much towards homeowners, very much towards certain demographics, towards certain neighborhoods.

[Justin Tseng]: That's something I, you know, if we're putting the energy into creating surveys, I want to make sure that that survey is representative.

[Justin Tseng]: I want to make sure that we're actually listening to a whole range of people and having a survey sample that represents our city as a whole.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't know if we will see the results of this survey, but given our city's record with previous surveys, I think that, you know, it remains as a concern of mine.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's concerning when we use faulty data to inform our decisions as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think, you know, this is an issue I'm sure all the councillors have heard a lot of things pro and con.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll put on the record too, I love dogs, but I think,

[Justin Tseng]: This is just symptomatic of our city's planning process.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think this is a symptom of the need to plan better, to think more far in advance, how we approach policy changes and how we approach soliciting public opinion.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think Councilor Scarpelli's resolution gets at that point, the process point.

[Justin Tseng]: In the same vein of things, I've talked with city staff for the last few months and with residents who'd like to see us, you know, update some of the decorations that we have in terms of, you know, who we're, you know, featuring in the city hall.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, they're great historical figures that we pay respect to, but I think a lot of residents would like to see their neighbors on there as well and to see us have, you know, portraits

[Justin Tseng]: decorations that are more representative of the diversity of our community.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I've long said that we shouldn't expect people to come to government.

[Justin Tseng]: We should expect government to go to people.

[Justin Tseng]: And there's a lot of work that even we can do better in this regard.

[Justin Tseng]: I thank my fellow Councilors for putting this on the agenda because I think it matches that spirit entirely.

[Justin Tseng]: I just would want to offer a quick, a short amendment to add the Traffic Commission in there as well, because I know they're working on a lot of the policy changes that Councilor Caraviello brought up.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know the director of the parking department has said that she doesn't involve herself in those discussions.

[Justin Tseng]: And so it's important that we have the decision makers also traveling into the neighborhoods.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I think I, I also you an apology.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I, I listening to especially I think to Councilor Scarpelli's remarks and Councilor Collins remarks I think reminds me of a few things I think the first, the most important thing is of the ideals that we held when we

[Justin Tseng]: chose to run for office.

[Justin Tseng]: And when I made the decision to jump into all of this, I really wanted to give a voice to people like me, who I didn't feel like were being properly represented in our community.

[Justin Tseng]: I, I was also sick and that's just, I mean that's not, that's not a good enough reason.

[Justin Tseng]: what happened to your daughter and the incidents that have occurred since are never acceptable, never, never, ever acceptable in our city, not anywhere.

[Justin Tseng]: We should recognize that there is an epidemic of school violence and that this has become a very persistent problem in the aftermath of COVID and

[Justin Tseng]: and especially with... Point of information?

[Justin Tseng]: Is the gentleman referring to in the Medford public school system or in general?

[Justin Tseng]: Well, I'll get to that.

[Justin Tseng]: So, I mean, it's been a persistent problem in the aftermath of COVID lockdowns and a general downturn in youth mental health, which this council has talked about.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, this isn't only happening in Medford, but we in Medford should be proactive about solving and tackling these challenges head on.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, this is a personal problem to me, because I still have a lot of siblings of my friends who attend the school system, and I just graduated not too long ago from Medford High.

[Justin Tseng]: This again, this isn't unique to Medford, but I think it's important in talking to students and teachers and school leaders about how we can prevent something like this happening.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we need to, you know, recognize that we need to stop the systemic failures that led to this in the first place, especially with the administrative problems.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we need to recognize that we need to treat this problem holistically and developmentally and focus just as much on physical well-being as well as on mental health and making sure that the problem is rooted out permanently and that we don't have students that get to that point at all.

[Justin Tseng]: But such a hard approach I think such a strong approach I think means that we'll have to take a really hard look at the systemic underfunding of our schools I think it will require us to build more accountability, build more trust.

[Justin Tseng]: I do really respect the spirit of the resolution itself.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I share my colleagues' worry that this wouldn't be actionable and that this wouldn't solve the administrative problems that we saw in your, unfortunately saw in your case, and that it would also be illegal and overstepping our authority vis-a-vis the governance of our public school system.

[Justin Tseng]: But I hope that my listening to the paper, I do hope that that's, again, one piece of the solution that's more actionable.

[Justin Tseng]: And that really focuses on building trust, trust and collaboration.

[Justin Tseng]: MHS is a safe place for most, if not many, but until it is a safe place for everyone, we have a lot of work to do.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's clear to me that school leaders, that parents, teachers, students, and members of our school committee are ready to work together to try to find something that

[Justin Tseng]: prevents the administrative problems that happened here and prevents the mental health problems and prevents the physical violence problems.

[Justin Tseng]: And my hope is that something like the deep paper will help us move forward in that direction.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I think it'd be valuable for people to be able to come in next week, if they have any ideas.

[Justin Tseng]: As one of the two main municipalities on this side of Tufts campus, I think it's incumbent upon us as elected officials to help those who are seeking fairness and equity in the work that they perform.

[Justin Tseng]: which is why supporting the RA union is so important for our city council to do.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, but I also believe that, um, the stories behind it are as powerful and as important as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: This resolution comes out of the many meetings that we've had on parking.

[Justin Tseng]: And something I had heard repeated by a lot of residents was that the list on the website was not updated.

[Justin Tseng]: And given all the flux that's going on, especially with parking in South Medford and Hillside with the arrival of the Green Line, residents have been frankly just confused about which streets are permitted, which streets aren't.

[Justin Tseng]: And they don't know where they can park.

[Justin Tseng]: or what the rules are.

[Justin Tseng]: And so something like this, something like this, that it's updated would really help residents, I think, know exactly where they can park and where they can't park.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, it's common sense.

[Justin Tseng]: And we, you know, this is something that should be consistently updated, but I think we need to give it a little bit of a jolt.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of residents, especially newer residents, when they were moving into Medford, you know, they want to know how the city government works, they want to know

[Justin Tseng]: what the services are, and a lot of them complained about the navigability of the website as a problem.

[Justin Tseng]: Furthermore, a lot of residents of color, especially immigrant residents, have told me that they don't really know how to navigate the website because the translation is so poor, because it's not a naturally translated website that uses Google Translate.

[Justin Tseng]: And actually in an email from the administration this week, we've learned that it's widgets like that that caused the website to crash so frequently, which is yet another problem with our city website.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, we talked about infrastructure as the gateway to our city, which is definitely true.

[Justin Tseng]: This is digital infrastructure.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is

[Justin Tseng]: 21st century gateway to our city.

[Justin Tseng]: When people think of Medford, when they think about moving here, oftentimes they look on the city website.

[Justin Tseng]: They look at the city website as a reflection of our city, of the things that we're doing as a community and the services that they can get here.

[Justin Tseng]: And

[Justin Tseng]: the level of transparency and communication there is between the city and between its residents.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I believe that meeting in the committee of whole would give us a chance to hear from residents about what the vision that they want to see from our website to gather more feedback for our administration and for our city in general, moving forward as we do move on to a new platform, which I believe is we're in the process of currently.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe a lot of the points I wanted to make have been made by fellow councilors.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think that's off of anyone's minds, but when I think about how we get out of that problem, how we get out of the hole, a position like this is key to getting out of that situation.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe that there is a unanimous, there is a unanimous support behind the rails for financial accountability, for fiscal transparency,

[Justin Tseng]: I am for increasing leverage and to make sure our city is making the right financial choices.

[Justin Tseng]: fiscal responsibility, which I believe in this case the money has already been appropriated to your department.

[Justin Tseng]: We're not taking money out of free cash, you know, there's financially that's that's that's the reality of the situation.

[Justin Tseng]: The other reality of the situation is as stable as things might currently be.

[Justin Tseng]: We also know that municipalities around us are competing to hire more planners and

[Justin Tseng]: I'm not saying this is what your office staff are thinking, right?

[Justin Tseng]: But who's to say that in a few months or in a few years, they don't see a lack of opportunity to move forward in our community and they just leave for another community, right?

[Justin Tseng]: We are also competitors in this market.

[Justin Tseng]: for planners, for city planners.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that leads me to my ultimate question that I always ask.

[Justin Tseng]: When I take votes like this, and I think really, when we think about how the question of accountability, how we're gonna hold the administration to account, I think this is the question that's gonna guide me from item to item, is if this is gonna tangibly improve the lives of our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: And that is I think ultimately the goal, the unified goal of the city council, you know we've, we've, I think there's a lot of agreement that we need to move forward on housing production on sustainability on the climate plan on phase two of zoning.

[Justin Tseng]: support like this in your office, right?

[Justin Tseng]: To get our own priorities through.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we need to ask that question for everything before us.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Collins, for inviting me to co-sponsor this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: I think you've really hit the heart of what's at stake here, which is public safety.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, our job as elected representatives of the city and it's a major branch of our city is to be the stewards of public safety.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, when I'm on the road, I would, I would want all the drivers on the road to be tested insured and licensed.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's, that's common sense, not just to prevent traffic accidents and to prevent situations where we might be driving on the road with people who aren't tested licensed or insured.

[Justin Tseng]: God forbid, if God forbid something were to happen, we want that trust with our police to be there as well, so that we prevent hit and runs.

[Justin Tseng]: So thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor say, thank you, President Merle, this is a question that a lot of residents in our community have been asking, especially with the opening of the Green Line extension coming upon us very soon.

[Justin Tseng]: more choices in terms of how to get to work in Cambridge Somerville in Boston, or just to travel to our neighboring municipalities.

[Justin Tseng]: Currently, there is a plan for the Somerville community bike path will open alongside the

[Justin Tseng]: a green line extension to moon square station and a lot of residents have been wondering more specifically about how we might be able to as a city connected that the office of planning development and sustainability and engineering department have been so gracious to

[Justin Tseng]: give me a pretty thorough response about their plans so far.

[Justin Tseng]: On this specific point about working to extend the GLX community path, there are no plans so far and part of the problem is that the right-of-way in between adjacent private properties on either side of the railway looks significantly narrower in the Medford section than in the Somerville section, which doesn't mean it's impossible to do but just means it's quite difficult to do.

[Justin Tseng]: However, our city is

[Justin Tseng]: taking a look at connecting to this community path via on-street bike facilities, and they'll put this in the new citywide bike plan that's coming out soon, or when they're ready, and they're going to suggest placing these bike facilities along that path, with one example being around Medford Street and Dexter Street.

[Justin Tseng]: Another possibility for our city connecting to the community path is via an off-street path between the Mystic River Greenways and the GLX community path extension.

[Justin Tseng]: This would be more towards Assembly Square and then up by the Mystic.

[Justin Tseng]: A feasibility study was actually conducted two years ago, and there's quite a lot of detail for how we would implement this if our city deemed it to be the best path forward.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, generally, residents might also be interested in bike path planning and power cities going about it.

[Justin Tseng]: While our city is space constrained in many places, our city's approach, and the approach of the planning department and the engineering department so far.

[Justin Tseng]: is to identify key routes that have the capacity for infrastructure and then to make design recommendations from a short-term perspective, so tackling what we can achieve with minimal changes and minimal resources and a long-term perspective where we look at things that we can build during larger roadway reconstruction projects.

[Justin Tseng]: The city is also prioritizing continuity between municipalities that's something we've heard in our climate plan meeting, and the comprehensive plan meeting as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And they're meeting, making special note of on and off street connections to Somerville Arlington Malden, etc.

[Justin Tseng]: And to make sure that we align our plans with their plans as well.

[Justin Tseng]: and the city is currently in the midst of developing a new bike, a citywide bike plan.

[Justin Tseng]: They will, when that starts, they'll launch a public outreach process with opportunities to get feedback and get involved.

[Justin Tseng]: I assume at that point, the city council would love to relay feedback and to look at these changes as well.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: This comes from a meeting of a subcommittee that we are on, the sustainability subcommittee, where we were looking at the tree protection ordinance.

[Justin Tseng]: And there were two sections, one section on defining code enforcement officer and one defining tree warden that were in the ordinance that we thought between

[Justin Tseng]: between the council, between city staff, and between legal advice we thought would be best to sever, and to let people with more know-how on this issue decide what to do with it, since it was outside our scope.

[Justin Tseng]: And so the recommendation was that we send this to rules and ordinances and let that committee look at these definitions and decide whether we need to update our city or code of ordinances with them, since there is no definition currently, whether we need that for the tree ordinance and what the best path forward is.

[Justin Tseng]: Right.

[Justin Tseng]: And the advice was that we shouldn't put it under the tree ordinance section of the code of ordinances.

[Justin Tseng]: That'd be better placed under.

[Justin Tseng]: Sure.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this item is, this resolution is pretty self-explanatory.

[Justin Tseng]: This is a monumental change to policy in our country.

[Justin Tseng]: To have people who have student loan debt be able to apply for this relief really truly does make a difference in a lot of people's lives.

[Justin Tseng]: The form is super short.

[Justin Tseng]: It takes at most five minutes to fill out and is a way in which we can help residents and families throughout what might be a more difficult economic time.

[Justin Tseng]: Madam President.

[Justin Tseng]: Motion to take paper 2245, 452 out of, 542, sorry, out of order.

[Justin Tseng]: We have a few people in the audience here to speak on the paper.

[Justin Tseng]: That's what I'm seeking?

[Justin Tseng]: Second, Councilor.

[Justin Tseng]: Just to clarify, by Election Day, does that include Election Day for the viewers who are watching?

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, I would second that motion, first of all.

[Justin Tseng]: In prepping for tonight, I thought of a conversation I had with one of my college mentors, who was a proud Italian American, and he knows Taiwanese culture really well, so my family background.

[Justin Tseng]: And we had a long talk about the values that we share in common, which are family, community, hard work, amongst other values.

[Justin Tseng]: And in Medford, we're extremely fortunate for the rich involvement of Italian Americans in building our city from, as Vice President Bears has stated, from teaching to public safety, work like plumbing and healthcare, public service and beyond.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to say I really appreciate that here in Medford I grew up learning about Italian culture, learning the language, learning about Italian foods, and being able to do my little diorama of Galileo's project, which is something I've come to realize outside of Medford is not such a common experience.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think Medford's past and present proves that these values, family, community, public service, hard work, they are fundamental to who we are as a city, and that the contributions of this community, of the Italian American community, have really shaped who we are, and that they prove that this is larger than any one person.

[Justin Tseng]: It's really about our community as a whole.

[Justin Tseng]: So thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: October is Domestic Abuse Awareness Month.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, we all have, I'm sure at this by this point we've all heard about the planned one month closure of the orange line, starting for August 19, I believe it goes until September 20.

[Justin Tseng]: You know this this is a massive inconvenience for anyone who uses orange line.

[Justin Tseng]: The first part is a nod to the work that our Councilors have already done.

[Justin Tseng]: the councillors who've come before me, and who are still with us today, have already done regarding the 325 326 and 710 the circumstances now are new.

[Justin Tseng]: And so we should just push again, in my opinion.

[Justin Tseng]: The numbers that the MBTA has kind of suggested just don't line up with the MBTA's own data with regards to how many people ride the Orange Line on a daily basis.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is going to be especially a huge problem for the primary election on September 6th, because it's going to force a lot of our voters to have to reconsider their plans and

[Justin Tseng]: you know, they might not even be able to make it from work to vote.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think that's particularly an important point that should be made.

[Justin Tseng]: Our federal officials, many federal officials, including our representatives and senators, have called for the elimination of subway and bus fares.

[Justin Tseng]: especially noted that the Congress has given money for the MBT to use to for this purpose.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's up to the MBT leadership to decide whether in the state leadership to decide whether they choose to take that route.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe that this is something that would really benefit, at least mitigate some of the negative effects of, of the Orange Line closures.

[Justin Tseng]: We also, the MBTA has announced that if you do hold a Charlie card, that you can show your Charlie card on a Purple Line train, a commuter rail train, and you can ride it for free as long as you're coming

[Justin Tseng]: from them to a zone 1A, zone 1B, and zone 2 station.

[Justin Tseng]: So for a lot of Medford residents, West Medford and North Station, West Medford and Malden Center are stations that they can get on trains with.

[Justin Tseng]: And the MBTA has also said that the Haverhill line will stop at Malden Center during the closures.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and the last part of this is just to ask the city administration to, um, work with them be to try our best to work with the MBTA and to really.

[Justin Tseng]: At the very least on our own end, um, expect that they're going to be increases in in car traffic and road traffic, given the closures and to see what we can do, um, to mitigate, uh, the negative effects and to make sure that, you know, traffic people can get to work as fast as possible.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, thank you, Vice President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, as, as we know, the federal government recently declared monkey pox a health emergency, a public health emergency.

[Justin Tseng]: I just, you know, people have been asking me what, um, what our government should do about it.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe I have confidence that in our board of health, but you know, in the spirit of reducing panic in the spirit of, you know, making, making sure our lives go, go on as normal.

[Justin Tseng]: Erin DiBenedetto was one of my mentors growing up.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, I think the other Councilors have put very well, you know, her service to the city.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm excited to see that she's continuing to serve, choosing to continue to serve our community.

[Justin Tseng]: I wish I could be there in person to see her, to give her a hug, but I'm happy to support her from my room and not to pass on my cough.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Justin Tseng]: I know this is a serious debate.

[Justin Tseng]: This is, you know, this is

[Justin Tseng]: This is a topic about which I've received dozens and dozens and dozens of emails and calls over the last few weeks, including during budget season.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think more importantly than all the messages that I've received, I live both sides of this debate.

[Justin Tseng]: My parents are homeowners in the city, they've invested in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: I recently graduated from the Medford Public Schools.

[Justin Tseng]: I know what the budget cuts look like.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know what the tightness of the money looks like.

[Justin Tseng]: And I've been on the doorsteps, and I've been asked to campaign, and they've been asked to improve our roads, improve our schools, do X, Y, Z. But the fact of the matter is something I've learned while in this office is we don't even have a bare bones budget.

[Justin Tseng]: Our budget cuts through the bone.

[Justin Tseng]: We can talk about a lean government, we can talk about a fiscally responsible government, we can talk about a government that only serves the basics, but we aren't even there yet.

[Justin Tseng]: And when we asked the mayor for a plan, what we heard was, we don't really have a plan, next year will be worse.

[Justin Tseng]: The only way we can, and the implication is the only way we can get out of this mess is to advance difficult, politically difficult ideas.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not on my wish list to raise taxes in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: No one likes it.

[Justin Tseng]: No one likes it.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's a political risk to do it anyways.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think we need to step up and lead and trust the people with this decision.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, you know, we've heard a lot about cutting spending and new growth.

[Justin Tseng]: The fact is, when we look at all the proposals of things that we could cut in the city budget, it doesn't get anywhere close to $12 million.

[Justin Tseng]: The only way we can get to that $12 million, as Vice President Bears said, is to lay off very essential staff in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: And even with the budget that we have now, even if we didn't have to cut, we are already losing important members of our staff.

[Justin Tseng]: We're already unable to fill very important positions in city government that every other city government in our region has.

[Justin Tseng]: When we talk about new growth, I think all seven of our Councilors here and everyone in city government is behind new growth in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: We want to see us grow our commercial tax base, and we want this to be the first path that we use.

[Justin Tseng]: But the fact of the matter is, because of practicality, even if we have all that new growth immediately, even if we were to sign all these deals tomorrow, we wouldn't be able to get out of the budget crunch that we're going to see for the next year, two years, three years.

[Justin Tseng]: because it takes years for a building to be built.

[Justin Tseng]: It takes years for those investments to be made.

[Justin Tseng]: I understand that this is coming at a very tough time for everyone.

[Justin Tseng]: And I understand that inflation is, you know, an issue that really does hit everyone.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, you look at the gas prices, you look at food, you know, it's evidence, right?

[Justin Tseng]: But these investments are long-term investments that will reap benefits, financial benefits to homeowners and to renters alike, to everyone in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, if we fix our roads, that means we don't have to spend as much on maintenance.

[Justin Tseng]: We don't have to, you know, we might not have to spend the, you know, spend the money that I did recently on fixing a flat, right?

[Justin Tseng]: These savings matter.

[Justin Tseng]: These savings matter.

[Justin Tseng]: And this investment, you know, in my personal opinion, comes at a difficult time.

[Justin Tseng]: I wish it didn't come at this time, but is, you know, an investment that I personally think

[Justin Tseng]: is worth it.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think that whole point doesn't get at the heart of the issue that actually is in front of us tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: The issue that's actually in front of us tonight is whether we send this to the voters, whether we trust the voters with this ask.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe that if you're a yes on this, if you're a no on this, as a councilor, it's our social responsibility to trust the voters with the final decision.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't want to impose my views on the voters.

[Justin Tseng]: And if the voters decide differently than I do, then so be it.

[Justin Tseng]: I trust the voters.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think the same works the vice, vice versa.

[Justin Tseng]: If, you know, if Councilors don't like, don't like this idea, leave it to the voters, trust the voters to decide.

[Justin Tseng]: That's my personal view, because I think, you know, this is a, this is a time where we really need to trust in our residents and we need to really trust in our democracy.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is,

[Justin Tseng]: the fairest, the most neutral path forward, you know, put aside my own personal views on this issue.

[Justin Tseng]: And if I were, you know, coming at it from a completely neutral standpoint, the only fair decision, in my opinion, is to send this to the voters and to trust them with the final decision.

[Justin Tseng]: I hope, you know, I know that many of our residents here tonight are not going to agree with me on what I just said.

[Justin Tseng]: I know that, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: Many will never agree or never come around to our viewpoint, but I hope that you understand where I'm coming from, as I try to understand where everyone comes from.

[Justin Tseng]: I hope that we can speak earnestly and honestly about this issue, and I hope that we can compromise a little bit and find reasonable solutions out of this budget crunch, out of this revenue crisis.

[Justin Tseng]: So thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: Well, yeah, sure.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Vice President Bears.

[Justin Tseng]: This is pretty self-explanatory.

[Justin Tseng]: We talk about curb appeal, we talk about beautification.

[Justin Tseng]: This is something that we can do to make Medford look better, but also to make Medford safer, especially for drivers and pedestrians who use Wellington Circle.

[Justin Tseng]: There are street lights that are knocked down, signs that have been

[Justin Tseng]: not down and not replaced.
