[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I didn't speak too much today because I wanted to make sure the public had a chance to speak, and I didn't want to belabor too many points.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to come before you all here today and tell you about how our city really dreamed big and how we created a budget that really combined ambition and actionability.

[Justin Tseng]: But unfortunately, these last two weeks of budget hearings have been grim.

[Justin Tseng]: Lack of transparency and lack of revenue means that we've been put in a difficult last-minute budget crisis.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and we are we on the council are just as frustrated as you residents are.

[Justin Tseng]: We keep hearing that this is a pandemic problem.

[Justin Tseng]: But the reality is that we're two and a half years to a pandemic that's affected every single city in this Commonwealth and Medford and yet Medford is unique in facing a crisis like this.

[Justin Tseng]: In the past few months that I've been on city council, I've worked particularly hard to foster a friendly and cooperative environment, especially with the mayor's office.

[Justin Tseng]: And I've worked hard to recognize shared priorities, the housing production plan, the comprehensive plan, climate action plan, improving diversity and equity.

[Justin Tseng]: And I've worked very hard to operate in good faith, taking

[Justin Tseng]: you know, even taking some pretty difficult votes, which mainly supported the mayor's priorities.

[Justin Tseng]: I've tried to be reasonable and open-minded with the red lines and requests, making sure that they're, you know, they are actionable, they are achievable.

[Justin Tseng]: And over the last few weeks, I've asked future-focused questions about our department's plans and ambitions to improve our city,

[Justin Tseng]: And the answer through our many, many hours of meetings is clear.

[Justin Tseng]: We have volunteers, we have employees, and we have department heads who are flush with ideas about how we can improve city services, and how we can lift up the standards of living, and how we can ensure that Medford is safe, just, and inclusive.

[Justin Tseng]: But the true Grim Reaper that we face is not a city unwilling to move forward.

[Justin Tseng]: The true Grim Reaper we face are budgets that box us in.

[Justin Tseng]: which is unfortunately what is on the agenda tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: I understand where the mayor's coming from, I understand that this was a difficult budget to put together.

[Justin Tseng]: And I thank the mayor for calling for calling me today and for talking through my concerns.

[Justin Tseng]: you know, we're elected to make difficult choices.

[Justin Tseng]: I've been, I haven't slept more than five hours a night since the beginning of the month.

[Justin Tseng]: But, you know, for the sake of transparency, I do want, I can't conscionably vote yes on this budget.

[Justin Tseng]: you know, there's just some of the simple priorities, right, that we on the council have been talking about, and those on the school committee have asked as basic asks.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, this budget doesn't even really delve into the more ambitious concerns about investments in true community safety, the expanding translation programs, veterans programming, etc.

[Justin Tseng]: Those of you who've tuned into city council meetings before know that at the end of the day, when they take a difficult vote, there's really one question, there's one litmus test for me.

[Justin Tseng]: And that question is, does this improve the lives of the residents of our city?

[Justin Tseng]: You know, the answer tonight is regrettably no.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think this budget as it is would help the longtime resident for whom our roads and sidewalks now pose a challenge to accessibility.

[Justin Tseng]: It wouldn't help the veteran or the new college student coming home who can't afford to settle down here in their hometown.

[Justin Tseng]: And it wouldn't help the renter who's facing an eviction notice.

[Justin Tseng]: It wouldn't necessarily help the parent and child who are catching up on elementary math after two years of the pandemic.

[Justin Tseng]: and it wouldn't help the black, brown, or Asian people in our city who are facing threats of safety and violence.

[Justin Tseng]: We as a council, we're ready for the difficult conversations to get our city back on track.

[Justin Tseng]: And perhaps most importantly, we are ready, and at least personally speaking, I'm excited to work with the city administration to find a way forward.

[Justin Tseng]: But the clock is ticking.

[Justin Tseng]: We have little time to solve a financial conundrum.

[Justin Tseng]: We're, you know, I think everyone's expressed this we just don't we it sucks we don't want to be in this position, but.

[Justin Tseng]: The measures that we've had to take are the only tools that we have as a city council to try to get a budget that's even better for our city.

[Justin Tseng]: This is our only chance for us to build that more ambitious city that we want.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, many of this administration's stated goals and plans are plans that I support and wish to see come true.

[Justin Tseng]: but these plans will remain mere wishes if we don't have the tools to put them into action.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's what I'm asking for.

[Justin Tseng]: Simple, low cost tools that will let us advance our shared priorities.

[Justin Tseng]: I hope in the next few days that we can all work together to get ourselves out of the situation and to advance our shared priorities and goals.

[Justin Tseng]: It's one I'll keep it simple.

[Justin Tseng]: outdated information on there, and if we chip away, hopefully we can fix the most glaring problems on the city website.

[Justin Tseng]: Right now, I was helping someone do some research into our COVID-19 policies, and in the FAQ section, it's just completely outdated.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the information is from probably October of 2020, which is almost two years ago.

[Justin Tseng]: And there's, as I said at the budget meeting, there's a lot of outdated information about where masks should be worn, a lot of outdated information about what's open for visitor entry, what's closed, what the city's policies are, the case count, everything.

[Justin Tseng]: If I could, Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: I, you know, I am one of the newer Councilors here, so I haven't had the pleasure to work with Commissioner Moki as much as the rest of my colleagues have, but in the committee meetings that we have had with them,

[Justin Tseng]: Commissioner Moki has always been a vital resource to us as a council and someone who's brought a wealth of knowledge and who has really helped us shape the work that we do here.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I just wanted to congratulate Commissioner Moki on his retirement.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell, and thank you for putting this on the agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: Essentially h 1234, you know what what it does is it makes a bad situation worse by enshrining it as Councilor Collins said into law.

[Justin Tseng]: If you, if you know, you know, an Uber driver.

[Justin Tseng]: Personally, many of my friends and family friends, drive for Uber or Lyft, you know the working situations are great.

[Justin Tseng]: you, you'll know that, um, you know, they've, they have been tricked, as Councilor Caraville have said and the rhetoric that these big corporations are using doesn't reflect their actual lived reality on the ground.

[Justin Tseng]: And by institutionalizing by legalizing it.

[Justin Tseng]: It makes a bad situation worse.

[Justin Tseng]: If if h 1234 goes through and I encourage people to read the body of the text of this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, drivers might make as little as for $4 82 cents per hour, and those who qualify for a health care site that may earn as little as 674 per hour.

[Justin Tseng]: When we have people making those amounts.

[Justin Tseng]: You know that also puts a strain on our, on our city's resources, and it puts a strain on our, our society as well, because we'll have to do more to as a government to fill in this hole that big corporations are leaving for us.

[Justin Tseng]: We also you know we spend a lot of time talking, both in the chambers and outside of the chambers about equity, but you know, h 1234 and the, the ballot proposition on the proposed the ballot proposition would would you know

[Justin Tseng]: would reverse all the good work that we are doing as a society when it comes to insurance equity.

[Justin Tseng]: This House bill would create an underclass of workers here in Massachusetts that is disproportionately black or brown and disproportionately immigrant, disproportionately working class, disproportionately

[Justin Tseng]: veterans, and you know, this is, this is all things that we should be concerned about as a city and things that affect us in our work is as a city council.

[Justin Tseng]: And so, you know, I, I urge everyone to do your research on this issue to read this resolution and not and not to be tricked by the big corporations that are running ads on TV, and on YouTube that you see all the time.

[Justin Tseng]: And

[Justin Tseng]: I think, again I think President moral for putting this on the agenda because it's just so important that we address this.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: Essentially, the U.S.

[Justin Tseng]: Supreme Court decided a few weeks ago in a case called Shurtleff v. City of Austin that the city has to be careful when it comes to approving or denying what flags can go up on government property.

[Justin Tseng]: Essentially, the most important lessons for us is that we either have to have a stated policy where we say that our flagpoles and our places for banners on city property

[Justin Tseng]: constitute governmental speech, or we just have to allow everyone to essentially be able to apply and use those platforms for speech.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, a lot of this has to be done through our law department, our legal department, they'll have to be the ones looking at

[Justin Tseng]: looking at the policies but I think it would be good for our city for our city council to be updated and to be able to have a voice in terms of what policies are being developed in response to the shortlist decision.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this is just a simple resolution asking the city administration to give us an update as to what it's doing in this case, before we get into any legal trouble.

[Justin Tseng]: I, I'm sure many many residents of the city of have now seen the bus network redesign proposal, but I wanted to put this on the agenda so that we got this the word out to you the more people.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, attempts to resolve this have not been successful.

[Justin Tseng]: Every municipality is different.

[Justin Tseng]: And for us to tackle Medford's problems, we will also need to know what is going on in our city better.

[Justin Tseng]: I've actually had school committee members reach out to me

[Justin Tseng]: and want to cooperate on this issue.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I'm optimistic that we can make progress on these issues going forward.

[Justin Tseng]: what are the steps that our city can take when it comes to those, especially when it comes to those young residents who fall outside of the public schools purview.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm thinking especially of our residents who are from the ages of 18 to 29, and to see what are some basic steps that our city can take to improve the mental health of young people living here.

[Justin Tseng]: My name is Justin Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm from Medford, Massachusetts.

[Justin Tseng]: I am in the class of 2022, and I study social studies and East Asian studies.

[Justin Tseng]: Growing up in Medford is actually a very rewarding experience because I find Medford very salt of the earth.

[Justin Tseng]: It's also very diverse.

[Justin Tseng]: And so you grow up with people who, neighbors who look different from you and who have different lived experiences from you.

[Justin Tseng]: That I think really broadens our world perspective.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's why I decided to run for office is because I think that that lived experience is super important for our politicians and our leaders to know about and to take into account when they're creating policy for a city.

[Justin Tseng]: Even if I wasn't going to win the election, it was important for me to step in there to try my best to shape the conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: They're still core issues to me.

[Justin Tseng]: But then you have the daily issues at City Hall, legal services or budgeting, the services we provide for our residents.

[Justin Tseng]: And so for me, the way to kind of marry these two sets of priorities is to really apply the issues that I've run on as a lens to the daily workings of City Hall.

[Justin Tseng]: When it comes to racial justice and racial equity, for me it's about seeing, you know, what is the city doing now in terms of providing services and how can we make those services more equitable.

[Justin Tseng]: I decided to run NOW as a student because I really think that I can bring a lens to the issue, a perspective on the issue, that really takes advantage of the now.

[Justin Tseng]: I looked in the mirror and I realized if we didn't take advantage of the moment in terms of responding to climate change, in terms of responding to racial justice issues in Medford, I would feel like we missed an opportunity there.

[Justin Tseng]: As we all know, we are facing a climate emergency, not only in our city, but this is a problem that affects every single one of us.

[Justin Tseng]: How can we, in the next two years, tangibly improve our school system?

[Justin Tseng]: And how can we relieve that financial pressure off of our families when it comes to paying rent and being pushed out of our city?

[Justin Tseng]: My hope is that in the next two years, we'll be able to address some of these issues.

[Justin Tseng]: The truth is, change takes a while, but I'm optimistic that we're heading in the right direction.

[Justin Tseng]: being one of these, you know, there's certain people you see in the chamber every week and as a new Councilor, it's those people that make you feel welcome and help you ease into the position.

[Justin Tseng]: And Kinga, you've really helped me personally ease into this job and learn more about, you know, what it is like to be a Councilor just by talking to you.

[Justin Tseng]: We'll miss you a lot.

[Justin Tseng]: It really is a shame that

[Justin Tseng]: corporate interests have decided that local news is going by the wayside.

[Justin Tseng]: Because, I mean, as as Councilor various has put it, going back into the archives can be an amazing experience.

[Justin Tseng]: Speaking as someone who comes from the academic realm, someone who works with historians and works with activists, it's actually the historical archives that teach you so much about social movements, about economics, about politics, about what works today and what lessons that we can drop in the past.

[Justin Tseng]: Actually, a really great example of this is I was in South Carolina right before the pandemic,

[Justin Tseng]: And there's a lot of organizing there about a local issue, where they're, you know, redeveloping all these condos.

[Justin Tseng]: And the grounds that they're trying to redevelop is actually historically black.

[Justin Tseng]: And by redeveloping the grounds, they're massively altering the environment that used to exist there, that black residents have lived off of for years, and all this alterations caused flooding and all of that.

[Justin Tseng]: But what struck me most on that trip was when I talked to the local activists, when I asked them, how did you even,

[Justin Tseng]: think about organizing around this issue, or how did you even come to care about this issue?

[Justin Tseng]: It was really, their answer was going back to look at local news back in the 1920s and 1930s, looking at the microfilms.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that experience really taught me how valuable local news coverage is to our future.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not even just about next Sunday or next week, it's about 2080.

[Justin Tseng]: 2180, right, like when people are looking back at Medford and they're learning about, through local news, they have a chance to learn about what our community looked like and they have a chance to learn about, you know, what has changed in the last X number of years.

[Justin Tseng]: they have a chance to learn about what environmental justice looks like in our community.

[Justin Tseng]: They have a chance to look at what economics looks like in our community, or what businesses, or even just social, you know, like who's playing at what baseball game.

[Justin Tseng]: And it really is a shame that that is going away.

[Justin Tseng]: It's really, speaking as someone who works with archival material, it's just really a shame that we're not gonna have that in the future.

[Justin Tseng]: I just saw that there are a few people in the audience here and I believe on Zoom who are here to talk about the SOI, the statement of interest.

[Justin Tseng]: I was wondering if I could motion to take this out of order.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you so much for coming to the city council meeting to present.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, you know, being a recent student from there, I can attest to how great the education in the building is but I think a lot of people, they you know they see the building, and they don't realize how you know how great our education there is which leads to this problem of outflow.

[Justin Tseng]: And, and there's also the problem that you've mentioned in the statement of interest that, you know, with around a third of the classrooms not having natural light with the, what you describe as a bleak environment that students feel and I, as someone who's gone there recently I can definitely tell you that this is what most students there feel.

[Justin Tseng]: the education that we could be giving to our Children.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and it sounds like, um, given the merger of the two schools to that there are, you know, there are significant, um,

[Justin Tseng]: differences in programming between what we could could be offering to our kids versus what we are currently offering to our kids.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think these are important points to bring out in this meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: I also I just thought this statement of interest was very well put together and I wanted to quickly bring up some points that you guys have brought up so that

[Justin Tseng]: our residents of the city could also hear them.

[Justin Tseng]: But you mentioned that there's suboptimal ADA accessibility, fire safety, security, and technological aspects.

[Justin Tseng]: And with the security point, you explained that while the school is a safe environment, sometimes the age of the building does pose some challenges compared to what we could optimally be having in the building.

[Justin Tseng]: You've, you've discussed the environmental aspects of this, the challenge of the institution right now as well, where MHS is estimated to be expending 77% more energy than an average American school facility which is really shocking.

[Justin Tseng]: And you've also mentioned that there are considerable challenges with respects to the cost and removal of hazardous material when it comes to air filtration, which we all I think now realize is such a priority for all of us.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think you really bring out the point in this report that

[Justin Tseng]: there are costs to the renovations that we need to keep this building in operation.

[Justin Tseng]: And so if we are constantly renovating bit by piece without a grand scheme, without a grand plan, which we would need estimates for, we could be spending more money in the future than if we actually had an actual plan.

[Justin Tseng]: And so that's another reason why I think absolutely approving this tonight is so important, right, because it actually is fiscally prudent, if we can get a bigger picture if we can get all the information that we can get from MSBA to know, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: to know what should we be spending on?

[Justin Tseng]: How much is it gonna cost?

[Justin Tseng]: And compared to not going on with this plan, what does that look like?

[Justin Tseng]: So I think you did a really good, your office did a really great job with presenting that in this report.

[Justin Tseng]: You also have described wildly fluctuating temperatures and relocation of classrooms, I think, and malfunctioning HVAC systems.

[Justin Tseng]: I think you really capture

[Justin Tseng]: for I think all residents in the city, the real gravity of the situation in that building and the urgency of action.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I just wanted to bring those points out because I thought this was very well put together.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think all of our residents deserve a chance to hear what you've put in this report.

[Justin Tseng]: totally agree with all everything that's been said.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it'd be valuable for us to look at such a program again.

[Justin Tseng]: Obviously, they're gonna be flooded with requests, but I think it could be a good idea to expand such a program to make it prominent on our website.

[Justin Tseng]: know a question of miss you know mismatch we I think we have people who are willing to shovel for for others, willing to be paid by the, if the city's willing to pay them.

[Justin Tseng]: I remember very fondly how Mrs. Lasky, who I had as my fourth grade elementary school teacher, brought Mr. Lasky to our class, and he talked to us about the NWRA, talked to us about his job,

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you so much President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: So this resolution is something that I was proud to submit with my fellow South Medford Councilor, Councilor Kit Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, this is when I knocked on doors in this neighborhood and in my home neighborhood,

[Justin Tseng]: This was something that came up, basically at every single door.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, there, I don't think it's an exaggeration to say that the issue salience was off off the records was off the charts.

[Justin Tseng]: When you when you walk down these kind of these.

[Justin Tseng]: cut through streets, as they're called, you realize how fast the cars go down them and how heavy the traffic is during rush hour.

[Justin Tseng]: And this poses a threat to the safety of the residents in those neighborhoods when it comes to something as simple as walking across the street.

[Justin Tseng]: And it actually is a problem for accessibility as well.

[Justin Tseng]: So, on the front on the matters of pedestrian safety when it comes to speed, when it comes to just the mere quality of the streets.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that this is a super important issue for a neighborhood that's been a little bit overlooked over the last few years.

[Justin Tseng]: The proposals, I've suggested the city look at are things that neighbors have written to me and emails in recent weeks, asking us to ask, asking us to explore, you know, they might not be the solutions but I think it's worth having our city.

[Justin Tseng]: Look into some of the proposals that our neighbors have brought up.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Justin Tseng]: So the context behind this resolution is this 2020 Massachusetts Uniform Citation Data Analysis Report, which is a super long name.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's why I'll call it the report.

[Justin Tseng]: This is a project that the state government put out there.

[Justin Tseng]: They found researchers from, I believe, Salem State and Framingham State.

[Justin Tseng]: to comb through data from almost every single municipality in Massachusetts to look at, you know, what is the relationship between race and ethnicity and the frequency of traffic stops and the outcome of traffic stops.

[Justin Tseng]: And what this report found was that in Medford, there's no statistically significant correlation between race and stops.

[Justin Tseng]: But there is a statistically significant relationship between race and stop outcomes.

[Justin Tseng]: And this report is very clear that this is not about blame.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not about labeling people as racist or anything.

[Justin Tseng]: This race could just, bias could be one of many, many, many reasons for why this is the case.

[Justin Tseng]: But what it does say is that there is a reason, there must be a reason why Black and Hispanic individuals are subject to different traffic stop outcomes.

[Justin Tseng]: And that this is not something that we can just say is a coincidence.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not something that we can put down to chance.

[Justin Tseng]: It is something that actually

[Justin Tseng]: has a cause.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this, this resolution is really about public safety.

[Justin Tseng]: It's really about building trust in in our law enforcement building trust in our city government to do what's right and to do what's fair for everyone.

[Justin Tseng]: We there it's it's no secret that that

[Justin Tseng]: police and racer sensitive issues.

[Justin Tseng]: They have been sensitive issues, especially in the last two years.

[Justin Tseng]: And part of how we should move forward as a community and how this report, this nonpartisan report puts it is that we need to build trust in our government again.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to rebuild that trust.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to rebuild trust in our law enforcement.

[Justin Tseng]: And the only way to do that is to be honest about, to have an honest conversation about

[Justin Tseng]: this data and to have an honest conversation about possible explanations for these disparities.

[Justin Tseng]: And so again, this is not about placing blame.

[Justin Tseng]: This is not about labeling people names or saying that something is necessarily bad.

[Justin Tseng]: This is about addressing this statistically significant data point and in taking the state's advice and how we should move forward and make our community safer.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not about stops.

[Justin Tseng]: It's about the outcomes in stock.

[Justin Tseng]: So it's not about the stocks.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, I mean, one of the one of the points in this resolution is the word are the words triggering offenses.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, the report tells us that we really in order to dig into these numbers and to explain the statistical relationships, we have to consider triggering offenses is one of the possible explanations right so it totally in this report is really clear it

[Justin Tseng]: There are many, many, many outcomes in this world where this is not actually about bias.

[Justin Tseng]: And that is exactly why we need to release more data.

[Justin Tseng]: That's exactly why we need to publish more data.

[Justin Tseng]: and make it transparent and open.

[Justin Tseng]: And when it comes to the word bias, this is how the report itself was written.

[Justin Tseng]: I've actually modified the language of the report to be more, I think, representative of how I think of the good character of the people working for a city and to make it less hostile and to make it more reasonable.

[Justin Tseng]: But I

[Justin Tseng]: I'll leave it there.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of the skepticism, I think, of this resolution is actually just resolved within the resolution itself.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's important, I think it's important to keep in mind that the report is actually good news if we're just looking at people being stopped because there is no statistical correlation between, there's no statistically significant relationship between the race of people being stopped in Medford and the traffic stops themselves.

[Justin Tseng]: It's more about the outcome, right?

[Justin Tseng]: you know, it's totally possible that triggering offenses could be the reason why, but that's exactly why we need to ask the police chief to dig into the data, as Councilor Bears, as Councilor Sparkoli said, in order to give us the transparency and give us that confidence in our own city's functioning.

[Justin Tseng]: So, I think this, this resolution does ask us to take a very holistic and very open minded view on this and, and, you know, again, that's why, that's why we asked about more transparent data that's why we were asking about triggering offenses, why we're asking that duration of stops.

[Justin Tseng]: et cetera, because, you know, I think it's important to go into this process with a holistic lens.

[Justin Tseng]: I think most, if not all of us are asking for the same thing, which is that, you know, the police chief just look into this and I trust the police chief.

[Justin Tseng]: I think the police chief would also be happy to do this.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, I'll leave this with a metaphor.

[Justin Tseng]: you know, when you walk into the doctor's office and the doctor sees something, asks you to get it checked out, you get it checked out because you trust the doctor, right?

[Justin Tseng]: The science is clear and you just, you know, it could be something, it could be nothing, but you trust the doctor because it could be something.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, this very well could be nothing, but I think this is when we go see that specialist and we go get this checked out.

[Justin Tseng]: I can offer a summary.

[Justin Tseng]: So this is a resolution that Haitian American community leaders actually reached out to me about putting on the agenda.

[Justin Tseng]: Let me walk through it first and then talk a little bit more about that.

[Justin Tseng]: Essentially, Boston, Metro Boston is home to the third largest Haitian diaspora in our country.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, the Haitian American community has been so vital to Medford in terms of its contributions to our workforce, to the economy and to the culture, general culture of our city.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, the Census Bureau I just looked this up on right before I submitted this resolution estimated in 29 late in around 2019 that I'm 7.9% of Medford's population was of Haitian descent.

[Justin Tseng]: And so, the, the immigration policy started during the Trump administration and continued under the Biden administration affects Medford disproportionately.

[Justin Tseng]: When we, when we look at what these policies are the policies that deportation.

[Justin Tseng]: This section of the report actually goes into language from both political and civil rights leaders, civil liberties leaders as well.

[Justin Tseng]: They cite our international, US, our national law and international law in saying that these Title 42 deportations are actually unconstitutional and illegal.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this is a resolution of support, which I think is especially important during Black History Month.

[Justin Tseng]: Support for our Haitian migrants who live in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: Support to make sure that they're not deported to a place where they barely know, to make sure that they're not deported to a place

[Justin Tseng]: of political, social, and economic strife, and a statement of support saying that we are a place of refuge and that Medford is a safe place for each and every single one of our community members.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm very well aware that this resolution

[Justin Tseng]: may well not have, you know, a national impact, but I think it's, I think that it's vital that we show our support for Asian neighbors.

[Justin Tseng]: And, and so talking a little bit more about how this resolution came to be, I talked to Councilor, Ruth see illusion in Boston.

[Justin Tseng]: who is who's working on the coalition to build a coalition of communities to express their support for the Haitian community and to ask the Biden administration to consider reversing their this illegal immigration policy.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, you know, I think it's important.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it's vital for us to show that we are a place that's willing to accept and celebrate our diversity and to and again,

[Justin Tseng]: to create public trust in our institutions with a population that's so important to our city's fabric.

[Justin Tseng]: And if you will indulge me, I just wanted to send a short message to our Haitian American community here in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't speak Haitian Creole, but I speak a little bit of French and I will translate it for the record.

[Justin Tseng]: So what I said was, I wish, I want to make it known that to the whole world and

[Justin Tseng]: in particular, our Haitian community here in Medford, that it's important for us that Medford is a city where we all feel safe, and that Medford is a city that's welcoming to all.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to,

[Justin Tseng]: start to wrap things up with some of my thinking, kind of response to some of what we've heard tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: When I first

[Justin Tseng]: I got this idea like when I first got a draft of what other communities were passing.

[Justin Tseng]: I too was a little skeptical given how, you know, obviously symbolic and ceremonial it can be.

[Justin Tseng]: But, as Mr. Navarre has mentioned, then I learned more about this project.

[Justin Tseng]: I learned more about how it was really grassroots effort that's happening in many, many communities around the area.

[Justin Tseng]: But also not just around the area.

[Justin Tseng]: This is an effort happening in other metro areas where there are a lot of Haitian-Americans as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And Mr. Nabarro mentioned Representative Pressley's letter, or bringing it up with President Biden.

[Justin Tseng]: She's also been spearheaded an effort to send a letter, which dozens and dozens of Congress people have signed, to the president.

[Justin Tseng]: these leaders, these congressional leaders have worked closely with Haitian American leaders and they've decided that this is the right step for our community.

[Justin Tseng]: Who am I to say that their strategy is wrong, right?

[Justin Tseng]: They've obviously thought about it a lot.

[Justin Tseng]: We can't deny them of their own agency.

[Justin Tseng]: And then I thought back to

[Justin Tseng]: Um, two years ago, I guess a year and a half ago, where, um, you know, our city council was also looking at some more symbolic resolutions.

[Justin Tseng]: And I thought back to when I was watching city council meetings and when I realized, you know, I know these resolutions are symbolic, but they're important to me, and it's important that it was important to me that our city council.

[Justin Tseng]: Number one, introduce something.

[Justin Tseng]: Number two, passed something that was symbolic.

[Justin Tseng]: Because to me, and I think to a lot of people who don't necessarily see themselves represented at the public forum, symbolism is the first step to action, right?

[Justin Tseng]: And in this case, our city council can't act on much.

[Justin Tseng]: But passing something ceremonial, passing something symbolic,

[Justin Tseng]: was an important indicator to me that I could trust my city government when I needed it behind my back.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think this is what people in our community and people in the Haitian American community are asking for is, can I trust my government to act on even simple symbolic measures?

[Justin Tseng]: Because if you aren't willing to do the symbolic, you probably aren't willing to take real action.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I thought back to that, and then I thought, you know what, this is the right thing to introduce.

[Justin Tseng]: I've also, I guess, I want to end with an anecdote.

[Justin Tseng]: I've spent much of my week talking to very close family friends in Ukraine, in Kiev, who are people who would likely be targeted if a Russian invasion were to target Kiev, right?

[Justin Tseng]: And in talking to them, it was astonishing to see how little they wanted to flee, and how little they wanted to leave their homes, their jobs, their family, their pets, everything that they had.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, now the situation is different, and the planning of leaving itself is a logistical nightmare.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, this isn't me going through the migrant experience, but then I think I thought back to Haitian migrants who moved to Medford, and I thought back to how much they must not have wanted to leave, even though the circumstances were not great.

[Justin Tseng]: I thought back to how difficult it must have been for them to get to a new place, number one, and number two, settle in a new place.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's important that our community show them anything it can, even if it is symbolic.

[Justin Tseng]: Just to say, we're behind you, we're standing with you, and you can trust us.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to put on the record that, um, you know what I was saying was, was, was, was just an argument for why, even if it's ceremonial I think we should pass it.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't question anyone's intentions here.

[Justin Tseng]: I think I'm actually very fortunate to work with colleagues

[Justin Tseng]: each of whom has done a lot for our marginalized communities here at Medford, every single one of us at this table.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's something that a lot of people don't necessarily see, but each and every one of us behind the scenes has worked to engage more residents in our community that are traditionally excluded from our decision-making process.

[Justin Tseng]: So I just wanted to put that on the record.

[Justin Tseng]: I respect the healthy debate that we're having about resolutions,

[Justin Tseng]: such as these, but this one in particular.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to put that out there that I'm not, I want everyone to know that I am fortunate to work with good colleagues who've done a lot for all of our communities here.

[Justin Tseng]: take a deep look at this, make sure that everything in here makes sense and that we have the support of everyone on here.

[Justin Tseng]: There's some decisions that are so important that they do require a lot of support from our council, not just the majority vote.

[Justin Tseng]: From what I'm hearing, I think everyone is bringing up good points.

[Justin Tseng]: There are accessibility problems, and then we can look to other cities.

[Justin Tseng]: working class families, families of color, LGBTQ folks, these are people who suffer the most from hunger in our society and this is a human right, to be fed is a human right.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, you know, this is a, it's a win win for everyone really.

[Justin Tseng]: Um, and so I'd like to see what the city is playing in terms of helping us close that gap as well.

[Justin Tseng]: members of our community to ask for some transparency, to ask for some oversight as well.

[Justin Tseng]: No.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay.

[Justin Tseng]: I also support this resolution.

[Justin Tseng]: I thank my fellow councillor for bringing this forward.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, I've, like Councilor Scarpelli, I've worked with and grew up with a lot of, you know, friends who are undocumented and I know how difficult it is for them to, you know, just live as normal human beings in our society.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, especially as we've all, as I've kind of

[Justin Tseng]: become more of a leader in the community, a lot of people ask me, can I use this resource without being told that I might be deported one day?

[Justin Tseng]: Can I turn to the police?

[Justin Tseng]: Can I turn to fire?

[Justin Tseng]: Can I turn to a state resource?

[Justin Tseng]: What can I apply for?

[Justin Tseng]: And it becomes confusing.

[Justin Tseng]: And a lot of this stuff affects all of us, right?

[Justin Tseng]: If we're thinking about public health,

[Justin Tseng]: We are all healthier if all of us have access to services.

[Justin Tseng]: We're all safer if all of us feel comfortable reporting, you know, reporting incidents.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think it's very important that we support this.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I wanted to first note my colleagues' concerns about us introducing these resolutions in support of state legislation, but I wanted to say, just in full transparency, that on my end, I had a conversation with Representative Christine Barber about this, and she asked me to come to the council to ask for our support on this specific bill.

[Justin Tseng]: And this is a good bill because I think it would, or let me just lay it out very, very clearly.

[Justin Tseng]: This bill would electrify MBTA and RTA, commuter rail service, and the bus fleet by the year 2035.

[Justin Tseng]: Studies have shown that this bill would reduce the CO2 emissions by millions of pounds.

[Justin Tseng]: And this bill would also create a standardized assessment system to measure air quality in our communities.

[Justin Tseng]: This bill would benefit Medford because we have, we have bus service in the city, we have a commuter rail station that goes through West Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: And air quality is all has always been an issue when it comes to transit when it comes to bus and commuter rail service.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this is, you know, this aligns with our communities values aligns with addressing our communities concerns and aligns with our communities already stated goals.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, um, many members of our community every shot to me over the course of campaign but also as a Councilor, asking to see our city, you know, even showed the symbolic steps to toward towards supporting diversity and equity in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this is one of those.

[Justin Tseng]: those pieces, those resolutions that reflect what constituents have been telling me.

[Justin Tseng]: I think, you know, this aligns with our community's values.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, we are an anti-racist community.

[Justin Tseng]: We are a diverse community.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think our community has been making a lot of steps forward in terms of talking about Black history, addressing racism in our community.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, I think we've made strides

[Justin Tseng]: together and talking earnestly and honestly about the two ideologies, racism and white supremacy, whose historical and sociological effects seep into the structures that shape our society.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, these aren't things that are, you know, these

[Justin Tseng]: are targeted at any community in particular, you know, it's not just it's not just you know it's not a white person issue this is something that you know happens in the Asian community as well that I know very well of.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this is about all of us kind of coming together saying.

[Justin Tseng]: telling history as it is because it's important to learn from our past, it's important to celebrate our past as well, because that's where we find unity is in telling the truth about about our city and about our history and, you know, looking positively towards the future to see how we move on.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to say that I'm happy to accept the amendments as proposed by Councilor Bears and the one on civics as proposed by Councilor Scarpelli.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, this is in line with residents who want to see our city more openly embracing our diversity and our different communities here.

[Justin Tseng]: Lunar New Year is the most important holiday for many Asian communities here in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, it's not, not just the Chinese holiday, it's one that's celebrated by many other communities as well by Koreans, by Vietnamese Americans, by Tibetan Americans, by Taiwanese Americans, and the list goes on and on.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, I wanted to note that this, this New Year's might be

[Justin Tseng]: particularly difficult, you know, we're still dealing with the pandemic, and it's traditional, it's kind of like an Asian Thanksgiving where you go into your family.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, for a lot of families are not able to make it back for, you know, be it.

[Justin Tseng]: they're sick, it's difficult to, the difficult situations to leave the country or the difficult situations to get into another country.

[Justin Tseng]: And so, you know, I think it's especially important for us to kind of lift each other up in this moment and to celebrate with each other.

[Justin Tseng]: A holiday which, you know, a holiday season which might be a little bit tougher for folks now.

[Justin Tseng]: I believe that last year there were there were reported incidents of this city council in the last session.

[Justin Tseng]: Right.

[Justin Tseng]: I think you know this is a general rise, that's consistent with that trend that we saw last year, you know.

[Justin Tseng]: Medford is a safe community, we are safe for Asian Americans but there are moments where it might be difficult and I think it's important for our city council to, to note that there are definitely, you know, anti Asian incidents that are often gone on reported.

[Justin Tseng]: a lot of people don't know about our city's reporting resources, be it with the police or with our city departments.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I also want to make that clear just for all of our residents here that there are different ways to report hate crimes or hate incidents if that happens to you, God forbid.

[Justin Tseng]: And yeah, I would say that

[Justin Tseng]: My short answer is that there's a general increase in the Boston metro area.

[Justin Tseng]: Mr. President, I can offer a summary.

[Justin Tseng]: I can offer a summary.

[Justin Tseng]: Well, so essentially this, this resolution is about the practice of data disaggregation.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I'll give a little bit of history on it, explain the policy, explain the policy and why I've written it this way, and explain why I'm doing it now and then explain why, where where we should go as a city with it with the resolution part.

[Justin Tseng]: So,

[Justin Tseng]: Going about the history, the OMB, the Office of Management and Budget, in 1997 created five racial categories for government agencies to report.

[Justin Tseng]: Now this is a standard that different government agencies in our country are expected to follow.

[Justin Tseng]: But they did allow this guidance, give states and municipalities the prerogative to break our data down even further and to be more specific in the way that we report our data.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this is something that, particularly in civil rights circles, in Asian American activist circles, and activist circles for different racial groups, this is something that's particularly important because

[Justin Tseng]: Racial data informs how we make policy decisions, it informs how we use funds, how we target communities in pandemic outreach and kind of different government city services as well.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know for certain that our city has been working, has been using racial data to help

[Justin Tseng]: help solve the vaccine gap issue to help address disparities in the pandemic response.

[Justin Tseng]: Now, so basically what this policy is, is that

[Justin Tseng]: We would, instead of, for example, take Asian Americans, instead of reporting it as solely Asian Americans, we will break that down into different communities, different racial and ethnic groups that the census has come up with to better help us identify trends within different racial groups.

[Justin Tseng]: The way that we currently report data actually covers up and papers over a lot of inequities within communities as well.

[Justin Tseng]: When you look at the poverty rate for Asian Americans in this country, I don't think you would expect that the poverty rate for Vietnamese Americans is 2.5 times the national average, that the rate of poverty for Hmong Americans is three times the national average.

[Justin Tseng]: When you look at English proficiency rates, you'll find that while English proficiency rates for Vietnamese Americans is low, those for Indian Americans are high.

[Justin Tseng]: And so these are things that just don't come out of the research that our city is doing, that cities generally in our country are doing.

[Justin Tseng]: They affect the city services right because if you have, if our city's targeting, you know, we need to provide city services in this language or publish this brochure in another language.

[Justin Tseng]: We're not thinking about fiscally is it actually does it actually make fiscal sense to spend that money on that translation not on another translation.

[Justin Tseng]: Does it, does it, you know, our is our targeting of one community.

[Justin Tseng]: Does that actually make sense fiscally and in terms of where we're spending our money.

[Justin Tseng]: And so, this, I'm this resolution calls for city administration to cause for us to ask our city ministrations to disaggregate data.

[Justin Tseng]: because I know this will take a while, I know it will take planning and it'll take resources over a few years.

[Justin Tseng]: That's why I've asked our cities to submit a report looking at long-term, what are the costs?

[Justin Tseng]: What are the benefits?

[Justin Tseng]: How else can we kind of affect change in data collection and data analysis?

[Justin Tseng]: How can we make it fairer and more transparent?

[Justin Tseng]: And so I think this revolution starts the conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: that will help us plan over a long term, what, you know, what, what our city needs to do to what does our city need to do in order to

[Justin Tseng]: disaggregate our data?

[Justin Tseng]: How do we get the community involved in this?

[Justin Tseng]: How can we get different departments involved in this?

[Justin Tseng]: This is really about starting that conversation.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, given our conversations about Asian American activism, I think that it is our Asian American issues in town.

[Justin Tseng]: I think it is a good time to also back that up with some action.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this is, this is the resolution, essentially.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm happy to answer questions.

[Justin Tseng]: I should also note, I forgot to mention that the reason why this is worded the way it is, is because this is taking from city council resolutions bits and pieces that apply to us, our community.

[Justin Tseng]: I've taken from different communities across the country and from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts as well, because there is a piece of legislation in the state legislature that is talking about this issue as well, which will affect

[Justin Tseng]: which would help if passed, which would help our city's data collection system.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: This state bill, this state house bill, is very similar to what we just passed.

[Justin Tseng]: It essentially is also about data desegregation for different communities at the state level.

[Justin Tseng]: This has been something that people have been fighting for.

[Justin Tseng]: As Councilor Bears did mention before, you know, the deadline week is this week.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think it's important if we are moving forward as a city, we ask the state to move forward as well, because that will also help us cut down on our resources if we choose to move forward with such a policy.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to add my voice to the chorus.

[Justin Tseng]: I know this is a difficult issue.

[Justin Tseng]: I know it takes resources, but I was just at the high school last week for a meeting and many students and teachers did bring that up to me as well.

[Justin Tseng]: I find the records in order and I move to approve.

[Justin Tseng]: All right, both in terms of transparency and in terms of community participation, I think this measure is important.

[Justin Tseng]: I also think it's helpful for our community when we have more people participating so they can give us their ideas and help us reach more innovative solutions.

[Justin Tseng]: So I definitely support this.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you for introducing this.

[Justin Tseng]: I know there are constituents out there who may be skeptical, right, of given national trends or national discussions, but I think we should look at the history here in our city, and we should look at the fact that our cars are over 100,000, you know, the mileage is over 100,000.

[Justin Tseng]: Those are the new ones.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: And so, and 100,000 for clarity is usually the median of where cars start to be, patrol vehicles start to be replaced.

[Justin Tseng]: And so, in order, you know, I think this is a reasonable request, although if the council would be so amenable, if, if you'd be able to amend this to say that we come up with a that the city administration come up with the capital, a complete capital plan.

[Justin Tseng]: Great.

[Justin Tseng]: And as a second amendment of mine would be to make sure that we are

[Justin Tseng]: exploring patrol vehicle policies.

[Justin Tseng]: This is something I've done a little bit of research on just looking into this.

[Justin Tseng]: It seems that in municipalities across the country, the cities have negotiated deals with police unions, with the police officers where, you know, the police have a little bit more agency and a little bit more initiative.

[Justin Tseng]: And this research has shown that

[Justin Tseng]: the longevity of patrol vehicles is longer and that cities save up on costs a little bit more.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm talking about cities, Miami is a very big example of one, but these policies are pretty common in the Midwest and the South.

[Justin Tseng]: And I would just ask that the city administration explore some of these policies.

[Justin Tseng]: We don't have to adopt anything, but I think it'd be worth our time to explore.

[Justin Tseng]: Right, no problem.

[Justin Tseng]: I've shared my reservations about this last week.

[Justin Tseng]: I've been thinking about it, and I do agree with my fellow councilors that our city needs a better plan.

[Justin Tseng]: Our city needs, our city council needs its own direct legal counsel to go to.

[Justin Tseng]: But again, I believe that we've been pushing this back and pushing this back.

[Justin Tseng]: There's so much in action in the city.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: And in this case, I will vote to move this forward.

[Justin Tseng]: But again, I would like to express that I have strong reservations about passing a budget this calendar year that doesn't have a direct legal representative for us, for the city council.

[Justin Tseng]: I want to thank Councilor Knight for bringing this forward and thank both Councilors Knight and Scarpelli for what they've said so far tonight.

[Justin Tseng]: Again, this I think would be a great program for veterans in our city.

[Justin Tseng]: I also think that this is about giving back to those who served us.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this is also about

[Justin Tseng]: justice and equity as well.

[Justin Tseng]: We know for a fact that those who serve our country are disproportionately working class, disproportionately people of color, disproportionately marginalized.

[Justin Tseng]: We know that when they come back from service, that we as a society don't always treat them the way that they should be treated.

[Justin Tseng]: Our government isn't always there to support them, to give them the support they deserve.

[Justin Tseng]: And so this, I think, is a step in the right direction, and I will be voting in favor of this.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Justin Tseng]: Just wanted to agree, and just note that this is also an environmental issue, the amount of pollution that's out there.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Councilor Collins.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tseng?

[Justin Tseng]: It's difficult to follow up such an eloquent explanation of this resolution, but I just wanted to give a little bit of anecdotal experience about growing up here in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: As someone who came from a different faith and cultural background, it wasn't always easy.

[Justin Tseng]: And you know, you would never, you

[Justin Tseng]: You wouldn't always have accurate depictions of your culture or the culture in which you grew up in.

[Justin Tseng]: But I am happy that our city has been making progress on this front over the last decade, especially.

[Justin Tseng]: And I just wanted to acknowledge that there's still a lot of work to be done.

[Justin Tseng]: And our, you know, communities of faith or cultural communities, ethnic communities here are counting on us to be the leaders in making sure that we get this right and that we build a city that's as inclusive as possible.

[Justin Tseng]: There's a lot that we haven't talked about as a city that I think merits discussion.

[Justin Tseng]: Antisemitism is one of those topics.

[Justin Tseng]: We've had recorded incidents of antisemitism in this city, of antisemitic attacks, violence, depictions.

[Justin Tseng]: Very unfortunately, we've had swastikas carved into fence posts and public spaces here.

[Justin Tseng]: and it's time for us to step up and address all these issues.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I'm, you know, we're, Councilor Collins and I are here today to make sure that, to reaffirm the work that our city is doing so far and to make sure that we are moving forward and we're challenging ourselves to move as inclusive a direction as possible.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Justin Tseng]: Last week we hit in our state record highs in terms of COVID-19 cases.

[Justin Tseng]: And even though we know that the circumstances are different from where we were two years ago, there are still community concerns about

[Justin Tseng]: on the spread of COVID-19 and the risk that this poses to our senior citizens living in senior living facilities here.

[Justin Tseng]: And so, especially given previous records, both in the city and nationally.

[Justin Tseng]: And so I propose this resolution to make sure that we are all informed as a community as to what our city is doing to make sure that our senior citizens are as safe as possible.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Caraviello.

[Justin Tseng]: Councilor Tsai.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Justin Tseng]: We know that Omicron is a more transmissible variant.

[Justin Tseng]: We're seeing the results of that in our case count today.

[Justin Tseng]: We also today, the CDC officials have confirmed that they are looking at updating mask guidance to recommend N95 and KN95 masks be worn.

[Justin Tseng]: And experts at top medical institutions have raised

[Justin Tseng]: this issue that we should be we should be distributing more KN95 masks to everyone and making sure that we are wearing these more protective masks.

[Justin Tseng]: You know it's given given all of these all the recent recommendations and given the possible change in guidance from the CDC.

[Justin Tseng]: It's going to be harder and harder to secure masks.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, it's already difficult for many people to figure out what's a counterfeit mask and what's not to secure those orders online.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm proposing this because I think we need to keep our workers safe.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we need to keep us all safe.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we need to mitigate the financial burden that mask buying can pose to a lot of working class families in this town.

[Justin Tseng]: And I also believe that if we are asking people to mask as a city, we should give them the means to do so.

[Justin Tseng]: And again, we need to address the problem of counterfeits, which is why I added the line about the National Institute for Occupational Safety.

[Justin Tseng]: We, I left out N95 masks because currently CDC guidance does not recommend that we stockpile N95 masks because they are, they should be treated as priority for medical staff.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to be transparent about that point and explain why this resolution focuses on KN95 masks.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Justin Tseng]: Where our statements give much of the reason for this resolution, we know that when we look at the effect of COVID-19, when we look at the spread, the severity, when we look at numbers such as vaccination rates, we see that working class communities and non-white communities have been suffering disproportionately from the COVID-19 pandemic.

[Justin Tseng]: Medford is no exception to this rule.

[Justin Tseng]: There is unfortunately a vaccination gap in town for the BIPOC community.

[Justin Tseng]: We also know that there's more that we can do as a city to address these issues.

[Justin Tseng]: The city council and the city government labeled racism as a public health crisis.

[Justin Tseng]: I think this is following up on that

[Justin Tseng]: action back last year or back then, I believe that we need to be consistent in our actions and that by uplifting the working class, by uplifting BIPOC folks, by uplifting marginalized folks, we are uplifting us, all of us, and keeping all of us safer, keeping every single one of us safer.

[Justin Tseng]: I that's why I'm putting this forward.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm aware that the city has taken a few measures on this front.

[Justin Tseng]: We, the city administration's let me know that they have, they've increased some public public health information campaigns in

[Justin Tseng]: neighborhoods of color, they have been working with faith leaders and community leaders to make sure that we are vaccinating as many people as possible.

[Justin Tseng]: But I think many of us have the question of what what comes next, how are we responding to the surge?

[Justin Tseng]: How can we?

[Justin Tseng]: How can we help as a city council?

[Justin Tseng]: How can we help as a community?

[Justin Tseng]: And how can we do better?

[Justin Tseng]: And how can we evaluate what we're doing?

[Justin Tseng]: So this is why I'm putting this forward today.
