[Justin Tseng]: Hi, I'm Justin Tsang.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm the son of Taiwanese immigrants and I'm running for Medford City Council.

[Justin Tseng]: Growing up in the working-class Wellington area, my parents worked around the clock to build a family.

[Justin Tseng]: They instilled in me the values of hard work and getting involved.

[Justin Tseng]: As a proud son of Medford and the product of the public school system, I graduated valedictorian of Medford High School and went on to attend Harvard University.

[Justin Tseng]: As we recover from this pandemic, we must ask ourselves, what kind of Medford do we want to live in?

[Justin Tseng]: My plan will fight for a future that works for everyone.

[Justin Tseng]: Build a Medford we can afford by protecting tenants' rights and expanding affordable housing.

[Justin Tseng]: Strengthening our schools by reversing education cuts and eliminating regressive student fees.

[Justin Tseng]: Invest in climate and infrastructure by reducing emissions and paving safer, transit-oriented streets.

[Justin Tseng]: And foster an inclusive city where politicians aren't afraid to stand up to systemic racism.

[Justin Tseng]: A city as vibrant as Medford deserves a strong, diverse city council with new energy and new ideas.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm keeping YW Shen and her family close to my heart today.

[Justin Tseng]: Last week, an attacker shouting racist slurs disturbed YW Shen's daily walk in Medford, shoving her to the ground by a busy playground before sprinting off.

[Justin Tseng]: For me, this is both heartbreaking and personal.

[Justin Tseng]: We have watched hate crimes against Asian Americans soar throughout the country, fueled by the casual racism of elected officials

[Justin Tseng]: and a long history of anti-Asian hate.

[Justin Tseng]: Many of my friends and I have spent the last year worrying about our own families and friends, and teaching our elders how to protect themselves.

[Justin Tseng]: I've spent the day thinking about something Mrs. Shen said.

[Justin Tseng]: People usually jump to help someone if they've fallen down.

[Justin Tseng]: It's as if we are not seen as really belonging to American society, so it feels okay to treat us differently.

[Justin Tseng]: These words hit close to home.

[Justin Tseng]: Medford is not immune to the epidemic of racism.

[Justin Tseng]: We must work together to join in the centuries-long fight against hate and white supremacy.

[Justin Tseng]: We must listen to and engage with our neighbors, and we must ensure that these stories don't go unheard.

[Justin Tseng]: We must address hate crimes in our own backyard, ensure that there are decent translation services available,

[Justin Tseng]: and create trusted channels for residents that report incidents of hate.

[Justin Tseng]: Diversity and inclusivity are not just slogans.

[Justin Tseng]: These values must guide us in everything we do.

[Justin Tseng]: Only this way can we truly stop Asian hate and keep our communities safe.

[Justin Tseng]: In Chinese, we have a cheer, jiayou, which means fuel up or let's go.

[Justin Tseng]: To Mrs. Shen,

[Justin Tseng]: to her family and to Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: Jiayou!

[Justin Tseng]: My name is Justin Tsang.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm a student, a first-generation Taiwanese-American, and a proud member of the Medford community.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm running for City Council to energize Medford with a bold, progressive vision and a commitment to justice.

[Justin Tseng]: This is where I grew up.

[Justin Tseng]: Like so many in Medford, my family moved here to settle down, build their careers, and raise their kid.

[Justin Tseng]: This will always be home to me.

[Justin Tseng]: Wellington embraced my family and it watched me grow up.

[Justin Tseng]: When I was five years old, my parents sent me off to the McGlynn.

[Justin Tseng]: I still remember Ms.

[Justin Tseng]: Keynes standing there with her welcoming smile.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, the McGlynn actually taught me what it meant to give back to my community.

[Justin Tseng]: I remember coming back as a middle schooler to volunteer at the after school program or to help kids with cello.

[Justin Tseng]: This is also where I learned about Medford's challenges.

[Justin Tseng]: I remember realizing that my family's financial challenges weren't unique.

[Justin Tseng]: I remember realizing that our teachers struggled to afford basic school supplies.

[Justin Tseng]: And I remember realizing that as much as we talked about diversity, students like me would struggle to fit in.

[Justin Tseng]: Here at Medford High, I made a commitment to ask the tough questions, to shine a light on injustice, and to think change.

[Justin Tseng]: I remember sitting in the library to draft our school's improvement plans and to help choose our first school superintendent of color.

[Justin Tseng]: And on Monday nights, I take the 134 down High Street, down to City Hall, where I work to uplift youth voices.

[Justin Tseng]: Ever since high school, I've kept the fight up.

[Justin Tseng]: I've worked on policy commissions and advocated for young Americans on the national stage.

[Justin Tseng]: Here in Medford, I fought for families and against cuts to schools.

[Justin Tseng]: I've never forgotten my roots and I've never forgotten my love for Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: It's this love that brings me back to City Hall.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm running for Medford City Council because it's time we had a dignified city government that pursues progress and not the status quo.

[Justin Tseng]: A diverse and representative city government that leads and listens.

[Justin Tseng]: Faced with a pandemic, a warming climate, significant cuts to schools, and our centuries-long fight against racism, we need leaders that realize that meaningful structural change starts right here at home.

[Justin Tseng]: Please join us and visit www.justinformedford.com.

[Justin Tseng]: Thank you.

[Justin Tseng]: Okay, well, I thank you for coming up and saying what a lot of our community is thinking and has been thinking throughout the past few years.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'll say, when I read the notice for that meeting, I also didn't take it as you would take the vote that you took.

[Justin Tseng]: And a lot of adults didn't take it that way either.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think the notice did say exactly what the meeting would be about.

[Justin Tseng]: It didn't lie.

[Justin Tseng]: There were no lies in it.

[Justin Tseng]: It stated the truth.

[Justin Tseng]: But there's a part of it that includes communication.

[Justin Tseng]: and communicating to school committee members, to the general public about what the meeting might entail.

[Justin Tseng]: And because of laws, you can't talk outside of a meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: That's the problem.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, and that's a huge problem that acts as a roadblock.

[Justin Tseng]: But maybe allowing the public to know via social media, which you guys are all very good about, but to know via social media what might happen in a meeting, and to tell people, come.

[Justin Tseng]: Come to this meeting.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that really helps out.

[Justin Tseng]: I'll say from the student perspective, when we read that on Facebook,

[Justin Tseng]: when our friends texted the news, there were two reactions, generally.

[Justin Tseng]: One was, what the heck?

[Justin Tseng]: How did this just suddenly happen?

[Justin Tseng]: And the other reaction was, oh, he was in for it.

[Justin Tseng]: We knew that this would happen anyways.

[Justin Tseng]: And both reactions aren't positive for our community.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not positive for the school community, not positive for the general public, not positive for Mr. Bellson and his leadership.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think a more open culture,

[Justin Tseng]: the so-called New Medford, I think that's what we want to try and foster, what we want to try and sponsor, and how we deal with these issues going on.

[Justin Tseng]: So being more open about what meetings might entail, and even, I would say, try more to advertise the committee of the whole meetings, because they're kind of put aside, and they allow for a more relaxed context, but I think it's important for people to know that these are important meetings,

[Justin Tseng]: important stuff gets done in these meetings.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's super important.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know Mr. Russo does this.

[Justin Tseng]: He does town halls.

[Justin Tseng]: He does meet the school committee member.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think that's a great way for people in the community to engage with school committee members.

[Justin Tseng]: So I say we have to take a step back, look at the bigger issue.

[Justin Tseng]: It's about trust.

[Justin Tseng]: And we need to build that trust between the general public and the Medford School Committee.

[Justin Tseng]: And there's trust, but it can be stronger.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's interesting to see this kind of come full circle with me at the end of my school year.

[Justin Tseng]: And yeah, I think it does boil down to unknown leadership.

[Justin Tseng]: I think that's a huge part of it, and the incidents that have happened at the school this year.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know earlier in the year, we talked about launching a PR campaign, and not necessarily

[Justin Tseng]: diminishing the role of the Andrews, because they've done some amazing work as well, but highlighting the achievements of the McGlynn.

[Justin Tseng]: So I think that's super important, and that we should try to use that to attract people back, but we also have to keep in mind the concept of equity.

[Justin Tseng]: And we have to make sure that the student populations at both schools are reflective of the community as a whole and not disproportionate towards ELL populations.

[Justin Tseng]: Well, that's a separate program, but towards certain populations and certain income groups.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, Mr. Russo raised a really interesting idea of doing half and half of different schools, and you know, we need time to explore that option.

[Justin Tseng]: But that does ensure, in a more fair way, that we have

[Justin Tseng]: a fair representation of different income groups and different racial groups and social groups there at both schools.

[Justin Tseng]: So we have to keep in mind that equity is super important in making sure the reputation of our school.

[Justin Tseng]: If you have more challenged population in one school, that's going to be reflected in your test scores.

[Justin Tseng]: And parents are going to look at that and choose one school over the other.

[Justin Tseng]: So we need to make sure that looks fair.

[Justin Tseng]: And another good idea is we talked about cohorts.

[Justin Tseng]: And I know Ms.

[Justin Tseng]: Van der Gloot, at the beginning of the year, talked about how a lot of parents are choosing the injuries because their friends or the friends of their kids are going there.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's the reality.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, they are going there because of their cohorts.

[Justin Tseng]: I'm just throwing this out there, and I'm not saying this is a perfect solution by far, but I know Harvard does blocking groups.

[Justin Tseng]: They have cohorts sign up together and request a certain dorm together and certain houses together.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think maybe exploring something along those lines, making sure that we have equity in our lines.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm not saying it's perfect by any means, but looking at the importance of cohorts in distributing your students.

[Justin Tseng]: Beautiful.

[Justin Tseng]: Justin?

[Justin Tseng]: Did you ask both questions?

[Justin Tseng]: No.

[Justin Tseng]: I've not asked yours yet.

[Justin Tseng]: Mine was the first one or the second one?

[Justin Tseng]: As you may know, the foreign language program at the high school has gone through many changes in the last decade.

[Justin Tseng]: We've gone from a 5 out of 6 day cycle to making it a full core class 6 out of 6 days.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of this is in response to people saying that the foreign language department isn't treated as equally with different departments and given the same attention, especially in a globalizing world.

[Justin Tseng]: So we focused on the high school, but what do you think we can do as a district at the elementary and middle school levels?

[Justin Tseng]: Taking a step back from foreign language and looking at globalization with a larger lens.

[Justin Tseng]: Many Medford High and Medford Public Schools graduates move on to work in different countries or go to different countries to study, and many come from families of different countries, like you and me.

[Justin Tseng]: So how would you help Medford Public Schools be plugged into this wider international community?

[Justin Tseng]: Hello.

[Justin Tseng]: So as you may know, the Medford High School is in the process of integrating with the Vogue.

[Justin Tseng]: And one of the biggest issues faced with this integration is the aligning GPAs from the Vogue side and the academic side.

[Justin Tseng]: Many Vogue students who were in the top 10 before now find themselves applying to colleges while their rank is in the top 100.

[Justin Tseng]: And to them, it doesn't seem fair because they've worked hard for their grades and suddenly compared to everyone else in the weighting system that we have, they've slipped.

[Justin Tseng]: So that's the academic part of that.

[Justin Tseng]: But there's also a social component to that as well, in that a lot of VOC students feel like they're outnumbered by high school students.

[Justin Tseng]: How would you reconcile these differences, academically and socially?

[Justin Tseng]: Hi, so a lot of social science teachers are pushing for a reinstatement of a civics curriculum in our education.

[Justin Tseng]: What do you think is the role of civic engagement at the high school, the middle school, and the elementary levels?

[Justin Tseng]: What do you see as the role of student leadership and student leadership groups in shaping school policy?

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of focus is given to the core subjects that are tested, English, math, science.

[Justin Tseng]: How would you balance the importance of getting high scores and devoting resources to those subjects and to other subjects that a lot of people don't consider core subjects, such as foreign language and various classes and extracurricular activities like sports and arts and music?

[Justin Tseng]: No.

[Justin Tseng]: I have a follow-up to that question.

[Justin Tseng]: What do you see as the role of student leadership in shaping school policy?

[Justin Tseng]: So, as you know, we live in a diverse community and in a globalizing society.

[Justin Tseng]: Our students come from all over the world, and after they leave high school, they end up in different countries, studying different countries, working in different countries.

[Justin Tseng]: How would you build a global connection between the Medford Public Schools and the world as a whole?

[Justin Tseng]: I have a follow-up to that.

[Justin Tseng]: So you talked about restless seniors, which I know all too well.

[Justin Tseng]: But there are restless students of other grades as well.

[Justin Tseng]: A lot of students who know they want to major in science, they don't get the point of taking a history class or an English class.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's the same with other subjects, with foreign languages or with math.

[Justin Tseng]: how would you propose to give classes more meaning to students?

[Justin Tseng]: So you have a lot of innovative ideas for the Medford Public School District, and you spoke a little about potentially scaring away some stakeholders in our community.

[Justin Tseng]: As you know, contract negotiations are going on this month, and they may not conclude until the new superintendent takes office.

[Justin Tseng]: If you were put in a situation where the contract did not allow you the flexibility that you desire to build this innovative teaching method, this innovative community, how would you work within that contract?

[Justin Tseng]: We talked about the VOC and one of the biggest issues that we've seen with the integration of the VOC in high school is grade alignment.

[Justin Tseng]: So a lot of people who were in the top 10 in the VOC now find themselves in the top 100 at Medford High.

[Justin Tseng]: And a lot of people from the VOC do want to attend four-year institutions.

[Justin Tseng]: They rely on their GPA, their ranking.

[Justin Tseng]: How would you attempt to balance the situation or solve this?

[Justin Tseng]: And the second part to this question is, how would you make sure that VOC students overall do feel like they're part of the Medford High community and not overshadowed by Medford High students?

[Justin Tseng]: We want our leaders to be proactive and to listen to us.

[Justin Tseng]: and to be truthful to us and not to go about what students perceive as the Medford way, backroom deals and talking behind our backs.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I would also like to add that CCSR is an organization that truly makes Medford unique among other communities.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, it really helps to stand out.

[Justin Tseng]: If you just look at all these projects and the projects that we see in the portfolio, and we know that Medford students

[Justin Tseng]: like to give back, they want to give back, and that Medford is in good hands.

[Justin Tseng]: It's one of the organizations that's central to so much in our community, and we see it in about everything that we do, regarding schools and even outside of the community.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I remember there was one meeting I was at, and

[Justin Tseng]: There was just a whole list of initiatives starting in Medford, and almost everyone has attended back in the CCSR.

[Justin Tseng]: And I just love to thank Mr. Trotta, Mr. Skorka, all the students, all the student leaders for doing so much for our community.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh yeah, I just wanted to echo what committee member said about having to make sure that

[Justin Tseng]: We're not discriminating against students because they don't have the financial need for a bunch of circumstances.

[Justin Tseng]: And I was also concerned that the word that you pointed out with regard to having two bunches of different policies charged at the same price.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think that's equal, and I think that needs to be reviewed.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I want to say that I feel that Mr. Bilson's analysis of the situation is completely accurate.

[Justin Tseng]: From my experience, students push and shove to get on the bus because they want preferential seating.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, you don't want to walk onto a bus where half the seats are already taken and you don't have as many options.

[Justin Tseng]: So, I mean, I've been on both sides of the situation where I've been pushed, and I, well, I haven't been shoved, but I'm purposefully shoving.

[Justin Tseng]: So, I mean, I know what it's like to, why we do this.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, what he says is completely correct.

[Justin Tseng]: And, you know, it's part of our responsibility as students to understand that, you know, this is a privilege and that we have to be respectful in using it.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we should find a way to advance that idea in the schools and within the student body.

[Justin Tseng]: And I'd like to thank Dr. Peralta for doing that thing.

[Justin Tseng]: I think moving the location where the bus picks up is very important and it will do us a lot of good.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I think baking is a really serious issue that really came out of nowhere.

[Justin Tseng]: And it really took hold about six months ago.

[Justin Tseng]: And I didn't know it was such a big issue until the beginning of this school year.

[Justin Tseng]: And I think we have to work with different communities.

[Justin Tseng]: talk about it too, because I know people who've gotten them from Uber or from different cities, and it's just, it's a super serious issue.

[Justin Tseng]: I think a really effective way we can tackle this, in addition to implementing lessons about it in the health department and with students, is having faculty, teachers talk about it with students too.

[Justin Tseng]: My math teacher just wrapped up a unit on drug use with our class, and I think it was super, super insightful and super effective.

[Justin Tseng]: And just having teachers be very genuine about, you know, you shouldn't do this.

[Justin Tseng]: And actually vaping is, could be, we don't know enough about it, but it could be worse than cigarettes because of the frequency, the high levels of nicotine and the frequency that people use it.

[Justin Tseng]: And I totally agree.

[Justin Tseng]: It just has to be a whole community effort.

[Justin Tseng]: And it's tougher to deal with than cigarettes because it's less visible.

[Justin Tseng]: But we have to try.

[Justin Tseng]: And we've been so, so successful with cigarettes in the last 20 years.

[Justin Tseng]: I think we need to start doing the same things with vaping.

[Justin Tseng]: And I trust that you and the school community will do whatever we can.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I would also like to add that CCSR is an organization that truly makes Medford unique among other communities.

[Justin Tseng]: We know that Medford students like to give back.

[Justin Tseng]: They want to give back.

[Justin Tseng]: And that Medford is in good hands.

[Justin Tseng]: It's one of the organizations that's central to so much in our community.

[Justin Tseng]: And we see it in about everything that we do regarding schools and even outside of the community.

[Justin Tseng]: I mean, I remember there was one meeting I was at.

[Justin Tseng]: there was just a whole list of initiatives starting in Medford.

[Justin Tseng]: And almost everyone has attended back in the CCSR.

[Justin Tseng]: And I would just love to thank Mr. Trotta, Mr. Skorka, all the students, all the student leaders for doing so much for our community.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, yeah.

[Justin Tseng]: I just wanted to echo what committee members have said about having and making sure that

[Justin Tseng]: We're not discriminating against students because they don't have the financial need for a bunch of circumstances.

[Justin Tseng]: And I was also concerned with the word that you picked up with regard to having two bunches of different policies charged at the same price.

[Justin Tseng]: I don't think that's equal, and I think that needs to be reviewed.

[Justin Tseng]: Yeah, I want to say that I feel that Mr. Gilson's analysis of the situation is completely accurate.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, you don't want to walk onto a bus where half the seats are already taken and you don't have as many options.

[Justin Tseng]: I would like to reinforce what we just said in that students at Medford High are so, we're so dedicated to learning and a bunch of us are so dedicated to learning foreign languages.

[Justin Tseng]: And I wanted to say to Carlo, we don't say thank you enough for all that you've done for us.

[Justin Tseng]: And especially those in the AP class, they all love you so much.

[Justin Tseng]: effort in the future as we move forward to a more globalized and more open world.

[Justin Tseng]: We should continue with all of the efforts that we've put into our language learning programs.

[Justin Tseng]: I'd like to thank the teachers of the Midland, my teachers, for coming here and standing up for yourselves and standing up for your students.

[Justin Tseng]: I think what we have here is an issue of, you know,

[Justin Tseng]: the public is more attracted to one school than the other.

[Justin Tseng]: But we need to find out why.

[Justin Tseng]: And I can give you my perspective on why.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not that McGlynn teachers are worse than Andrews teachers.

[Justin Tseng]: It's definitely not that.

[Justin Tseng]: Because I've talked to students coming from the Andrews and to parents who have students at the McGlynn, at the Andrews, or even in the elementary schools.

[Justin Tseng]: And that's not their concern.

[Justin Tseng]: It's not that the staff at the McGlynn is poorly paired or it's

[Justin Tseng]: that it doesn't work well, but rather that the Andrews just, they look at technology, and they look at a component of who's at the school.

[Justin Tseng]: And there's a perception that the McGlynn is a step behind the Andrews when it comes to technology.

[Justin Tseng]: And there's also a perception that the McGlynn is a step behind the Andrews when it comes to wealth, and how we use that wealth, and how that's portrayed in our socioeconomic status.

[Justin Tseng]: And what we really have to do is look at, you know, these are the problems.

[Justin Tseng]: How do we solve these problems?

[Justin Tseng]: Not that, you know, oh, you know, the teachers are the problems or, you know, it's about working together.

[Justin Tseng]: You know, we shouldn't make random decisions when we don't have to.

[Justin Tseng]: If we know that teachers aren't the problem, we shouldn't shuffle them around because it doesn't really work that way.

[Justin Tseng]: We need to identify the problems that we have at hand.

[Justin Tseng]: And that means 60% of McGlynn kids are high need.

[Justin Tseng]: How do we find out, how do we figure out that balance between the two schools?

[Justin Tseng]: And I'm sorry to say it, but I don't believe it, but that 60% of students are high needs, and the diversity of school leads some people to prefer the Andrews over the MacLennan.

[Justin Tseng]: It's a sad reality, it's a sad truth.

[Justin Tseng]: And it doesn't mean that it is the truth.

[Justin Tseng]: It's just what people think.

[Justin Tseng]: And just like Mrs. DiBenedetto said, it's about PR.

[Justin Tseng]: And we need to make sure that people in our community understand that both schools have great teachers and that we even out the playing field for both schools from now on.

[Justin Tseng]: Oh, well, I mean, I've seen the videos throughout the school for the no more campaign.

[Justin Tseng]: Yes.

[Justin Tseng]: And I've seen people wear the shirts and yeah, there's a presence.
